ServiceUnit: 1st Regiment Royal Canadian Horse Artillery (1 RCHA)
IncidentDetails: Bombardier Ouellet was found dead in an accommodation room at Kandahar Airfield at approximately 2:15 p.m. Kandahar time on March 11.  No further details are available at this time, although enemy action has been ruled out.

ServiceUnit: 4th Battalion, 25th Field Artillery Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: on Oct. 27 in Salerno, Afghanistan, from non-combat related injuries.
Bio:
Michael V. Bailey wanted to make people proud of him. Believing that it was sometimes hard to do that in civilian life, he decided to enlist in the Army.
å¦   "'It's the only way I can see that I can make something of myself,'" Gladys K. Wilborn, an older friend and neighbor, recalled him saying.
å¦   Bailey, 20, of Waldorf, Md., died Oct. 27 in Salerno of non-combat related injuries. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   About a year and a month ago, Sierra Washington met Bailey at the St. Charles mall. They hit it off.
å¦   "He was my fiance," she said. They talked constantly by telephone and the last time they spoke, she said, he "told me how much he loved me," she said. But that was not surprising. "He tells me that all the time."
å¦   Wilborn said Bailey was a happy person who laughed and "made you laugh along with him." He was especially fond of her chocolate chip cookies. "Anything home-cooked, he loved," she said.
å¦   Josh Batschelet, a friend, said Bailey "seemed to want to make you feel good and boost your self-esteem." Brandon Frere, who rode the school bus with Bailey said: "He was a good kid."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division
IncidentDetails: died of injuries suffered when his vehicle struck an explosive Oct. 31 in Wygal Valley, Afghanistan
Bio:
Douglas E. Sloan was ejected from the school library many times for being too loud, and would subsequently sneak back in, crawling on his hands and knees.
å¦   "It really aggravated the librarian _ this tough, serious lady," said Van Sloan, his older brother. "Then, at his graduation party, she showed up with this huge present. Even when he was in trouble, the people who were supposed to discipline him would laugh."
å¦   Sloan, 40, of Evans Mills, N.Y., was killed by a roadside bomb Oct. 31 in Wygal Valley. He was a 1985 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   His childhood buddies recall a charismatic jokester who loved prank phone calls, toy soldiers and marathon sessions of Risk, the game of world domination. He graduated Western Michigan University in 1996 with a major in history and minors in French and military science.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Kerry, and their four children.
å¦   "He was a great leader. He wouldn't ask you to do anything he wouldn't do, and you liked him and respected him, and from my experience in the military there wasn't too many officers like that," said Spc. Andrew Coughlin.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division
IncidentDetails: died of injuries suffered when his vehicle struck an explosive Oct. 31 in Wygal Valley, Afghanistan
Bio:
When Alex Oceguera was 16, he started talking about going into the Army. His art began to reflect those dreams and a drawing of an appealing furry character in camouflage and holding a weapon is one of his mother's prized possessions.
å¦   Even more valuable to Ofelia Oceguera is the drawing he did for her on Mother's Day 1997, when he was 10. "He told me how happy he was that I was his mother, that I was the best mother," said his mother.
å¦   Oceguera, 19, of San Bernardino, Calif., died Oct. 31 of injuries suffered when his vehicle struck an explosive in Wygal Valley. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   "There is a Hollywood version of an infantry soldier as a cold, steely-eyed man who never smiles," said Brig. Gen. Robert W. Cone. "But Alex was smart, dedicated and a loyal friend to fellow soldiers who worked selflessly and without complaint patrolling villages and valleys."
å¦   He sent her part of his paycheck every month and told her to let him know if she needed more. "He said, 'If something is going to happen to me, it could happen over there or here on the street,'" said his mother.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion Princess Patricia‰Ûªs Canadian Light Infantry
IncidentDetails: Private Terry John Street, from 2nd Battalion Princess Patricia‰Ûªs Canadian Light Infantry was killed today when his armoured vehicle struck a suspected Improvised Explosive Device (IED).

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 3rd Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: injuries suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his convoy vehicle.
Bio:
William R. Brown wasn't one to hesitate when it came to career or love. In June 1994, just two weeks after graduating, he joined the Army. A few months later, he married his wife, Audra.
å¦   "Billy was one of the few people I knew at an early age that was good to the core," said Jimmy Melton, a high school friend. "I remember him as always standing up for what was right and following through with his plans. Integrity could sum him up best in my mind."
å¦   Brown, 30, of Fort Worth, Texas, was killed by a roadside bomb Nov. 6 in Sperwan-Gar. He was assigned to Fort Bragg and was on his second tour of duty in Afghanistan. He had done a tour in Iraq.
å¦   His mother, Anita Walton, said her son's goal after leaving the Army was to return to Texas and work for the Drug Enforcement Administration.
å¦   His first Army assignment was at Fort Benning, where he served for seven years. He held numerous positions there, including squad leader and operations sergeant. Brown then successfully completed a two-year tour in Dallas as a recruiter.
å¦   He also is survived by a 10-year-old daughter, Emily; and a stepson, Trenton, 15.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 188th Air Defense Artillery
IncidentDetails: Spc. Chris Kleinwachter, 29, of Wahpeton, N.D., died Nov. 30 in Ghazni, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered when his vehicle rolled over during combat operations.
Bio:
Relatives of Chris Kleinwachter said he was a go-getter who put the needs of others in front of his own.
å¦   "One of Christopher's greatest attributes was his care for other people," said his mother, Carmen. "He was always attempting to bring peace to those in conflict. He would even step between those coming to blows with one another and take them up himself to stop the fighting. Add to this his great sense of humor, and you can get a glimpse into my son."
å¦   Kleinwachter, 29, of Wahpeton, N.D., was killed Nov. 30 in Ghazni in a vehicle accident. He was a 1995 high school graduate and was assigned to Grand Forks.
å¦   Kleinwachter was a full-time student at North Dakota State College of Science in Wahpeton from fall 2000 through spring 2002 and was a part-time student during fall 2004.
å¦   He enlisted in the North Dakota Army National Guard as a high school senior. He was serving as a power generator equipment repairer.
å¦   "He was proud to serve his country," said his mother. "Christopher chose once again to place himself in between those who would choose to do harm to others and paid the ultimate price."
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Clare.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 102nd Infantry Brigade
IncidentDetails: Phaneuf, 38, of Eastford, Conn., was killed Dec. 15 in Mehtar Lam when his vehicle struck an explosive.
Bio:
Joseph E. Phaneuf's 13 nieces and nephews were nuts about him. He sent them desert hats and gifts, issuing all of them ranks, but never higher than his own. He loved to give the kids in Afghanistan coveted ballpoint pens and candy.
å¦   Sometime, he'd slip in a few Fireballs, "just to see their little faces," said his wife, Michele. "He wasn't perfect."
å¦   Phaneuf, 38, of Eastford, Conn., was killed Dec. 15 in Mehtar Lam when his vehicle struck an explosive. He was assigned to Hartford and had also done a tour in Iraq.
å¦   He was an emergency medical technician and firefighter. He and Michele, also an EMT, met in high school but started dating when they met again while Michele was getting EMT training.
å¦   Phaneuf and some other fathers built the playscape at the local elementary school. They embedded a dime in the pavement, imagining the future generations of kids trying to pick it up.
å¦   Phaneuf also is survived by his three children, Ryan, 15, Danielle, 11, and Jordan, 9.
å¦   "Joseph Phaneuf was a volunteer citizen-soldier who served his state and country in the truest sense," said Gov. M. Jodi Rell.

ServiceUnit: 15 Field Ambulance
IncidentDetails: Corporal Starker was killed at approximately 11:45 a.m., May 6, 2008, when the patrol he was with came under fire.

ServiceUnit: USS Bataan (LHD 5)
IncidentLocation: USS Bataan, off the coast of Somalia
IncidentDetails: Died of apparent natural causes while deployed aboard the multipurpose amphibious assault ship the USS Bataan. The cause of death is under investigation.
Bio:
According to Brian Middleton, Laquita Pate James was recognized as the hardest working and most knowledgeable police officer at Kings Bay Security Department, even though she was fresh out of master-at-arms school.
å¦   "I have trained a lot of police officers at Kings Bay. No person made me as proud as Laquita did," he said. "She had more than a can-do attitude: She had a will-do attitude. Nothing was going to stand in her way."
å¦   James, 23, of Orange Park, Fla., died Feb. 12 of apparent natural causes while deployed aboard the USS Bataan. She was a Navy master-at-arms supporting operations off the Horn of Africa.
å¦   James was a 1991 high school graduate and was stationed at Norfolk. She is survived by her sons, Stephen and Di'Jimon.
å¦   Being a single parent, coupled with long shift work and a potentially dangerous occupation, could break anyone. But to co-workers, James always performed at a high level whenever she was scheduled to work, even taking over shifts when the situation arose.
å¦   "When she was supposed to be at work, she was here. She was more than a co-worker, she was a friend. I can't believe she is gone," said Watch Commander Lt. Trey Ripley.

ServiceUnit: 24th Special Tactics Squadron
IncidentDetails: died Feb. 18 when the coalition CH-47 helicopter he was riding in crashed in eastern Afghanistan.
Bio:
Scott E. Duffman loved to ski, to snowboard, to scuba dive, to climb mountains, and just about anything else risky.
å¦   "Everything he did in his job, he loved doing, anyway," said his mother, Rose. "He was the kind of son that put every single gray hair in his mother's head."
å¦   Duffman, 32, of Albuquerque, N.M., died Feb. 18 when his helicopter crashed in eastern Afghanistan. He was a 1992 high school graduate and was assigned to Pope Air Force Base.
å¦   Duffman decided when he was 10 that he wanted to be a pararescueman. He joined the Air Force in 1992 and swore he would retire after 20 years. "But then he said maybe he'd to work for the CIA," Rose Duffman said. "I said 'Could you just take an accounting job or something?'"
å¦   Duffman thrived on bets, dares, pranks and mixtures of all three. One time he and some pararescue buddies came to visit his mom and decided one night to bet on what time the sun came up. They crawled onto the roof and drank until they had a winner. The loser had to strip naked and run the cul de sac on foot.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Mary, and 4-month-old daughter, Sophia.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment
IncidentDetails: killed when their helicopter crashed in southeastern Afghanistan.
Bio:
Kristofer D.S. Thomas saw joining the military as a way to help stop suffering _ including people with AIDS, refugees in Darfur and Iraqis plagued by civil war.
å¦   "I don't want to just sit back and watch the casualty numbers climb on CNN," he wrote in his senior class paper. "I need to do something to help out."
å¦   Thomas, 18, of Roseville, Calif., was killed Feb. 18 when his helicopter crashed in southeastern Afghanistan. He was assigned to Fort Benning.
å¦   Thomas was remembered a popular and outgoing teenager who enjoyed computer games and sports. He helped neighbors set up personal computers and looked after their homes while they were away.
å¦   He worked out and boxed at a local gym and learned about nutrition to get into shape before basic training, school counselor Jeff Clark said.
å¦   Before shipping out to Afghanistan, he returned to speak to seniors in his former economics and government class.
å¦   "He told them they needed to care about what's going on in the world and question things and do what they think is right," said teacher Kathy Enos.
å¦   Thomas is survived by his parents, Rodney Thomas and Debby Getz.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment
IncidentDetails: Garbs, 20, of Edwardsville, Ill., died Feb. 18 when his helicopter crashed in southeastern Afghanistan.
Bio:
Ryan C. Garbs played soccer and baseball until his junior year of high school. He quit sports to train physically and keep his grades up because he wanted to qualify for the elite Rangers.
å¦   "He researched all he would have to do to be an Army Ranger. And he did it," said Doug Garbs, his father. "We had a weight bench and a boxing bag and he ran miles nearly every day and he studied."
å¦   Garbs, 20, of Edwardsville, Ill., died Feb. 18 when his helicopter crashed in southeastern Afghanistan. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Benning.
å¦   After graduation Garbs wouldn't discuss going to college or other career options. "He was going to join the Army _ adventure," Doug Garbs said.
å¦   "He was a good guy, soft-spoken," he said. "He was focused pretty much on getting into the Army after school. He had a goal, a purpose, a plan."
å¦   His spare time was spent "hanging out with his friends" and using his computer, Garbs said. "He was a typical high school kid. He was a computer kid. I remember his showing me he'd made a computer game."
å¦   Garbs also is survived by his mother, Jill.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Gordon, 21, of Naples, Fla., died Feb. 18 when his helicopter crashed in southeastern Afghanistan.
Bio:
Before he was a soldier, Brandon D. Gordon was the first employee hired at Thermal Wire and Cable. Owner Mark Gegenwarth worked beside Gordon for four years, before he took a leave of absence from the company during his deployment overseas.
å¦   "He was a very spirited individual," Gegenwarth said. "From the moment he came in to the moment he left he was a hard worker, and he made me laugh nonstop. I was so proud of him."
å¦   Gordon, 21, of Naples, Fla., died Feb. 18 when his helicopter crashed in southeastern Afghanistan. He was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   Gordon was adventurous, even as a child, said Gegenwarth, who also was a neighbor. He recalled with a laugh daring Gordon, then about 10, to stand in an ant pile for $10. Gordon happily accepted the dare and the cash, Gegenwarth said.
å¦   "As a kid, he was always looking for some sort of excitement," he said. "He certainly thought outside of the box."
å¦   Gegenwarth said he taught Gordon how to shoot a rifle, and the pair often skipped lunch and went to the shooting range during the week.
å¦   Gordon is survived by his father, Gene Gordon, and mother Terri Gordon.

ServiceUnit: Battalion, 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Seven soldiers were killed in a helicopter crash in southeastern Afghanistan.
Bio:
Shawn Nunnally, a friend of Travis R. Vaughn, said the two were always doing something _ good or bad.
å¦   "In the winter we had snowmobiles and were out snowmobiling. In the summertime it was dirt bikes. Travis couldn't sit still."
å¦   Vaughn, 26, of Reinbeck, Iowa, was killed Feb. 18 when his helicopter crashed in southeastern Afghanistan. He was a 1999 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   "He was so proud of himself, the way he carried himself and walked. He had turned into a man on us," said Kandie Vaughn, Travis' stepmother. She added that he loved to tear his toys apart when he was a child
å¦   Vaughn fought in eight professional Ultimate Fighting bouts between December 2000 and November 2001. Chad Bergmeier, a promoter, called him a "hard worker" and "dedicated."
å¦   "When you're setting up a cage for events, people usually do it once or twice, and they don't usually want to do it again," Bergmeier said. "That wasn't the case with Travis. He always worked really hard and was always raring to go for the next time around."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Heather Reinertson, and Reinertson's son, Taylin, 5.

ServiceUnit: Battalion, 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Seven soldiers were killed in a helicopter crash in Afghanistan.
Bio:
Adam A. Wilkinson joined the Army in 2002 and served as a petroleum supply specialist. After a deployment to Iraq, he switched his specialty to repairing Chinook helicopters and was assigned to the 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment.
å¦   "Adam spent the last two years training with and supporting a unit that he loved," said his wife, Tyffanie. "The 160th was like a second family."
å¦   Wilkinson, 23, of Fort Carson, Colo., was killed Feb. 18 when his helicopter crashed in southeastern Afghanistan. He was a 2001 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   "He believed firmly in the principles ingrained in him by his family from an early age _ loyalty, perseverance and an overwhelming sense of patriotism," said Tyffanie.
å¦   He also is survived by his son, Carson, 1.
å¦   "Adam would want to be remembered as someone who died the way he lived _ providing support for some of America's finest young men," said his wife.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Seven soldiers were killed in a helicopter crash in southeastern Afghanistan.
Bio:
John A. Quinlan's neighbor recalled how the pilot liked to fly his MH-47 Chinook over his home on his way to and from Fort Campbell, hoping to catch a glimpse of his three daughters playing in their backyard, and in turn hoping they would be able to see their father at work.
å¦   "It was great to see him with his daughters," said Jan Williams, "they all got special treatment."
å¦   Quinlan, 36, of Clarksville, Tenn., was killed Feb. 18 when his helicopter crashed in southeastern Afghanistan. He graduated high school in 1988 and was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   As a kid, he built an elaborate helicopter from Legos and often got in trouble for flying paper airplanes. Quinlan spent eight years in the Marines before joining the Army, specifically so he could fly helicopters.
å¦   In his free time, he renovated his home and worked on classic cars. Whether it was building a fence or kitchen cabinets, Quinlan was always there if he was needed, Williams said. "He was larger than life, unaware that there was anything he couldn't do."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Julie, and daughters Keely, 10, Madeline, 8, and Erin, 3.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Seven soldiers were killed in a helicopter crash in southeastern Afghanistan.
Bio:
Hershel D. McCants Jr. was always prepared for any situation, toting a first-aid kit and ropes on family outings to the Oregon Dunes.
å¦   "He was one of those kids that schools don't accommodate very well," said his aunt, Sandy Finneran. "He was very smart, but he didn't like sitting around in school."
å¦   McCants, 33, born in Medford, Ore., died Feb. 18 when his helicopter crashed in southeastern Afghanistan. He was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   He completed his education in the military, winning a general's award in boot camp. He started building bridges with an Army engineering company, but then trained as a medic and served on a Blackhawk helicopter.
å¦   He ultimately became a Special Forces pilot and had been on several tours of duty in Afghanistan.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Shannon, 11-year-old son Trevor and a baby daughter, Kylie.
å¦   Finneran said McCants regularly reassured worried relatives that life is inherently dangerous, but he was doing important work.
å¦   "He said, 'If I don't make it back, know that I was doing what I love. It's my job,'" she recounted.

ServiceUnit: 3rd General Support Aviation Battalion, 82nd Combat Aviation Brigade, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Johns, 19, of Frankton, Ind., died Feb. 21 in Bagram of a non-combat related injury.
Bio:
Jason D. Johns was a burly man who stood more than 6 feet tall, but he had a gentle, easygoing spirit.
å¦   "We were all terrified that if he ever had to shoot somebody, he wouldn't be able to do it," said his grandmother, Marlies Paolino. "Or if he did, that he wouldn't be able to live with himself."
å¦   Johns, 19, of Frankton, Ind., died Feb. 21 in Bagram of a non-combat related injury. He earned a GED and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   In Iraq, he was computer/detection systems repairer. In his off time, he enjoyed playing video games and card games. His father, Jeffrey Johns, said his son was a notorious hugger.
å¦   "He was probably the biggest on hugs on anybody you'd ever meet," said Jeff. "Sometimes he'd just stop and want to hug you passing through the house, which I was always glad of, but sometimes it was like, 'What did you do?'"
å¦   One thing Johns didn't like was running. "He called me every day saying it was tough to do all the running," recalled close friend Michael. "He hated to run."
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Kim.
å¦   "He was," his father said, "the most pure and nicest person that I have ever met."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 180th Infantry, Oklahoma Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: died Feb. 19 in Kamdesh, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his unit came in contact with enemy forces using small arms fire and rocket propelled grenades.
Bio:
Scoutmaster Dave Yeager, who mentored Buddy J. Hughie from Cub Scouts to Boy Scouts, said it was uncharacteristic if Hughie wasn't grinning.
å¦   "If he wasn't smiling, something was really wrong," Yeager said.
å¦   Hughie, 25, of Poteau, Okla., was killed by small-arms fire and rocket-propelled grenades Feb. 19 in Kamdesh while attempting to save the lives of two Afghan Army soldiers. He was a 2000 high school graduate and was assigned to Ada.
å¦   Hughie dedicated his life to putting others before himself, according to Cindy Pollard, whose son attended high school with Hughie.
å¦   "He was the type of person who would do anything for anybody," Pollard said. "It's not a shock that he entered military service because that's what he was born to do."
å¦   Family members said he loved to play the piano and trombone. He was taught to read by age 3, and later preached and recited Scripture from a stump in his back yard.
å¦   He was full of energy and always smiling. "Even though he had a short life, he had a full life," said the Rev. Jim Parsley, who officiated at a memorial service.
å¦   Hughie is survived by his wife, Alexis, his 3-month-old son, Cooper.

ServiceUnit: 1st Transportation Movement Control Agency, 21st Theater Support Command
IncidentDetails: Zizumbo, 27, of Chicago, was killed Feb. 27 in a suicide bomb attack at Bagram on the day Vice President Dick Cheney was visiting the base.
Bio:
At a chapel in Germany, soldiers bid farewell to Daniel Zizumbo, someone they described as a person of pride and integrity.
å¦   "I know he was proud of being in the military, and I, along with all my fellow comrades, owe him a debt of gratitude we will never be able to pay," said Spc. Jessica Jones, a friend and comrade.
å¦   Zizumbo, 27, of Chicago, was killed Feb. 27 in a suicide bomb attack at Bagram on the day Vice President Dick Cheney was visiting the base. He was assigned to Kaiserslautern, Germany.
å¦   He joined the Marines at age 17 and spent four years in the corps. After that, he tried for years to find a job in Chicago, applying at O'Hare International and Midway Airports.
å¦   Zizumbo briefly attended two colleges during this time, but unable to find work, he enlisted again, this time in the Army.
å¦   "He was a soldier. He did as he was told and tried to excel in everything his job required," said Senior Airman Erica Crim, Daniel's girlfriend. "He was very giving. His parents were hard workers, and Daniel took care of his four siblings when they were young."
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Jose and Landa.

ServiceUnit: Seal Team 10
IncidentDetails: Eight Navy SEALs and eight members of the Army's 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment known as the Night Stalkers were aboard the Chinook helicopter that crashed in the eastern mountains of Afghanistan on Tuesday, the military said.
Bio:
NEW ORLEANS _ Chief Petty Officer Jacques Fontan, 36, was serving his final days of deployment when he was killed, relatives said.
å¦   "He's my baby brother, we were very close," said his sister, Suzanne Fontan Gonczy. "The family is obviously devastated."
å¦   Fontan joined the Navy 17 years ago, said his father, Earl Fontan.
å¦   He served as a fire control specialist aboard Navy fighting ships, managing electronics that controlled weapons systems, and was a veteran of the first Persian Gulf War. He was serving at the Naval Amphibious Base in Little Creek, Va.
å¦   Jacques Fontan had planned to retire with his wife in Florida, his father said. å¦   "Family was important to him. On leaves, he spent them with our family _ most of which was in New Orleans, some of which now is in Atlanta," Earl Fontan said. "He was great with his niece and nephews. He delighted in playing roughhouse with them."

ServiceUnit: Company B  3D Battalion  160Th Soar
IncidentDetails: Eight Navy SEALs and eight members of the Army's 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment known as the Night Stalkers were aboard the Chinook helicopter that crashed in the eastern mountains of Afghanistan on Tuesday, the military said.
Bio:
DANVILLE, Ohio _ Staff Sgt. Shamus Goare tricked his mother into letting him join the military at the age of 17, shortly before his high school graduation.
å¦   Twelve years later, he was a member of an elite Army team known as the Night Stalkers, trained to fly special forces commandos behind enemy lines under cover of night.
å¦   His father, Charles Goare, said he and his wife were proud of their son, a member of the 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment based at Hunter Army Airfield, Ga. He remembered how their son had fooled his mother, Judy, into signing his enlistment form.
å¦   "He told her it was a form for something else; I don't remember what," Charles Goare said. "That was 11 years ago."
å¦   "He thought maybe he's get to see the world before he went to college," he said. "Then he just stayed in."

ServiceUnit: Company B  3D Battalion  160Th Soar
IncidentDetails: Eight Navy SEALs and eight members of the Army's 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment known as the Night Stalkers were aboard the Chinook helicopter that crashed in the eastern mountains of Afghanistan on Tuesday, the military said.
Bio:
CLARKS GROVE, Minn. _ Warrant Officer Corey J. Goodnature, 35, was on his fourth tour of duty in Afghanistan and Iraq.
å¦   "He never made us feel like it was dangerous for him to be there, so we just took it for granted that he was going to be safe," said his father, Don Goodnature.
å¦   Corey Goodnature, who grew up in Clarks Grove in southern Minnesota, earned an associate's degree in aerospace engineering from the University of Minnesota in 1991 and had always wanted a military career.
å¦   "One thing about Corey _ he never wavered," said his mother, Deb Goodnature, who last spoke with him on Mother's Day.
å¦   Corey Goodnature was assigned to the 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment based at Hunter Army Airfield in Savannah, Ga. He and his wife, Lori, lived in Savannah, Ga., with their two sons, Shea, 14, and Brennan, 12.

ServiceUnit: Sdv Team One
IncidentDetails: died while conducting combat operations when the MH-47 helicopter that they were aboard crashed in the vicinity of Asadabad, Afghanistan
Bio:
MANCHESTER, N.H. _ Senior Chief Petty Officer Dan Healy joined the military after high school and became a Navy SEAL and father of four.
å¦   He was midway through a six-month tour in the Middle East when the helicopter was shot down, his mother, Natalie Healy, said.
å¦   "He was a lovely young man who loved his children, his family, his service," she said. "He was proud to serve his country. He was very happy to have the opportunity to fight."
å¦   Dan Healy, 36, had gone to school in Exeter, N.H. He had two children living in San Diego and two in Honolulu, where he was stationed at Pearl Harbor, his mother said. She remembered visiting the family last year and the fun they had horseback riding and going to the zoo.
å¦   "His greatest joy was being with his children," she said. "He loved to enjoy life. He loved his friends."

ServiceUnit: Company B  3D Battalion  160Th Soar
IncidentDetails: Eight Navy SEALs and eight members of the Army's 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment known as the Night Stalkers were aboard the Chinook helicopter that crashed in the eastern mountains of Afghanistan on Tuesday, the military said.
Bio:
POMPANO BEACH, Fla. _ Sgt. Kip A. Jacoby grew up in Pompano Beach and enlisted in the Army in October 2002, the year he graduated from high school.
å¦   "Kip believed his choice of service for our country was meaningful and right," his parents, Stephen and Susan of Pompano, Fla., said in a statement. "He loved what he was doing, he knew the risks, and he was proud to be a soldier fighting so others wouldn't have to. He made us very proud."
å¦   "He was smart, gifted, and innovative. He has touched all of our lives in ways we can never forget. Even in the face of danger, he showed courage and bravery as well as a keen sense of humor," they wrote.
å¦   Jacoby, 21, was trained as a helicopter repairman. His assignment was as a flight engineer in the Army's 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment.

ServiceUnit: Seal Team 10
IncidentDetails: Eight Navy SEALs and eight members of the Army's 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment known as the Night Stalkers were aboard the Chinook helicopter that crashed in the eastern mountains of Afghanistan on Tuesday, the military said.
Bio:
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. _ Lt. Cmdr. Erik S. Kristensen, 33, was the senior officer among the SEAL team, Pentagon officials said.
å¦   He graduated from the Naval Academy in 1997 and was assigned to SEAL Team Ten in Virginia Beach, Va.
å¦   Kristensen was the only child of retired Read Adm. Edward K. Kristensen and Suzanne Kristensen, who live in the Washington area. His father oversaw the Navy's salvage efforts of TWA Flight 800, which crashed off Long Island, N.Y., in 1996, The Virginian-Pilot in Norfolk reported.

ServiceUnit: Seal Team Ten
IncidentDetails: killed while conducting combat operations when the MH-47 helicopter that they were aboard crashed
Bio:
PRINEVILLE, Ore. _ Petty Officer 1st Class Jeff Lucas had been in the Navy since he was just 17 and had been assigned to Afghanistan since last November, his family said.
å¦   "He was a warrior, he was a patriot, he was a good father, a good husband, a great brother," said his brother, Jamie. "I'm proud of him. I'm proud of all of them."
å¦   Lucas doted on his wife, Rhonda, and his 4-year-old son, Seth, said his father, Rick Lucas. They live in Virginia Beach, Va., where Jeff Lucas had been stationed for the past several years.
å¦   "I feel like I lost a good friend," his father said.
å¦   Lucas, 34, had been a running back in high school and played basketball and ran track, Rick Lucas said. As an adult, he loved to ski and golf, even buying his young son a set of toy clubs.

ServiceUnit: Seal Team Ten
IncidentDetails: Eight Navy SEALs and eight members of the Army's 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment known as the Night Stalkers were aboard the Chinook helicopter that crashed in the eastern mountains of Afghanistan on Tuesday, the military said.
Bio:
PORTVILLE, N.Y. _ Lt. Michael McGreevy was the kid who had it all.
å¦   "He was a great athlete, great student, nice personality, and was so polite," said Linda Scott, a high school guidance counselor in Portville, a town of about 4,000 near the Pennsylvania border.
å¦   McGreevy graduated third in his class, then enrolled at the U.S. Naval Academy for a career serving his country.
å¦   "Everyone just described him as a true gentleman," school Principal Kevin Curran said.
å¦   At 30, he was a Navy SEAL with a 1-year-old child in Virginia Beach, Va.

ServiceUnit: Hhc  3D Battalion  160Th Soar
IncidentDetails: Eight Navy SEALs and eight members of the Army's 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment known as the Night Stalkers were aboard the Chinook helicopter that crashed in the eastern mountains of Afghanistan on Tuesday, the military said.
Bio:
INDIANAPOLIS _ Sgt. 1st Class Marcus V. Muralles planned to return to the United States in time to celebrate his daughter's 10th birthday on Monday until another medic suffered a leg injury, family members said.
å¦   "When the Army officer came to tell us that Marcus was on the helicopter, I told him that couldn't be," Muralles' stepfather, Bob Dill of Shelbyville, said Saturday.
å¦   "I said, 'His wife talked to him two days ago and he was all packed up and ready to go for his daughter's birthday,'" Dill said.
å¦   Muralles, 33, had been in the Army since 1994 and was a flight medic in the elite special operations forces.
å¦   He was born in Louisiana and raised in Shelbyville, about 20 miles southeast of Indianapolis. He and his wife had two children. He served with the 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment.

ServiceUnit: Sdvt One
Seal Delivery Vehicle Team One
IncidentDetails: Eight Navy SEALs and eight members of the Army's 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment known as the Night Stalkers were aboard the Chinook helicopter that crashed in the eastern mountains of Afghanistan on Tuesday, the military said.
Bio:
LAS VEGAS _ Petty Officer 2nd Class Eric Shane Patton was following in his father's steps when he joined the military and became a Navy SEAL.
å¦   "Boulder City and the state of Nevada lost a true hero. His sacrifice and love of country will not be forgotten," said Keith Gronquist, a court administrator who works with Patton's father, James Patton, a city marshal and retired Navy SEAL.
å¦   Eric Patton was a 2000 graduate of Boulder City High School.

ServiceUnit: Hhc  160Th Special Operations Aviation Regiment
IncidentDetails: Eight Navy SEALs and eight members of the Army's 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment known as the Night Stalkers were aboard the Chinook helicopter that crashed in the eastern mountains of Afghanistan on Tuesday, the military said.
Bio:
FRANKLIN, Tenn. _ Sgt. 1st Class James "Tre" Ponder III was an unlikely hero _ "not real tall, somewhat thin, but tough as nails," said his father-in-law, the mayor of Ponder's hometown in central Tennessee.
å¦   "He was a young man who could love his young children and then go out into the desert and fight with a great deal of energy. He's a real warrior, and the warrior in him has made this situation somewhat comforting for the family," father-in-law Tom Miller said.
å¦   Ponder, 36, grew up in Franklin, 15 miles south of Nashville, and enlisted in the Army after a few semesters at Auburn University.
å¦   He was a father of two young girls and a flight commander stationed with the Army's 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment at Fort Campbell, Ky. He had been overseas for about three weeks when the helicopter was shot down, Miller said.
å¦   "My granddaughter just this week asked her mother the question as they were saying their prayers and asking for safety for Tre. She said, 'Mommy, how do we know when Jesus is calling Daddy home to be an angel?" Miller said. "Faith and knowing that Tre is doing what God wanted him to do is sustaining the family."

ServiceUnit: Company B  3D Battalion  160Th Soar
IncidentDetails: killed while conducting combat operations when the MH-47 helicopter that they were aboard crashed in the vicinity of Asadabad, Afghanistan in Kumar Province on June 28
Bio:
WASHINGTON, Conn. _ Maj. Steve Reich carried the U.S. flag for Team USA as its pitcher in the early 1990s, then proved his patriotism on the battlefield in Afghanistan.
å¦   "Steve was always able to do everything he tried. People imagined any corner or situation he got himself into he would come out of it," said Richard Sears, a town official in Washington, Reich's hometown in the rolling hills of northwestern Connecticut.
å¦   Reich, 34, was on his fourth tour of duty. He had been a company commander in the 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment at Hunter Army Airfield, Ga., and had been married just four months earlier.
å¦   As a young man, Reich had been a star pitcher for the U.S. Military Academy and represented Team USA in 1993 at the World University games on a team that included major leaguers Paul Wilson, Todd Helton, Todd Walker and Dustin Hermanson. He pitched briefly in the Baltimore Orioles system in 1996 before being recalled to active duty.
å¦   "You see this big, huge smile of pride," family spokesman Gary Fitzherbert said, remembering Reich carrying the flag at the 1993 games. "That's how we all remember him."
å¦   Helton, now a first baseman for the Colorado Rockies, remembered Reich as "one of the nicest guys I ever met."

ServiceUnit: Company B  3D Battalion  160Th Soar
IncidentDetails: killed while conducting combat operations when the MH-47 helicopter that they were aboard crashed
Bio:
FREDERICKSBURG, Va. _ Master Sgt. Michael Russell had been sent to Afghanistan six times since the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, but he never complained about the deployments.
å¦   He "was doing what he absolutely loved to do. It was a dream for him," said his uncle, Kenneth Luehrs of Spotsylvania County.
å¦   The 31-year-old flight engineer was a member of the 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment at Hunter Army Airfield, Ga. He had joined the Army after graduating from North Stafford High School in 1991.
å¦   His father, Lee Russell, said he last spoke with his son a few days before his deployment a month and a half ago.
å¦   "When he went back this time, he told me they would be really busy," Lee Russell said. On previous missions, he said, his son had been able to call or e-mail once every two weeks.
å¦   Michael Russell's duties often kept him away from his two young daughters, his father said, but when he was home, "he was with them all the time."

Bio:
JACKSONVILLE, Fla. _ Chief Warrant Officer Chris Scherkenbach had served tours in Germany and Korea before being sent to Afghanistan.
å¦   "Our family very much appreciates the outpouring of support and prayers that we have received from our friends and communities," his family said in a statement. "Chris will be dearly missed as a devoted husband, as well as a loving son, brother and uncle."
å¦   "Chris died doing what he loved," his family said in a statement.
å¦   The 40-year-old Jacksonville native had enlisted in the Army in 1987. He was based with the 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment at Hunter Army Airfield, Ga.

ServiceUnit: Sdvt One
IncidentDetails: Eight Navy SEALs and eight members of the Army's 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment known as the Night Stalkers were aboard the Chinook helicopter that crashed in the eastern mountains of Afghanistan on Tuesday, the military said.
Bio:
DEERFIELD BEACH, Fla. _ Petty Officer 2nd Class James Suh had joined the Navy in early 2001, when he was 24.
å¦   He began his rigorous SEAL training five months after he entered the Navy. His latest assignment was in SEAL Delivery Vehicle Team One, Pearl Harbor, Hawaii.
å¦   Members of the 28-year-old's family declined to comment when reached at their Deerfield Beach home late Saturday.

IncidentDetails: died Jan. 27 at Landstuhl Regional Medical Center, Germany, from wounds received as a result of an improvised explosive device while traveling in a convoy in Afghanistan on Jan. 25.
Bio:
Billy D. Brixey Jr. was remembered as a jokester who always had a smile on his face and who brought smiles to the faces of the other Marines.
å¦   "But his sense of humor belied an inner strength and confidence that made him, even at his present rank, a leader of Marines," said Staff Sgt. Donald Pastorcich, a former bunkmate. "Whatever he did, he did it to the max. Whether he was playing basketball or football after a hard day's work or attacking the mission he was given by his superiors, he always gave his best."
å¦   Brixey, 21, of Ferriday, La., died Jan. 27 while en route to Landstuhl Regional Medical Center in Germany from wounds he received from a roadside bomb in Afghanistan. He was based at Kaneohe Bay.
å¦   A 2002 high school graduate, the 6-foot-3 Brixey made the football team his senior year and trained as a mechanic in the military.
å¦   "He was just one of the sweetest kids I ever taught," said Assistant Principal Jana Lincecum. "He didn't have a mean bone in his body. His temperament was so kind. He was lovable."
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Billy and Cassandra.

ServiceUnit: A Co  1St Bn  3Rd Mar  3Rd Mar Div
IncidentDetails: Bertolino was traveling in a convoy when his vehicle was hit by enemy fire
Bio:
Matthew L. Bertolino went skydiving with his sister just before he shipped off to basic training. When he returned home, he planned to go bungee jumping.
å¦   "One time he told me this quote he tried to live by," his sister Kimberly remembered. "He said, 'Everyone is alive, but not everyone lives.' I think that describes him pretty well."
å¦   Bertolino, 20, of Hampstead, N.H., was killed in a vehicle rollover Feb. 9 near Jalalabad. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Kaneohe Bay.
å¦   His family remembered Bertolino as someone who lived life to the fullest, whether he was hiking, rock climbing or playing paintball. In high school, he was a wrestler and a soccer player.
å¦   His mother, Joyce, said her son was good with his hands and was halfway through redoing the family kitchen. He bought a Jeep Wrangler, replaced the interior and worked hard to pay it off.
å¦   "He was a wonderful, perfect, handsome 20-year-old who loved being a Marine," she said. "He was going to be a police officer when he got home. He was going to build a house. He had so many plans."
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Stan.

ServiceUnit: 1St Battalion  3Rd Marine Regiment  3Rd Mardiv
IncidentDetails: died when enemy forces opened fire on a U.S. patrol
Bio:
During John Thomas Fralish II's years of military service, he picked up the nickname "Captain America."
å¦   His bald head and facial features probably had something to do with it, Lt. Col. James Bierman, Fralish's commanding officer wrote in a letter read during a funeral service.
å¦   "Like a superhero, he seemed to be everywhere at all times," Bierman wrote. "He seemed larger than life."
å¦   Fralish, 30, of New Kingstown, Pa., was killed Feb. 5 in a firefight in northeast Afghanistan. He was assigned to Marine Corps Base, Hawaii, and had served two tours in Iraq.
å¦   Fralish was an avid surfer and 1994 high school graduate. He worked at North Atlantic Coffee Co. in Camp Hill before he enlisted in the Navy in 2002.
å¦   "He was a great person to talk to," said Brenda Crawford, a classmate. "I confided in him for a lot of things and he always gave you a shoulder to cry on."
å¦   He is survived by his parents, James and Jean.
å¦   "He was an amazing man. He could have become anything, an admiral, a governor, even the president," said John C. Fralish Jr., his uncle. "This was someone who had real potential."

ServiceUnit: Hsc  3D Battalion  7Th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: died when an improvised explosive device detonated near their HMMWV during combat operations
Bio:
In his last e-mail to his best friend, Edwin H. Dazachacon told Jerry Costello Jr. he was thinking of him.
å¦   "He explained to me that he was going out on patrols and that he had a lot of stories for me, that he loved me and the kids and to tell my family that he loved them," said Costello.
å¦   Dazachacon, 38, of Shiloh, Ill., was killed Feb. 13 by a roadside bomb north of Deh Rawod. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Dazachacon was born in Colombia and grew up in Miami.
å¦   In 1996, he pulled security detail when former President Bill Clinton visited U.S. troops in Bosnia. The Washington Post interviewed several soldiers, including Dazachacon, to gauge the effect a visit from a president without a military background would have on troops.
å¦   "From a soldier's perspective, it's good to see the leader out here asking about our needs," Dazachacon said. "That's true whether the leader is the lieutenant or the president."
å¦   After leaving the Army, Dazachacon joined the National Guard.
å¦   He is survived by his mother and two sisters in California and his father, who lives in Colombia.

ServiceUnit: Co B  3D Battalion  7Th Special Forces Group (TF CJSOTF-A)
IncidentDetails: died when an improvised explosive device detonated near their HMMWV during combat operations
Bio:
When Chad A. Gonsalves was home, he spent every free minute with his sons. He loved when they were dressed in overalls _ so he could pick them up by the shoulder straps like weights.
å¦   "The boys turned him into a little boy himself," said his wife, Julie. "He lived for those boys."
å¦   Gonsalves, 31, of Turlock, Calif., was killed Feb. 13 when his vehicle was struck by a bomb in Afghanistan. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   In sixth-grade camp, he made a wooden medallion with the words, "Chad Gonsalves, U.S. Army, Green Beret, Special Forces." He joined the Army in July 1996 and volunteered for the Special Forces in 2000.
å¦   Julie first met Chad in a Fort Bragg nightclub in the summer of 2000 after he returned from Germany. The first thing she noticed were Chad's eyes, Julie said, then his great sense of humor.
å¦   "He made everybody laugh," she said.
å¦   After almost a year of courtship, Julie and Chad married the day after his graduation. "He was not one of those romantic guys, that's why I liked him," she said.
å¦   He also is survived by 4-year old son Cody and 1-year-old twins Blake and Dylan.

ServiceUnit: Co G  1St Battalion  7Th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: died when an improvised explosive device detonated near their HMMWV during combat operations
Bio:
Alberto D. Montrond Jr. made military news a year ago when he was featured as part of an Army program to better outfit soldiers with new equipment.
å¦   He was pictured placing padding in a new helmet and quoted about receiving a new pair of steel-toed boots.
å¦   "After deploying three times, I want the steel-toed boots," he told a reporter for a military online journal. "I won't have to worry about a gate or vehicle crushing my toes. It's good protection."
å¦   Montrond, 27, of Suffolk, Mass., was killed Feb. 13 by a roadside bomb north of Deh Rawod. He was assigned to Fort Bragg and had re-enlisted for a third time last December after being deployed in Kosovo and Afghanistan.
å¦   "He loved the Army and serving for America," said Maria Montrand, his mother.
å¦   Montrand emigrated from Cape Verde to Boston in 1996, was a member of Junior ROTC in high school and started his Army career in 1998 with the 82nd Airborne Division. He was a chemical equipment repair quartermaster.
å¦   Montrond leaves his wife, Krystal, and their two young children, Nazereah and Kevyn.

ServiceUnit: 492D Civil Affairs Battalion  (TF CJSOTF-A)
IncidentDetails: died when an improvised explosive device detonated near their HMMWV during combat operations
Bio:
Clint Newman was in the Middle East helping to rebuild schools. He took a collection of school supplies that elementary students collected during Thanksgiving.
å¦   "Anyone who knew him knew he was a really giving man," said his stepfather Bill Agnew. "He always helped those in need. He also did that in his military career."
å¦   Newman, 26, of Pleasanton, Texas, was killed Feb. 13 when a bomb exploded next to his Humvee in Dihrawud. He was assigned to Fort Sam Houston.
å¦   A 1997 high school graduate, Newman was a member of the band, the football team and the National Honor Society. He served tours of duty in Bosnia and Germany. He later joined the Reserves and attended the University of Texas at San Antonio for six months.
å¦   While serving in the Reserves, Newman received the award for Soldier of the Year. He visited Washington, D.C., where he met many generals and his efforts were applauded.
å¦   Newman is survived by his mother, Deborah; and his father and stepmother, Fred and Deborah Newman. "Clint always expressed the utmost respect and pride for his fellow brothers-in-arms," his family said in a statement.

ServiceUnit: Hmh-464  Mag-29  2D Maw  Mcas New River
IncidentDetails: died when two CH-53 helicopters crashed into the Gulf of Aden in the vicinity of Ras Siyyan, northern Djibouti, while flying a training mission in the Godoria Range area
Bio:
Friends and relatives called Brandon R. Dronet a typical country boy who made good.
å¦   "His family was so proud of him. His grandmother had a large picture of him over the fireplace and was praying for his safe return," said Warren Perrin, a family friend.
å¦   Dronet, 33, of Erath, Ga., was killed Feb. 17 when a pair of Marine helicopters crashed off the coast of Africa. He was assigned to New River.
å¦   Dronet was on active duty with the Marines for 10 years as a staff sergeant and then earned a degree in business in 2002 from Louisiana State University.
å¦   "As I recall, he was a very polite kid and a good student. He wasn't trouble. He was a sweet little fellow," said Denise Nugent, who taught Dronet in high school.
å¦   He married his high school sweetheart, Summer Landry, and they had four children. At his officer's commissioning ceremony, Dronet was presented a key to the city of Abbeville.
å¦   "I would just hope the citizens of Vermilion Parish, especially the children, realize the great sacrifice he made for our country. My prayers and condolences go out to the family," said Mark Piazza, mayor of Abbeville.

ServiceUnit: Hmh-464  Mag-29  2D Maw  Mcas New River
IncidentDetails: died when two CH-53 helicopters crashed into the Gulf of Aden in the vicinity of Ras Siyyan, northern Djibouti, while flying a training mission in the Godoria Range area
Bio:
James F. Fordyce was not about to back down from a tough situation.
å¦   "Whether he was at a checkpoint in Iraq or in Africa, he always looked forward to a challenge," said Fordyce's friend and neighbor, Lynsey Hetzner. "As rough as he told me it was, he loved all the new experiences and said he would never trade it for anything."
å¦   Fordyce, 22, of Newtown Square, Pa., was killed Feb. 17 when a pair of Marine helicopters crashed off the coast of Africa. He was assigned to New River and had served two tours in Iraq.
å¦   A 2001 high school graduate, Fordyce enlisted in the Marines just prior to the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Hetzner said he never looked back.
å¦   "I know a lot of people had doubts about their decision after 9/11, but he really wanted to go to the battlefield and serve his country," she said. "When he came home for the first time, he had totally changed. His head was on straight and he knew what he was doing."
å¦   In his downtime, Fordyce liked to tinker with cars and spend time with his friends. "He loved to work with his hands," Hetzner said.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, James and Margaret.

ServiceUnit: 92D Communications Squadron
IncidentDetails: died when two CH-53 helicopters crashed into the Gulf of Aden in the vicinity of Ras Siyyan, northern Djibouti, while flying a training mission in the Godoria Range area
Bio:
Alecia S. Good was a single mom, relying upon a network of loving family and friends to raise her daughter. In return, her loved ones got unforgettable smiles.
å¦   "Every day that I come into work I can't help but look over at the desk behind me in the office where you used to sit. I just remember you being there, drinking your daily health shakes, and laughing and smiling about something," said former colleague Dustin Heideman.
å¦   "I don't think there was anyone in this world that your smile, your laugh, and your passion for life did not touch in some way."
å¦   Good, 23, of Broadview Heights, Ohio, was killed Feb. 17 when a pair of Marine helicopters crashed off the coast of Africa. She graduated high school in 2001 and was assigned to Fairchild Air Force Base.
å¦   Good was on her first overseas assignment, and had been in the Air Force for about four years. She had served at bases in Bedford, Ohio; San Antonio, Texas; and Biloxi, Miss. She loved to snowboard and would often go to a mountain in Idaho or Colorado.
å¦   She is survived by her daughter, Tabatha, 2; and parents, Paul and Claire.

ServiceUnit: Hmh-464  Mag-29  2D Maw  Mcas New River
IncidentDetails: died when two CH-53 helicopters crashed into the Gulf of Aden in the vicinity of Ras Siyyan, northern Djibouti, while flying a training mission in the Godoria Range area
Bio:
Samuel W. Large Jr. had shown an interest in the military sine he was 14 or 15 years old, said his father, Sam. He thinks his son saw something on the news that got him thinking.
å¦   "He had made a comment that he believed way back then, 'You know what Dad? I think everybody should have to join the military and serve a minimum time in the military and they would appreciate living where they live.' It kind of floored me," his father said.
å¦   Large, 21, of Villa Rica, Ga., was killed Feb. 17 when a pair of Marine helicopters crashed off the coast of Africa. He was assigned to New River.
å¦   Large had been stationed in Djibouti for about 6 months. His mother, Ada, remembers talking to him about everyday things, like his habit of rising at 5 a.m. so he could go on a 5-mile run.
å¦   Ada Large said that when her son decided to join the military, it was natural that he would choose the Marines.
å¦   "He just thought the Marines were the best," she said, "the toughest and the best. Sam always tried his best and wanted to excel in whatever he did."
å¦   He also leaves behind a wife, Whitney Large, and their infant son, Tyler.

ServiceUnit: Hmh-464  Mag-29  2D Maw  Mcas New River
IncidentDetails: died when two CH-53 helicopters crashed into the Gulf of Aden in the vicinity of Ras Siyyan, northern Djibouti, while flying a training mission in the Godoria Range area
Bio:
Donnie Leo F. Levens was just 3 when his mother bought him a book about airplanes. From that point on, he begged her daily to take him to the airport.
å¦   "It's what he always wanted to do as a young child," Margaret Levens said. "It was his passion. He would just sit there and beam every time a chopper passed over the house."
å¦   Levens, 25, of Long Beach, Miss., was killed Feb. 17 when his helicopter crashed into the Gulf of Aden. He graduated high school in 1998 and was assigned to New River.
å¦   Levens enrolled in the Marines before he turned 18 and left for boot camp just three days after his birthday.
å¦   Jerry Levens, Donnie's uncle, said that the Marine learned an early lesson about caring for others when he went on missions to Saltillo, Mexico, to assist the community there.
å¦   "He truly was changed by the process and fell in love with helping. You could sense his compassion for people who needed help," Jerry Levens said.
å¦   Donnie worked with kids during the weeklong stays, handing out Mardi Gras beads, playing and distributing food and clothing.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Grady Stone.

ServiceUnit: Hmh-464  Mag-29  2D Maw  Mcas New River
IncidentDetails: died when two CH-53 helicopters crashed into the Gulf of Aden in the vicinity of Ras Siyyan, northern Djibouti, while flying a training mission in the Godoria Range area
Bio:
Matthieu Marcellus was the son of Haitian immigrants who joined the Marines three years ago to fulfill his dream of flying.
å¦   "Though he was getting older, he passed all his exams with flying colors," said his younger brother, Jacob. "He was too old to actually be a pilot. So he did the next best thing and became a technician."
å¦   Marcellus, 31, of Gainesville, Fla., died Feb. 17 when a pair of Marine helicopters crashed off the coast of Africa. He was assigned to New River.
å¦   Serving in the military was "a calling" along with flying, said Ruth Marcellus-Hanchell, a sister. "Going fast, flying, racing cars, he loved all that," she said. "Being in the helicopter where he died was what he wanted to be doing."
å¦   Marcellus was the son of Haitian immigrants who settled in New York before moving to Miami when he was 10. He moved to Gainesville in the late 1990s where his first wife attended college. There, he worked as an assistant manager at Toys 'R' Us.
å¦   Marcellus, a huge a Miami Heat fan, graduated high school in 1992 and attended Santa Fe Community College in Gainesville. He is survived by his wife, Donna Marie.

ServiceUnit: Hmh-464  Mag-29  2D Maw  Mcas New River
IncidentDetails: died when two CH-53 helicopters crashed into the Gulf of Aden in the vicinity of Ras Siyyan, northern Djibouti, while flying a training mission in the Godoria Range area
Bio:
Kathy McCullough was at the hospital the day Jonathan E. McColley was born and was grateful to be able to watch him grow up with her son.
å¦   "He was so full of life. He just loved life," she said. "It's just so hard to believe he's not here anymore."
å¦   McColley, 23, of Gettysburg, Pa., was killed Feb. 17 when a pair of Marine helicopters crashed off the coast of Africa. He was assigned to New River.
å¦   In a recent e-mail to his family, McColley displayed his sense of humor, attaching a photo labeled "sexy guy." The picture showed McColley, gun in hand, in a sandy, desolate area with a few trees in the background.
å¦   McColley enrolled in the military as a junior in high school, then started his training in August 2000 after graduating. His assignments had taken him to California, North Carolina, Guam, Japan and Iraq.
å¦   He was remembered as an outstanding swimmer with long, red hair. He loved listening to the Beach Boys, Jimmy Buffett and the Grateful Dead.
å¦   "If you did not know him you were truly missing out on something great," said friend Dan Brouten.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Susan and John.

ServiceUnit: Hmh-464  Mag-29  2D Maw  Mcas New River
IncidentDetails: died when two CH-53 helicopters crashed into the Gulf of Aden in the vicinity of Ras Siyyan, northern Djibouti, while flying a training mission in the Godoria Range area
Bio:
Nicholas J. Sovie always had a nugget of advice to offer his older brother when he needed reassurance.
å¦   "He was not only my brother; he was my best friend," Joshua Sovie said.
å¦   Sovie, 20, of Ogdensburg, N.Y., was killed Feb. 17 when a pair of Marine helicopters crashed off the coast of Africa. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to New River.
å¦   Sovie joined the Marines in August 2003 and achieved high scores on aptitude tests to attend flight school. He had worked as crew chief aboard CH-53E helicopters. In high school, he participated in soccer and ran track. He also enjoyed hiking in the Adirondack mountains, fishing and camping.
å¦   "He was an exceptional kid and a good leader in the service," cousin Richard Sovie said. "He was proud to be a Marine. He always wanted to be a Marine. His family was very proud of him."
å¦   A newspaper carrier for the Ogdensburg Journal and Advance News, Sovie was never known to turn down someone needing a chore done around the house. "He did the odd jobs that needed to be done," the Rev. F. James Shurtleff said.
å¦   He also is survived by his parents, Stephen and Mary.

ServiceUnit: Hmh-464  Mag-29  2D Maw  Mcas New River
IncidentDetails: died when two CH-53 helicopters crashed into the Gulf of Aden in the vicinity of Ras Siyyan, northern Djibouti, while flying a training mission in the Godoria Range area
Bio:
Last fall, when Bryan D. Willard was on leave, he stopped by his high school and went to a football game. The former player couldn't stay on the sidelines.
å¦   "They were losing, and at halftime he went into the locker room and gave them a pep talk," said his father, David. "The team later sent him an autographed football."
å¦   Willard, 33, of Hummelstown, Pa., was killed Feb. 17 when a pair of Marine helicopters crashed off the coast of Africa. He was a 1990 high school graduate, had served two tours in Iraq and was assigned to New River.
å¦   "He was always fun to be around, always had a smile on his face. One of those kids that just never felt any pressure _ you know he could always take bad situations and make them good," said Jeff Barlup, childhood friend.
å¦   Willard graduated from Lock Haven University, then studied mortuary science at Northampton College.
å¦   "Bryan helped evacuate people from New Orleans during Hurricane Katrina," his father said. "He was very proud of being a Marine, and we were very proud of him. The whole community was proud of him."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Shannon.

ServiceUnit: Company B  3D Battalion  7Th Special Forces Group  ( CJSOTF-A)
IncidentDetails: died when an improvised explosive device detonated near his HMMWV during a reconnaissance mission
Bio:
There were tears on the cheeks of Emigdio E. Elizarraras Jr.'s father. "My son's body is dead," he said. "He will always be special here," he added, with a hand pressed to his chest.
å¦   Elizarraras, 37, of Pico Rivera, Calif., was killed Feb. 28 by a roadside bomb in Tarin Kowt. He graduated high school in 1986 and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   His first assignment was at Fort Campbell, during which he served in the first Gulf War. He also had served at Schofield Barracks and as an instructor at the Western Hemisphere Institute for Security Cooperation at Fort Benning. In 1997, he volunteered for Special Forces training.
å¦   Elizarraras "committed himself to the dangerous task of protecting our freedom," Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said in a statement. "His dedication to this country will not be forgotten."
å¦   Elizarraras is survived by his wife, Kris; daughters Sally and Olivia; and a son, Andrew.
å¦   He was "a loving husband, a devoted father, a caring son and a selfless soldier," said a family statement. "He gave his life for this country _ protecting our freedoms, our families and America's way of life."

ServiceUnit: Company A  391St Engineer Battalion
IncidentDetails: died when an improvised explosive device detonated near their HMMWV during combat operations
Bio:
Even as a boy, Kevin D. Akins was curious, rambunctious and lively.
å¦   His mother, Elizabeth Harrisen, remembered the time Kevin, at age 4, hopped in his aunt's vehicle and took off driving, running the car through an orange grove. She also laughed when she talked about the time he put gravel in her gas tank.
å¦   Akins, 29, of Burnsville, N.C., was killed March 12 by a roadside bomb west of Asadabad. He was assigned to Asheville and had already done a tour in Iraq.
å¦   "He enjoyed life. He enjoyed the 29 years to the fullest," said his father, Don Akins.
å¦   Akins, a grocery store manager, loved being an uncle to his sister's children, now 4 and 7. He was ideal in the role, riding them piggyback, wrestling with them on the floor.
å¦   "They called him Uncle Bubba," said Sam Robertson, former husband of his sister Kelly. "He was a true-to-life uncle."
å¦   Akins was a mentor to countless soldiers and had a legendary work ethic. "No one outworked Big Ake. He led by example; a natural leader that soldiers desired to follow. And follow him they did," the military said in a statement.
å¦   He also is survived by his stepfather, Herbert.

ServiceUnit: Hhc  391St Engineer Battalion
IncidentDetails: died when an improvised explosive device detonated near their HMMWV during combat operations
Bio:
Anton J. Hiett didn't have to be in Afghanistan.
å¦   "He volunteered to go even though his unit wasn't going," said his father, George Hiett. "He felt like he needed to go. His whole life's goal was to make a difference in other people's lives."
å¦   Hiett, 25, of Mount Airy, N.C., was killed March 12 by a roadside bomb west of Asadabad. He was assigned to Greenville.
å¦   Hiett, who drove a truck for Swift Transportation, joined the military after graduating high school in 1998. He later became a combat medic and a reservist.
å¦   "Whenever you saw a group of people having fun, Sgt. Hiett was often in the center leading the group," the military said in a statement.
å¦   He and his wife, Misty, married on Feb. 2, 2005, the day before he left for Afghanistan. The couple already had bought tickets to take a belated honeymoon cruise in June to the Bahamas.
å¦   "He was very funny, very compassionate," said Leslie Moore, a friend. "He was trustworthy, a person you could confide in and talk to and trust. If he could help you in any way, he would."
å¦   He also is survived by his 2-year-old daughter, Kyra.

ServiceUnit: Company A  391St Engineer Battalion
IncidentDetails: died when an improvised explosive device detonated near their HMMWV during combat operations
Bio:
Joshua L. Hill knew when he was coming back.
å¦   "He was 30 days, 12 hours and 20 minutes from home," said his father, Terry Hill. "He had it all figured out exactly."
å¦   Hill, 24, of Fowlerton, Ind., was killed March 12 by a roadside bomb west of Asadabad. He was assigned to Asheville and had done a tour in Iraq.
å¦   Hill was studying nursing at Indiana Business College, and was an avid NASCAR and Colts fan.
å¦   "That boy thought he could drive like a pro," said his mother Susan Kay Hill. "He had a Beretta, and he got into more trouble with that thing. It was scary."
å¦   Hill, a 2002 high school graduate, joined the Army Reserve when his wife, Alexis, was expecting their first child, who's now 6. The couple also have a 1-year-old daughter, Ariana.
å¦   "He thought it was the best thing to do because he was having a baby," Terry Hill said.
å¦   His mother said he revealed to her his two goals while overseas: riding a camel and riding a donkey. He attempted to achieve one of those by hopping on a donkey's back, startling it and causing it to break into a gallop.
å¦   Josh was left in the dust, and the owner was left running after the animal.

ServiceUnit: Company A  391St Engineer Battalion
IncidentDetails: died when an improvised explosive device detonated near their HMMWV during combat operations
Bio:
Joseph R. Ray was well liked _ even in jail.
å¦   He worked in maintenance at the Buncombe County Detention Center, where his father worked in the sheriff's department for 30 years. When he was 7, Joe wanted to take the rest of his birthday cake to the jail to share with the inmates.
å¦   "Everyone who knows Joe will tell you he always had a smile on his face, a kind word for everyone and never met a stranger," said county manager Wanda Greene.
å¦   Ray, 29, of Asheville, N.C., was killed March 12 by a roadside bomb west of Asadabad. He was a 1995 high school graduate and was assigned to Asheville. He'd already done a tour in Iraq.
å¦   Ray loved working with his hands and taking things apart, even if he didn't always manage to put them back together. "He was the best big brother anyone could ever imagine," said Tyler Ray, Joe's brother.
å¦   "When anybody mentioned his name, they think of him and they think of that huge, big smile of his," Janet Herren, a co-worker. "My heart is broken."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Anna, a stepson and a daughter.
å¦   Ray got a tattoo of his young daughter's hand before he left for another tour. "He said, 'I want to take her with me,'" Herren said.

ServiceUnit: 1St Bn  3D Mar  3D Mar Div
IncidentDetails: died in a vehicle incident while conducting combat operations
Bio:
Nicholas R. Anderson and his sister, Jessica Yanke, got tattoos in December _ the Chinese symbols for brother and sister. Anderson's tattoo was on his bicep; Yanke had hers tattooed on her back.
å¦   "We've always been very close, so it was just a way to stay close to each other," Yanke said.
å¦   Anderson, 21, of Sauk City, Wis., was killed March 13 when his Humvee tipped over near Jalalabad. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Kaneohe Bay.
å¦   Friends remembered Anderson as a bright young man who loved fishing, weightlifting and riding his Harley-Davidson through the Sauk County countryside.
å¦   "He liked to play soldier as a kid," his sister said. "He was always wearing helmets and playing with guns." Her brother had also served in Afghanistan.
å¦   His father, Jim Anderson, said he and his son kept in touch with instant messaging early in the morning, and sometimes, if he slept in a few minutes, Nick would be there, waiting. Now he gets messages from Nick's buddies in his unit.
å¦   "They tell me he was an outstanding Marine, he made friends quick and it's hard for them," he said.
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Barbara, and stepmother, Cindy.

ServiceUnit: Hhc  2D Battalion  20Th Special Forces Group (CJSOTF-A)
IncidentDetails: died when his HMMWV came under enemy small arms fire during combat operations
Bio:
Christopher L. Robinson was always up for a good time and loved skydiving and water sports.
å¦   "Once when I lived in southern California he came to visit and I had this old car and he said, 'Hey cousin, we've got to rent a convertible and I'm going to wear my cowboy hat for the occasion," said his cousin, Ramona Prince. "We went in 50-50 on a convertible Mustang and drove all over Los Angeles. He was just so much fun."
å¦   Robinson, 36, of Brandon, Miss., died March 25 when his vehicle came under fire in Sangain District. He graduated high school in 1987, was assigned to Jackson and was on his second deployment to Afghanistan.
å¦   "I can't tell you what a wonderful, wonderful hero he is. Chris died for everybody to be free," said his aunt, Ola Buntin. "He died for the people that protested the war and he died for the people that supported the military."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Tamara, 5-year-old daughter Savannah, and 1-year-old son.
å¦   Prince said Robinson's daughter realized that something had happened to her father. "She said, 'I know my daddy is gone, but I had a fun daddy,'" Prince said.

ServiceUnit: Hhc  86Th Brigade  42D Infantry Division (TF Phoenix)
IncidentDetails: died as a result of enemy mortar and small arms attacks during combat operations
Bio:
John T. Stone was a junior in high school when his older brother, Dana, a freelance photographer, disappeared in Cambodia. He joined the Army in 1971, motivated at least in part by a desire to learn what had happened.
å¦   "He had it in his mind he might go and try to find his brother," when he enlisted, said Elisha Morgan, who played football with Stone in high school.
å¦   Stone, 52, of Norwich, Vt., was killed March 29 in Lashkagar by mortar and small-arms attacks. He was assigned to South Burlington and was on his third tour in Afghanistan.
å¦   Dana Stone was listed as MIA for years and was eventually listed as dead. But Tom Stone never lost the sense of adventure the military imbued in him or his desire to help those around him.
å¦   "He was the best friend anyone could have, anybody," Morgan said. "I know when he was shot he was helping others. That's all he did. He never cared about financial gain. He did it out of love for humanity."
å¦   Over the years Stone served in the regular Army, the reserves and the Vermont National Guard. Between 1992 and 2000 he walked around the world, literally, 22,000 miles through 29 countries.
å¦   He is survived by his life partner, Rose Loving.

ServiceUnit: Co B  3D Bn Gsab  10Th Aviation Regiment  (TF Centaur)
IncidentDetails: died when their CH-47 Chinook helicopter crashed during combat operations
Bio:
Bryan A. Brewster, a crew chief on a CH-47 Chinook, had the ultimate goal of becoming a pilot. He was just two months away from being transferred from the front lines to helicopter training school.
å¦   "Since he was a little kid, 4 or 5 years old, he would go to school wearing camo," said his brother, Scott. "He knew what he was doing right upon graduation; he was ready."
å¦   Brewster, 24, of Fontana, Calif., died May 5 when the helicopter he was in crashed east of Abad. He was based at Fort Drum.
å¦   Brewster had just graduated from high school when he enlisted at age 18. In only three years, he achieved the rank of sergeant. He easily earned the trust and loyalty of the 30 men in his unit.
å¦   Brewster was described as sweet but with a wicked sense of humor. He had toilet-papered his share of homes.
å¦   Brewster celebrated his 21st birthday in Afghanistan and his 22nd in Iraq. "It's an awful lot of missed birthdays and anniversaries," said his father, Louis Brewster.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife Kati. "She loved that boy, and he loved her," Louis Brewster said. "They were meant for each other."

ServiceUnit: Co B  3D Bn Gsab  10Th Aviation Regiment  (TF Centaur)
IncidentDetails: died when their CH-47 Chinook helicopter crashed during combat operations
Bio:
Christopher B. Donaldson graduated high school in 1995 without much aim or sense of purpose. He took a semester of courses at a local community college but never found a vocation. Until the military.
å¦   The Army "changed him. He stood up straighter. He was more respectful and thoughtful," said his mother, Lynne Donaldson. "You could tell he was a man."
å¦   In her proudest moment, she pinned her son's wings to his chest in 2004.
å¦   Donaldson, 28, of Effingham, Ill., died May 5 when the helicopter he was in crashed east of Abad. He was based at Fort Drum.
å¦   High school teachers remembered him as a quiet kid who shone on the football field and baseball diamond. "He really excelled in football and baseball, but he was painfully quiet and hard to know," said guidance counselor and former baseball coach Larry Micenheimer. "He seemed just interested in getting through school."
å¦   After his first military commitment ended, Donaldson immediately re-enlisted, determined to become a pilot. By his death, he had earned a bachelor's degree through the military and served in Germany and South Korea.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Bill.

ServiceUnit: Co E  3D Bn Gsab  10Th Aviation Regiment  (TF Centaur)
IncidentDetails: died when their CH-47 Chinook helicopter crashed during combat operations
Bio:
John C. Griffith played with toy soldiers when he was 5 years old. Eager to adopt the military lifestyle, he joined the Navy Junior ROTC in high school, where he was on the rifle drill team.
å¦   "He was always a soldier," said his mother, Barbara. "He told me 'I will not live my life with would-have and should-have and could-have. I will do what has to be done.'"
å¦   Griffith, 33, of Las Vegas, died May 5 when the helicopter he was in crashed east of Abad. He was a 1991 high school graduate and was based at Fort Drum.
å¦   Griffith first enlisted in the Army in the spring of 1991. He served as a paratrooper with the 82nd Airborne Division. In a freak incident at Fort Bragg in 1995, an angry soldier fired shots across a field and a bullet lodged in his right thigh.
å¦   He left the service and worked as a mechanic for about four years and served in the Nevada National Guard. The 2001 terrorist attacks prompted him to rejoin the regular Army in 2003. He served in South Korea as an ambulance mechanic, then was reassigned to the 10th Mountain Division.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Christa, and their children Hunter, Spencer and Kailynn.

ServiceUnit: Co B  3D Bn Gsab  10Th Aviation Regiment  (TF Centaur)
IncidentDetails: died when their CH-47 Chinook helicopter crashed during combat operations
Bio:
Though Paul Bloom, a high school guidance counselor, sees plenty of faces, he could recognize Christopher T. Howick's instantly.
å¦   "I remember that face, that cherubic face," Bloom said. "He had that big smile and was just a delightful young man to be with. He was a genuinely likable kid."
å¦   Howick, 34, of Hamburg, N.Y., died May 5 when the helicopter he was in crashed east of Abad. He was a 1990 high school graduate and was based at Fort Drum.
å¦   School officials described Howick as boyish, saying that he looked like a freshman, even in his graduation photo. He majored in business and had average grades.
å¦   "For as long as you've been alive, Chris has been out there, one of the faceless, nameless troops working to keep freedom alive. And like so many, he was unknown to you until he died," Kathy Mendez, a secretary at the high school, told students over the public-address system.
å¦   After enlisting in the Army in 1991, Howick was assigned as a helicopter repairman at Fort Wainwright, moved to Fort Drum and Fort Wainwright, and then Fort Rucker as a helicopter repair instructor.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Una, and a daughter, Noel.

ServiceUnit: Troop A  3D Squadron  71St Cavalry  3Bct  (TF Spartan
IncidentDetails: died when their CH-47 Chinook helicopter crashed during combat operations
Bio:
Last year, Joseph J. Fenty Jr. was among about 230 officers who participated in a 10.4-mile motivational brigade run. In an interview with a military newsletter, he hailed his fellow officers for their spirit of cooperation.
å¦   "I think it was awesome to get all the brigade officers out there with a team-building focus," he said. "And most importantly, they were all together at the finish line cheering each other on."
å¦   Fenty, 41, of Watertown, N.Y., died May 5 when the helicopter he was in crashed east of Abad. He was based at Fort Drum.
å¦   Fenty was "my role model," said Army Lt. Col. Christopher G. Cavoli. "He was the soldier my father always taught me to aspire to be, and the gentleman my mother always wished I were."
å¦   He was commissioned into the infantry in 1986 after graduation from Belmont Abbey College in Belmont, N.C., and in 1998, he received a master's degree in education from Troy State University.
å¦   Carlos Lobo, Fenty's old college roommate, said Fenty as "very intense," and "real physical and competitive," but with a "real soft demeanor _ a genuine good person. His word was gold."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Kristen, and daughter Lauren.

ServiceUnit: Troop A  3D Squadron  71St Cavalry  3 Bct  (TF Spartan)
IncidentDetails: died when their CH-47 Chinook helicopter crashed during combat operations
Bio:
Brian M. Moquin Jr. is being memorialized permanently _ via ink etched into friends' skin.
å¦   Adam Labbe got Moquin's name tattooed on his upper left arm along with the initials R.I.P. A teenage girl got a similar tattoo, and two other teenage boys got a version of Moquin's design of the classic "Suicide King" playing card: a man stabbing himself in the head with a dagger.
