å¦   "He was one of the best friends you could ever have," said Labbe.
å¦   In recent years, Moquin had become a tattoo enthusiast, getting seven tattoos in a single week after coming home from basic training.
å¦   Moquin, 19, of Worcester, Mass., died May 5 when the helicopter he was in crashed east of Abad. He enlisted in March 2005 and was based at Fort Drum.
å¦   Peter Bissonnette, who is engaged to Moquin's mother, Tracy Vaillancourt, remembered Moquin as a young man who was still finding his way. He had dropped out of high school and obtained his GED before enlisting.
å¦   "He was looking for some direction," said Bissonnette.
å¦   Moquin was an accomplished artist and musician who wrote poetry. He loved skateboarding and was unfailingly loyal to his friends.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Brian.

ServiceUnit: Hhc  149Th Brigade  35Th Infantry
IncidentDetails: died when he came under enemy small arms fire during combat operations
Bio:
When Kenneth Miles and Clayton L. Adamkavicius teamed up, there was certain to be what they called "grown-up playing."
å¦   "We just enjoyed being together and running around fishing, hunting, riding four-wheelers through the woods," said Miles, a neighbor. "He was always friendly with everybody _ just a fantastic neighbor."
å¦   Adamkavicius, 43, of Fairdale, Ky., was shot April 21 while investigating a weapons cache discovered near Dihrawud. He was assigned to Louisville and his first two deployments were to Bosnia in 2003 and 2004.
å¦   He also had served in the Air Force as an active duty enlisted man from May 1983 through March 1990 and then served in the Nevada Army National Guard from April 1993 to March 1999.
å¦   Maj. Gen. Donald C. Storm, adjutant general of the state Guard, said Adamkavicius "was a fine young officer and will be missed by his family, his fellow soldiers and everyone who knew him."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Bonnie, of Louisville. His father, Edmond Adamkavicius, lives in Pasadena, Calif., and he has a daughter who lives in Nevada.
å¦   "We're heartbroken, but we're so determined," Storm said.

ServiceUnit: 1St Communications Squadron
IncidentDetails: died when two CH-53 helicopters crashed into the Gulf of Aden in the vicinity of Ras Siyyan, northern Djibouti, while flying a training mission in the Godoria Range area
Bio:
More than a year ago, Luis M. Melendez Sanchez was sent to the Middle East. His wife, also a staff sergeant, understood why he had to go. But they never got a chance to really say goodbye.
å¦   Regretting it, she refused to let Sanchez leave this time without a proper send-off.
å¦   "We bowled, we piggy-backed, we had a wonderful, loving time together," Mi'chele Cetto said, smiling at memories of a last-minute trip to Florida's Walt Disney World. "It was like we knew."
å¦   Sanchez, 33, of Bayamon, Puerto Rico, was killed Feb. 17 when a pair of Marine helicopters crashed off the coast of Africa. He was based at Langley Air Force Base.
å¦   "He was someone I could count on no matter how difficult the task," said Lt. Col. Michael Black. "When airmen needed a shoulder to cry on or advice, he was there. When airmen needed a swift kick or a pick me up, he'd do that as well."
å¦   Sanchez, a radio technician, was described as soft-spoken with a dry sense of humor and a passion for flying.
å¦   "He loved being around airplanes. He loved being in airplanes," Cetto said.
å¦   He also is survived by his sons, Gabriel, 5, and Adrian, 4.

ServiceUnit: Troop A  3D Squadron  71St Cavalry  3 Bct
IncidentDetails: died when their CH-47 Chinook helicopter crashed during combat operations
Bio:
Justin L. O'Donohoe's parents will keep the message he left not long ago on their telephone answering machine. They play it for visitors, although their son's voice moves them to tears.
å¦   "Hi, this is Justin. I guess I caught you at a bad time," he said in a tired-sounding voice. "I'm doing OK here. I love you."
å¦   O'Donohoe, 27, of San Diego, died May 5 when the helicopter he was in crashed east of Abad. He was based at Fort Drum.
å¦   O'Donohoe was involved with soccer, martial arts, fencing, piano, computers, strategy games and magic. He spoke Russian and Japanese, and even learned some of the Afghan language Pashtun before going overseas.
å¦   "He was a force of nature," said his father, Pat. "You could go along with him and ride the bow wave, or you could step aside."
å¦   After graduating from high school in 1996, O'Donohoe got a bachelor's degree in political science at San Diego State in 2000. He worked for the San Diego Unified School District as a computer technician.
å¦   In 2004, Justin surprised his family by choosing the life of an enlisted soldier over being an officer. "He didn't want to sit at a desk and do paperwork," Pat O'Donohoe said.
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Pam.

ServiceUnit: Troop A  3D Squadron  71St Cavalry  3 Bct  (TF Spartan)
IncidentDetails: died when their CH-47 Chinook helicopter crashed during combat operations
Bio:
David N. Timmons Jr.'s father said one memory from his son's childhood stands out. In elementary school, a well-meaning white teacher told the young black child that he would have to work twice as hard as his white counterparts to succeed.
å¦   "I was kind of upset at first," said David Timmons Sr. "Then, I told him he had to show her he was bigger than that and that's what he did until the very end. If you compare his life to a card game, then I would say he took his hand and played the best game he could for 23 years."
å¦   Timmons, 23, of Lewisville, N.C., died May 5 when the helicopter he was in crashed east of Abad. He was based at Fort Drum.
å¦   He was a 2001 high school graduate, a lithe 6-foot-4, 180-pound student athlete who played football, basketball and track. He also played trombone in the band.
å¦   He had been a student at Forsyth Technical Community College when he decided to join the military about two years ago. He found out he'd be going to Afghanistan in February.
å¦   "He knew it was a difficult assignment," Timmons said. "The last time I saw him face-to-face, he cried like a baby. But he knew he had to suck it up and do his job."

ServiceUnit: Company B  3D Battalion Gsab  10Th Aviation  (TF Centaur)
IncidentDetails: died when their CH-47 Chinook helicopter crashed during combat operations
Bio:
Eric W. Totten found his passion in life as a boy at the movies. "The first time he saw 'Star Wars' he was fascinated with aviation," recalled his brother Noel.
å¦   Totten, 34, raised in St. Paul, Minn., and lately of Dallas, died May 5 when the helicopter he was in crashed east of Abad. He was based at Fort Drum.
å¦   Totten was a career Army pilot who had been in Bosnia and Iraq and was on his second tour in Afghanistan. Noel Totten said there was a major change in his brother's life after a friend died.
å¦   "He said, 'I don't want to go that way _ I want to make something of myself,'" Noel Totten said. "And he did. We're very proud of him."
å¦   He became an accomplished musician, learning to play the trumpet, clarinet, piano and guitar. "He had a very natural ability to pick up instruments and just start playing," said his brother.
å¦   Totten was known for his humble personality and sense of humor. He sent his nieces and cousins postcards from all over the world after learning that they collected them.
å¦   "He was so spontaneous," said Jackson. "He really loved life. He enjoyed it to the fullest."
å¦   Totten is survived by a stepmother, Tommie Totten, and five siblings.

ServiceUnit: Company B  3D Battalion Gsab  10Th Aviation  (TF Centaur)
IncidentDetails: died when their CH-47 Chinook helicopter crashed during combat operations
Bio:
Only about 20 students graduate each year from Utopia High School and Jeffery S. Wiekamp was one of them in 2001 _ although he kept a low profile in such a small class.
å¦   "Jeffery was a very quiet young man. He was very friendly, but he was very shy," said longtime business teacher Jeanine Hawkes. "He was such a sweet, shy kid."
å¦   Wiekamp, 23, of Utopia, Texas, died May 5 when the helicopter he was in crashed east of Abad. He was based at Fort Drum.
å¦   Wiekamp was described as handsome, big-hearted and quick-witted during the memorial service. A lanky lad, Wiekamp played on the Running Buffaloes basketball team, the top sport in a 1A district that's too small to field football squads.
å¦   "Its affected pretty much everybody in town, as far as bringing the war closer to home," said Sterlin Boyce, 17, who grew up with Wiekamp. "Everybody knows him. It's a real tragedy," Boyce said.
å¦   "Jeffery was a fine young man," the Rev. George Kealin, pastor of the Church of Christ.
å¦   Wiekamp is survived by his wife, Ashley.
å¦   "All I can say is I'm very proud of him and all the boys that are over there," said his father, Randy Wiekamp.

ServiceUnit: Company B  710Th Brigade Support Battalion  3 Bct (TF Spartan)
IncidentDetails: died from a non-combat related cause
Bio:
Maj. Steven Tunnell, director of an academy for at-risk youth, said Derek A. Stanley arrived with typical teenage problems, but set a goal and met it.
å¦   "He was like a lot of kids disillusioned, he fell in with the wrong crowd, but he was never in trouble or arrested," Tunnell said. "His goal when he arrived here was to earn his GED, complete the program and enlist in the military and make a career in the military."
å¦   Not only did he achieve those goals, Stanley graduated in the top 10 percent of his class. "He was a peer mentor and a leader," Tunnell said. "He set a good example for the other kids."
å¦   Stanley, 20, of Tulsa, Okla., died June 5 of a noncombat injury while serving at Salerno. He graduated high school in 2003 and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   "He was cool," said Amber Osburn, his sister-in-law. "He was one of the strong, silent types. He loved to go on long walks. I'll miss him to death."
å¦   He is survived by his mother, Darlyn Smith, and his father, Faron Stanley.
å¦   "He was a man of principle who believed in what he was doing," said Mark Smith, the soldier's uncle. "He will always be my hero."

ServiceUnit: Company B  3D Battalion  7Th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: died from wounds sustained when his convoy came under enemy small arms fire during combat operations
Bio:
Christian Longsworth used his Internet telephone calls and instant messages to occasionally tease his girlfriend, Jessica Cruz, about the size and cut of a diamond engagement ring he planned to buy her.
å¦   "I said, 'I don't want to know the details. ... Save your money for something else,'" said Cruz. "He had a heart of gold, and he loved his friends and family."
å¦   Longsworth, 26, of Newark, N.J., was killed May 19 in Uruzgan province from wounds suffered when his convoy came under attack. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   The son of a longshoreman from El Salvador and a home health aide from Honduras, Longsworth opted for an Army career in part to gain an education that would have cost his family too much money.
å¦   Longsworth joined the Army in 1998 right after graduating from high school. He later volunteered for the Green Berets, and was promoted to staff sergeant in 2003.
å¦   "I didn't even look at it as working with him. He was just a great friend, and I enjoyed spending time with him," said Sgt. David Nolan. "He loved life."
å¦   He also is survived by his 5-year-old daughter, Jaylin Araya.

ServiceUnit: Battery A  1St Bn  188Th Air Defense Artillery  (TF Vigilant)
IncidentDetails: died when their HMWWV struck two anti-tank mines during combat operations
Bio:
Inside Curtis R. Mehrer's flag-draped casket were pictures of his infant daughter, Hailee, including a large photograph of the two of them together. Perched beside the photos were two small duck toys.
å¦   "It's a story of devotion," Gov. John Hoeven said during a memorial service. "Devotion to his family, devotion to his state, devotion to his country and devotion to his ideals."
å¦   Mehrer, 21, of Bismarck, N.D., was killed June 6 in Khogyani when his vehicle struck two anti-tank mines. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Grand Forks.
å¦   "He loved the military. And he was a big family guy," said Nikki Heck, whose husband, Staff Sgt. Shawn Heck, served alongside Mehrer in Afghanistan.
å¦   Mehrer followed in the footsteps of his father and grandfather when he joined the military. "He was a fun guy, just loved to have fun," said John McKenna, who lived with Mehrer for a few months last summer.
å¦   Mehrer planned to become engaged to Crystal Schmidt and wanted to be a helicopter pilot when he returned from Afghanistan. He also is survived by his parents, Kevin and Joyce.

ServiceUnit: Battery A  1St Bn  188Th Air Defense Artillery  (TF Vigilant)
IncidentDetails: died when their HMWWV struck two anti-tank mines during combat operations
Bio:
Travis A. Van Zoest put education and wedding plans on hold so he could serve his country, a decision his family said he made after the 2001 terrorist attacks.
å¦   "He represents the very best of us in America," Gov. John Hoeven said at Van Zoest's funeral. "He risked _ and lost _ his life because he wanted us all to live in freedom."
å¦   Van Zoest, 21, of Larimore, N.D., was killed June 6 in Khogyani when his vehicle struck two mines. He was assigned to Grand Forks.
å¦   Zoest graduated from high school in 2003 and attended Bismarck State College and Minot State University from 2003 until his deployment.
å¦   Pictures of his Van Zoest's family and fiancee were placed inside his casket, as was a pheasant feather. His family said he enjoyed sports and pheasant hunting.
å¦   "The one thing I'm gonna miss is the effect he had on me," said his father, Ben. "He changed me when he was near me."
å¦   He is survived by fiancee Keisia Austin; mother, Sheila Richter; stepfather, Terry; and stepmother, Deborah.
å¦   At his funeral, the Rev. Paul Becker said the soldier "gave his life for those who were the victims of violence."

ServiceUnit: Company B  321St Military Intelligence Battalion (TF Guardian)
IncidentDetails: died from wounds sustained when his convoy came under enemy small arms fire and an improvised explosive device detonated during combat operations
Bio:
When Bernard P. Corpuz arrived at California's central coast in the early '90s, he had long hair and often wore heavy-metal T-shirts. But the awkward teenager soon began to blossom.
å¦   "When he went out for track, that turned him around completely. All the teachers commented on the changes in him once he found out he could do something really well," said Gerry Flowers, a retired vice principal.
å¦   Corpuz, 28, of Watsonville, Calif., was killed June 11 from small-arms fire and a roadside explosive in Ghanzi. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   Corpuz excelled in track, receiving an athletic scholarship to attend Hartnell College in Salinas, where he specialized in the 400-meter intermediate hurdles. He later transferred to the University of La Verne, a private college near Pomona, graduating in 2000.
å¦   Before heading to Afghanistan, Corpuz finished a six-month stint studying French at the Defense Language Institute in April 2005.
å¦   "Bernard was a very communicative person, very sincere, hard working, very ambitious," said Chams Gandali, a French professor at the institute. "He was one of my favorite students."
å¦   He is survived by his mother, Margaret, and father, Bernaldo.

ServiceUnit: Training Site Command
IncidentDetails: died from a non-combat related cause
Bio:
At Camp Guernsey, a 33,000-acre training center for both Guard members and active duty military in Wyoming, Charles E. Munier was the guy you had to know.
å¦   "Lt. Col. Munier was a pivotal member of the Camp Guernsey staff and an outstanding officer who took his duties as a citizen soldier seriously," said Maj. Gen. Ed Wright, Wyoming's adjutant general, in a statement.
å¦   Munier, 50, of Wheatland, Wyo., died June 12 at Walter Reed Army Medical Center of a stroke he suffered June 5 in Kabul. He was a facilities manager at Guernsey.
å¦   He served as company commander at Fort McClellan and was the deputy provost marshal in Heidelberg, Germany. He was an assistant professor of military science at the University of Wyoming from 1994 to 1998 and an admissions field representative for the U.S. Military Academy.
å¦   He was the resident deputy in Rock River with the Albany County Sheriff's Office and the assistant detention administrator. He was the detention administrator for Platte County and served as Wyoming State Park range at Guernsey State Park.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Nancy, and a daughter, Victoria.

ServiceUnit: Hhc  1St Battalion  32D Infantry
IncidentDetails: died when his unit took small arms fire
Bio:
Russell M. Durgin was the consummate jokester. He was a goofy dancer and a karaoke fanatic who wasn't ashamed to belt out an '80s ballad like "Total Eclipse of the Heart."
å¦   One friend, Michael McManus, recalled the time he and Durgin stole some pumpkins. Instead of smashing them, they carved them and returned them to the spot they came from.
å¦   Durgin once ate a whole pie in 2.3 seconds while wearing a cheerleading uniform. There were other stories that his mother Jean never knew about.
å¦   "We all agree that there are some things that are better left unsaid," said McManus. "Jean, maybe someday we'll tell you what really happened to your old Subaru."
å¦   Durgin, 23, of Henniker, N.H., was killed June 13 in Korengel by small-arms fire. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Durgin was a 2001 high school graduate and played lacrosse. He enlisted at age 17 while his twin brother, Sean, signed up for the Air Force. He served in South Korea and Iraq before going to Afghanistan in March.
å¦   He also is survived by his fiancee, Michele, and his father, Lester.
å¦   "He's safe now," said his mother. "I don't have to worry about him anymore."

ServiceUnit: Medical Company  10Th Sustainment Brigade
IncidentDetails: died when his convoy came under enemy small arms fire during combat operations
Bio:
Roger P. Pena Jr. had an interesting way to try to convince Joe Castro, his best friend since the seventh-grade, to come with him to church.
å¦   "He told me it would be a good way to meet girls," Castro said. "He always had a way to get you to do what he wanted."
å¦   Pena, 29, of San Antonio, was killed June 14 in Musa Qulah by small-arms fire. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Roger and Castro went to the University of Texas in 1995 and while pursuing a degree in history, he met Marisol Gomez, and not long after that the two were married.
å¦   After the wedding, Roger took a semester off of school. He had originally planned on going back to finish his degree, but instead he started working and eventually decided to join the Army.
å¦   "There are many men in this world. There are very few real men. That's who Roger was," said Rita Martinez, his godmother.
å¦   He also is survived by his sons Ivan, 5, and Gabriel, 2.
å¦   While in Kabul, Pena would videotape himself reading children's books, then send the tape and the book home to his two boys. "Look, here's Piglet, and here's Pooh," he'd say, pointing to the pictures.

ServiceUnit: Hhc  240Th Engineer Group
IncidentDetails: died from a non-combat related cause
Bio:
Patrick D. Damon, who worked as policy adviser to four speakers of Maine's House of Representatives, would leave his house at 7 a.m. and sometimes work until 3 a.m. the next morning. He called the job a "blessing."
å¦   "He said, 'What you can do in one day in Augusta, you can't do in a lifetime outside. You can really affect people's lives,'" said his wife, Halley.
å¦   Damon, 41, of Falmouth, Maine, died June 15 of an apparent heart attack in Bagram. He was assigned to Augusta.
å¦   After high school, Damon hitchhiked to Washington, D.C., to enter American University with only enough money to get him through a semester. He married Halley in 1986 and worked in Washington for a few years after graduation before moving back to Maine, where Damon got involved in politics.
å¦   Attorney General Steven Rowe, who was speaker of the House in 1999 and 2000, called Damon "one of the most honorable and decent people I have ever known."
å¦   Damon joined the National Guard in 1986 and had served in Guatemala and Panama. In October he would have completed his 20th year of service and could have retired.
å¦   He also is survived by children Mikayla, 14, and Jan-Christian, 12.

ServiceUnit: Company C  1St Battalion  32D Infantry  (TF Spartan)
IncidentDetails: died when their all terrain vehicle struck an improvised explosive device during combat operations
Bio:
There was talk in 2001 that the Whitworth College track team play it safe in the final men's relay race to preserve the championship, even if it meant not winning that race.
å¦   Forrest P. Ewens refused. "I remember Forrest making the comment, 'I want to win the race but I will do whatever it takes for the team to win.' That was Forrest," said Whitworth College track coach Toby Schwarz.
å¦   Ewens, 25, of Chewelah, Wash., was killed June 16 in the Pech River Valley when his all-terrain vehicle struck a roadside bomb. He received a bachelor's degree in history from Whitworth in 2004 and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   "He was the best of the best, very sincere, loyal, hardworking, passionate. He was selfless," said Lt. Col. Alan Westfield, one of Ewens' ROTC instructors.
å¦   He was described as a track team captain who competed so hard that he would pass out from exhaustion. He was a dedicated historian determined to learn about both the good and bad in America's past
å¦   "He had a passion for life, and great determination in everything that he attempted," said Lt. Col. Alan Westfield.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Megan.

ServiceUnit: Company A  1St Bn  32D Infantry  10Th Inf Bde (TF Spartan)
IncidentDetails: died when their all terrain vehicle struck an improvised explosive device during combat operations
Bio:
Cheryl McLeod has some favorite photos of her nephew, Ian T. Sanchez. There's a shot of Sanchez, about age 5, playing in the snow with friends. And there's her favorite _ of the soldier standing as tall as John Wayne, framed by a doorway.
å¦   "He went from being a skinny kid to the type of guy who walked into a room and just commanded respect," said Gordon McLeod, the soldier's uncle.
å¦   Sanchez, 26, of New York City, was killed June 16 in the Pech River Valley when his vehicle struck a roadside bomb. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Calling his mother "My Earth," Sanchez wrote in 2002, "If it weren't for you, where would I be? Thank you for a great childhood and life up to this point. You should be very proud of your baby boy, who is now a man. You have done everything you can to make sure I grew up happy and loved and you succeeded."
å¦   After earning a GED, he worked various odd jobs, including as a groundskeeper at a golf course and helping disabled children learn to swim and play basketball.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Jennifer, a 6-year-old daughter, Jesenya, and a son, Marcus, who will turn 2 in August.

ServiceUnit: Hht  3D Squadron  71St Cavalry  3 Bct  (TF Spartan)
IncidentDetails: died when he encountered enemy forces using small arms fire and rocket-propelled grenades during combat operations

ServiceUnit: 159Th Air Ambulance Medical Company
IncidentDetails: died when his UH-60 helicopter hoist malfunctioned while attempting to evacuate Pfc. Bradbury during combat operations
Bio:
As a cross-country runner, Heathe N. Craig was the consummate teammate. He would sometimes purposely fall back in the pack to encourage his teammates at the rear.
å¦   "It meant a lot to their parents, and it meant a lot to me," said his mother, Donna M. Sloan.
å¦   Craig, 28, of Severn, Md., was killed June 21 when his helicopter hoist malfunctioned while attempting to evacuate a fellow soldier. He was a 1997 high school graduate and was assigned to Wiesbaden, Germany.
å¦   As a junior in 1996, he was district wrestling champion at 119 pounds under coach Dean Shew. He finished third in the region that year.
å¦   "He was easy to coach _ if you asked him to do something, he did it," said Shew. "If you told him to run through a wall, he'd run through that wall."
å¦   Shew wasn't surprised that Craig would put himself in harm's way to help someone else. "He could come through when it was real important. He always came through."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Judy; a 5-year-old son, Jonas; and a 1-year-old daughter, Leona.
å¦   His stepmother, Sheila Craig, said he loved his job enough to re-enlist. "He loved to help people and care for the suffering," she said. "He was very unselfish."

ServiceUnit: Troop C  3D Squadron  71St Cavalry
IncidentDetails: died when they encountered enemy forces using small arms fire and rocket-propelled grenades during combat operations
Bio:
Though Patrick L. Lybert had served in Iraq and Afghanistan, he hoped one day to return to his roots in northern Wisconsin and patrol the streets as a police officer.
å¦   "He always had an inner drive to help others. That's how this young man really was," said Dean Meyer, the police chief of Ladysmith, Wis.
å¦   Lybert, 28, of Ladysmith, was killed June 21 by small-arms fire and rocket-propelled grenades in Gowardesh. He was assigned to Fort Drum and had served in Iraq.
å¦   In high school, Lybert wrestled, played football and baseball, and ran cross country. As a teenager, he earned his Boy Scout Eagle award by restoring a half-mile trail along the Flambeau River.
å¦   "He believed in making a difference. He was always there helping people in the community," said Meyer.
å¦   He graduated from Western Wisconsin Technical College in La Crosse with an associate degree in criminal justice before enlisting.
å¦   "He was probably the best man that anyone could ever hope to know," said Lybert's former girlfriend, Shelly Saegrove. "When he would walk into a room, his smile would light it up."
å¦   Lybert is survived by his father, David, and mother, Cheryl.

ServiceUnit: Troop C  3D Squadron  71St Cavalry
IncidentDetails: died when they encountered enemy forces using small arms fire and rocket-propelled grenades during combat operations
Bio:
Jared C. Monti seemed to always put the needs of others before his own.
å¦   While serving in South Korea, he was swept down a river after testing a crossing to make sure it was safe. In Kosovo, he picked up a group of Albanian kids who were being harassed by Serbs and drove them to school. He never went home for Christmas or Thanksgiving because he wanted the married guys to be with their families.
å¦   "We use to send him care packages, and he would give them to all the kids," said his brother, Tim. "He carried candy around in his pocket for them, and he would tell us how he would give kids rides in the Humvee because they were scared to walk across town."
å¦   Monti, 30, of Raynham, Mass., was killed June 21 by small-arms fire and rocket-propelled grenades in Gowardesh. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   He joined the Army immediately after he graduated high school in 1994 to make enough money to go to college. He wanted to be a fifth-grade teacher.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Paul and Janet.
å¦   "He was just a kid that liked people and did a lot of things quietly. He was a very humble boy," said his father.

ServiceUnit: Hhc  53D Infantry Brigade
IncidentDetails: died when his HMMWV came in contact with enemy forces using rocket-propelled grenades and small arms fire during combat operations
Bio:
Joseph F. Fuerst III's page on MySpace.com has a heart-wrenching note from his wife of a little more than a year.
å¦   "I love you baby and I miss you so much, I don't even know where to begin," wrote Tara, who also is serving in Afghanistan. "I don't know what I'm going to do without you, I'm so completely lost and heartbroken. ... I love you."
å¦   Fuerst, 26, of Tampa, Fla., was killed June 24 in Panjway district from small-arms and grenade fire. He was assigned to Pinellas Park.
å¦   Fuerst graduated from high school in 1998 and graduated from Hillsborough Community College with an associate's degree in criminology. He also graduated from the Police Academy at the college and planned to have a career in law enforcement.
å¦   "He did what he thought was right," said John Moroney, one of Fuerst's mentors in the Boy Scouts. "He was excellent. A leader. He taught the younger kids and participated in just about everything."
å¦   He loved hunting, paintball and country music.
å¦   "Joseph will be remembered for his bravery, patriotism, his friendship and his love of serving others," said his father, Joseph Fuerst II.

ServiceUnit: Company C  2D Battalion  7Th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: died when his patrol unit came in contact with enemy forces using small arms fire during a cordon and search mission
Bio:
Thomas D. Maholic was athletic and enjoyed bicycling and swimming, which was how he first met his future wife.
å¦   The two swam together in high school and the local YMCA. Thomas eventually asked Wendy out for a date in high school and they became sweethearts, later marrying in 1993.
å¦   Maholic, 38, of Bradford, Pa., died June 24 in Ghecko from enemy fire. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Maholic started his military career in the Pennsylvania Army National Guard, where he enlisted in 1986 and served as an infantryman for five years. In 1991, he was assigned to Fort Kobbe, Panama.
å¦   Maholic graduated from the Special Forces Qualification Course in 1995 and became a medical sergeant.
å¦   In 2003, he was assigned to the U.S. Army John F. Kennedy Special Warfare Center and School at Fort Bragg, where he served as an Advanced Noncommissioned Officer Course instructor.
å¦   Dorothy Maholic, the soldier's mother, she said the entire ordeal has been difficult for the family. "I told John, my oldest son, that I had lost my baby, and he said Mom, we all did," she said.
å¦   He also is survived by his son, Andrew.

ServiceUnit: Company A  1St Battalion  32D Infantry
IncidentDetails: died when he came in contact with indirect fire while on patrol during combat operations
Bio:
Before he went to basic training after graduating high school in 2005, Justin R. Davis could be seen running around the neighborhood wrapped in plastic to sweat off the last few pounds he needed to qualify.
å¦   His mother, Paula Davis, said he told him: "I don't mind you going in, but I wish it wasn't wartime." He replied: "Mom, you should've had more kids."
å¦   Davis, 19, of Gaithersburg, Md., died on June 25 in eastern Kunar province. The military was investigating the death as a possible friendly fire incident.
å¦   His mother said she will miss the noise he brought to her quiet house: the television, the music, the stomping up and down the stairway.
å¦   "I could have cried and begged him not to go, and he probably wouldn't have, because he loved his mom," she said. "But then he would have been miserable, and I would have been miserable because I would have known I was making him miserable."
å¦   After serving his time in the military, he wanted to go to UCLA and become an actor. On Mother's Day, he remembered not only to call his mother but also his aunt.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Dennis Johnon, and his stepmother, Karen Johnson.

ServiceUnit: Troop R  4Th Sqdn  278Th Armored Cavalry Reg (TF Knighthawk)
IncidentDetails: died when his helicopter crashed during combat operations
Bio:
Pastor Hiram Harrison remembered that William T. Flanigan once said he wanted only to be a fighter pilot.
å¦   "I told him if he had, the Army would have missed having the best Apache helicopter pilot there ever was," Harrison said. "Tim gave me that knowing grin like the cat that swallowed the canary and said, 'Yeah, well I can boogie in an Apache, too!'"
å¦   Flanigan, 37, of Milan, Tenn., was killed July 2 when his helicopter crashed in Kandahar. He was assigned to Jackson.
å¦   "He had super integrity," William Flanigan said of his son. "You could always go to the bank with what he told you. He was a very straightforward guy, even if it indicted him."
å¦   Flanigan had spent time overseas in Germany and Bosnia-Herzegovina while in the Army. He enlisted in 1993, soon after he graduated from Indiana State University with a degree in aerospace technology and a professional piloting license.
å¦   "I remember that bellowing laugh that would fill the building," said one buddy, Sgt. William Newman. "He'd laugh, and we'd all feel better."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Cassie; daughter, Meghan, 11; and son, Brodie, 9.

ServiceUnit: Hhc  2D Battalion  87Th Infantry  3 Bct  (TF Catamount)
IncidentDetails: died of injuries sustained when his vehicle struck a mine during combat operations
Bio:
Jack Blanton, Aaron M. Griner's former soccer coach, said that although his coaching techniques are sometimes brash, Griner never snapped back. Instead, he just smiled.
å¦   The habit earned him the nickname "Grinner."
å¦   Blanton recalled Griner coming to his house last year to say goodbye before deploying to Afghanistan. "I got to hug him," Blanton said. "I told him I love him. Thank God I got to give him that hug."
å¦   Griner, 24, of Tampa, Fla., was killed June 28 when his vehicle struck a mine in Helmand province. He was based at Fort Drum.
å¦   As a youngster, Griner battled a slight learning disability. He passed the GED test and began searching for a career path. After working various odd jobs and traveling to Costa Rica, he decided to join the military.
å¦   He loved novelist Kurt Vonnegut, comedians Chris Farley and Adam Sandler, and Corona beer. Griner was a medic, which suited his easy going, peace-loving personality.
å¦   "He was not a fighter," said Griner's aunt, Beverly Bridges Fernandez. "He felt the calling to help the innocent people affected by war."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Amanda and son, Austin, an infant.

ServiceUnit: Hhc  2D Battalion  152D Infantry  (TF Phoenix)
IncidentDetails: died when his unit encountered enemy forces using small arms fire
Bio:
Nicholle McLochlin said her husband, Jeffrey A. McLochlin, was going to retire soon from the Indiana National Guard. "Leaving his kids was just getting too hard," she said. "He was turning into a softie."
å¦   She holds tight to a memory of her 230-pound, 6-foot-2 husband once sitting down to a tea party with his 5-year-old daughter, Kennedy.
å¦   McLochlin, 45, of Rochester, Ind., was killed July 5 by small-arms fire in the Gayan District of Paktika province. He was assigned to Marion.
å¦   McLochlin graduated from high school in 1979 and was an All-American middle linebacker at Wabash College in the early 1980s. After college, he served as an Army Ranger for four years before joining the National Guard. He then worked for the Rochester Police Department before moving to the Plymouth force.
å¦   He also is survived by two other children, Darby, 16, and Connor, 8.
å¦   "This man was amazing. There will never be another, that's for sure," his wife said. "18,000 miles away and he called me daily when he could. He did everything he could to be a good father and a good husband."

ServiceUnit: Company C  2D Battalion  4Th Infantry (TF Warrior)
IncidentDetails: died when his platoon encountered enemy forces small arms fire during combat operations
Bio:
Robert P. Kassin lived his life "full throttle," said Dean Turvaville, minister of Highland Baptist Church.
å¦   "He was a redneck so he would have loved that he died with his boots on _ he was a soldier so he would have loved that he died with his rifle in his hands," Turvaville said.
å¦   Kassin, 29, of Las Vegas, was killed July 16 while on patrol by small-arms fire near Larzab. He was assigned to Fort Polk and was on his second tour.
å¦   "Robert was strong and tough," Lucia Kassin said of her son. "He was definitely not a mamma's boy. But he was mamma's boy."
å¦   She described a young man who brought home stray kids, always wanting to help others who needed a place to stay.
å¦   "When he went into the Army, he was spreading that out," she said. "I know when he went out to check the perimeter it was to protect his buddies there."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Judy; a son, Joseph, with a previous wife; and two stepdaughters, 6 and 12.
å¦   His unit had built three schools for Afghanistan children, one in a community that had never had a school before, Kassin told his parents.
å¦   "He was proud to be a part of that," said his father, Robert Joseph Kassin.

ServiceUnit: Hhc  2D Bn  87Th Inf  3 Bct  10Th Mtn Div (TF Catamount)
IncidentDetails: died when his convoy encountered enemy small arms fire
Bio:
After high school, Kevin F. Edgin took construction jobs, most recently putting up drywall. In 2004, he decided to join the Army, against his father's wishes.
å¦   "I was dead against it," said Gordon Edgin, who'd also served in the Army. "I didn't want him to go. He just said, 'I'm going. period.' Can't argue with a grown man."
å¦   Edgin, 31, of Dyersburg, Tenn., was killed July 6 by small-arms fire in the Baghran Valley. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Edgin graduated from high school in 1993. He didn't like studying, but he loved hunting and playing football and was named team MVP his senior year.
å¦   He was the youngest of three sons and lived at home with his parents. He'd never married. He had the same friends since kindergarten.
å¦   His father said his son knew he'd likely be sent to Iraq or Afghanistan. "I think he was proud. He enjoyed service," Gordon Edgin said.
å¦   He and his wife, Margaret, have received countless calls and visits from townspeople and officials. "Everybody loved him," his father said. "He was just a good guy that we don't have anymore."

ServiceUnit: Company B  2D Battalion  4Th Infantry
IncidentDetails: died when his patrol encountered enemy forces using rocket-propelled grenades and mortars
Bio:
Robert J. Chiomento tried to lead his daughters by example. To show them the value of education, he decided to pursue the completion of his bachelor's degree.
å¦   Chiomento, who earned an associate's degree in 2004, began to take business classes in the year before his deployment, said his wife, Staci.
å¦   "I would trade a million anythings for him to be back here, but I'm proud of what he did, and his children will grow up knowing what he did, and they'll be proud of him, too," she said.
å¦   Chiomento, 34, of Fort Dix, N.J., died July 17 when his vehicle was struck with rocket-propelled grenades and mortars in Khwaya Ahmad. He was assigned to Fort Polk.
å¦   He graduated from high school in 1990 and joined the Army in October 1991, the same year his father retired from the Army, said a cousin, Tom Chiomento.
å¦   "He was a kid who knew what he wanted, and he went after it," Tom Chiomento said.
å¦   At his first posting, at Fort Wainwright in Alaska, Chiomento met his future wife, then also in the Army. Together, the couple had two daughters, Ambre, 13, and Syleste, 5. He saw his first combat experience in Panama.

ServiceUnit: Company B  3D Battalion  7Th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: died when his combat reconnaissance patrol came in contact with enemy forces using small arms fire during combat operations
Bio:
Eric Caban's MySpace page, decorated with the insignia of the Texas Rangers, Dallas Mavericks and New York Giants, is now filled with farewell comments for a popular guy whose online name was "BamBam."
å¦   Caban, 28, of Fort Worth, Texas, died July 19 in southern Afghanistan from small-arms fire. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   In 2001, Caban jumped into Afghanistan to seize Kandahar Airfield. He left active duty in 2002 to attend college. He completed one year at the University of Texas at Arlington, but his heart wasn't in school.
å¦   Caban, who was born in New York City, returned to the Army in 2003 and served as a sniper instructor before being selected to join Special Forces.
å¦   "That is where his passion was. That is where he thrived. He believed in the cause," said Efren Caban, his brother.
å¦   His online name came from the lovable Flintstones cartoon character: short, improbably strong and always popular. Some of Caban's friends have temporarily changed their MySpace names to something honoring him. Others have created photo slideshows in his honor or blog their memories.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Efren and Elvira Caban.

ServiceUnit: Company C  1St Battalion  32D Infantry
IncidentDetails: died of injuries sustained when his platoon encountered enemy forces small arms fire
Bio:
In a final e-mail to a female friend, David M. Hierholzer offered his life's philosophy.
å¦   "Life is a fatal adventure; it can only have one ending. So why not make it as far-ranging and as free as possible?"
å¦   Hierholzer, 27, of Lewisburg, Tenn., was killed July 24 by small-arms fire in Pesch, Afghanistan. He was a 1998 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Hierholzer played football in high school and was something of a daredevil. His father recalls his fearless son doing backflips off jet-skis and four-wheeling on dangerous terrain.
å¦   After high school, David Hierholzer attended at least two area universities, including Columbia State and Middle Tennessee State University, where he studied criminal justice.
å¦   It was after "goofing off at MTSU when he knew he had to do something," said his father, David. "That's when he said he was going to enlist."
å¦   After this second tour, David Hierholzer planned to go back to school to finish his education. He told his father he wanted to pursue a career with the FBI.
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Christine.

ServiceUnit: National Guard 153rd Cavalry Squadron
IncidentDetails: Staff Sgt. Daniel A. Suplee, 39, of Ocala, Fla., died on Aug 3 at James A. Haley Veterans Hospital, Tampa, Fla., of injuries sustained on Apr 1 in Kabul, Afghanistan, when his HMMWV was involved in a traffic accident.
Bio:
Daniel A. Suplee was riveted by the military, tirelessly studied the Revolutionary War and regularly participated in re-enactment groups.
å¦   "He was a walking encyclopedia of the Revolutionary War," said his brother, Andy Suplee. "He was always interested in the military."
å¦   Suplee, 39, of Lakeland, Fla., died Aug. 3 in a Tampa hospital from injuries suffered in a traffic accident on April 1 in Kabul. He was assigned to Ocala and was 1984 high school graduate.
å¦   "He was always trying to better himself as a soldier and leader," said Sgt. 1st Class Jimmy Nugent. "He really motivated groups to get things done and led by example and through demonstration. He could accomplish any task."
å¦   The sergeant spent much of his free time fishing, camping, sailing, playing guitar, dancing, horseback and bicycle riding, carpentry, model building, billiards, card games and gem faceting, his family said.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Bernadine; a son, Benjamin, 14; and a daughter, Jennifer, 13.
å¦   "He was just a very kind, loving, generous person," said his wife. "He's my hero, my best friend, my guardian angel. I just loved him so much."

ServiceUnit: Corps Support Battalion, Theater Support Command
IncidentDetails: Spc. Andrew Velez, 22, of Lubbock, Texas, died on July 25 in Sharona, Afghanistan, from a non-combat related injury.
Bio:
While growing up, Andrew Velez was the cocky one, ready to face any challenge. His brother Fred was the more passive one, a team player with patience.
å¦   Both boys were very athletic, competing in high school football, track, wrestling and basketball, said their father, Roy Velez. In high school, Fred was in the medical magnet program, and Andrew in the criminal justice one.
å¦   Now both are gone. Andrew Velez, 22, of Lubbock, Texas, died July 25 from a self-inflicted gunshot wound in Sharona. His older brother died in Iraq in 2004.
å¦   Andrew had the option to stay home after his brother died _ being the only surviving son. His father had asked him not to return to combat. The Velez are the first family to lose two children in the war.
å¦   But Andrew insisted. He believed terrorism had the potential to spread like a disease in the U.S. "He said, 'I won't sign it, Daddy,'" of the paper that would have released him from his contract. "'I'm going to pick up where my brother left off.'"
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Veronica and their three children: Jasmine Jade, 5; Jordan Davis, 3; and Jacob Andrew, 2.

ServiceUnit: Army 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: died when their platoon came in contact with enemy forces using rocket-propelled grenades and small arms fire during combat operations
Bio:
Guile Gonzalez said he will miss his nephew's constant joking. "That kid seemed like he was on a sugar high all the time," Gonzalez said of Rogelio R. Garza Jr. "We thought he'd grow out of it, but he never did."
å¦   Garza, 26, Corpus Christi, Texas, was killed by small-arms fire Aug. 11 in Nangalam. He was a 1998 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Before enlisting, Garza was a sanitation worker who was known to bring things home that he picked up on his route, including a stereo with a blown-out speaker.
å¦   "He was like, 'I am going to fix it and we are going to use it. It will be like brand-new again.' He was so funny," said his wife, Renee. "He never did, but he would try to fix it."
å¦   The couple eloped in 2002. He got down on a knee, grabbed a ring already on one of her fingers and asked her to marry him. He enlisted in part to get health insurance for his children: daughter, Myracle, 3; and sons, Antonio, a newborn, and Rogelio R. Garza III, 1.
å¦   "Roger grew up without a father," said Gonzalez. "After his father died in a car wreck, he became the family rock, always protecting his four sisters, and a great dad always playing with his own kids."

ServiceUnit: Company B  1St Battalion  32D Infantry  (TF Spartan)
IncidentDetails: died when their platoon came in contact with enemy forces using rocket-propelled grenades and small arms fire during combat operations
Bio:
Shane Hill met Andrew R. Small in grade school and the friendship never faltered.
å¦   "We were all praying for him," said Hill. "I remember, when we were kids, looking over and seeing him do a cartwheel down a hill. We were always there for each other."
å¦   Small, 19, of Wiscasset, Maine, was killed Aug. 11 in Nangalam by small-arms fire. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   "He was an all-around good kid," said his former high school principal, Susan Poppish. "He was a good friend to a lot of kids. Teachers liked him. He always did the right thing."
å¦   Richard Ranta, owner of a Dairy Queen, said he remembered Small as a 14-year-old on his first job.
å¦   "You know, he was like most 14-year-olds, a kid," Ranta said. "He did come by here to visit after basic training, and he was no longer a kid. He was a man."
å¦   His mother, Cynthia, said her son had wanted to join the Army since he was a small boy, following in the footsteps of several other family members.
å¦   "Before he left, he said, 'If something should happen to me, I want people to be proud of me,'" she said. "And we are."
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Terrance.

ServiceUnit: Army 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: They died in Nangalam, Afghanistan on Aug. 11, when their platoon came in contact with enemy forces using rocket-propelled grenades and small arms fire during combat operations.
Bio:
James P. White Jr. had a serious, competitive side. But he also was remembered for knocking a racquetball off the wall with his head while playing a game he and friends called "head ball."
å¦   "He was a big goofball," said Casey Sullivan, a friend.
å¦   White, 19, of Huber Heights, Ohio, was killed Aug. 11 in Nangalam by small-arms fire. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   "He was fun-loving, very caring," said Amy Phipps, White's maternal grandmother.
å¦   Just before his 18th birthday, White told his father he was ready to enlist in the military. "We talked it over. I asked him if he was sure that is was what he wanted," James White said. "He was sure."
å¦   At his funeral, Marine Reserve Lance Cpl. Ryan Pennington remembered his friend, who had gone through four years of ROTC with him. They enlisted in the military their senior year and teased each other about having joined the better branch.
å¦   "I know J.P. knew the risks. We all do and we accept them," said Pennington.
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Robin.
å¦   "He was a wonderful kid. Very well behaved and well respected with people. Quiet," said his father.

ServiceUnit: Company B  2D Battalion  87Th Infantry  (TF Spartan)
IncidentDetails: Cpl. Jeremiah S. Cole, 26, of Hiawatha, Kan., died in Bermel, Afghanistan, on Aug. 16 of injuries sustained when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle during combat operations.
Bio:
In kindergarten, Jeremiah S. Cole donated his beloved new Spider-Man mittens to the poor because he told his mother his old mittens still worked well enough.
å¦   In high school, he spent hours helping a friend's brother who had been in a car accident finish physical therapy.
å¦   While at community college, he took under his wing a boy with Down syndrome, helping him in physical education classes and with showering and dressing afterward.
å¦   "He saw people as whole people always," said his mother, Candice Cole. "He just cared about them."
å¦   Cole, 26, of Hiawatha, Kan., died Aug. 16 in Bermel when an explosive detonated near his vehicle. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   "He was doing what he wanted, he loved his wife, he loved his boy he loved his country and he loved his town," said his mother.
å¦   Cole enlisted in 2004. While stationed at Fort Drum, he met Andrea Clevenger. The two fell madly in love and married Oct. 8, Candice Cole said.
å¦   "In the two years they had together, they lived more life and loved more than most people do in a lifetime," she said.
å¦   He also is survived by a son, Nicholas, a toddler.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division
IncidentDetails: Pvt. Joseph R. Blake, 34, of Portland, Ore., died on Aug 17 in Turkalay, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered when his platoon encountered enemy forces small arms fire.
Bio:
Looking over some of Joseph R. Blake's grade school papers, his parents discovered that the military was on the top of his list of potential careers for several years.
å¦   "He said he had thought about it for many years, and if he didn't do it now, he wouldn't be able to because of his age," said his father, Douglas.
å¦   Blake, 34, of Portland, Ore., died Aug. 17 from small-arms fire in Turkalay. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Blake played on soccer, basketball and track teams and participated in long-distance bike trips with a youth group at his church.
å¦   He held several jobs in construction and seemed to thrive on outdoor jobs involving heavy lifting. He moved from Michigan to Florida and later to Portland in search of work.
å¦   Blake, in his 30s, was the oldest guy in his basic training class. Many of his classmates, still teenagers, used to kid around and call him the "old man."
å¦   "He was so proud of his accomplishments and what he had achieved," said his father. "He felt good about what he was doing and was committed to the soldiers in his unit and the job they were doing."
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Joann.

ServiceUnit: Company A  1St Battalion  32D Infantry  (TF Spartan)
IncidentDetails: died when an improvised explosive device detonated near their convoy vehicle
Bio:
In his yearbook, Robert E. Drawl Jr. gave himself the nickname "BluBoi" for his penchant for the military. The quiet, soft-spoken young man listed his "favorite things" as food, his wife and kids, video games and French Vanilla coffee.
å¦   Drawl, 21, of Alexandria, Va., was killed Aug. 19 in Kunar by a roadside bomb. He graduated high school in 2003 and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Family members said Drawl loved the carnival rides at Ocean City. He wore a rattail long after the hairstyle went out of fashion, and friends found his allegiance to the Pittsburgh Steelers baffling and constantly teased him about it.
å¦   He and childhood friend Steven Escobar spent hours playing spades and PlayStation. He recalled that "BluBoi" loved the military and also the color.
å¦   "Blue T-shirts, blue hats all the time," Escobar said. "He drove a black Honda Civic, but he wished it was blue."
å¦   Drawl's car also was an expression of his personality, family members said. His license plates read "Klwnluv" _ in honor of his favorite band, Insane Clown Posse.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Kathryn, and two daughters, Kaylee, 3, and Samantha, 1.

ServiceUnit: Company C  710Th Combat Support Battalion  (TF Spartan)
IncidentDetails: died when an improvised explosive device detonated near their convoy vehicle
Bio:
Wakkuna A. Jackson was the youngest of three children, but her father says she was the strongest.
å¦   "Everybody came to Wakkuna in this family if they had a problem. If the computer was going bad, 'Get Wakkuna,' if they couldn't spell a word, 'Get Wakkuna,'" said her father Sherman Jackson.
å¦   Jackson, 21, of Jacksonville, Fla., was killed Aug. 19 in Kunar when an explosive hit near her vehicle. She graduated in 2003 and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   "Wakkuna Jackson is the kind of kid that you know immediately when you walk into the classroom," said Meg Hawley, a former teacher. "She had a tremendous presence; she was clearly a leader."
å¦   Her family said her name means "princess" in Hawaiian and that's how they will remember her. "If Wakkuna was here today and if she had to do this again, she'd do it again, she'd do it again," her father said.
å¦   Shenka Jackson said her sister, who served as a medic, wanted to be a pediatric surgeon. "She was the kind of person you could talk to and she would give you advice. She was caring," she said.
å¦   She also is survived by her mother, Teresita Jackson.

ServiceUnit: 23D Special Tactics Squadron
IncidentDetails: died when his vehicle came under hostile fire in Uruzgan province
Bio:
Adam P. Servais started at outside linebacker as a senior on the football team, but "volunteered for every special teams job we had," said a former coach, Pete Liska. "It was always, 'Coach, what do you need?' That was Adam."
å¦   Once, late in a tight game, his team's kicker sent a low-flying kickoff to the opposing team's kick returner, who fumbled it. Instantly, No. 70 _ Servais _ was there to pounce on the ball near the goal line.
å¦   "He had sprinted the entire length of the field," Liska said. "He just blew right by everybody. It's one of the most amazing hustle plays I've ever seen."
å¦   Servais, 23, of Onalaska, Wis., was killed Aug. 19 when he came under hostile fire in Uruzgan province. He graduated high school in 2001 and was assigned to Hurlburt Field. He had also done a tour in Iraq.
å¦   He was remembered as a hockey player happy to play defense, who had no interest in scoring goals, and who never shied away from a challenge.
å¦   "It's this image of a big guy with red hair leveling someone in front of me," said Drew Larson, a friend. "I could trust him. We had that rapport."
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Susan and Pete.

ServiceUnit: Company C  710Th Combat Support Battalion (TF Spartan)
IncidentDetails: died when an improvised explosive device detonated near their convoy vehicle
Bio:
Christopher F. Sitton and his family moved from Texas to Colorado near the end of his sophomore year in 2001. What could have been a tough period for many teens was relatively smooth for Chris.
å¦   "He was this really awesome Texan that transferred into school," said Sarah Ackerman, a classmate, noting that he usually had a smile or a bear hug waiting for his friends. "His personality just drew in everybody around him."
å¦   Sitton, 21, of Montrose, Colo., was killed Aug. 19 when a roadside bomb detonated near his convoy. He graduated high school in 2003 and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   He was remembered as an Eagle Scout, a track standout, and an outgoing personality with a penchant for Oreo cookies and hiking in the mountains.
å¦   "He camped, hiked, skied, water-skied, you name it," said his father, Stephen. "Chris was a high-speed, low-drag guy. Life was about fun."
å¦   "And friends," his mother, Judy Sitton, added.
å¦   "He was so good with little kids," she said. "Everyone loved him _ he was one of those people that other people gravitated toward. He was almost always happy and every new day brought a new social experience."

ServiceUnit: 405th Civil Affairs Battalion
IncidentDetails: They died in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Sept. 8, when a vehicle-borne improvised explosive device detonated near their HMMWV.
Bio:
Merideth L. Howard worked to fit into a male-dominated job when she became the first female firefighter in the Texas city of Bryan more than 25 years ago.
å¦   Initially, some were apprehensive. But not after she helped set up an onsite air system allowing the department to fill its own respiration tanks, said Bryan Fire Department Chief Mike Donoho.
å¦   "By doing a good job and gaining respect, it gave everyone else a better chance. They had an easier road ahead of them because of what she established," Donoho said.
å¦   Howard, 52, of Alameda, Calif., was killed Sept. 8 by a roadside bomb in Kabul, becoming the oldest female U.S. soldier killed in action in Afghanistan and Iraq. She was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Howard, a Peace Corps veteran, graduated with a master's in marine resource management from Texas A&M in 1978. She became a fire risk-management specialist, eventually helping set up a consulting company in California.
å¦   She loved the ocean, traveling and was passionate about fire safety. "She gave the shirt off her back to help each and every friend she had," said Howard's husband, Hugh Hvolboll.

ServiceUnit: 405th Civil Affairs Battalion
IncidentDetails: They died in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Sept. 8, when a vehicle-borne improvised explosive device detonated near their HMMWV.
Bio:
Robert J. Paul loved the outdoors so much, he came to his wedding in a pair of sport sandals. "I guess he didn't realize it was formal," joked his former mother-in-law, Arlene Domue.
å¦   Paul, 43, of The Dalles, Ore., died Sept. 8 in Kabul when an explosive detonated near his vehicle. He was assigned to Fort Bragg and had done a tour in Iraq to help build infrastructure.
å¦   Originally from Hammond, Ind., Paul served as a Peace Corps volunteer in Kenya from 1987-1989. He joined the Army Reserve in April 1997, two years after earning a master's degree in urban planning and economic development at the University of Maryland.
å¦   In 1998, Paul joined the City of The Dalles Planning Department as an associate planner, and became a senior planner while working for the city. In 2001, he joined the Wasco County Planning Department.
å¦   "Bob loved this area so much," said Planning Director Todd Cornett. "He moved out here because he loved the west, he loved Oregon, and he loved the gorge. He was very much into hiking and trailrunning and whitewater kayaking, all the outdoor experience."
å¦   He is survived by his daughter, Ilena.

ServiceUnit: Army National Guard‰Ûªs 35th Special Troops Battalion
IncidentDetails: Sgt. 1st Class Michael T. Fuga, 47, of Nuuli, American Samoa, died on Sept. 9 in Kandahar, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered when he encountered enemy forces using small arms fire during combat operations.
Bio:
Justina Fuga didn't want her husband, Michael T. Fuga, to go to Afghanistan, but she remembered how disappointed he was about being stuck in Germany during the Persian Gulf War.
å¦   After Sept. 11, 2001, she knew she would not be able to stop him.
å¦   "He knew how I felt, but at the same time he was very excited about having the opportunity to do something instead of just watching what was going on," said Justina Fuga.
å¦   Fuga, 47, of Nuuli, American Samoa, died Sept. 9 in Kandahar from small-arms fire. He was assigned to Kansas City.
å¦   Fuga joined the military just three months after he finished high school, his wife said. He worked for many years as a stocker for Southwest Airlines and played on Fort Riley's cricket team.
å¦   "He went willingly _ no matter if it cost his life _ for the freedom of everybody," said Ula Sao, a relative and member of the Samoan Community Organization of Independence.
å¦   He also is survived by a 12-year-old daughter, Salome.
å¦   "He was the best dad any little girl could ever ask for," said Justina. "To me he was one of a kind. It's as if when Mike talked, everybody listened."

ServiceUnit: Army National Guard's 41st Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Staff Sgt. Nathaniel B. Lindsey, 38, of Troutdale, Ore., died on Sept. 9 in Shajoy, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained when his HMMWV encountered undetermined ordnance from enemy forces during patrol operations.
Bio:
Nathaniel B. Lindsey had a nightly ritual of changing into pajamas _ even in the battlefield. After endless ribbing from Col. David Stuckey, Lindsey found a pair of camouflage pajamas and gave Stuckey a pair.
å¦   "Here sir, these are for you," Lindsey said, with a gleam in his eye. "Soldiering is what he loved to do," Stuckey recalled.
å¦   Lindsey, 38, of Troutdale, Ore., died Sept. 9 in Shajoy when his vehicle was struck by bomb. He was assigned to Portland.
å¦   He began his military career as a cook in the Navy and joined the National Guard in 1996. Lindsey served in Saudi Arabia in 1999 and 2000, 15 months in Iraq in 2003 and 2004, and last year helped Louisiana residents in Hurricane Katrina's wake.
å¦   Back in Afghanistan, he worked a safe desk job as a radio transmission officer but volunteered to patrol with the Afghan National Army.
å¦   "He wanted to be with the boys," Chaplain Daniel Thompson said. "He wasn't an office guy."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Joyce; daughter, Michelle, 8; and stepchildren, Brandon and Marcus Laureta, and Kailina Don.
å¦   He loved playing video games with Brandon and coaching Michelle's soccer team.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division
IncidentDetails: Sgt. Jeremy E. DePottey, 26, of Ironwood, Mich., died on Sept. 11 in Asadabad, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered in a single vehicle accident.
Bio:
Staff Sgt. Ernest Williams _ who served in Jeremy E. DePottey's company _ considered himself a close friend and described him as a dedicated soldier.
å¦   "He loved his country and he loved his job serving as an infantryman in the U.S. Army," said Williams. "He will never be forgotten."
å¦   DePottey, 26, of Ironwood, Mich., died Sept. 11 in a motor vehicle accident while on patrol near Asadabad. He was assigned Fort Drum.
å¦   Williams said DePottey was a hard-working man who would do anything for anybody. "He will be missed by a lot of his close friends _ those who served with him and knew him well," said Williams.
å¦   He was a McMillan resident for eight years, formerly employed at Foster's Ace Hardware in Newberry. He briefly resided in Bessemer prior to enlisting in the Army on April 1, 2002.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Jacqueline; two children, Jeremy Edward II and Cierra Mae; and a stepson, Dylan Watkins.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Cpl. Fernando D. Robinson, 21, of Hawthorne, Calif., died on Oct. 2 in Korengal, Afghanistan, from injuries sustained when his patrol came under attack by enemy forces using small arms fire and rocket propelled grenades.
Bio:
Before leaving for Afghanistan, Fernando D. Robinson proposed to his girlfriend, Maria, on her family's front porch. He had planned to send money to her so she could buy her engagement ring.
å¦   Instead, his mother is having a white-gold band with four small diamonds sized for Maria's finger _ the same ring her son once borrowed from her bedroom drawer.
å¦   Robinson, 21, of Hawthorne, Calif., died Oct. 2 in Korengal after being shot twice. He graduated high school in 2003 and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   He was a daredevil of a kid who always impressed his friends with his expert aim with a slingshot. He once chipped one of his front teeth by crashing his bike off a jump; years later, his friends in the Army called him "Chomper."
å¦   Friends in the neighborhood knew him as "Commando Fernando" because he always wore fatigues and watched war movies. He signed up for Junior ROTC and never missed a chance to talk to visiting recruiters.
å¦   "He was a very kind person, cared for a lot of people," said his mother, Elizabeth Estrada. "A true friend to everybody. He had a good heart."
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Ricardo Acosta.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division
IncidentDetails: Cpl. Angelo J. Vaccaro, 23, of Deltona, Fla., died on Oct. 2 in Korengal, Afghanistan, from injuries suffered during combat operations.
Bio:
Angelo J. Vaccaro's parents said he hated leaving his unit, even when he went on vacation.
å¦   "When he was on leave and he found out one of his men died, he cried," said his father, Ray. "He said he should've been there."
å¦   Vaccaro, 23, of Deltona, Fla., died Oct. 2 in Korengal after trying to recover wounded soldiers in combat. He was a 2001 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Linda Vaccaro, Angelo's mother, said her son was the head medic for his unit. He enlisted to "turn his life around and make something of himself," she said.
å¦   "He was going to further his nursing career and become a physician's assistant," Linda Vaccaro said. "That was his dream in life."
å¦   In the mountains of Afghanistan he had found the direction he needed after a troubled youth. Every time he came home, his parents could see the difference.
å¦   "The last time he came home from Afghanistan, he was a man," said his father.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Dana.
å¦   "He was a loving person, and had a big heart," said his mother. "There was nothing he would not do for someone. He embraced his family and loved his country. He took pride in what he was doing."

ServiceUnit: Company C  37Th Engineer Battalion
IncidentDetails: died as a result of shrapnel wounds suffered, while he was coordinating a response to a mortar and possible rocket-propelled grenade attack
Bio:
Christopher C. Rafferty met both of his loves while he was still in high school _ his wife, and the military. He would marry his high school sweetheart and join the National Guard at age 16.
å¦   "He loved everything about the military," said his mother, Sandra Hustava. "He loved his soldiers. He said, 'Mom, I train them hard. I give them more than they need so if they are ever in war, I won't have to worry about them.'"
å¦   Rafferty, 37, of Brownsville, Pa., died July 21 in Sharana of injuries he sustained on July 20 when his unit was hit by a mortar. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   "He was always there when you needed a friend," said 1st Sgt. Martin Humphreys.
å¦   Hustava said that while her son was small in stature, only 5-feet-6, he had a lot of charisma. "He would just tease and tease and tease. When he put on his serious face he looked like a stranger," Hustava said.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Wendy, and two daughters, Samantha, 13 and Kayla, 11. Rafferty's daughters wrote messages on a T-shirt for their dad to take with him on his deployment.
å¦   "We love you, Dad," the girls wrote. "Come home soon."
å¦   He wore it all the way to Afghanistan.

ServiceUnit: Army National Guard 35th Division Artillery
IncidentDetails: Deghand, 42, of Mayetta, Kan., died on Sept. 15 in Spira, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered when his unit encountered enemy forces using small arms and rocket-propelled grenade fire during combat operations.
Bio:
When Bernard L. Deghand was deployed to Bosnia in 2003, his wife, Lisa, bought a Webcam so she could see and talk to her husband across the globe.
å¦   When he was deployed to Afghanistan in January, she fired up the Webcam again. They would have a cyber-date every Monday.
å¦   They talked about "small things." About "big things." About how they missed each other. Through the Web, he saw the first steps of his daughter, Emma. Sometimes, they would stay up into the middle of the night talking.
å¦   "Thoughtful," is what Lisa called him.
å¦   Deghand, 42, of Mayetta, Kan., died Sept. 15 in Spira, from small-arms fire. He was a 1982 high school graduate and was assigned to Hutchinson.
å¦   "He was outgoing," said Capt. James Sullivan. "He would volunteer for everything. Always ready to go, to be in the middle of everything."
å¦   He enjoyed hunting, fishing, training and breaking horses, playing softball, volleyball, archery, coaching baseball and football, fishing, golfing, and playing cards and family board games.
å¦   In addition to Emma, he also is survived by a daughter, Jamie, 19, and a stepson, Craig, 11.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 3rd Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Chief Warrant Officer Scott W. Dyer, 38, of Cocoa Beach, Fla., died Oct. 11 in Banditemur, Afghanistan, from injuries suffered during combat operations.
Bio:
Scott W. Dyer's mother was told that at a somber ceremony in Afghanistan when the military loaded her son's coffin onto the plane to bring him home, some 500 people showed up to honor him.
å¦   "Scott was in the service for 19 years, and he made the most incredible friends," said Sandy Miller. "We've had calls from Iraq, Afghanistan, Japan, Nigeria, everywhere he's been. They are coming in by the hour and by the day."
å¦   Dyer, 38, of Cocoa Beach, Fla., died Oct. 11 in Banditemur when his Black Hawk came under small-arms fire. He was on his third tour and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Dyer was 5 when he announced he wanted to join the military.
å¦   "He was going to be a soldier, he was going to ride a motorcycle and he was going to jump out of airplanes," his mother said. "That was his life's desire."
å¦   Dyer, who graduated high school in 1987, was on the track, football and wrestling teams. When he was home on leave, Dyer spent time helping to rebuild basketball courts and other children's recreational amenities in the neighborhood.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Jodi, and children, Casey, 10, and Sidney, 6.

ServiceUnit: Company A  2D Battalion  30Th Infantry
IncidentDetails: Lucas, 24, of Columbus, Ohio, died on Oct. 13 in Kandahar, Afghanistan, from injuries sustained when his vehicle was struck by a suicide bomber using a vehicle-born improvised explosive device.
Bio:
1st Lt. Daron Moreno chuckled as he recalled when Jason A. Lucas would perform his favorite impersonation, acting like a high school football coach, sticking out his gut and screaming, "What the heck is going on here, I can't believe what you are doing!!"
å¦   Moreno said that Lucas would continue "ranting and raving" as the coach and by the end of his performance the rest of the soldiers would be laughing.
å¦   "Lucas was an excellent soldier, but his personality was his greatest asset. He knew how to live and how to make others laugh," said Moreno.
å¦   Lucas, 24, of Columbus, Ohio, died Oct. 13 in Kandahar after his vehicle was struck by a suicide bomber. He was assigned to Fort Polk.
å¦   "His personality made training easier. He also wasn't afraid to stand up and take charge. When you were with him you wanted to work for him, he didn't have to tell you to work," said Cpl. Christopher Jackson.
å¦   He excelled at baseball, bowling, golf and hunting. He was affectionately known as Smiley by many of his friends and also picked up the nickname Cutie because of his ability to attract girlfriends.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Monica, and sons, Zausten, 5, and Ethan, 3.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 3rd Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: died from injuries suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his combat patrol.
Bio:
Kyu H. Chay had just written a letter to his 5-year-old son, Jason, who has begun to read. He told the boy how much he loved him.
å¦   "He was just a wonderful father and husband to me," said his wife, Cathy. "He could not have been or said anything more," she added, about the affection he showed for Jason and his daughter, Kelly, a newborn.
å¦   Chay, 34, of Fayetteville, N.C., died Oct. 28 in Oruzgan Province when an explosive detonated near his patrol. He was assigned to Fort Bragg and died the day before his sixth wedding anniversary.
å¦   Chay was born in South Korea and lived there until he was 7, moving to Cincinnati and then to New York City. His hometown allegiances stuck with him as he cheered for the New York Mets and Cincinnati Bengals, Cathy Chay said.
å¦   He attended Brooklyn Law School and was finishing up his last three credits so he could become a Judge Advocate General in the service. He was a cryptologic linguist who served as a special operations support soldier.
å¦   "He passed up law for serving in the Army," said Dan Long, a friend of the couple. "He enjoyed his job, the work that he did."

ServiceUnit: A-Co 3Rd Bstb
IncidentDetails: They died of injuries suffered when an IED detonated near their vehicle Oct. 31 in Wygal Valley, Afghanistan. McClain later died in Asadabad, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Charles J. McClain's grandmother said he believed he had found his calling in the military. He often asked about her father, who was killed in the Battle of the Bulge in World War II.
å¦   Visiting home on leave last month, McClain, a combat engineer, worried about the men in his unit, said his grandmother, Beatrice Meyers. Though he feared being killed, he told her he felt he needed to return.
å¦   "He said there weren't enough soldiers in Afghanistan, and they had to look after each other," Meyers said.
å¦   McClain, 26, of Fort Riley, Kan., died Oct. 31 in Asadabad of injuries suffered when his vehicle struck an explosive in Wygal Valley. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   McClain served twice in Iraq before serving in Afghanistan. Lt. Col. Richard Kaiser said McClain "truly loved life and his fellow soldiers and fellow sappers."
å¦   "If you didn't recognize it in his Cheshire cat grin that always graced his face, you should have," said Kaiser. "He truly loved life and loved serving his country. I think that is a lesson and a great reminder for all of us."
å¦   McClain is survived by two sons, Logan Jack Fair, and Kole J. Swihart.

ServiceUnit: Hhb  1St Battalion  188Th Air Defense  (TF Spartan)
IncidentDetails: died of injuries suffered when his unit came in contact with enemy forces using small arms fire and rocket propelled grenades
Bio:
Nathan J. Goodiron volunteered to dress up as Santa Claus and the Easter Bunny to entertain children. If you had computer problems, he was the person to go to.
å¦   "He was a funny, enjoyable person to be around," said Nathan Hale, a Tribal Council member.
å¦   Goodiron, 25, of Mandaree, N.D., was killed Nov. 23 when a grenade struck his vehicle in Qarabagh. He was assigned to Grand Forks.
å¦   Goodiron, a student at Minot State University, was a 1999 high school graduate and worked for a time as a technical assistant for the Three Affiliated Tribes.
å¦   Elton Spotted Horse said Nathan was a big tease in school, but was serious when he needed to be. "If people had problems, they could talk to him," he said. "He'd make them feel better."
å¦   Tribal officials said Goodiron enjoyed working with computers, and developed a power-point program about the tribal constitution.
å¦   "He was proud to be an American soldier, an American Indian soldier. He knew the meaning of the word sacrifice," said Marcus Wells Jr., the chairman of the Three Affiliated Tribes.
å¦   Goodiron is survived by his wife, Eileen; son, Cooper; and stepchildren, Alexander and Joely.

ServiceUnit: Hhb  1St Field Artillery  (ISAF)
IncidentDetails: of injuries sustained when his unit came in contact with enemy forces using small arms fire and rocket propelled grenades while on patrol during combat operations
Bio:
As a child, Scott B. Lundell was meticulous about the snow forts he built. He would pour water over them to form ice that would keep enemy snowballs from penetrating a fort's exterior.
å¦   He would try to engage his sister in snowball fights, but when he realized one particular battle was unfair in his favor, he invited her into his fort. He told her, "'You stay here and be my snowball maker,'" said his sister, Andrea Miner.
å¦   Lundell, 35, of West Valley City, Utah, was killed Nov. 25 in Oruzgan province from small-arms fire. He was assigned to Camp Williams.
å¦   Lundell was a 1990 high school graduate, student-body president and lettered in football. He served a mission in the Philippines for The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. He went on to earn a bachelor's degree in economics from the University of Utah.
å¦   "Even though he was very popular and a great athlete, he was friendly to everyone," said Terry Bawden, his seminary teacher. "He was always kind to everyone he knew."
å¦   His wife, Jeanine, said the 2001 terrorist attacks inspired his service. He also is survived by four children, Adam, 10, Allison, 8, Logan, 5, and Liberty, 3.

ServiceUnit: Military Police Company, 95th Military Police Battalion, 18th Military Police Brigade
IncidentDetails: They died Nov. 28 in Logar, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle during combat operations.
Bio:
Jeffrey G. Roberson would try anything to stop his mother's tears.
å¦   "He was such a jokester. He found a joke in everything," Virginia Jones said, adding "if he could, I know he'd want to find a way now to say, 'It's OK, stop crying.'"
å¦   Roberson, 22, of Phelan, Calif., was killed Nov. 28 by a roadside bomb in Logar. He was assigned to Kaiserslautern, Germany.
å¦   His family says his dream was to join law enforcement, specifically the California Highway Patrol. The Army was supposed to be his first step on that career path.
å¦   Being the prankster he was, Jeffrey would sometimes disguise his voice from whomever answered the phone back home. His younger stepbrother, Dalton, 12, recalls hanging up on him twice before realizing who the strange, faraway voice was.
å¦   Longtime friend Brynt Butolph described Roberson as a person who took life as it came and appreciated each experience as fully as possible.
å¦   "He was a person I didn't know existed, a kind of friend I never had before," Butolph said. "Jeffrey made me realize there's more to me and more to life, more meaning in the little things in life than I thought."

ServiceUnit: 230th Military Police Company, 95th Military Police Battalion, 18th Military Police Brigade
