IncidentDetails: They died Nov. 28 in Logar, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle during combat operations.
Bio:
Though Michael A. Shank graduated from Dodd City High School 10 years ago, teachers still recall the way he always cared about the other students.
å¦   "He always seemed to realize life wasn't just about him," said Shank's former English teacher, Louise Knight. "He was a really neat kid to know."
å¦   Shank, 31, of Bonham, was killed by a roadside bomb Nov. 28 in Logar. He was assigned to Kaiserslautern, Germany.
å¦   "He was a typical teenager but he was a good one," Lt. James Manis said. "He served his country well."
å¦   He had been in Iraq for a year and then was stationed in Germany for three years prior to being sent to Afghanistan in 2006. He had also done a tour of Bosnia.
å¦   His funeral service was brought to a close with a song by Vince Gil, titled "Go Rest High On That Mountain." Soft sobs could be heard across the auditorium as the lyrics played: "You weren't afraid to face the devil, you were no stranger to the rain. Go rest high on that mountain, son, your work on Earth is done. Go to Heaven a shoutin' love for the Father and the Son."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Brandy, and their two daughters, KateLynn, 7, and Michaela, 4.

ServiceUnit: 141St Brigade Support Battalion
IncidentDetails: died of a non-combat related wound
Bio:
The Rev. Richard Sirianni, an Air National Guard chaplain, celebrated Long N. Nguyen's devotion to his family and for inspiring a "culture of excellence" in those around him.
å¦   "He took people seriously," Sirianni said. "He listened with great care, and he was lavish in his generosity and kindness."
å¦   Nguyen, 27, of Portland, Ore., died Feb. 10 in Mazar-e Sharif of a non-combat related wound. He graduated high school in 1996 and was assigned to Portland. He was awarded the 2005 Non-Commissioned Officer of the Year.
å¦   To his fellow soldiers, Nguyen was hardworking and showed a true love for the Army, said Maj. Gen. Raymond Rees. Any job given to Nguyen was done to perfection, and he frequently volunteered for extra responsibilities, he said.
å¦   Gov. Ted Kulongoski praised Nguyen, a Vietnamese refugee who had moved to Portland 25 years ago, for serving his country.
å¦   "Long before he became a naturalized citizen, Sgt. Long Nguyen had the heart of a citizen," said Kulongoski, who announced that Nguyen had been made an American citizen posthumously.
å¦   Survivors include his parents, Quan Thi and Su Van.

ServiceUnit: Combat Logistics Regiment 37, 3rd Marine Logistics Group, 3rd Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Lewis, 20, of Lawrenceburg, Ky., died Feb. 15 as a result of cardiac arrest in Jolo, the Philippines.
Bio:
Family members of Timothy D. Lewis weren't extremely worried about his service overseas. He had been in Japan, far enough away from the roadside bombings in Iraq and violence in Afghanistan.
å¦   "He wasn't in Iraq, so we thought he was safe. This caught us so off guard," said his great-aunt, Marie Hellard.
å¦   Lewis, 20, of Lawrenceburg, Ky., died Feb. 15 as a result of cardiac arrest in Jolo, the Philippines. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Okinawa, Japan. He played basketball and football and also enjoyed fishing.
å¦   He was in Jolo as part of joint exercises with Filipino troops aimed at isolating al-Qaida-linked militants in the southern Philippines.
å¦   "He wanted to make something of himself, and this was a dream of his," Hellard said. "If he went _ he told his mother _ then maybe somebody would be able to come home to their family."
å¦   He is survived by his mother, Julie Cox Coubert and her husband James; his father, Tim Lewis and his wife Hallie; his daughter, Alexi Jade Lewis. 1.

ServiceUnit: Company C  1St Battalion  4Th Infantry  (Task Force Grizzley)
IncidentDetails: died from injuries suffered when his unit came in contact with enemy forces using small arms fire during combat operations
Bio:
Isaiah Calloway and Alecia Denee were high school sweethearts who began dating during their junior year. Friends kept urging them to get together until finally he approached her about a date.
å¦   "He seemed shy at first but then he opened up," revealing a "goofy" side she found quite appealing, she said.
å¦   Calloway, 23, of Jacksonville, Fla., was killed Oct. 30 by small-arms fire in Marah. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Hohenfels, Germany.
å¦   Staff Sgt. Eric Boyce said the soldier was a keen student of the military. "At lunch when we were watching television he'd always be outside studying manuals," he said.
å¦   He had served in the Army for three years. "We knew he was something special from the beginning," said Boyce. "He was a soldier's soldier." His Army nickname was Crunk Juice.
å¦   Andre Persaud, a friend of Calloway's since third grade, said his friend loved to draw. For years, Persaud said, he kept a Calloway drawing of Sonic the Hedgehog, a video game character.
å¦   "He was a fun-loving guy," Persaud said.
å¦   He also is survived by his daughters, Alexius, 4; Aleiah, 3; and a son, Isaiah Jr., 2.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Squadron, 71st Cavalry Regiment (Reconnaissance, Surveillance, Target Acquisition), 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division
IncidentDetails: Keating, 27, of Shapleigh, Maine, died Nov. 26 in Kamdesh, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered when his vehicle turned over.
Bio:
Benjamin D. Keating's family described him as having a longtime fascination with literature and ancient history. "He absolutely loved reading," said his mother, Beth.
å¦   "He would always be reading two, three, or even four different books at a time _ he'd have one in every room of the house." Keating even brought Latin to read while he was stationed in the Middle East: a book about Alexander the Great's conquest of Afghanistan.
å¦   Keating, 27, of Shapleigh, Maine, was killed Nov. 26 in a vehicle accident in Kamdesh. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Keating graduated magna cum laude from the University of New Hampshire in 2004 with a bachelor's in history and classics.
å¦   "He really felt that everyone had a duty to learn about the past _ that was the only way we could make effective decisions about our future," said his sister, Jessica.
å¦   Military science professor Major Scott Silfies described Keating as engaging, intellectual and inquisitive. "As a teacher I've found I do more learning than teaching, and Ben was one of those students I learned a lot from."
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Kenneth.

ServiceUnit: Vmgr-352  Mag-11  3D Maw
IncidentDetails: aircraft crash

ServiceUnit: Vmgr-352  Mag-11  3D Maw
IncidentDetails: aircraft crash

ServiceUnit: Vmgr-352  Mag-11  3D Maw
IncidentDetails: aircraft crash

ServiceUnit: Hhc  2D Bn  27Th Infantry Regiment  25Th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Oct.27 at Landstuhl Regional Medical Center in Landstuhl, Germany, from injuries sustained when his vehicle struck an improvised explosive device on Oct. 20 in Naka, Afghanistan.

ServiceUnit: Vmgr-352  Mag-11  3D Maw
IncidentDetails: aircraft crash

ServiceUnit: Company A 1St Battalion 87Th Infantry
IncidentDetails: gunshot wound

ServiceUnit: Vmgr-352  Mag-11  3D Maw
IncidentDetails: aircraft crash

ServiceUnit: Company A  3D Battalion  5Th Sfg (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: killed by friendly fire

ServiceUnit: Company D  3D Battalion  5Th Sfg
IncidentDetails: killed by friendly fire

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 294th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: Died of injuries sustained during a vehicle roll-over.
Bio:
Debra Fejeran said her husband, Gregory D. Fejeran, planned to take his family on vacation after returning from the Horn of Africa in a few months.
å¦   Fejeran, 28, of Barrigada, Guam, was killed March 5 when his vehicle overturned in Dire Dawa, Ethiopia. He was on his third deployment and was assigned to Barrigada, Guam.
å¦   "As a soldier and being in the Guard with Sgt. Fejeran, I can tell you the Guard is a family, just like we are overall an island family, and any time we lose any member of our family, it is a big loss," said acting Gov. Mike Cruz, who is a colonel in the Guam Army National Guard.
å¦   Fejeran was a graduate of George Washington High School and Guam Community College. He worked for the Guam Waterworks Authority as a wastewater operator.
å¦   "He was a good man. He provided for his family and he was someone I came to know," said Sgt. 1st Class John Johnson. "A job like this, the business we are in, comes with some sort of risk, and as soldiers, we accept that risk."
å¦   He also is survived by his children, Shirae and Keleko.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 294th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: Died of injuries sustained during a vehicle roll-over.
Bio:
Joseph Fernandez remembered his son, Christopher, as enjoying sports, fishing, surfing and barbecuing at the beach with his friends.
å¦   "He was a friendly boy," he said. "He didn't cause any trouble for anybody."
å¦   Fernandez, 28, of Dededo, Guam, was killed March 5 his vehicle overturned in Dire Dawa, Ethiopia. He was assigned to Barrigada, Guam.
å¦   Fernandez worked as a driver before being deployed. Before that, he was a waiter and cook at the Outback Steakhouse. He graduated from high school in 2000.
å¦   He also is survived by a daughter, Kaenani, 5
å¦   "I am proud of my son," Joseph Fernandez said. "He joined the Guard so he could take care of his daughter. His is a hero and no one will say that he isn't one."
å¦   His mother, Marie Fernandez, said that the family had recently sent him a package with some of his favorite foods including M&Ms and Cocoa Pebbles.
å¦   "He always liked to joke around," she remembered.
å¦   "I ask that you remember him as an honorable person," National Guard Lt. Col. George Charfarous said, "a young man who wished to better his life, an honorable path as a soldier."

ServiceUnit: Brigade Support Battalion, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: died March 29 in North Kabul, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered during a non-combat related vehicle accident on March 28 in North Kabul.
Bio:
Edmund W. McDonald always made sure that no one felt left out. He asked his older sister, Chris Cronin, to organize letter-writing campaigns to soldiers. He shared presents he got from the community and relatives.
å¦   "Except for the brownies," Cronin said.
å¦   McDonald, 25, of Casco, Maine, was killed March 29 when his vehicle overturned in Kabul. He was assigned to Fort Bragg and was on his third tour.
å¦   His family said that during his time in the Army, McDonald did everything from conquering his fear of heights to becoming a mentor for other soldiers. He loved to play guitar and the Grateful Dead.
å¦   Cronin said that even after he cut his hair and learned to follow a regimented lifestyle, McDonald remained his tenderhearted self. He called her son's preschool from Iraq on the boy's third birthday, she said.
å¦   He showered his family with presents, including paintings he commissioned from artists when he was in the Middle East. One of them _ a portrait of his beloved Jessie, the deceased family dog _ hangs amid the antler displays at his mother's house.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Melissa.

ServiceUnit: 782nd Brigade Support Battalion, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: died March 29 in North Kabul, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered during a non-combat related vehicle accident on March 28 in North Kabul.
Bio:
Agustin Gutierrez often called and sent letters to his adoptive family. His last e-mail came several days ago from a security post where he was working a 72-hour shift.
å¦   "He joked with us and said, 'Don't all of you feel safer knowing that I'm over here looking after our country?'" said his sister Cecilia Mendoza, one of six siblings.
å¦   Gutierrez, 19, of San Jacinto, Calif., was killed March 29 when his vehicle overturned in Kabul. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   "He would always talk to us with joy of the training he was doing, and we were very proud of him," said Mendoza.
å¦   The Mendozas described Gutierrez as a quiet teen who earned As and Bs in high school and enjoyed wood shop and playing baseball and football at the neighborhood park.
å¦   "He was wise, never complained about anything and always did his best to help people," said Cecilia's husband, Leabin Mendoza. "He was just beginning to live his life."
å¦   He also is survived by his fiancee, Rebecca Collado.
å¦   "He was one of a kind," said Spc. Zeeshan Mithani, who served with Gutierrez at Fort Bragg.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division
IncidentDetails: died Mar. 29 in Korengal Outpost, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered from a rocket propelled grenade explosion.
Bio:
The Rev. Donald H. Bradley said Christopher M. Wilson joined the Army because of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
å¦   "To understand Christopher, we need to examine his love for this country," Bradley said. "He always knew he was going to be a soldier someday. He lived his dream."
å¦   Wilson, 24, of Bangor, Maine, was killed March 29 in Korengal Outpost in a grenade explosion. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   "Chris had a lot of love for people, especially family and friends, and cared a lot about his country," said Stephanie Audette, a friend. "Chris was indeed a true hero. He was my hero."
å¦   Wilson was born in North Dakota, and spent time in Massachusetts and Maine. Before enlisting, Wilson studied culinary arts in Bangor with the Penobscot Job Corps.
å¦   Family friend Monique LaRiviere said Wilson's enthusiasm for the Job Corps encouraged her son to follow him into the program.
å¦   "He was always trying to push my son into something better," LaRiviere said. "He would say, 'You should do what I did, because I'm really happy this way.' He really did a lot for my son."
å¦   He is survived by a 4-year-old daughter, Jayden.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 4th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: died April 7 in Eastern Afghanistan of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
Conor G. Masterson's family said his effusive wit made people feel happy to be with him.
å¦   "He was a comedian," said his mother, Sandra Masterson. "And it didn't matter what was happening, he made you laugh."
å¦   Masterson, 21, of Inver Grove Heights, Minn., was killed by a roadside bomb April 7 in eastern Afghanistan. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Hohenfels, Germany.
å¦   When his younger brother, Evan, was born, Masterson asked his parents if they could "bring all the babies home with us from the nursery," said Sandy Masterson. "A week later, he wanted to know if we could return him."
å¦   He loved his grandmother's apple pie, playing the alto sax and learning about other cultures. His mother said he "lived his life in fast-forward" and could be impulsive and passionate, especially when it came to learning Spanish quickly in order to woo a beautiful Taco Bell co-worker.
å¦   Masterson married his former Taco Bell co-worker, Lorena, while home on leave in June. Nicknamed "Dougie" after a character on the popular TV show "Scrubs," he planned to study medicine at college.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Hernandez, 23, of Hyattsville, Md., drowned April 11 when he fell into the Korengal River in Afghanistan during a combat patrol.
Bio:
Edelman L. Hernandez had fulfilled his four-year commitment to the U.S. Army last month _ pulling a one-year combat tour in Iraq and another in Afghanistan. But because his unit was still deployed in a combat zone, he was prevented from leaving the service.
å¦   Hernandez, 23, of Hyattsville, Md., drowned April 11 when he fell into the Korengal River in Afghanistan during a combat patrol. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Though members of his unit began an immediate search, the soldier's body was not recovered until the next morning, some distance downstream from where he had reportedly fallen.
å¦   His mother, Norma, said her eldest of four sons had wanted to be in the military since growing up in Hyattsville. She is left to mourn two of her sons. A younger son, Edwin, died three years ago to the day, in a car crash.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Jose Hernandez.
å¦   "He was the kindest person I knew and would give whatever he had to you," said his close friend Emily, who wanted to be identified only by first name.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 508th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Died April 12 in Miri, Afghanistan, when his vehicle was struck by an improvised explosive device during combat operations
Bio:
Casey D. Combs and Amber Wise met during the summer of 1999.
å¦   "I was working in a tanning salon, and he came in. He said he was there for a 9 p.m. appointment, but we were closed and I told him to leave," Amber said. "That started some playful banter back and forth every time he came back."
å¦   The couple started dating and married in 2002.
å¦   Combs, 28, of Auburn, Wash., was killed April 12 by a roadside bomb in Miri. He was a 1997 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Combs loved sports, lettering in baseball and tennis during high school. He worked as a construction-site foreman until Sept. 11, 2001.
å¦   "I remember that day. We were both upset," Amber Combs said. "Later that week he said he had to do something. That following week we had a recruiter at our house."
å¦   While Combs served three tours in Iraq, his wife attended college to become a schoolteacher and cared for daughter Hallie, 6, and son Trenton, 2.
å¦   "He wanted to be a high school teacher," said his mother, Colleen Combs. "While he was in the military he was getting credits for his teaching degree."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 508th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails:
Died April 12 in Miri, Afghanistan,
when a makeshift bomb struck their vehicle during combat operations.
Bio:
Megan Stephens said her husband, David A. Stephens, was a huge Bob Dylan fan and took an iPod filled with Dylan songs on the deployment.
å¦   Stephens, 28, of Tullahoma, Tenn., was killed April 12 when his vehicle was struck by an explosive in Miri. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   He graduated from the University of Tennessee in Chattanooga in 2002 and joined the Army in March 2005. Stephens, a combat medic, was an avid reader of classics and political and history books.
å¦   "Anyone that had the pleasure of meeting Alex, it would feel as if he had been your best friend forever. His humor and wit was incredible. He made everyone around him smile," said his aunt, April Sayers.
å¦   He had been selected for officer candidate school but turned it down to train as a medic because his mother had died of a heart attack and he wanted to help people, his wife said.
å¦   "Sgt. Stephens was an inspiration to all the paratroopers of his unit," said 1st Lt. Dennis Curry. "He always volunteered to help others."
å¦   He also is survived by a 3-month-old daughter.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 508th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: died Apr. 20 in Sangin, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when a land mine detonated near his unit during combat operations.
Bio:
June would have marked Alexander van Aalten's third year in the Army. Only a few weeks ago, he signed up to serve for another six years.
å¦   "He loved serving his country," said his mother, Susan van Aalten. "He just was a really good person. He loved being in the Army. He believed in what he was doing."
å¦   Van Aalten, 21, of Monterey, Tenn., was killed April 20 in Sangin by a land mine. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   So determined to be a soldier, he transferred into a school that offered ROTC and became a brigade commander. He had already served a tour of duty in Iraq.
å¦   He loved the outdoors and participated in everything from four-wheeling to rock climbing and kayaking. A black-belt in karate, he became an instructor.
å¦   "I remember him being very smart, very well liked. He could talk about a lot of subjects; he knew a lot about a lot of things. We were all so saddened to hear about this," said Mary Ann Kotus, his elementary school principal.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Shana.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Died Friday in Hirat Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his unit came in contact with enemy forces using from rocket propelled grenades and small arms fire.
Bio:
Michael D. Thomas would sneak into his home unannounced to surprise his little sisters _ "my girls," he called them. He doted on them, considered himself their protector.
å¦   On one trip home, he found that his older sister, Krista _ then in high school _ had a boyfriend sleeping in the spare room. Thomas woke the kid up with a punch to the ribs.
å¦   Then he invited him on a five-mile run.
å¦   Halfway through, the boyfriend, Jaye Bridwell, was on his knees, puking. But when they got back to the house, Thomas told the family that Bridwell had won the race.
å¦   "Jaye kicked my butt," he said.
å¦   Thomas, 34, of Seffner, Fla., died April 27 in Hirat Province of wounds from rocket propelled grenades and small-arms fire. He was a 1991 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Teresa, and his children, Diana and Craig. One of the oldest man in his Army Special Forces unit, he was nickname "Gramps"
å¦   Thomas was an accomplished guitarist, though his musical taste sometimes inspired grins, Bridwell said. "Michael was stuck in the '80s," he said. "He'd wear high-top Nikes with jeans and Pink Floyd T-shirts."

ServiceUnit: Division Special Troops Battalion, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Died Friday in Bagram, of injuries suffered from a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
Though still not old enough to legally drink a beer, Daniel F. Mehringer had been in the Army almost three years. He enlisted in September 2004, about three months after graduating from high school.
å¦   "Specialist Mehringer loved the adrenaline rush of jumping out of an aircraft, and he was proud to be an 82nd Airborne Division Paratrooper," said Sgt. 1st Class Rahn Bass, Mehringer's supervisor. "He was the consummate professional and was looking forward to serving his country for many years to come."
å¦   Mehringer, 20, of Morgantown, W.Va., died April 27 Friday in Bagram of injuries from a non-combat related incident. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   "Dan was an outdoorsman who enjoyed scuba diving and horseback riding," said Spc. Kali Wilson. "He was a family man who enjoyed watching movies with his wife, Maria, and taking walks with her and their dog, Thor."
å¦   Mehringer had been accepted for Army flight training but died before he could begin, said his stepmother, Sally Mehringer. He wanted the responsibility of flying a helicopter and overseeing a crew _ just as his father had done in Vietnam.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division
IncidentDetails: Army Cpl. Jeremy R. Greene, 24, Springfield, Ohio; died Saturday at Forward Operating Base Tillman, due to injuries suffered from a non-combat related incident
Bio:
It wasn't unusual to find Jeremy R. Greene sitting on the floor playing dolls with his niece Sierra.
å¦   "He just adored his nieces," said his mother, Cindy Greene. "He made time for you, no matter what."
å¦   Greene, 24, of Springfield, Ohio, died April 28 at Forward Operating Base Tillman of injuries from a non-combat related incident. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   The 2001 high school graduate was due to return home in February, but his tour was extended. Although disappointed, he didn't express that to his fellow soldiers, said his brother, Mickey Webster.
å¦   "He said he was trying to be strong for all the guys who had wives and families," Webster said. "He said he was just trying to keep his head together."
å¦   Webster said he wasn't too surprised when his brother enlisted.
å¦   "He was always doing crazy stuff when we were kids _ rock climbing, rappelling, jumping off stuff," he said. "He was one of the strongest people I've ever known."
å¦   When his brother was home, the two spent their best times just hanging out. "It didn't really matter what we did, even if it was just sitting in the car."
å¦   Greene also is survived by his father, Richard.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 508th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: died May 3 at Forward Operating Base Warrior, Afghanistan. His death is under investigation.
Bio:
Joseph G. Harris' ability to laugh was something his family remembered fondly.
å¦   "He kept us all in stitches when we got together at family gatherings," said his aunt, Sally Branson. "He was a great kid. A great sense of humor, a great wit."
å¦   Harris, 19, of Sugar Land, Texas, was killed May 3 at Forward Operating Base Warrior while on guard duty. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   He graduated from the Houston Learning Academy in 2005 and attended Wharton Junior College before deciding to join the Army in August 2006.
å¦   Branson said relatives had been able to communicate with Harris fairly easy and regularly via the Internet and text messaging. "Just a couple of days ago he was talking with his sister by instant message and she asked him if he was still happy about joining the military and he said, 'Absolutely.'"
å¦   Graham is survived by his father and stepmother, Gary and Gretchen Harris; and his mother, Jean Anne Harris
å¦   "He was a devoted son, adored brother and committed friend to many," his family wrote. "His handsome face, warm smile and irrepressible sense of humor will never be forgotten."

ServiceUnit: U.S. Military Police School
IncidentDetails: Two U.S. service members were killed and two others wounded Sunday when an apparent Afghan National Army soldier fired shots into their vehicles as they left the Pol-E-Charki Prison in Kabul.
Bio:
In his 17-year military career, Wilberto Sabalu Jr. had served in South Korea, Panama, Kansas, Missouri and Virginia. "He was a gung-ho soldier," said friend Ana Lozano. "He died doing what he loved."
å¦   Sabalu, 36, of Chicago, was killed May 6 when the convoy he was riding in was fired on by an Afghan soldier at a prison in Pol-e-Charki. He was assigned to Fort Leonard Wood.
å¦   After his Puerto Rican family moved to Chicago from New York as a young boy, Sabalu graduated from Lane Technical High School. He joined the Army in 1990 and served as a corrections specialist in Afghanistan, taking care of prisoners for the military police
å¦   "You're torn as a soldier and a father and a husband," said Lozano. "He was very good at what he did, so he was proud to be there. But he knew it was a sacrifice to be away from his family."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Amy, who also works for the Army's military police. He has two children, Joshua, 12, and Nadia, 10. He was a coach for his children's soccer team for several years and enjoyed family cookouts.

ServiceUnit: U.S. Army Command and General Staff College
IncidentDetails: Two U.S. service members were killed and two others wounded Sunday when an apparent Afghan National Army soldier fired shots into their vehicles as they left the Pol-E-Charki Prison in Kabul.
Bio:
James W. Harrison Jr. spent much of his childhood in Germany, where he played soccer, not football. When he moved to America, he went to the football coach and said, "I want to play football, but the only thing I can do is kick."
å¦   The coach appeared skeptical, but let him try out. "He kicked one 40 yards and was in," said Lori Brown, a classmate. "He was a heck of a guy."
å¦   Harrison, 47, of Belleville, Ill., was killed May 6 when the convoy he was riding in was fired on by an Afghan soldier at a prison in Pol-e-Charki. He was assigned to Fort Leavenworth.
å¦   Harrison graduated from the U.S. Military Academy in 1981. He also earned a master's in business administration from Syracuse University and a master's in national security and strategic studies from the National Defense University.
å¦   "He has friends all over the world," said retired Army Lt. Col. Ed Healy.
å¦   Before Harrison's deployment in December 2006, he was the director of the School of Command Preparation at the U.S. Army Command and General Staff College.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Mary, and three sons, Braden, Ross and Josh.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: died May 8 in Tarin Kwot, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his unit was attacked by enemy forces during combat patrol operations.
Bio:
Staff Sgt. Keith Batchelder, who served with Timothy P. Padgett, stood among the mourners at an airport as they waited for the helicopter carrying his body to arrive.
å¦   "It was an honor to serve with him," Batchelder said. "He was the best medic I ever knew."
å¦   Padgett, 28, of Defuniak Springs, Fla., was killed by enemy fire May 8 in Tarin Kwot. He was a 1997 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   He volunteered with the Argyle Volunteer Fire Department when he was a teenager. His mother, Glenda Penton, remembers that he would ask her to drive him to fire calls because he didn't have a license yet.
å¦   "If he met you, you were automatically his friend," she said. "Tim smiled even on the rainy days."
å¦   While Padgett was away, he asked his mother to collect small stuffed animals and ship them to him so he could hand them out to kids at clinics he and his team set up in Afghanistan.
å¦   He was a firefighter paramedic with the South Walton Fire District before he joined the Army. His fellow firefighters often called him "smiling Tim."
å¦   He also is survived by his 8-year-old daughter, Summer.

ServiceUnit: 4th Brigade Special Troops Battalion, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: died May 14 in Teri Mengel, Pakistan, of wounds sustained from enemy small arms fire.
Bio:
Army Maj. Larry J. Bauguess Jr.
å¦   Despite conflict raging, Larry J. Bauguess Jr. played tic-tac-toe with his young daughters over e-mail.
å¦   "He would put the game on a Power Point slide, fill in his move and then e-mail it off to them. Then the next day he would get an e-mail back with their moves filled in," said Maj. Kenneth J. Ratashak.
å¦   Bauguess, 36, of Moravian Falls, N.C., was killed May 14 by small-arms fire in Teri Mengel, Pakistan. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Bauguess graduated from Appalachian State University in 1993 and was in the ROTC program. He deployed to Saudi Arabia in 1997 for four months and also served in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom in 2005.
å¦   "Larry would want to be remembered as a father, a husband, a son and a paratrooper. He loved his family unconditionally, and he loved his work with his soldiers just as much. He was a positive influence on all who knew him. He was passionate about his life," his family said in a statement.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Wesley Ann; and two daughters, Ryann, 6, and Ellie, 4.
å¦   "He was where he wanted to be; next to his commander, on the ground, in the fight," said Ratashak.

ServiceUnit: Mobilization Command, Deployment Processing Command, Marine Corps Installations East
IncidentDetails: Marine Lt. Col. Michael A. Robinson, 42, of Sylacauga, Ala., died Friday in Kabul, Afghanistan of an undetermined cause;
Bio:
David Simpkins said he and Michael A. Robinson were good buddies in school. He said his classmates nicknamed Robinson "Chuckwagon" in about the seventh grade.
å¦   "I can't recall how he got the name. He was a real cut-up and I'm sure that had something to do with it," Simpkins said.
å¦   Robinson, 42, of Sylacauga, Ala., was found dead in his sleep June 1 in Kabul. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   Robinson was a 1983 high school graduate and earned an ROTC scholarship to Auburn University and obtained a bachelor's in industrial engineering.
å¦   Following tours in Japan and Panama, Robinson served as an artillery instructor at Fort Sill. He also was based at Fort Worth and served a tour of Iraq, where he was responsible for training the Iraqi National Army.
å¦   Harold Brooks, director of the Boys Club of Sylacauga, said Robinson attended the club as a young boy and until he graduated from high school.
å¦   "He would do whatever I told him to do. He supervised the younger boys when I asked him to. I never had any reservations about putting him in charge," Brooks said.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Kristi.

ServiceUnit: Company B, 1st Battalion, 158th Infantry Regiment, Arizona National Guard
IncidentDetails: Died of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment (Airborne) 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Died of wounds suffered when his unit was attacked by insurgents using small arms fire.
Bio:
Sgt. Andy Short remembered assigning Timothy R. Vimoto a simple task shortly after he arrived on post. The task wasn't as simple as it first appeared, but Vimoto accomplished it and did it quickly and well.
å¦   "No matter what Vimoto was doing, he had a smile on his face," Short said.
å¦   Vimoto, 19, of Fort Campbell, Ky., was killed June 5 in Korengal Valley by small-arms fire. He was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Ederle, Italy.
å¦   "I miss you so much words just can't even explain it. Your time here with us before you left went by so fast, yet so precious. You have made an impact on everyone you've come across. I know you will be missed by so many people," wrote Vimoto's second-oldest sister, Brina, on her MySpace page.
å¦   Vimoto was the oldest son of the 173rd Airborne Brigade's top enlisted soldier, Command Sgt. Maj. Isaia Vimoto.
å¦   "Throughout his childhood, he watched his father train, deploy redeploy and develop into one of the strongest leaders in the Army," said Capt. Matthew Heimerle, the battalion's rear detachment commander.
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Misimua.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 508th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Sgt. Charles E. Wyckoff Jr., 28, of Chula Vista, Calif., died June 6 in Helmand Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered from enemy small arms fire.
Bio:
In Afghanistan on his first combat deployment, Charles E. Wyckoff Jr. found ways to ease the anxieties of his family back home. He tried to downplay the hardships in his letters, phone calls and videos.
å¦   "His fun-loving nature was always there," said his sister, Alina Perez. One video showed mountain ranges, some difficult living conditions and Afghan children learning to recite the Pledge of Allegiance.
å¦   In the video's closing moments, he wrote a message of love to his wife, Erika, on a rock. And to his family, he spelled "I love you" with flowers.
å¦   Wyckoff, 28, of Chula Vista, Calif., was killed by small-arms fire June 6 in Helmand province. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Wyckoff graduated from Embry Riddle Aeronautical University in 2002 and enlisted in the Army with the goal of becoming a warrant officer and attending flight school.
å¦   "He loved parachuting," his sister said. "There was something about being airborne, an adrenalin thing. He loved it. He would have his cell phone camera on while he was jumping. He was a crazy kid, nothing but courage in everything he did."
å¦   He also is survived by his children, Alexandra and Joshua.

ServiceUnit: Company B, 2nd Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: died June 15, in Shkin, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered from enemy small arms fire.
Bio:
Because military service is a family tradition, Arthur L. Lilley's father wasn't surprised when Arthur began talking about joining the Army while in high school.
å¦   "He knew what he wanted to do. He wasn't afraid. He wanted to serve his country," said Arthur F. Lilley. "I know what it's like. I told him, 'If that is your choice, I will back you 100 percent.'"
å¦   Lilley, 35, of Smithfield, Pa., was killed June 15 in Shkin from small-arms fire. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Lilley was colorblind and couldn't pursue his goal of being an air traffic controller for the Air Force, so the Army became an option he never regretted, said his mother, Elizabeth.
å¦   "He was an excellent son," his father added. "He played sports in high school. I guess you could say that he was an average student. He raced motocross, and he liked BMX bicycle racing. His recent hobby was reconditioning SUVs and using them for rock climbing. He belonged to a club. They traveled all over. He was in Utah recently. It was a dangerous sport, but he loved it."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Christine; daughter, Mackenzie; and son, Cole.

ServiceUnit: 1st Brigade, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Staff Sgt. Roy P. Lewsader, Jr., 36, of Belleville, Ill., died June 16, in Tarin Kowt, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered when his vehicle was struck by a rocket-propelled grenade.
Bio:
Roy P. Lewsader Jr. loved music and played the guitar. When he packed his bags for deployment, Lewsader dismantled his guitar so he could take it with him.
å¦   It wasn't long before he called his wife, Melissa, from Afghanistan and told her he had forgotten to pack his guitar amplifier.
å¦   She remembers her husband asking, "Can you send the amp?"
å¦   Lewsader Jr., 36, of Clinton, Ill., was killed by a bomb blast June 16 in Tarin Kowt. He was assigned to Fort Riley. He did two tours of duty in Korea and was on his second tour of Afghanistan.
å¦   "I am so proud of him. He's done what he's wanted to do since he was 6 or 7 years old. He died doing what he wanted to do. He died for his friends," said Beverly Price, his mother.
å¦   Mark Lewsader, a younger brother, said he got a thrill out of aggravating his older sibling. "I picked on him and teased him about his hair, the way he ate or slept, just about anything I could think of," Mark Lewsader said. "I don't claim him as a hero, I claim his as a brother."
å¦   He also is survived by four daughters, Briana, Ozzra'D, Cheyenne and Keebee; and a son, Billy.

ServiceUnit: 1st Brigade, 1st Infantry Division (Transition Team)
IncidentDetails: Thee soldiers died June 17 in Panjway, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
Joshua E. Steele loved rocks and dinosaurs from the age of 5 and read books about both. As he grew older, he began to read J.R.R. Tolkien.
å¦   His sister, Gina Steele, said Josh convinced his mother to read some of those works. "And he would quiz her about them," she said. "I remember he was actually working his way through 'War and Peace' when he was 8."
å¦   Steele, 26, of North Henderson, Ill., was killed June 17 by a roadside bomb in Panjway. He was assigned to Fort Riley.
å¦   He graduated magna cum laude from the University of Missouri-Rolla in 2002, with a bachelor's degree in geological engineering, and was active in Phi Kappa Phi.
å¦   He adopted a mustang when he was 13, he loved to raise pigs, and won a soil identification contest. "I always tried to study with him," said Jonathan White. "He was always cracking some kind of joke."
å¦   While he wasn't a star football player, he was enthusiastic. "He was pretty gung-ho about football," White said. "I think any little bit of playing time he had, he was on top of the world."
å¦   He also is survived by his parents, Paula and Philip.

ServiceUnit: 1st Brigade, 1st Infantry Division (Transition Team)
IncidentDetails: Three soldiers died June 17 in Panjway, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
Jim Henderson described his son, Christopher, as someone who was "very well organized."
å¦   "If you could find a way to say 'neat freak' without saying neat freak, that would describe him," the elder Henderson said.
å¦   His wife, Jennifer Henderson, agreed. "Things are never clean enough for him," she said. "If it was clean, it wasn't enough for him. It had to be done right."
å¦   Henderson, 35, of Hillsboro, Ore., was killed June 17 by a roadside bomb in Panjway. He was a 1991 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Riley.
å¦   The handsome blond teen was a diligent student, always did his homework and, of course, kept his room clean. He was a favorite with his high school girlfriends' parents.
å¦   It wasn't uncommon for the family to take a trip to a local gun club and practice trap shooting. "They showed an interest early on and we just went out as a family," Jim Henderson said.
å¦   He was deployed to Florida during one of the hard-hitting hurricanes in the early 1990s and he also policed the streets in Panama City.
å¦   Henderson also is survived by his daughter, 8-year-old Kayley.

ServiceUnit: Louisiana National Guard's 3rd Battalion, 156th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: Three soldiers died June 17 in Panjway, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
A little bit of John M. Hennen rubbed off on his son _ at least the flirtatious part.
å¦   Hennen's 4-year old son, John Michael Hennen II, nicknamed T-John, has already learned a few tricks from his daddy's playbook.
å¦   "Everywhere he goes, he makes eyes at pretty women," said Susan Moreno, his mother. "He even tries to whistle at them."
å¦   Hennen, 26, of Vinton, La., was killed June 17 in Panjway after an explosive detonated near his vehicle. He was a 1999 high school graduate and was assigned to Lake Charles.
å¦   Hennen set his sights on the Army from the time he was a little boy. His mother reluctantly signed a waiver for him to join before he turned 18.
å¦   "I have a great husband, I have a great family, but John was the greatest man I ever knew," said Katherine Bleichroth, a sister.
å¦   Hennen's parents said they will fulfill one of their son's goals in the future.
å¦   "He wanted to go to Australia with T-John when he returned to the States," said his father, Paul Moreno. "We decided we're going to take him there when he's a little bit older, when he can understand that it's something that his daddy wanted for him."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 508th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Perrott died Thursday in Miri of wounds suffered when an explosive detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
Dustin J. Perrott once stood in front of a bulldozer that was ready to plow over ramps and jumps where he and his friends used to ride their bikes.
å¦   "That was Dusty," said childhood friend Chris Birkl. "He stood up for what he believed."
å¦   Perrott, 23, of Fredericksburg, Va., died June 22 in Miri of wounds suffered when an explosive detonated near his vehicle. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   As early as third grade, Perrott was the class clown. In high school and beyond, he channeled that energy into playing drums with his band.
å¦   "Dusty had an ear for music like nothing I've ever seen," said his wife, Anna. He couldn't read sheet music, but he could hear something once, like an Elton John tune, and play it right back without error.
å¦   A 2003 high school graduate, he volunteered to go to Iraq, serving there from December 2004 to March 2005. He sought to follow in the footsteps of his father, a sergeant, who died when Perrott was 4.
å¦   "Everyone always seemed drawn to his kindness," said his wife. He "would give you the shirt off his back and the last dollar to his name."

ServiceUnit: 1st Brigade, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Army Capt. Darrell C. Lewis, 31, Washington, D.C.; died Saturday in Vashir City, of wounds sustained when his unit was attacked by rocket propelled grenades, mortars and small arms fire
Bio:
Darrell C. Lewis was raised in an area known for drugs and violence. But his family described him as a natural leader who used an inquisitive mind to chase his dreams.
å¦   He showed no fear when walking down dangerous streets, and from an early age he rode buses across town to schools outside the neighborhood.
å¦   "He knew there was more to life," said Trina Lewis, a cousin.
å¦   Lewis, 31, of Washington, D.C., died June 23 in Vashir City after his unit came under attack. He was assigned to Fort Riley.
å¦   "You can't express it in words; it was in his face," said his mother, Hannah Lewis. "Being in the military was the happiest I've ever seen my child."
å¦   At Wittenberg University, Lewis learned Japanese and Chinese. After joining the Army, he served in Georgia and Washington state, then completed a two-year tour in South Korea.
å¦   Hannah Lewis recalled embracing her son for what would be the last time at his wedding reception in San Antonio in December. "I knew he was going away, and I just remembered the hug," she said.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Elizabeth, and infant son, Rashawn. Lewis also had a 7-year-old daughter, Taylor.

ServiceUnit: 546th Military Police Company, 385th Military Police Battalion
IncidentDetails: McGee died July 6 of wounds sustained when his vehicle struck an improvised explosive device in Wazi Khwa, Afghanistan.
Bio:
As a trainer in Afghanistan, Thomas P. McGee struggled at first to assert himself amid louder colleagues.
å¦   "He was having a hard time because his style of sergeant training is a little bit different than most," said his mother, Sylvia McGee. "He's not a yeller or a screamer, and a lot of them are."
å¦   But he soon became an effective trainer and was soon known in his platoon for a catch phrase _ "I'm on it," he'd always say.
å¦   McGee, 23, of Hawthorne, Calif., was killed July 6 by a roadside bomb in Wazi Khwa. He was assigned to Fort Stewart.
å¦   "No soldier could ask for a better leader," said Army Staff Sgt. William Gaston. "He brought his laid-back Southern California nature to our squad."
å¦   McGee was in Junior ROTC program and Lt. Col. Ken Falasco remembered him as dependable. "When you asked him to do something, it was done," he said. "You didn't have to follow him around."
å¦   In Afghanistan, he gave up his phone time so married colleagues could call their wives. "It was harder on us, but we understood," said his mother.
å¦   McGee is also survived by his father, Tom McGee.

ServiceUnit: 2d Battalion, 503d Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173d Airborne Brigade
IncidentDetails: Miracle died July 5 of wounds sustained from enemy small arms fire and indirect fire in the Watapor Valley of Kunar Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Joseph A. Miracle's brother-in-law, Matthew Joneson, said the eight years he knew Miracle were marked by selflessness and increasing maturity.
å¦   "I saw him the past year or so in the military really blossom into a really confident, good man," Joneson said. "He was so giving. I remember we gave him a high school graduation watch and he gave it to somebody."
å¦   Miracle, 22, of Ortonville, Mich., was killed July 5 during a firefight in the Watapor Valley. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   He was a running back and served as a co-captain of the football team, earning an award for being the most valuable player.
å¦   "He was a really cheerful kid," said his sister, Jeannette Miracle-Leshan. Miracle attended Oakland Community College after graduation but later decided to join the military.
å¦   "I think he missed the camaraderie of the football team, and he loved the physical aspect of it," said his sister. "He chose the airborne right there in the recruiter's office."

ServiceUnit: 2d Battalion, 503d Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173d Airborne Brigade
IncidentDetails: Honaker died July 5 of wounds sustained from enemy small arms fire and indirect fire in the Watapor Valley of Kunar Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Christopher S. Honaker was known for his large bags of Gummi Bears, his prowess on a skateboard and his work ethic. Members of his unit called him "Hardcore."
å¦   "Honaker was on point all the time," Pfc. Ryan Normandin said. "You could count on him to have your back, or sometimes pick up your slack if you goofed up."
å¦   Honaker, 23, of Cleveland, N.C., was killed July 5 by small-arms fire and indirect fire in the Watapor Valley of Kunar province. He was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   "Chris was one of the funniest kids I've ever met," said his friend Matt MacIntosh. "He always shined the brightest in the group when we got together. He was always trying to do something funny to one-up us."
å¦   Despite his junior rank, the Marine "acted as both coach and mentor to his peers. Specialist Honaker was the type of soldier that led by example and was the type of soldier that leaders want under their command," said Capt. Matthew Heimerle.
å¦   He was a graduate of Universal Technical Institute's NASCAR technology program in Mooresville.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, George and Eva.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 10th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Died July 7 in Kidal, Mali, of injuries sustained from a non-combat related incident. His death is under investigation.
Bio:
During a five-minute slideshow shown at his funeral, Sean K. Mitchell was smiling in just about every photo. He grinned while holding his bride, while holding his baby, while deployed with his team in Afghanistan and while in some back yard, just goofing off.
å¦   Mitchell, 35, of Monterey, Calif., was killed July 7 from injuries received during a sand and windstorm in Kidal, Mali. He was a 1991 high school graduate and was assigned to Stuttgart, Germany.
å¦   He was part of the Special Operations Command Europe's Trans-Sahara Counter Terrorism Partnership, a joint program between the departments of State and Defense. He was a student of Russian at the Defense Language Institute at the Presidio of Monterey, graduating in 2001.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Sonja, and 3-month-old son, Cameron. His widow said Sean spoke to the infant by speakerphone while on assignment in Mali, so he could hear his daddy's voice.
å¦   "Sean will keep on living in him, and I will raise him to the best of my ability," Sonja Mitchell said. "His baby boy has no father now; this is what is killing me the most."

ServiceUnit: 56th Logistics Readiness Squadron
IncidentDetails: Master Sgt. Randy J. Gillespie, 44, of Coaldale, Colo., died July 9, in Herat, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered during small arms fire outside of Camp Stone
Bio:
In Afghanistan, Randy J. Gillespie met a young boy who walked around barefoot.
å¦   When Gillespie offered to have his family send him a pair of shoes, the boy refused, afraid he would be killed by militants if they saw him wearing the shoes.
å¦   Determined to help, Gillespie instead sneaked the boy chocolate bars. "He was the type of guy who would give you the shirt off his back," said his brother, Roger Gillespie.
å¦   Gillespie, 44, of Coaldale, Colo., was killed July 9 by small-arms fire in Herat. He was assigned to Luke Air Force Base and was on his second tour.
å¦   Gillespie, a 24-year veteran of the Air Force, was a mechanic, and working close to jet engines had left him deaf in one ear, but his brother said that he handled it with good humor.
å¦   "He laughed about it all the time," Roger Gillespie said. "He would always have to turn to hear what you said."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Lisa Gillespie, and four children: Cory, Cristopher, Ethan and Amanda.
å¦   "He was the type of guy who would give you the shirt off his back," Roger Gillespie said.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 4th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: Died July 23 in Arghendab District, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his unit was attacked by enemy forces using indirect fire.
Bio:
Zachary R. Endsley had a knack for traveling light, even showing up for his first duty station in Germany with very little baggage.
å¦   "And we get off the plane and run into Endsley. He's getting this one bag off the baggage check. He's got a full beard, and he grabs his cowboy hat and puts it on and that's all he's got. He showed for his first duty station with a cowboy hat, a guitar and one bag of clothes," recalled Pfc. Tim Hanke.
å¦   Endsley, 21, of Spring, Texas, died July 23 in Afghanistan's Arghendab district of wounds from indirect fire. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Hohenfels, Germany.
å¦   In his spare time he was an avid video gamer and often could be counted on to entertain by displaying his talent with a guitar and as a singer.
å¦   "He had respect for his peers and his subordinates, and always looked out for his fellow soldiers," said Sgt. Rickie Gander. "He took his job very seriously, but he knew when it was time to be serious and when it was time to mess around."
å¦   He is survived by his parents Terry Endsley, and Melinda and David Carroll.

ServiceUnit: Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died July 23 in Sarobi District, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
For Christmas 2004, Michael S. Curry Jr. returned home, teased his eldest sister about how he was still the big brother and gave out big, tight hugs.
å¦   "I was so proud of him," said older sister Keisha Robinson. "If wrong was going left, he was always going right."
å¦   Curry, 37, of Dania Beach, Fla., was killed by a roadside bomb July 23 in Afghanistan's Sarobi district. He graduated high school in 1987 and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   "My first impression of him was that he was going to do great things for our Army," Sgt. Maj. Earl Rice. "And he never let me down."
å¦   He served in the Persian Gulf War and landed in Iraq during the March 2003 invasion. Curry's commander, Capt. Joe Curtis, described him as an "incredible soldier and unequaled warrior."
å¦   "He was a wonderful husband, father and son," said Curry's sister Niki Martin. "He was so wonderful, like something that is too good to be true."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Lucia, and sons Taylor and Kevin.
å¦   "He was my hero," said Robinson, who like other relatives and friends knew her brother as Lil' Mike.

ServiceUnit: Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died July 23 in Sarobi District, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
Big of stature and big of heart, Travon T. Johnson had an infectious laugh, a love for USC Trojan football and love for his family above all else.
å¦   "He was such an amazing guy," said Salvador Sanchez, a family friend. "He was shot once, and nearly shot another time, and still he went back. But in the end, he had too many close calls."
å¦   Johnson, 29, of Palmdale, Calif., was killed July 23 by a roadside bomb in Afghanistan's Sarobi district. He was on his third deployment and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   Spc. Russell Humphries, a friend, said Johnson was "a man of humility; he treated all as equals. If someone had a problem or was upset, he wouldn't come down to your level to talk, he would bring you up to his."
å¦   Johnson's paternal grandmother, Julia Shotlow said he never caused trouble as a child. "Everybody liked him," she said. "He was so sweet and friendly."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Sara Faresin-Johnson, and two children from previous relationships.
å¦   Several years ago, Sanchez organized a letter-writing program at an elementary school. When Johnson returned home, he visited the class with teddy bears for each child.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died July 23 in Sarobi District, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
Adam J. Davis' friends told of his ability to jump into any conversation and just talk _ whether he knew what he was talking about or not.
å¦   "He always had some input, even though some of the most senior guys would look at him all crazy and stuff," said Spc. Michael Preston. He is also remembered for his love of the outdoors and poor driving skills.
å¦   Davis, 19, of Twin Falls, Idaho, was killed July 23 by a roadside bomb in Afghanistan's Sarobi district. He was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   Davis made a conscious decision to drop out of high school, obtain his GED at the College of Southern Idaho and to enlist in the Army.
å¦   He was following in the footsteps of numerous family members, including his 85-year-old grandfather, Albert Davis, who died this winter from cancer.
å¦   "He was a great paratrooper and soldier, an awesome friend to those around him and a fine young man. He will be truly missed and never replaced in our memory," Command Sgt. Maj. Richard Weik wrote in an e-mail from Afghanistan.
å¦   Davis is survived by his father, Timothy, and mother Tracy L. Carrico.

ServiceUnit: Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died July 23 in Sarobi District, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
Born in Texas but raised in Alaska, Jessy S. Rogers was an avid snowboarder and would teach anyone who wanted to learn.
å¦   "At first he was a quiet type of person, trying to keep to himself. But as soon as one of the guys was able to break him out of his shell, he was on the loose. But from time to time, he would get his time alone," said Spc. Brody Hall.
å¦   Rogers, 20, of Copper Center, Alaska, was killed July 23 by a roadside bomb in Afghanistan's Sarobi district. He was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   "His favorite words were 'super' and 'sweet,'" Martinez said, adding that people liked hearing him use them "not because of the words themselves, but because how he said it."
å¦   Pfc. Stephen Martinez recalled Rogers' trips to the mountains in Italy last winter to go snowboarding: "Not because it was fun, but because it reminded him of home."
å¦   Martinez remembered Davis as a joker. "His smile defined him," he said. "Davis was known for telling a joke, giving away the punch line and being the only one laughing at the end."
å¦   He is survived by his father, David, and mother, Donnetta.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Restrepo died July 22 in Korengal Valley, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his unit using small arms fire.

ServiceUnit: Squadron, 91st Cavalry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died July 27 near Kamu, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained when their unit came in contact with enemy forces using small arms fire during combat operations.
Bio:
Sgt. 1st Class Bobby Bostick called his older brother "Big Bubba" and looked to him for guidance and strength after he joined the military.
å¦   "He took care of his soldiers," said Bostick about his brother, Thomas G. Bostick Jr. "He was definitely a good mentor and was one of the top captains in the Army."
å¦   Bostick, 37, of Llano, Texas, was killed July 27 by small-arms fire near Kamu. He was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   Brenda Richardson said her son had talked about retiring from the Army in a year, after his tour was over. "He wanted to be a teacher," she said. "He wanted to come back to Llano and help younger children succeed."
å¦   Bostick served in Operation Iraqi Freedom in 2003 and Operation Just Cause in Panama in 1989, the U.S. mission to remove Gen. Manuel Noriega from power.
å¦   "He was always a fine gentleman and a gentleman of character and certainly a hero," said Llano County Judge Wayne Brascom.
å¦   Bostick is also survived by his wife of 14 years, Jennifer Bostick, and their daughters, Jessica, 18, and Ashlie, 13.
å¦   "He was a great person, a great leader," Tom Bostick Sr. said.

ServiceUnit: 1st Squadron, 91st Cavalry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died July 27 near Kamu, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained when their unit came in contact with enemy forces using small arms fire during combat operations.
Bio:
William R. Fritsche played on the varsity basketball team in high school and received the American Legion School Award before joining the Army at age 17 under the delayed-entry program.
å¦   Fritsche let others know early on that his intention was to join the military, but he would have been successful in any career, said his former principal Don Alkire.
å¦   "Ryan worked hard at whatever he did," Alkire said.
å¦   Fritsche, 23, of Martinsville, Ind., was killed July 27 by small-arms fire near Kamu. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   He was chosen to serve in the Old Guard at Arlington National Cemetery and also marched in President Bush's inaugural procession in Washington, D.C., in 2005.
å¦   Tim Wolf, his former basketball coach, said he was always the first in the gym for practice and the last to leave when lights were turned off. Wolf said that if he had a business, Fritsche was the type of person he would want to run it.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Brandi.
å¦   "I could have seen Ryan serving in the military as a general," said Sheriff's Deputy Scott Hamilton.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: 1st Lt. Benjamin J. Hall, 24, of Virginia, died July 31 in Asadabad, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his unit during combat operations in Chowkay Valley, Afghanistan.
Bio:
While taking tickets at a movie theater where he once worked, Benjamin J. Hall wore comical glasses with a fake nose and mustache to get a rise out of people
å¦   A runner, Hall once raced in a marathon and, a year later, participated in another in full combat gear. Hall also ran with the bulls in Pamplona, Spain.
å¦   "Everyone looked up to him," said 2nd Lt. Adam Moore. "Everybody followed him."
å¦   Hall, 24, of Woodbridge, Va., was killed July 31 when insurgents attacked his unit in Chowkay Valley. He was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   He graduated from Michigan Tech with a degree in political science in 2005. He was a great athlete, a harmonica player and a card-carrying Eagle Scout. His 10-year-old brother, Joe, was one of his best buddies.
å¦   "He was just my hero," said his father, John Hall, a retired Army colonel. "Just the type of person he was _ giving, humble _ and he was just the type of guy people were drawn to."
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Sarah.
å¦   "He was just a beautiful young man I'm so proud of him. We all are," John Hall said. "We're going to miss him."

ServiceUnit: 202nd Military Intelligence Battalion, 513th Military Intelligence Brigade
IncidentDetails: Sgt. Taurean T. Harris, 22, of Liberty, Miss., died Aug. 2 in Kala Gush, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained from an improvised explosive device
Bio:
Taurean T. Harris' mother said her son could never keep his hands off the appliances around the house and he tinkered with anything electrical, from ceiling fans to televisions.
å¦   "He always thought he could hook up everything," said Yolanda Wagner.
å¦   Harris, 22, of Liberty, Miss., died Aug. 2 in Kala Gush of wounds sustained from an explosive. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Gordon.
å¦   "Taurean was such a fun-loving, kind, honorable person. And it's sad to lose someone that outstanding," former neighbor and classmate Lashonya "Shon" Harris.
å¦   The news of his death shook up hearts in his small southwest Mississippi hometown.
å¦   "He had a close relationship with his teachers, and every one of them that I've run into talked about how intelligent and how well mannered he was," said Charles Jackson, an assistant principal.
å¦   Harris also is survived by his father, Cecil Harris, and 1-year-old daughter Tiana. "Everything he did was for her," Wagner said. "I want the world to know what I lost, because I lost a beautiful child."

ServiceUnit: 4th Squadron, 73rd Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Died Aug. 11 in Zormont, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered from an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Jordan E. Goode enjoyed doing things on the edge _ whether skateboarding, snowboarding or jumping from military planes.
å¦   "He loved the thrill," said his mother, Sheri Goode. "Once when Jordan snowboarded, he went down the end of a slope and there was no snow at the bottom. He had a concussion."
å¦   Goode, 21, of Kalamazoo, Mich., was killed Aug. 11 in Zormont by an explosive. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   "He was a great kid and he loved his family," Sheri Goode said. "He believed in what he was doing and he was doing the right thing."
å¦   Aubrey Goode said she was introduced to her future husband by a friend while in middle school. "The first time I saw him skateboarding, I had a crush on him," she said.
å¦   They were married nearly two years ago, when she was expecting the couple's daughter, Amirah. Sheri Goode said her son surprised everyone by joining the Army.
å¦   "We were trying to get him into art school. He was an absolutely phenomenal artist," she said. "But his girlfriend was pregnant at the time. He decided to step up to the plate, do the right thing and provide for his family."
å¦   Goode also is survived by his father, Tony.

ServiceUnit: 782nd Brigade Support Battalion, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentLocation: near Forward Operating Base Sharana, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: Died Aug. 12 near Forward Operating Base Sharana, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered from a non-combat related accident.
Bio:
å¦   Alan J. Austin's greatest gift was his kind, loving heart, said his mother, Rhonda Austin. She said she lost more than a son; he was her best friend.
å¦   "He helped me raise his brother, who has autism," she said. "That's where he got his compassionate heart. He was so protective of us and he loved us so much. He always said he wanted to take care of his brother."
å¦   Austin, 21, of Houston, died Aug. 12 when his Humvee rolled over near Forward Operating Base Sharana. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   "Alan was quiet," said Glenda Breeding-Wright, a family friend. "He didn't talk a lot. He was real focused. He knew where he wanted to go in life and he was getting there."
å¦   Austin graduated high school in 2004 and spent a year attending culinary school. He worked briefly as a security guard before enlisting. He loved cooking, dancing and parades.
å¦   "The job market was not what he needed or wanted," his mother said. "He wanted to do more with his life, and he thought he could be a help to his country."
å¦   "He enjoyed what he was doing, and he was very proud," she said. "He used to sign his letters 'Your American Soldier.'"

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Died Aug. 12 in Nangarhar Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
The last time he talked to his son, Ronald Kettle said, was in late June after Houston Astro Craig Biggio notched his 3,000th base hit _ a topic that interested Jeffrey because he had played baseball.
å¦   The elder Kettle said that after their conversation he sent his son a "Biggio 3000" T-shirt.
å¦   Kettle, 31, of Madill, Okla., was killed by a roadside bomb Aug. 12 in Nangarhar province. He was a 1993 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   "Jeff was the ultimate warrior," said Ronald Kettle. "Every game was a battle to him," he said.
å¦   In 2003, Kettle received a Bronze Star during his first tour of duty in Afghanistan after uncovering a major weapons cache, Ronnie Kettle said.
å¦   Kettle began playing soccer at age 5 and continued playing through high school and during his military career in Saudi Arabia, Italy, Germany, Hawaii and Japan.
å¦   He also played baseball and loved the outdoors and would hunt squirrels when he visited his uncle.
å¦   "He wore his uniform proud and did his job beyond well," Ronnie Kettle said.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Brandi, and sons Jeffrey and Logan.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Died Aug. 12 in Nangarhar Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
Standing 6-foot-3 and weighing more than 230 pounds, Jesse G. Clowers Jr. could bench-press 400 pounds but wasn't too tough to be soft.
å¦   One family friend was struck by how Clowers, even as a teenager, would tell his parents and two sisters that he loved them, even as his high school buddies looked on.
å¦   "He was a gentle giant," said Jeremy Sartain. "As big as he was, his heart was bigger."
å¦   Clowers Jr., 27, of Herndon, Va., was killed Aug. 12 by a roadside bomb in Nangarhar province. He graduated from Virginia Tech in 2003, where he made the cheerleading squad and earned a degree in business. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   He shipped out when his wife, Kaytie, was seven months pregnant with their second child. His homecoming in late September would be Clowers' first chance to meet his newborn daughter, Danielle.
å¦   "He was definitely counting down the days," said his sister Nikki Clowers. "Almost every e-mail he sent us, he was talking about how much he was looking forward to hugging his wife and playing with his son and meeting his baby girl."
å¦   He also is survived by a son, Jesse, 2.

ServiceUnit: 345th Psychological Operations Company, 2nd Psychological Operations Group, U.S. Army Civil Affairs and Psychological Operations Command (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Died Aug. 12 in Nangarhar Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
The Rev. John Kha Tran tells a story of how Charles B. Kitowski III found his dog, Andy _ a story that illustrated his compassion, quick thinking and acceptance of risk.
å¦   Spotting the wet stray on a busy rain-slick freeway, the priest said, "he U-turned. That is a lot of heart."
å¦   Kitowski, 31, known as Trey, of Farmers Branch, Texas, was killed Aug. 12 by an explosive in Nangarhar province. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   "Trey loved life," said Tran.
å¦   Born in Gulfport, Miss., Kitowski worked in the finance department at Southwest Airlines in Dallas before deploying to Afghanistan. He had a bachelor's in management information systems from the University of St. Thomas.
å¦   His fiancee, Berri Gentry, said he "was always ready with laughter," and volunteered with Habitat for Humanity and the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
å¦   "He had joy in his heart," she said.
å¦   Friend Daniel Garcia said Kitowski had to do something after terrorists attacked in 2001. "It was in his heart," said Garcia. "He couldn't just sit there."
å¦   Kitowski also is survived by his parents, Chuck and Theresa.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment
IncidentDetails: Libby died Monday near Khowst, Afghanistan, from a non-combat cause.
Bio:
Challenges were nothing to George V. Libby
å¦   "George, when he enlisted, decided he was going to be an Army Ranger," said his mother, Nell Allen. "I don't know how many succeed. At some point, they do tough training. Each thing he approached, he would say something like, 'only 30 percent finish it.' He rose to every challenge presented to him. I was so impressed by my son.
å¦   "He took on and beat every challenge in his pursuit of becoming a warrior. That is how I see him: becoming the very best warrior he could, for the United States Army. That sounds a little corny, but that's how I feel."
å¦   Libby, 23, of Aberdeen, N.C., was killed Aug. 20 when the vehicle he was riding in rolled over during nighttime drivers' training near Khost. He was assigned to Fort Lewis and spent two years studying computer science at Sandhills Community College in Pinehurst.
å¦   His wife, Valorie Libby, said his decision to join the Army was because of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. He had also served a tour in Iraq. "He believed in this mission, and I believed in him. My husband was a good and loving person," she said.

ServiceUnit: 1st Brigade, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died of wounds sustained from a non-combat related incident in Herat, Afghanistan.  The circumstances surrounding the incident are under investigation.
Bio:
Daniel E. Miller's father, Harold, remembers his son's love of reading, playing baseball, history, playing in the band and being in the drama club in high school.
å¦   "We got in the car one summer to go on a three-week vacation and asked Dan where he wanted to go," Harold smiles, his eyes misty with tears. "He hopped in and we were off to travel the Sherman trail."
å¦   Miller's mother, Susan, recalls another thing from that summer. "I remember he had hurt his leg that summer and was on crutches, but it sure didn't stop him from climbing a hill to see how Sherman had positioned his men," she said.
å¦   Miller, 43, of Rossford, Ohio, was killed Aug. 24 when the Humvee he was riding in rolled over near Herat. He was assigned to Fort Riley.
å¦   Miller's love of drama took him straight to his wife, Anne. The pair met while at a drama competition and they married in April 1985.
å¦   "She was and is the perfect one for Dan," said Shelly Kaufman, Miller's sister. "She has amazing strength and supported Dan in whatever he did."
å¦   The couple also have six children _ Michaela, 13, Lucas, 9, Maggie, 7, Dominic, 4, Marianna, 2, and Lucy, 7 months.

ServiceUnit: 2d Brigade Combat Team, 34th Infantry Division of the Iowa Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: died of wounds sustained from a non-combat related incident in Herat, Afghanistan.  The circumstances surrounding the incident are under investigation.
Bio:
å¦   Scott M. Carney was on his first combat mission, and he was part of a team of 50 Iowa soldiers training Afghan police and soldiers. He arrived in Afghanistan in May.
å¦   "He was a man who really liked what he was doing," said Col. Tim Orr. "The Army was his life. He loved his family dearly. He was a great soldier, a great family member and he also was part of the team."
å¦   Carney, 37, of Ankeny, Iowa, was killed Aug. 24 when his Humvee rolled over during convoy operations near Herat. He was a 1988 high school graduate and earned an associate's degree from Upper Iowa University in 2003.
å¦   "Scott died doing what he loved, serving his country and protecting the freedom that we enjoy and providing the people of Afghanistan with the opportunity for freedom," his family wrote in a statement.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Jeni, and twin sons, Jacob and Justin.
å¦   Carney's brother-in-law, Jamie Mahne, said Carney was a model husband and father who loved to take his 12-year-old twin sons fishing. "He was truly an all-American dad," Mahne said. "He truly was a saint."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 138th Field Artillery Regiment, Kentucky Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Army Staff Sgt. Nicholas R. Carnes, 25, Dayton, Ky.; died Sunday in Orgun-e, from wounds suffered by small arms fire in Lewanne Bazaar; assigned to the 2nd Battalion, 138th Field Artillery Regiment, Kentucky Army National Guard, Carrollton, Ky.
Bio:
å¦   Nicholas R. Carnes and his wife, Terri, would have celebrated their first wedding anniversary in a few weeks.
å¦   "I was his world," she said. "He put me on a pedestal. He loved me, and he loved what he was doing. I don't know where we go from here. But I know that if he had to do it over again, he would."
å¦   Carnes, 25, of Dayton, Ky., was killed Aug. 26 by small-arms fire in Lewanne Bazaar. He was a 2000 high school graduate and was assigned to Carrollton.
å¦   He entered the Army National Guard at 17 and went to work at BB Riverboats, which is owned by Terri's father. He became a captain before leaving on his Guard deployment in October 2006. It was his first tour.
å¦   "He was an outstanding worker, someone we really valued," Alan Bernstein said of his son-in-law. "We were so happy to have him, not only working for us, but also seeing our daughter."
å¦   "He was the most kind, gentle, loving young man," said his mother, Wray Jean Carnes. "There wasn't anyone he ever met who didn't love him. He never grumbled. He was always there to lend a helping hand. He was a giving young man."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment (Air Assault), 173rd Airborne Brigade
IncidentDetails: died of wounds suffered when his unit came in contact with enemy forces using a rocket propelled grenade and small arms fire
Bio:
Jacob M. Lowell's friend, Steve Strimel, said during his eulogy that Lowell lit a cigar while home on leave in April. After a few drags, Lowell wrapped the cigar and gave it to his friend for safekeeping, to finish when he returned.
å¦   During Lowell's funeral, Strimel placed that same cigar inside his friend's flag-draped coffin.
å¦   "I'll always love you, Jake," Strimel said.
å¦   Lowell, 22, of New Lenox, Ill., was killed June 2 near Gowardesh by small-arms fire. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Ederle, Italy.
å¦   In high school, Lowell was an offensive lineman, and Strimel was a running back. "He always made sure I had a hole to run through," Strimel said.
å¦   Jumping from planes was one of the things Lowell liked about the Army. "He would always call and let someone know when he was scheduled to jump," Strimel said.
å¦   He attended St. Xavier University before signing up. Lowell not only loved playing football, he was an avid fan. "He would yell 'Go Bears!' at the most unusual and inopportune moments," Staff Sgt. James Christy said.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Raymond and Bernardine.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Whitaker, 23, of Long Beach, Calif., was killed May 15 in Qalat by small-arms fire.
Bio:
Joshua R. Whitaker was an only child, born and raised by his mother, Catherine Whitaker, and his uncle, Robb Whitaker. His cousin, Laura Whitaker, said their bond was close.
å¦   "I didn't just think of Josh as a cousin, he was more like my brother and my hero," she said. "When I was diagnosed with diabetes, he was one of the first people to visit me in the hospital. He's been there for me since day one."
å¦   Whitaker, 23, of Long Beach, Calif., was killed May 15 in Qalat by small-arms fire. A Green Beret, he was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Longtime friend Matt Miller and Whitaker got matching tattoos that said "Friends for Life" in Latin. "No words can describe what Josh meant to me," Miller said. "He put a smile on my face. And I'm sure he did that for a lot of other people too."
