å¦   Miller said his friend enlisted after the 2001 attacks for adventure and to do his duty. "I'm proud of him as an American hero, but he's still my little baby," Robb Whitaker. "He was looking forward to making a difference in the world. He'll always be a hero to me."
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Frank Dougherty.

ServiceUnit: 3rd General Support Aviation Battalion, 82nd Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: died when their helicopter crashed apparently due to enemy fire
Bio:
Christopher M. Allgaier went to St. Louis University to pursue a longtime interest in flying, his father said.
å¦   "He was always picking up little model airplanes and aviation books when he was a kid," Bob Allgaier said.
å¦   Allgaier, 33, of Omaha, Neb., was killed May 30 when his helicopter crashed in Upper Sangin Valley. He was assigned to Fort Bragg and was on his second tour of duty in the country.
å¦   He was easygoing and cheerful, and often played peacemaker between his younger sister, Sharon, and older brother, Rob.
å¦   "You couldn't ask for a better brother," said Sharon Allgaier. "He was very empathetic. He was a very good listener, always there for me any time I needed to talk."
å¦   Allgaier graduated from Saint Louis University in 1995 and got a master's degree in aeronautical science from Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University in 2001.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Jennie, and daughters, Natalie, Gina and Joanna. "More than anything, he was devoted to his family and we are comforted by knowing how much he loves us," his wife said.

ServiceUnit: 3rd General Support Aviation Battalion, 82nd Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Rodgers, 29, of Carson City, Nev., died May 30 when his helicopter came under attack in Upper Sangin Valley.
Bio:
Linda Moshier said her nephew, Joshua R. Rodgers, was born three weeks early and lived his life that way.
å¦   "He was the kind of person any time anyone needed help, he was the first one there," she said. "He was a wonderful, wonderful human being."
å¦   Rodgers, 29, of Carson City, Nev., died May 30 when his helicopter came under attack in Upper Sangin Valley. He was a 1997 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Chief Warrant Officer Cesar Lariano, a member of Rodgers' unit, met Rodgers in late 2004. "I thought he was so loud and obnoxious, I couldn't believe we got him," Lariano said. "I didn't realize he was laying out the seed for being the comedian, keeping everybody laughing and happy."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Casey, and three daughters: Madison, 7, Autumn, 3, and Ashlyn, 2.
å¦   "I never met a man who loved his wife and children the way he did," Chief Warrant Officer Michael Turner said. "He will always be an inspiration to me."
å¦   Lariano said Rodgers' youngest daughter was born on the day the unit was deployed. "Josh thought it was the right thing to do to go," Lariano said. "He didn't ask anybody to stay back."

ServiceUnit: 3rd General Support Aviation Battalion, 82nd Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Bagwell, 28, of Lake Toxaway, N.C., was killed May 30 when his helicopter was struck by a rocket-propelled grenade in Upper Sangin Valley.
Bio:
Classmates voted Charlie L. Bagwell, who was a junior varsity basketball player and varsity football center, most athletic in 1997, his senior year.
å¦   "I've coached a lot of kids, but Charlie's one you ain't going to forget," said football coach Dan Essenberg. "He wasn't blessed with tremendous speed, but he was a hardworking kid."
å¦   Bagwell, 28, of Lake Toxaway, N.C., was killed May 30 when his helicopter was struck by a rocket-propelled grenade in Upper Sangin Valley. He was assigned to Fort Bragg. In 2005, Bagwell served in Iraq.
å¦   "You couldn't help but like Charlie. He was just one of those people you rarely meet that leave a lasting impression on you," said Chief Warrant Officer Dave Cox.
å¦   After high school, Bagwell worked briefly as a carpenter and then entered the military and became a mechanic and crew chief.
å¦   "I am so excited and I am so thankful for Charlie Bagwell and how he touched my life and how he influenced my life and the life of our church," the Rev. Don Waters said.
å¦   Bagwell is survived by his parents Lane and Judy; and a son, Preston Owen, 8.

ServiceUnit: 3rd General Support Aviation Battalion, 82nd Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Blamires, 25, of West Jordan, Utah, died May 30 in Upper Sangin Valley when his helicopter crashed.
Bio:
Craig Blamires said some of his fondest memories of his son, Jesse A. Blamires, revolve around Scouting. The father and son would often go into the wilderness to ponder and relax.
å¦   "I lost my camping buddy," his father said.
å¦   Blamires, 25, of West Jordan, Utah, died May 30 in Upper Sangin Valley when his helicopter crashed. He was a 1999 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg. Between 2005 and 2006, he served in Iraq.
å¦   Rick Hansen was looking forward to seeing his younger cousin, who always was smiling. He and his wife, Celeste Hansen, are going to miss his e-mails filled with jokes.
å¦   "He made everybody laugh," Hansen said. "He brought out the cheer in everybody."
å¦   Blamires loved animals and once nursed a wild bird back to health. He loved practicing Capoeira, a Brazilian form of martial arts.
å¦   The son was well-respected by his fellow soldiers and his commanders, and was known to take extra shifts and help others in need, Craig Blamires said.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Kimberly, and their daughters: 5-year-old Kelly and 8-month-old Danika Leah.

ServiceUnit: 3rd General Support Aviation Battalion, 82nd Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Hadaway, 25, of Valley, Ala., was killed May 30 when his helicopter crashed after coming under attack in Upper Sangin Valley.
Bio:
Brandon E. Hadaway was remembered for his smile by those who knew him and served with him.
å¦   "When you saw him in the hall and every where you went, Brandon always had a smiling face and always cared about everyone in the school. He was an outstanding guy," said Kristin Nelson, a classmate.
å¦   Hadaway, 25, of Valley, Ala., was killed May 30 when his helicopter crashed after coming under attack in Upper Sangin Valley. He was assigned to Fort Bragg and was on his third tour of duty.
å¦   "Brandon was a kid at heart," said childhood friend Stephen McClain. "He was a grown man in body but he was a kid at heart. He always wanted fun. Can I put a face on him? No, because Brandon had his own face _ a face you learned to love and you loved to care about."
å¦   Family friend David Powell said there was never a dull moment with Hadaway. "He was always joking and always trying to make you laugh," he said.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Rachel, and sons Levi, Dillon and Hunter.
å¦   "He always had a smile on his face. He celebrated life. He made us laugh and feel good about ourselves," soldiers from his unit wrote.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Pfc. Thomas R. Wilson, 21, of Maurertown, Va., died Aug. 27 in Paktika, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his unit during combat operations.
Bio:
Thomas R. Wilson cherished life around the family farm. He was active in the Future Farmers of America and the 4-H. He was keenly interested in preserving the environment and loved heading off to hike.
å¦   "Mom, how's the wildlife doing?" he would write in letters from his overseas postings.
å¦   Wilson, 21, of Maurertown, Va., was killed Aug. 27 during combat operations in Paktika. He was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   Wilson was recruited from West Virginia University, where he studied wildlife and fishery management. Wilson ran track and played basketball in high school, which he graduated in 2004. He also was a Boy Scout and served on the council of Mount Zion Lutheran Church.
å¦   Wilson was "such a great kid, a good, all-around American who was very strong in his faith," said his cousin Terry Barker. "He lived what he believed."
å¦   "This is what Thomas wanted to do, to serve his country," said neighbor Susan Fleming. "His mom told me, 'In my eyes, he will always be a hero.'"
å¦   "He always had a smile on his face," Fleming said.
å¦   He is survived by his mother, Julie Elizabeth Hepner, and his father Tom Wilson.

ServiceUnit: 585th Engineer Pipeline Company, 864th Engineer Battalion, 555th Engineer Brigade
IncidentDetails: Died Aug. 28 in Jaji, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered from an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Boxing coach Leo Montoya said ever since Rocky H. Herrera started punching around at age 8, he knew the kid was special. He was sharp. He was well-behaved. And he never had a hair out of place.
å¦   Herrera went on to fight in several states and earned his nickname "The Rock."
å¦   "He used to hit like a rock," said Montoya. "He used to have a beautiful stand and beautiful jab."
å¦   Herrera, 43, of Salt Lake City, was killed Aug. 28 by a bomb blast in Jaji. He was assigned to Fort Lewis and had done a tour in Iraq. His specialty was as an engineer, helping to build roads and bridges in Afghanistan.
å¦   He loved grilling steaks, the Chicago Cubs and drinking Budweiser with his brother. Other loves included hunting deer and fishing, and betting on football; his favorite team was the Miami Dolphins.
å¦   Tony Thompson, who had known Herrera since kindergarten, said he used to be picked on by bullies at school and Herrera taught him "how to stick up for myself."
å¦   "He always watched out for me," he said.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Traci; daughter, Clarissa, 16; stepdaughter, Tristan, 20; and sons Matt, 22, and Mark, 20.

ServiceUnit: 585th Engineer Pipeline Company, 864th Engineer Battalion, 555th Engineer Brigade
IncidentDetails: Died Aug. 28 in Jaji, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered from an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Cory L. Clark had a sharp sense of humor, said his grandmother, Gladys Randell. Clark nicknamed his sister Ediena "Monkey." He dubbed his older brother Markis "Ugly." He called himself "Handsome."
å¦   "If you met Cory," Randell said, "you would never forget him."
å¦   Clark, 25, of Plant City, Fla., was killed Aug. 28 by an explosion in Jaji. He was a 2000 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Lewis. He had also served in Iraq.
å¦   "Everybody loved him," said Wrenita Codrington, Clark's mother. "He laughed all the time. I can't believe I won't see his smile again."
å¦   His giggle lingers. "I keep hearing him laugh," said his sister, Ediena McGee. "I keep hearing his voice."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Monica, and his four children, Malik Mitchell, 6; twins Cory Jr. and Quinton, both 3; and Kar-Yhana, 9 months.
å¦   Wrenita Codrington, Clark's mother, said that although her son received commendations and combat medals, he preferred a simpler domestic life.
å¦   "He enjoyed quiet time, to stay home and cook," Codrington said. "He enjoyed his family. He enjoyed that the most."

ServiceUnit: Headquarters Support Company, 864th Engineer Battalion, 555th Engineer Brigade
IncidentDetails: Died Aug. 28 in Jaji, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered from an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Army Capt. Eric A. Parthemore got a taste of Bryce D. Howard's sense of humor during a session at Yakima Training Center.
å¦   Parthemore recounted watching Howard carefully instructing younger soldiers about the intricacies of surveying and road building, among Howard's primary duties in Afghanistan.
å¦   Parthemore, new to the engineering unit he was commanding, then walked up and introduced himself to Howard, saying, "Wow, you have to be pretty darn smart to do this stuff."
å¦   Howard raised an eyebrow, smiled that mischievous smile and replied: "No, sir. Just smarter than you."
å¦   Howard, 24, of Vancouver, Wash., was killed Aug. 28 from wounds suffered from an explosive in Jaji. He was a 2001 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Lewis.
å¦   His father, Dean, said his son "had a smile that could get him out of trouble."
å¦   Bryce was killed while deployed on his second tour in Afghanistan. In his spare time he enjoyed spending time with his family, riding his motorcycle and playing basketball. He planned to become a surveyor after leaving the military.

ServiceUnit: 1st Brigade, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Died Aug. 27 at Forward Operating Base Naray, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered when insurgents attacked their unit during combat operations in Jalalabad, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Henry S. Ofeciar volunteered to be deployed to the Middle East, just as he did twice in the mid-1990s for peacekeeping missions in Bosnia.
å¦   "He passed away in the hands of what he loved, serving, and he's always very, very proud to serve his country," said Ofeciar's mother, Agnes San Nicolas Rillera.
å¦   Ofeciar, 37, of Agana, Guam., was killed Aug. 27 when insurgents attacked his unit during combat operations in Jalalabad. He was assigned to Fort Riley.
å¦   He attended the University of Guam, where he earned a bachelor's degree in business administration with a minor in military science in 1993. He also had a double master's degree in finance and public administration from Syracuse University.
å¦   Ofeciar's sister, Orlene Ofeciar Arriola, said that what she remembers most about her brother was the way he acted toward others. "He understood the danger of his job. He didn't take any moment for granted," she said.
å¦   Not one to sit behind a desk, Ofeciar volunteered to go to Afghanistan. "He was like the father of the family out there," his mother recalled.

ServiceUnit: 55th Brigade, Pennsylvania Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Died Aug. 27 at Forward Operating Base Naray, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered when insurgents attacked their unit during combat operations in Jalalabad, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Scott R. Ball, a motorcycle patrolman and training officer, was a well-liked, charismatic leader who mentored many new troopers, said his supervisor.
å¦   "We looked to him to put his stamp on our younger members because we wanted them to emulate his performance," said Sgt. Jonathan Mays. "We look to the best among us to fill that role as an educator and he certainly was one of those. He's going to be sorely missed."
å¦   Ball, 38, of Mount Holly Springs, Pa., died Aug. 27 when insurgents attacked his unit during combat operations in Jalalabad. He received an associate's degree from Harrisburg Area Community College and was assigned to Scranton.
å¦   Ball was an active soldier in the Army during the Gulf War, where he served as a paratrooper and enlisted in the National Guard when the war ended. He also served as a state trooper for eight years, including three in the motorcycle unit.
å¦   "He was just a great guy a personal guy that could get along with anybody," said Trooper Brian Livingston of the motorcycle unit.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Leslie, and their children, Tyler, 10, and Allie, 6.

ServiceUnit: 55th Brigade, Pennsylvania Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Died Aug. 27 at Forward Operating Base Naray, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered when insurgents attacked their unit during combat operations in Jalalabad, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Jan M. Argonish's bravery was noted even as a young boy.
å¦   "Even at the ages of 9 and 10 in the neighborhood, Jan Argonish kind of ran things," said Monsignor Peter Madus. "Jan looked out for other kids, and he was a natural born leader."
å¦   Argonish, 26, of Peckville, Pa., died Aug. 27 when insurgents attacked their unit during combat operations in Jalalabad. He was assigned to Scranton.
å¦   Argonish graduated from high school in 1999 _ where he played football and was a member of the swim team _ and worked as a correctional officer in Waymart. He received a Bronze Star after a tour of duty in Iraq and had been assisting the Afghan National Army.
å¦   "I've known Jan since he was a little boy," said Joe Weston, a neighbor. "He was always willing to help, always friendly and he was such a good athlete."
å¦   An avid outdoorsman, Argonish enjoyed hunting, fishing and riding motorcycles and all-terrain vehicles with his son, Jakub, 8, and Talia Walsh, whom he planned to marry.
å¦   He loved country music and classic cars, and attended a car show in Atlantic City, N.J., with his father every February.

ServiceUnit: 31st Medical Support Squadron
IncidentDetails: Airman Master Sgt. Patrick D. Magnani, 38, Martinez, Calif.; died Tuesday near Bagram, in a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
Patrick D. Magnani was stationed in Spain, England, Germany, Spain, Italy, South Korea, Greenland and Washington D.C., adapting to life wherever he was.
å¦   "He just never had a bad attitude," said his twin brother, Christopher Magnani. "He always looked forward to places he was going. He volunteered for places that most people probably wouldn't, without hesitation and without apprehension."
å¦   Magnani, 38, of Martinez, Calif., died Sept. 4 near Bagram, Afghanistan, in a non-combat incident. He was a 1987 high school graduate and was assigned to Aviano Air Base, Italy.
å¦   He still holds two high school records in track _ 15.4 seconds in the 110-meter hurdles and 41.4 seconds in the 300-meter hurdles.
å¦   While serving abroad, Magnani made the most of opportunities to indulge his interest in history and other cultures. He was particularly fond of castles and, though not a big drinker, Belgian beer.
å¦   "He became a world traveler," said his mother, Jeanne Magnani. "Because he traveled so much, he had a lot of friends in a lot of places."
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Thomas.

ServiceUnit: Arizona Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 6 in Zabul Province, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained during combat operations.
Bio:
On patrol in Afghanistan, Mykel F. Miller was surrounded by children when he brought them something exotic and delightful: An Etch-A-Sketch.
å¦   "He was mobbed by Afghan children," wrote Sgt. 1st Class Steven Bowers, Miller's platoon sergeant in Afghanistan. "It was like magic to them. They seemed more amazed by its ability to erase by shaking it than anything, and Miller relished showing it to Afghan children."
å¦   Miller, 19, of Phoenix, was killed Sept. 6 in Zabul Province combat operations. He was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Phoenix.
å¦   "Miller would frequently play music for the rest of us, and the entire platoon would chuckle when he would jump upon the hood of the Humvees and begin dancing," said 2nd Lt. Brett Yeater.
å¦   Bowers wrote that Miller would talk endlessly about motorcycles and tease his squad leader, Phoenix Police Officer Marcell Cox, that when he got back to Phoenix he would speed by Cox and see if he could catch him.
å¦   "Every time I was down about something he always knew how to make me smile," said Miller's friend Samantha Ineich.
å¦   He is survived by stepfather, David, and mother, Maria.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 1st Marine Regiment, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Cpl. Travis M. Woods, 21, of Redding, Calif., died Sept. 9 from wounds suffered while conducting combat operations in Northern Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Travis M. Woods' MySpace page is festooned with pictures of him flying through the air, often upside down, on his bike or board.
å¦   "He was awesome. He was funny and fun and always kind of a risk taker," said a friend, Aislinn Anderson. "But after high school he turned into this real man."
å¦   Woods, 21, of Redding, Calif., was killed Sept. 9 during combat in Helmand province. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Pendleton. He had already completed a tour of duty in Iraq.
å¦   Stacey Woods said her son had a passion for BMX bikes, surfing and snowboarding. She said he was a perfectionist, who would practice each sport until he was an expert.
å¦   "Everything he did was big," she said.
å¦   Even his closest friend didn't know how Woods earned a Navy Commendation medal with "Combat V" for valor. He apparently saved the life of a fellow Marine.
å¦   "It was another card he kept up his sleeve," said Woods' friend, Sgt. Nate Hahn.
å¦   Hahn also has stories of Woods' exploits, including slipping a friend laxatives and scaring the daylights out of one of his sister's dates.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Paul.

IncidentDetails: 2nd Lt. Lukasz Kurowski, 28, was mortally wounded in an exchange of fire when a military convoy was attacked some 20 kilometers (12 miles) southeast of its base in the city of Gardez, Minister Aleksander Szczyglo said on TVN24 television.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion (Airborne), 503rd Infantry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Blaskowski died Sunday in Asadabad, Afghanistan, from small arms fire.
Bio:
Only three months after being wounded in 2005 during a six-hour firefight in Afghanistan, Matthew D. Blaskowski returned for his platoon.
å¦   "He wanted to help people, to see it through," said his mother, Cheryl. "He turned around a lot of guys in that platoon. Some were the type that just had no direction and were about out of chances, but he gave them all an opportunity to change. It probably saved their lives later on with some of the things they've been through."
å¦   Blaskowski, 27, of Levering, Mich., was killed by a sniper Sept. 23 in Asadabad. He was a 1998 high school graduate and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   Blaskowski, who played football, basketball and ran track in high school, always wanted to help other people, his mother said.
å¦   "When he was 3 or 4 years old, he was watching one of those Sunday morning TV specials about starving kids," she recalled. "He ran up to our room and was crying that we needed to send them all our money, that they were hungry and we had to help them. That's the way he's always been."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Daniela, whom he met and married while in Italy.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Marine Special Operations Battalion
IncidentDetails: Milam died September 25 while conducting combat operations in Helmand Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Charles Luke Milam graduated from Columbine High School in 1999 _ the year two fellow students attacked the school, killing 12 students and a teacher _ and joined the Navy on June 14 that year.
å¦   "He wasn't shot or wounded or shot at," said his brother, Keith, "but absolutely, it was the defining moment of his life."
å¦   Milam was the first in his family to enter a medical field, dedicating himself to helping people deal with injuries and death in combat situations.
å¦   Milam, 26, of Littleton, Colo., died Sept. 25 during combat in Helmand province. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune and was on his fourth tour of duty. He had served three tours in Iraq.
å¦   "Luke was responsible for the health and well-being of the men in his platoon," Keith Milam said. "He basically served as their doc _ from everyday aches and pains to severe combat trauma."
å¦   Keith Milam said his brother was a "real outdoorsy guy" whose life revolved around backpacking, mountain biking, hiking, canoeing, scuba diving and skydiving. "He loved anything outdoors," said his sister, Jaeme Milam.
å¦   He also is survived by his parents, Michael and Rita.

ServiceUnit: 1st Squadron, 91st Cavalry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Pfeifer died Sept. 25 in San Antonio, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his unit using small arms fire Aug. 17 near Kamu, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Two days after Christopher F. Pfeifer's family disconnected him from life support, his wife gave birth to their baby daughter.
å¦   "It's a really sad day, a sad week. He was a very good person, and we hate to lose him," said Jim Kleffner, a close family friend who grew up with Pfeifer's father.
å¦   Pfeifer, 21, of Spalding, Neb., died Sept. 25 at the Brooke Army Medical Center of wounds suffered from small-arms fire Aug. 17 near Kamu. He was assigned to Schweinfurt, Germany.
å¦   "It was a miracle that Chris even made it back to the United States alive," said his father, Mike. Between whole blood, plasma and platelets, his son needed 90 units to keep him alive.
å¦   Pfeifer worked with his father in Kleffner's shop, People's Service, which makes fuel deliveries to rural customers. While in the Job Corps, he met his wife, Karen.
å¦   Eventually, Chris decided to enlist in the Army, influenced in part by an older brother, who was serving as a Green Beret.
å¦   "He needed direction, and when he met Karen, he found the love of his life," Kleffner said. "I think the service fit him real well."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion (Airborne), 503rd Infantry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 26 in San Antonio of wounds sustained when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle July 23 in Sarobi District, Afghanistan.

ServiceUnit: 726th Finance Battalion, Massachusetts Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Durkin died Friday at Bagram Airfield, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered from a non-combat incident.
Bio:
Ciara M. Durkin was credited last April with helping a contractor who fell more than 26 feet after slipping off a ladder in the building where she worked.
å¦   Her regular duties included making sure the finances of soldiers were in order and that their families were getting benefits.
å¦   "She wanted to be somewhere where she could help," said Fiona Canavan, a sister. "She felt it was an important job."
å¦   Durkin, 30, of Quincy, Mass., was killed Sept. 28 by a gunshot at Bagram Airfield. She was a 1996 high school graduate and was assigned to West Newton.
å¦   Her family left Ireland for America in 1986. She joined the Army National Guard in October 2005 after getting laid off from her information technology job.
å¦   During her recent leave she found time to paint the front and back stairs, mow the lawn and even take out the trash at her sister Deirdre Durkin's home.
å¦   "Ciara was the most wonderful person. She was thoughtful and so helpful. After my husband died she took my children under her wing and really looked out for them," said Durkin.
å¦   She also is survived by her mother, Angela.


å¦   BOSTON (AP) _ The U.S. Army has ruled that the controversial death of a Quincy soldier in Afghanistan was a suicide.
å¦   The family of Ciara Durkin said in a statement on its Web site that the Army has concluded Durkin shot herself in the head in September 2007.
å¦   The family said it was "very upset and saddened" by the finding.
å¦   Durkin's family has said the 30-year-old Army specialist was a passionate person who would never have killed herself.
å¦   Concerns about her death were heightened by an e-mail to friends in which Durkin claimed someone had pulled a gun on her. She also told family that she made some enemies after seeing things she "didn't like."
å¦   They family said the Army initially told them Durkin was killed in action.
å¦   In its statement, the family asked for "privacy to grieve."

ServiceUnit: 4th Squadron, 73rd Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Tellier died Saturday at Firebase Wilderness, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered from small arms fire.
Bio:
Zachary D. Tellier received the Bronze Star with valor for pulling two comrades from a burning vehicle in April. Despite burning his hands in the rescue, Tellier jumped in the turret to return fire, said Army Sgt. Michael Layton.
å¦   "Zachary Tellier has to be the biggest hero I've ever known or heard of, not just because of what he did, but because of his personality," Layton said.
å¦   Tellier, 31, of Charlotte, N.C., died Sept. 29 at Firebase Wilderness from small-arms fire. He graduated from American University in 1998 and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   In high school, he worked for Manchester Community Television in New Hampshire and taught children at the German Language School. In 1993, Tellier was chosen to participate in a student exchange program in Poland, where students produced documentaries to learn each other's languages and cultures.
å¦   He loved camping, roughhousing, playing "Risk" and laughing with his brothers, James and Dan, and giving "helicopter rides" to his youngest brother and sister, Sam and Hannah.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Sara.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Marine Regiment, 3rd Marine Division, III Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Cannon died Tuesday during combat in Kunar province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Mark R. Cannon, a medic who stood 6-foot-5 and weighed 250 pounds, would take the time to patch up Iraqi kids.
å¦   "He was kind of a softie on that," said his father, Tom. "I mean, as big as he was, he had a real soft, tender side to him, and he loved kids, and he loved helping people."
å¦   Cannon, 31, of Lubbock, Texas, was shot Oct. 2 while giving medical aid to a wounded Marine in Kunar province. He was a 1994 high school graduate and was assigned to Marine Corps Base Hawaii.
å¦   Prior to his tour in Afghanistan, he served in Iraq and volunteered to tend to sick and wounded Marines in another war zone.
å¦   "He was very proud of his time in Iraq. He didn't want to push papers," said his uncle, Bob Orf.
å¦   The Rev. Margaret Austin said he made regular trips to her church, occasionally to visit his mother's grave. "He'd pop into my office and give one of those bone-crushing hugs," she said.
å¦   "I would tell him all the time, 'It's an honor to know you,'" said family friend Kelly Whitman.
å¦   "He had a hell of a big grin and a big laugh _ that's what I'm going to miss most," Tom Cannon said.

ServiceUnit: Headquarters and Headquarters Company, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Quinn died Oct. 6 at Forward Operating Base Phoenix, near Bagram, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
Adam D. Quinn always stressed the importance of enjoying life and even had the words "eat, drink and be merry" tattooed on one wrist and "for tomorrow we may die" on the other.
å¦   Quinn, 22, of Orange City, Fla., was killed Oct. 6 near Bagram when an explosive detonated near his vehicle. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   "Adam loved to joke around and just have fun. It didn't seem like much ever got him down," said Spc. Shawn Dempsey. "If he saw you down, he knew just what to say to get you back in a good mood."
å¦   Quinn, a paratrooper and an automation specialist, is survived by his wife, Faye. The couple's first child is due in March.
å¦   "He had a wonderful sense of humor. He was so funny," Faye Quinn. "He was really excited, very proud to be a father."
å¦   Quinn's 19-year-old brother Asa, said "nobody will ever forget him."
å¦   "He made you laugh," Asa Quinn said. "He was just this goofy kid."
å¦   Adam Quinn planned to make a career out of the military, his brother said. "He loved doing what he was doing _ jumping out of perfectly good airplanes."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503rd Airborne Infantry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentLocation: Sawtalo Sar Mountain, Kunar Province, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: Died Oct. 23 in Sawtalo Sar Mountain, Kunar Province, Afghanistan, of wounds when he was engaged by enemy small arms fire during combat operations.
Bio:
Larry I. Rougle was on his third tour in Afghanistan. He also had completed three tours in Iraq. He felt he owed his country something _ his brother said that the military "straightened him out 180 degrees."
å¦   "It was the best thing for him," David Rougle said. "He was proud to serve. He believed in what he was doing. And he would debate with anyone who said anything differently."
å¦   Larry Rougle, 25, of West Jordan, Utah, was killed Oct. 23 by small-arms fire in Sawtalo Sar Mountain. He was stationed in Italy.
å¦   "My Larry was always pretty happy. He smiled; he was just the greatest," said his mother, Nancy Rougle.
å¦   He also is survived by his former wife, Jackie Rougle and their daughter, Carmin, 3. "I couldn't ask for a better dad for my little girl," she said.
å¦   "He was a very proud soldier and loved what he did," said Rougle's aunt, Char Rodriguez. "He was a young man full of dreams that have now come to a stop."
å¦   David Rougle said he had discussed with his brother the possibility that this tour might end badly. "He knew the stakes," David Rougle said. "He just said, if I get waxed, don't let there be any drama in the family."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 263rd Armor Regiment, South Carolina National Guard
IncidentDetails: Philpot, 38, of Latta, S.C., was killed Oct. 23 when his vehicle rolled over northwest of Kandahar.
Bio:
Edward O. Philpot's sister said she heard from other soldiers in his unit that he was quick to volunteer for missions and duty.
å¦   "When they asked for volunteers, they said his hand was the first to go up, especially if it meant one of the other soldiers would have the opportunity to go on leave and see his family," said his sister, Renee Crockett.
å¦   Philpot, 38, of Latta, S.C., was killed Oct. 23 when his vehicle rolled over northwest of Kandahar. He was a graduate of Coastal Carolina University in Conway and was based in Mullins.
å¦   In a note to his mom, Edward said he was proud to be part of the U.S. effort in Afghanistan, where he was working to help train the Afghan police. He said he was making a difference, especially for the children, both over there and in the U.S.
å¦   "I would like to help the children over here," Edward said in the note.
å¦   "When we asked, he always said he didn't need anything, but he wanted candy and things for the local Afghan children," said his sister.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Stephanie, and three daughters _ Hollen, 9, Lily, 5, and Ella Grace, 1.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503rd Airborne Infantry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died of wounds sustained when they came in contact with enemy forces using RPG, machine gun and small arms fire during combat operations on Oct 25, in Korengal Valley, Afghanistan. The soldiers were assigned to the 2nd Battalion, 503rd Airborne Infantry R
Bio:
Joshua C. Brennan and his mother, Janice Gates, communicated through Gates' MySpace page. After Brennan's platoon sergeant died, she posted the song, "Heaven Was Needing a Hero," to comfort her son.
å¦   "Never in my wildest dreams did I know heaven was needing him, too," Gates said.
å¦   Brennan, 22, of Ontario, Ore., died Oct. 26 in Asadabad of injuries suffered from small-arms fire the day before in Korengal Valley. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy. Brennan was on his second tour of duty in Afghanistan.
å¦   Brennan was wounded in the leg in early August. "Within days of being shot, he was insistent he wanted to be back out with his men," Gates said. "He wanted to make sure they were OK."
å¦   In high school, Brennan ran the hurdles, played football and hunted elk. After the military, Brennan intended to attend college and pursue a career in forensic science or criminology.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Michael Brennan, and stepfather, Jared Cutler.
å¦   "He was just such a responsible young man," she said. "I know he would have done absolutely amazing things in his life."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503rd Airborne Infantry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died of wounds sustained when they came in contact with enemy forces using RPG, machine gun and small arms fire during combat operations on Oct 25, in Korengal Valley, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Friends of Hugo V. Mendoza remember him as a person who loved to sit around and discuss philosophy.
å¦   "He loved religion and trying to find the answers to age-old questions," said Christi Ramirez, a childhood friend. "He was a very loving soul."
å¦   Mendoza, 29, of Glendale, Ariz., was killed Oct. 25 of small-arms fire in the Korengal Valley. He was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   "My brother gave his life for another," said his brother, Jesus Carlos Mendoza Jr. "He was trying to save another gentleman, Army brother's life."
å¦   Born in California, Hugo Mendoza spent most of childhood days in El Paso, Texas. As a high school junior, he moved to Phoenix 12 years ago. He worked in sheet metal construction after graduating from high school.
å¦   "Once he got money for being in service, he was going to use it to go to school and follow his dream of being a firefighter," his brother said.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Jesus Carlos Mendoza Sr., and his mother, Sara.
å¦   "He had an infectious smile," his brother said. "He treated you the way you wanted to be treated. He was very giving of himself and his time, especially recently."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 1st Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Died Oct. 27 in Siet, Lake Jolo Island, Philippines from injuries sustained in a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
A swimmer since he was a youngster, Joseph F. Curreri broke many a record while at North Baltimore Aquatic Academy, trained at a Catholic preparatory school until graduating in 1998, and went on to captain the University of Southern California's Trojans swim team.
å¦   Brad Schertle, a fellow swimmer, compared Curreri to Olympic swimmers Mark Spitz and Matt Biondi _ two of the greatest swimmers of all time.
å¦   "When it came to swimming, that's who I wanted to follow," Brad Schertle.
å¦   Curreri, 27, of Los Angeles, drowned Oct. 26 during a training exercise near Panamao in the southern Philippines. Curreri's family was told that he had completed an intensive scuba training mission in Siet Lake, and went back into the water without a tank to look for something he had dropped. He then became disoriented and blacked out while trying to resurface.
å¦   Curreri was not only fast, "he had this aura about him," Schertle said. He had leadership and motivational qualities that you didn't see in an average 14-, 15-, 16-year-old kid, he added. "He had the drive of a Fortune 500 CEO."
å¦   He is survived by his widow, Athena Wickam.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Brigade, 100th Division, U.S. Army Reserve
IncidentDetails: Died Oct. 28, in Kabul, Afghanistan from a non-combat related illness.
Bio:
Thomas L. Bruner liked Christmas so much that he even decorated the inside of the garage.
å¦   "He had reindeer, he had lights, a snowman, a sled," said Bruner's wife, Jane Bruner. "We've always had big Christmases."
å¦   Bruner, 50, of Owensboro, Ky., died Oct. 28 in Kabul from what is believed to have been a heart attack. He was on his second deployment to Afghanistan.
å¦   "He was just a soldier doing his job and he loved it," said his wife.
å¦   He was assigned to Owensboro. Bruner was on active duty from 1975 to 1979, followed by 26 years in the Army Reserve beginning in 1981.
å¦   "He knew his guys," said Patrick Rowe, training coordinator at the Owensboro Army Reserve Center. Bruner knew his men's attitudes, where they stood in their careers, their abilities and what they could handle. "You could ask him anything about anybody."
å¦   Brian Sandefur, one of Bruner's two stepsons, said he was never treated like anything but Bruner's own son. "He was always there," Sandefur said. "He was a good father, husband and friend."
å¦   "He spoiled me rotten. He would do anything for me," Jane Bruner said. "He was my everything."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 20th Special Forces Group (Airborne), Massachusetts National Guard
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 29 in Kajaki, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated while he was on dismounted patrol.
Bio:
Jeffrey R. Calero commanded a group of Special Forces in 2002 who all had previously fought alongside each other. Even so, Calero fit in easily with the group.
å¦   "He was a great professional and commanded a lot of respect from the men," said Lt. Col. Randy Zeegers. "These guys served together for a long time, so it is hard to move in with a new group of guys during combat, but he did a fantastic job."
å¦   Calero, 34, of New York City, was killed Oct. 30 in Kajaki from an explosive. He was assigned to Springfield and was on his second tour of Afghanistan.
å¦   He attend Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in upstate New York, where he earned a degree in mechanical engineering in 1996. He also had done a tour in Korea.
å¦   He was working for Manhattan-based FSI Architecture as an engineer and living on East 80th Street in Manhattan when he was activated June 18, his father said. Army officials sent him to Nevada for special training before he went overseas.
å¦   In his high school yearbook, the slogan underneath Jeffrey's picture read, "Live free or die." He is survived by his parents, Raymond and Roselle.

ServiceUnit: South Carolina National Guard's 1st Battalion, 263rd Armor Battalion
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 30 in Sperwan Ghar, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his unit using RPG rounds, machine gun fire, mortars and small arms fire during combat operations.
Bio:
James D. Bullard's childhood hero was Superman. He wore a cape made from a towel as a kid and collected comic books starring the super hero as an adult.
å¦   And the final song played at his funeral was the "Superman" theme.
å¦   Bullard, 28, of Marion, S.C., was killed Oct. 30 in Spearwan Ghar by machine-gun fire, mortars and small-arms fire. He was assigned to Marion.
å¦   Like Clark Kent, Bullard could be mild-mannered. But he was ready for action whenever he was needed, said the Rev. Mike Watkins.
å¦   "Even as a young child, he wanted to right evil," Watkins said.
å¦   Before being deployed on active duty, Bullard worked as a grocery manager for a Food Lion. He attended Florence-Darlington Technical College.
å¦   Bullard leaves behind Amber, his wife of about a year, and their son, 8-week-old Kristopher Hayden Bullard.
å¦   "He was in for 11 years and he died doing what he loved," said his brother-in-law, Harold Caldwell. "His family made him happy. He was a real good family guy."
å¦   Watkins remembered Bullard as someone who cared about the people around him. "David didn't let life get him down," he said. "He enjoyed life; he was full of life."

ServiceUnit: 1st Brigade, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Walls died Nov. 2 in Uruzgan, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his unit using small arms fire during combat operations.
Bio:
Johnny C. Walls' sister held on to a note Walls wrote to her when he was 16 years old. It says, "If I ever called you a Twinkie, it's because you're so sweet."
å¦   Walls, 41, of Bremerton, Wash., was killed Nov. 2 in Uruzgan by small-arms fire. He was a 1985 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Riley.
å¦   "He joined right out of high school," said his sister, Roxana Browning. "He was in Desert Storm in 1990, and he had a tour of Iraq in 2003. He didn't mind going back for another tour. He thought it was his duty."
å¦   As an adult, Walls enjoyed fishing, gardening, cooking, tinkering with his '69 Mustang and spending time with family.
å¦   Walls was always a tough guy, said his brother Harvey. Big for his age, he was a hard-hitting linebacker in junior high. He didn't grow much more, however, peaking at about 5-foot-7 and 170 pounds.
å¦   Harvey remembers the two of them playing football and flying kites. They liked to build model ships, take them down to the bay and blow them up with firecrackers.
å¦   Walls is survived by his wife, Alene; stepson Brent Fitts; and sons Alex and Bradley.

ServiceUnit: Marine Corps Mountain Warfare Training Center
IncidentDetails: died Nov. 9 while conducting combat operations in Aranus, Afghanistan.
Bio:
For three years, Phillip A. Bocks was stationed at the Marine Corps Mountain Warfare Training Center, where his family says he honed his leadership skills while sneaking out to ski whenever possible.
å¦   "He trained people how to survive a winter experience," said Monica Bocks, his stepmother. "He thrived in the Corps."
å¦   Bocks, 28, of Troy, Mich., was killed Nov. 9 during combat operations in Aranus. He was assigned to Bridgeport.
å¦   He moved with his family from Michigan to Truckee, Nevada, when he was in seventh grade. He returned to Michigan to complete high school, and developed a flair for cooking. He then worked for several Detroit restaurants before joining the Marines in 2000.
å¦   In high school, Bocks acted in school plays and was a member of the swim club. "He loved to act, especially in the play, 'Li'l Abner,'" said Monica Bocks.
å¦   "He was a great friend to many of us down here. Even when he was having a bad day, he found a way to make himself and everyone else laugh," said a friend, Jennifer Pickering.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Ken, and his mother, Peggy Bocks.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503rd Airborne Infantry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died of wounds sustained when their patrol was attacked by direct fire from enemy forces in Aranus, Afghanistan, on Nov 9.
Bio:
Joseph M. Lancour was a hunter who was known for being a jokester. He drew attention with local friends after duct-taping the antlers of the first buck he ever killed on top of his Oldsmobile.
å¦   "He was proud of it," his mother, Starla Owens said with a laugh. "That was just Joe. He followed in his own footsteps, to the beat of his own drum. He loved life."
å¦   Lancour, 21, of Swartz Creek, Mich., was killed Nov. 10 during an ambush in Aranus. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   As a little kid, he liked super heroes, especially Batman and the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. His father, Rob, remembered Joe skateboarding as his mode of transportation because he didn't seem very interested in driving, not receiving his license until he was 18.
å¦   Steve Brockelbank, his football coach during the fall of 2003, said Lancour was the team's kicker and defensive end.
å¦   "He was kind of a skinny football player, but he'd go out there and play hard," Brockelbank said. "He'd get knocked around out there a lot."
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Starla Owens, and stepmother, Sue.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503rd Airborne Infantry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died of wounds sustained when their patrol was attacked by direct fire from enemy forces in Aranus, Afghanistan, on Nov 9.
Bio:
Two days before he died, Lester G. Roque posted a message to his wife, declaring his love and his distaste for being away from her.
å¦   "I'm still here, but I wish I could be in your arms instead," he wrote. "I don't wish for you to be here with me, I wanna be there with you."
å¦   Roque, 23, of Torrance, Calif., was killed Nov. 10 during an ambush in Aranus. He was graduated high school in the Philippines and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   Love between Roque and his girlfriend, Leigh, bloomed in the course of a long-distance friendship, mostly through expensive cellular phone calls and the Internet.
å¦   "The first time I saw you, I felt something different," he wrote to her. "It's like no other. I knew you were heaven sent."
å¦   During a two-week leave in the Philippines, Lester discussed wedding plans with Leigh. They were to marry in January.
å¦   "I'm just this regular guy," he wrote. "But with someone special in my life, life is good. I love my Honey! Full time hubby. My home is where she is, where my life is."
å¦   He also is survived by his parents, Antonio and Lisa.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503rd Airborne Infantry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died of wounds sustained when their patrol was attacked by direct fire from enemy forces in Aranus, Afghanistan, on Nov 9.
Bio:
Sean K. A. Langevin met his future wife Jessica when they both worked at a pizza parlor. They married in January 2006 and their first child is due in February.
å¦   "You have your 'shoulda, coulda, wouldas,'" Jessica said. "I don't have those with Sean. I have no regrets. That's where I find a little of my peace."
å¦   Langevin, 23, of Walnut Creek, Calif., was killed Nov. 9 when his patrol was attacked in Aranus. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   Langevin was an inline skater and a snowboarder. He bungee-jumped, tried tandem skydiving and took courses for a couple of semesters at Diablo Valley College. He also was an Eagle Scout.
å¦   Langevin had signed up for the Navy but then broke a wrist snowboarding and didn't join. He eventually settled on the Army.
å¦   Langevin called Jessica daily, sometimes asking her to pray for him before a dangerous assignment. Two days before he died, they managed to talk.
å¦   "It was a half-hour conversation, and the whole time he told me how much he loved me and how much he missed me and the baby," she said. "It was just a great one of our last conversations. That was a good last one."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503rd Airborne Infantry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died of wounds sustained when their patrol was attacked by direct fire from enemy forces in Aranus, Afghanistan, on Nov 9.
Bio:
Jeffery S. Mersman was remembered as a guy who loved mud runs, as an eager fishing buddy and always as a friend.
å¦   "We spent a lot of time fishing," said Abraham Hays, a family friend. "The last time I saw him, he was dressed up in his airborne uniform. I asked him if he was going to stick to it, and he said he was doing just what he loved to do."
å¦   Mersman, 23, of Parker, Kan., died Nov. 10 after his patrol was attacked in Aranus. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   Mersman liked sports, mainly such outdoor activities as hunting and fishing. He also played football in high school. He was on his fourth deployment and was shot by a sniper on his third.
å¦   "Oh, I'm proud of him. He's the best there ever could be," said Mary Ritch, Jeff's mother. "He took care of his sisters so Mom could work."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Lynn.
å¦   "He would do anything for you," said Mark Michelle, a friend. Said Jeff Lynch, Mersman's roommate at Fort Bragg: "His biggest value was his heart."
å¦   "He would always be there if you needed him," he said.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503rd Airborne Infantry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died of wounds sustained when their patrol was attacked by direct fire from enemy forces in Aranus, Afghanistan, on Nov 9.
Bio:
å¦   New Zealand Defense Minister Phil Goff said Monday his nephew was one of six U.S. soldiers killed in eastern Nuristan province in a recent attack.
å¦   Lt. Matthew Ferrara was born in the United States and had dual U.S.-New Zealand citizenship, Goff said. He had graduated near the top of his class at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point and had been serving in Afghanistan for about five months.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 10th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: died Nov. 10 in Bagram, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered in Tagab, Afghanistan, when his vehicle was struck by a rocket propelled grenade and small arms fire.
Bio:
Patrick F. Kutschbach followed his mother, Debbie _ a competitive volleyball player and coach _ and became one of two all-state players on his high school's volleyball team in his senior year. They won the section title and made it all the way to the state finals.
å¦   "He was just a very aggressive young man who just enjoyed the competition," said Mitchell Galiyas, the school's athletic director. "Patrick was the type of boy that if he bought into something, you had him heart and soul and he gave it his all."
å¦   Kutschbach, 25, of McKees Rocks, Pa., died Nov. 10 from wounds suffered in Tagab when his vehicle was struck by a rocket-propelled grenade and small-arms fire. He was assigned to Stuttgart, Germany.
å¦   His dedication convinced Galiyas to hire Kutschbach as an assistant volleyball coach after graduating in 2000. He later decided to join the Special Forces.
å¦   "He was the type of person who could make a joke out of anything," said Tim Dorish, a friend. "You could be in the worst situation in the world and Pat would find a way to make you laugh."
å¦   Kutschbach is survived by his wife, Ginger, and son Bastian, 1.

ServiceUnit: st Squadron, 91st Cavalry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died Nov. 12 in Bermel, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when the vehicle they were in was struck by an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
David A. Boris' sister remembers him as a guy so determined to attend West Point that he underwent a battery of medical tests to prove his fitness when he failed a physical because of a benign heart murmur.
å¦   "He was my rock. I could turn to him for anything," said Jennifer Possinger.
å¦   Boris, 30, of Pottsville, Penn., was killed Nov. 12 by a roadside bomb in Bermel. He was a 1999 graduate of the U.S. Military Academy and was assigned to Schweinfurt, Germany.
å¦   "If you talk about leadership and character, that's Captain Boris," said Joseph Opalenick, his former principal. "He had a passion for teaching. He would have been an excellent professor at West Point."
å¦   In high school, Boris was the senior co-captain of both the swim and soccer teams. He was a member of the National Honor Society and president of the Spanish club. He also worked on the newspaper and a literary magazine.
å¦   "He was very bright, but he was also one of the guys. You always remember those who were special," said Ned Hampford, Boris' high school swimming coach.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Jaime.

ServiceUnit: st Squadron, 91st Cavalry Regiment, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: died Nov. 12 in Bermel, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when the vehicle they were in was struck by an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
In Adrian E. Hike's high school yearbook, the young man stood out. While most of his classmates were shown close-up with a colorful background, Hike was pictured kneeling on the roof of his workplace sporting a cap worn backward.
å¦   "I am Batman," the caption read.
å¦   Hike, 26, of Callender, Iowa, was killed Nov. 12 when his vehicle hit a roadside bomb in Bermel. He was a 2000 high school graduate and was assigned to Schweinfurt, Germany.
å¦   It was the second tour in the Middle East for Hike, who in 2005 was awarded a Purple Heart after he was injured while serving in Iraq.
å¦   "He recovered fine," said his brother, Martin Bird. "When he came back he looked like himself."
å¦   Martin Bird said his brother enjoyed fishing and hunting. "I want everyone to remember his smiles, his laughs, to remember the happy times with him," said his mother, Kim Bird.
å¦   Said former employer Darwin Otto, "His goal was always to strive for the best. That's why he ended up what he is, because that's what he wanted to be. He wanted to do something with his life."
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Robert Bird.

ServiceUnit: 122nd Aviation Support Battalion, 82nd Combat Aviation Brigade, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Nov. 13 in Bagram, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered in a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
Stuart F. Liles was a quiet, reflective person, who classmates and professors describe as intelligent and kind. Graduate student Sara Harvey said she thought of Stuart as profound but reserved in the classes she shared with him.
å¦   "Some days he wouldn't say anything, but when he did speak, it was something you thought about all day," Harvey said.
å¦   Liles, 26, of Hot Springs, Ark., died Nov. 13 in Bagram of injuries sustained in a non-combat related incident. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Liles was born in Germany while his father was serving in the U.S. Air Force. "His father's service had a lot to do with Stuart enlisting," said Nick Golleher, a friend since seventh grade.
å¦   "His courage and sacrifice in Afghanistan will never be forgotten. I join Arkansans in offering my prayers and expressing my sympathy to the Liles family," said Sen. Mark Pryor.
å¦   Liles is survived by his wife, Aubre, and his daughter, Aurora, 2.
å¦   Victoria Vela, who knew him both in college and high school, said she thought of him as dedicated to family. "He was wild about his little girl. She meant the world to him," Vela said.

ServiceUnit: USS Port Royal
54th Quartermaster Company, 49th Quartermaster Group, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: BAGRAM AIRFIELD, Afghanistan ‰ÛÒ A Coalition servicemember died Dec. 11 in Kandahar Province from noncombat related circumstances.
Bio: Staff Sgt. Gregory L. Elam, 39, of Columbus, Ga., died Dec. 11 in Kandahar, Afghanistan, as a result of a non-combat related illness.  He was assigned to the 54th Quartermaster Company, 49th Quartermaster Group, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault), located at Fort Lee, Va.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 508th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Cpl. Tanner J. O‰ÛªLeary, 23, of Eagle Butte, S.D., died Dec. 9 in Musa Qal‰Ûªeh, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated.
Bio:
Tanner J. O'Leary was a good student with a keen interest in biology,
å¦   "Teaching him made me go home and want to teach better, because he just ate it up," said Chris Bohlander, who taught science. "He was hungry to learn."
å¦   O'Leary, 23, of Eagle Butte, S.D., was killed Dec. 9 by an explosive in Musa Qal'eh. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   "You know he was rough and ready, rambunctious, a take-no-prisoners kind of guy," said Sandra LeBeau, a family friend.
å¦   O'Leary, an enrolled member of the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe, had one daughter, Alexis, 4. He attended Northern State University in Aberdeen before joining the Army in 2005.
å¦   In high school he competed in football, basketball and track. He was in school plays and active in the community.
å¦   Bohlander will cherish memories of O'Leary's infectious smile that usually hinted "he was coming up with a zinger."
å¦   His grandmother Arlene O'Leary said he worked hard on the ranch, at school and at life. "He was my happy little clown," Arlene O'Leary said. "He was a trickster. I loved him so much from infancy."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade
IncidentDetails: died in Afghanistan from wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
As a staff sergeant, Michael J. Gabel could have traveled in the back of the convoy, but chose to ride in the lead vehicle.
å¦   "That was Mike," said Gabel's high school friend, Terrence Zeringue. "He wasn't the type of person who would rather put other people's lives in danger. He would protect others before he would protect himself."
å¦   Gabel, 30, of Crowley, La., was killed Dec. 12 by a roadside bomb at Forward Operating Base Curry, Afghanistan. He was assigned to Camp Ederle, Italy.
å¦   Gabel, who struggled with dyslexia and asthma and was built like a "string bean," pushed himself to excel. A graduate of the Louisiana Culinary Institute, Gabel spent two years honing his craft in France and learning French.
å¦   He used his skills as a chef to put on parties for friends and family. He saw a sense of purpose in the Army and, in particular, in helping the Afghani people to understand the United States.
å¦   "He was one of those guys that just kept plugging and plugging and plugging and made himself into something," wrestling coach Bill Bofinger said.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, John and Catherine.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade
IncidentDetails: died in Afghanistan from wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Joshua C. Blaney got a G.I. Joe cake for his fifth birthday. He would pitch a tent and play Army with his uncle, who was in the Special Forces. They would eat MREs.
å¦   "There was the time at Wal-Mart," said his mother, Dianne Massey. "He was 8, or 9. We walked out, and he had this bulge in his pocket. I asked him, 'Josh, what's in the pocket?' Out comes the G.I. Joe. I marched him right inside and made him give it back."
å¦   Blaney, 25, of Matthews, N.C., was killed Dec. 12 by a roadside bomb near Forward Operating Base Curry. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Ederle, Italy.
å¦   He began his first tour of duty in March 2003 with a combat jump into northern Iraq. Later that year, a roadside bomb sent shrapnel into his leg, and he was awarded the Purple Heart.
å¦   In February 2005, he began the first of two tours of Afghanistan. He had recently re-enlisted for two more years. "He told me he would make a career out of it," Massey said. "He told me the Army would give him the discipline he needed, the focus he needed to figure out what he wanted to do with his life."
å¦   He also is survived by his stepfather Eric, and father, Charles Blaney.

ServiceUnit: 5 Combat Engineer Regiment
IncidentDetails: Cpl Gonthier was killed at approximately 1:40 p.m. Kandahar time on January 23, when the armoured vehicle he was in struck a suspected Improvised Explosive Device (IED), 35 km south-west of Kandahar City.
Bio: Born in QuÌ©bec, Corporal Ìätienne Gonthier joined the Canadian Forces on July 21st, 2004. A Combat Engineer, Ìätienne‰Ûªs was a member of 5 Combat Engineer Regiment, based in Valcartier. He was 21 years old and was on his first tour overseas.

ServiceUnit: 60th Medical Operations Squadron
IncidentDetails: Eischen died Dec. 24 in Bagram Air Base, Afghanistan in a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
Pastor Tim Rolen had known Nicholas D. Eischen since he was about 12 and a first baseman on the Babe Ruth team that Rolen coached.
å¦   Rolen said Eischen was well-mannered with a mischievous side as well: "You knew he was kind of up to something by the smirk on his face."
å¦   Eischen, 24, of Sanger, Calif., died in his sleep Dec. 24 at Bagram Air Base. He was a 2001 high school graduate and was assigned to Travis Air Force Base.
å¦   Mike Vogt, his former football coach, said Eischen was not a star player, but was dedicated to the team and well liked. He played offensive tackle. Jason Baca, a teammate, recalled Eischen bulking up to become a key component of the team his senior season.
å¦   After high school, Eischen attended Fresno City College and worked for two years until he decided to join the Air Force in 2003. He is survived by his wife Leah and had a 2-year-old son, Braeden.
å¦   "His love for his son shows in the fact that 'Dora the Explorer' and 'The Care Bears' were among his favorite television shows," Rolen said. "He was strong, sweet, loyal, happy, patient and caring."

IncidentDetails: A suicide bomber targeting Italian soldiers building a bridge killed Paladini and six Afghans and wounded three other Italian soldiers.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team, Camp Ederle
IncidentDetails: Pfc. Gorham died Dec. 31 at Fort Sam Houston, Texas, of wounds suffered on Dec. 12 in Afghanistan when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Brian L. Gorham's uncle, Charles Rigsby, remembered his nephew being proud to be in the military. Gorham could have been promoted to Ranger because he was such a fast learner, Rigsby said.
å¦   "He was moving up in the ranks in the ROTC and I was told he was one of the fastest learners," said Rigsby. "He took pride in what he was doing."
å¦   Gorham, 21, of Woodburn, Ky., died Dec. 31 at Fort Sam Houston of wounds suffered from an explosive Dec. 12 in Afghanistan. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   The explosion left Gorham with severe burns over more than half his body. Unsuccessful skin grafts and a blood clot complicated the recovery process.
å¦   Gorham was well-liked in the small community where he was raised. "If you were around Brian for very long you would like him," said Jack Wright, a Sunday school teacher at Woodburn Baptist Church.
å¦   Debbie Brown, a church secretary, said Gorham would often arrive at church services wearing his Army ROTC uniform. "I remember that he looked very distinguished and I'm sure he was proud to wear that uniform," Brown said.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Tony and Shirley.

ServiceUnit: 178th Engineer Battalion, 218th Infantry Brigade, South Carolina Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Hill died Jan. 2 in Khowst Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Shawn F. Hill's former football coach remembered him as a hardworking, hard-hitting defensive end, an "all-around good kid" and a good student.
å¦   "The biggest thing about Shawn you remember is that he had one speed and that was full," said Fred Coan. "From the time the game started to the moment it ended he went hard, and he was a hard worker in practice. He was always giving everything he had."
å¦   Hill, 37, of Wellford, S.C., died Jan. 2 in Afghanistan's Khowst province of wounds from an explosive. He was a 1990 high school graduate and was assigned to Rock Hill.
å¦   "Shawn made a difference in his short life, a life that was cut way too short," said U.S. Army Brig. Gen. Robert Livingston. "He made more of a difference than 99 percent of people in this world ever make in their lifetime."
å¦   A self-employed electrician and 12-year member of the Guard, Hill is survived by his wife, Julie Ann, and five sons.
å¦   Hill was someone all soldiers respected and liked, said Lt. Tony Hedrick, his platoon leader: "He was a big guy. Everybody loved him. He was a big part of the heart of the platoon."

ServiceUnit: Headquarters, V Corps
IncidentDetails: They died Jan. 7 of wounds suffered when their vehicle struck an improvised explosive device in Laghar Juy, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Michael L. Green's twin sister said he always looked out for soldiers who didn't have family or friends to go home to over the holidays.
å¦   "He would always bring a stranger to our house for the holidays to eat Thanksgiving dinner," said Michelle Green LeBatard. "He was full of life. He never met a stranger."
å¦   Green, 39, of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, died Jan. 7 in Laghar Juy of wounds sustained when his vehicle struck an explosive. He was assigned to Heidelberg, Germany.
å¦   After graduation from high school in 1989, where he ran track and cross country, Green attended Fairmont State in West Virginia, where he was a member of the school's ROTC unit.
å¦   He was a Green Beret assigned to training troops at Camp Shelby to prepare them to go overseas. He was a fan of Jimmy Buffett and would fly across the nation to catch Buffett's shows.
å¦   Friend Robert Grimmer recalled the first time he met Green, who was wearing aviator sunglasses that were "a size too big" and binoculars around his neck. "The first thing I thought was I need to be friends with that man," said Grimmer.
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Jane.

ServiceUnit: 703rd Explosive Ordnance Detachment
IncidentDetails: They died Jan. 7 of wounds suffered when their vehicle struck an improvised explosive device in Laghar Juy, Afghanistan.
Bio:
James K. Healy was a "Star Wars" fanatic who was nimble with a pen. He designed a T-shirt for his company, as well as the company coin.
å¦   "He loved to draw," said Sgt. Gregory Boyett, who met Healy in explosive ordnance school. "He was a great soldier, dedicated and loyal."
å¦   Healy, 25, of Hesperia, Calif., was killed Jan. 7 in Laghar Juy by a roadside bomb. He was a 2000 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Knox.
å¦   "James will be remembered as a protector of freedom and a patriot of our country," Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger wrote in a statement.
å¦   In a letter he sent to his mother-in-law from Afghanistan a few months ago, Healy wrote about people asking him what he does. He said he replied that he works hard to save lives every second of every day that he is away from his family.
å¦   Dave Olney, Healy's father-in-law, said he was a wonderful husband and father, someone who was dedicated to two things: his family and helping others.
å¦   "Fort Knox is sad one of our own has died," said Ryan Brus, a spokesman for the base.
å¦   He survived by a wife, Shannon, and a 13-month-old son.

ServiceUnit: 508th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Sgt. David J. Drakulich, 22, of Reno, Nev., died Jan. 9 in Chagali, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle struck an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
David J. Drakulich enlisted in 2004 in part to join America's fight against terrorists.
å¦   "Four years ago, he said, 'Dad, I'm going to be an airborne ranger,'" said his father, Joseph. "I was floored by that. He was fearless. He knew what he was doing."
å¦   Drakulich, 22, of Reno, Nev., was killed Jan. 9 by a roadside mine in Chagali. He was assigned to Fort Bragg and was on his third deployment to Afghanistan.
å¦   Recently, he was credited with saving his unit by calling in an air strike from his position as a forward observer.
å¦   "We will always remember him for the funny situations he found himself in, never leaving us with a dull moment, but a good laugh instead," said Sgt. 1st. Class Christopher Hieb.
å¦   He was a 2003 high school graduate and attended Truckee Meadows Community College for two semesters before enlisting. Drakulich planned to return to college when he returned from Afghanistan.
å¦   Drakulich also is survived by his mother, Antoinette.
å¦   "His commitment to the team and dedication to duty are examples for us all to follow. He will be missed," said 1st Sgt. John Condliffe, Drakulich's former first sergeant.

ServiceUnit: Pennsylvania Army National Guard Medical Detachment, Erie Clinic
IncidentDetails: Richard J. Berrettini, 52, of Wilcox, Pa., died Jan. 11 in San Antonio of wounds suffered on Jan. 2 in Khowst Province, Afghanistan, when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Richard J. Berrettini's final months were spent treating comrades and civilians throughout Afghanistan.
å¦   "He enjoyed the mission. He felt he was making an impact, particularly with helping the children there," his brother Nello Berrettini said. "He'll always be a hero to me."
å¦   Berrettini, 52, of Wilcox, Pa., died Jan. 11 in San Antonio, nine days after he was injured by a roadside bomb in Khowst province. He was assigned to Erie.
å¦   As a civilian, Berrettini was a Port Allegheny High School nurse. He was a former active duty sailor and joined the National Guard in 1984.
å¦   Berrettini dressed as Santa Claus to cheer up needy children around Christmas. Even in Afghanistan, Berrettini organized a community clinic for children and raised donations to help get shoes for deprived children.
å¦   "I could see that he touched many with his life," chaplain Louis Kaminski said. "We have a picture of someone who wanted to spend his life healing. He dedicated his life to helping people who were in pain and suffering."
å¦   Berrettini is survived by his wife, Jane, and sons, Vincent, 26, and Christopher, 22.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 3rd Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Died Jan. 25 in Barikowt, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when he encountered small arms fire while conducting combat operations.
Bio:
In high school, Robert J. Miller was on a gymnastics team that went to state, and he helped spark the beginning of a dynasty in that sport. His school has been back to state five times since.
å¦   "I literally had to kick him out of the gym, because he wouldn't stop working out," said Chad Downie, his coach. "He wouldn't rest. He was a really intense guy, a focused guy, and just pushed himself to the limit."
å¦   Miller, 24, of Iowa City, Iowa, was killed Jan. 25 by small-arms fire in Barikowt. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   A former teacher remembered Miller as someone with a strong value system. "He was nice to other people, which is remarkable sometimes in 8th grade," said Peggy Flynn. "He wasn't really aware of peer pressure. Say some kids were going to misbehave in class and it was planned; he wouldn't do it."
å¦   He had spent a year at the University of Iowa but opted for the Special Forces. He became skilled in several languages. "He was this rare kid who took Latin in high school because he thought it would be challenging," Downie said.
å¦   Miller is survived by his parents, Philip and Maureen.

ServiceUnit: 5. Spejdereskadron fra Gardehusarregimentet
IncidentDetails: Denmark's Army Operational Command said the two soldiers killed Thursday in a gunbattle with the Taliban. They were part of a Danish reconnaissance unit that came under fire in Gereshk Valley in Helmand Province.

ServiceUnit: 5. Spejdereskadron fra Gardehusarregimentet
IncidentDetails: Denmark's Army Operational Command said the two soldiers killed Thursday in a gunbattle with the Taliban. They were part of a Danish reconnaissance unit that came under fire in Gereshk Valley in Helmand Province.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Died Jan. 26 in FOB Fenty, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained from small arms fire in Waygul, Afghanistan. Possible friendly fire.
Bio:
Matthew Ryan Kahler, while a young student, scraped together $10 one year so that he could attend an American Indian multicultural event.
å¦   Every year after joining the service, Kahler would send a teacher a card with a $10 bill attached and a note that it should be used to pay the way for another student to attend the event.
å¦   "That was Matt Ryan Kahler," said Ben Lecy, a high school teacher. "He was just a great kid."
å¦   Kahler, 29, of Granite Fall, Minn., was killed Jan. 26 by small-arms fire in Waygul. He was a 1997 high school graduate and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   As a high schooler, Kahler participated in wrestling and competed through pain that would have stopped another's participation, said a friend, Dixon Diebold.
å¦   He was on his second tour in Afghanistan and had completed one in Iraq. He was an avid coyote and pheasant hunter who shielded a younger brother with Down syndrome from taunts and teasing.
å¦   "Matt always looked out for both of us and did everything he could to keep anything bad from happening to us," said his younger sister, Patrice Kahler Luker.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Vicki, and a 4-year-old daughter, Ali.

Pte Costall was killed on March 28, 2006 at the Forward Operating Base Robinson during an attack of Taliban insurgents. Pte. Costall was killed by gun fire originating from a weapon manned by a US Army soldier.
Bio:
Statement Released at the Request and on Behalf of the Costall Family
CEFCOM NR‰ÛÒ07.031 - August 7, 2007

OTTAWA ‰ÛÒ Rob Costall was a true Canadian son who valued life and lived it to the fullest with everything our beautiful country could offer him.  He was the type of person who would hold a door open for a complete stranger, with a smile and a hello.

He should be remembered for holding the door of hope open to the people of Afghanistan.

Remembered not for how he died but rather for what he lived for.  Being Canadian, proud, strong and free.

ServiceUnit: 5 RÌ©giment d‰Ûªartillerie lÌ©gÌ¬re du Canada
IncidentDetails: Gunner Dion was killed December 30, 2007 when the armoured vehicle he was traveling in struck a suspected improvised-explosive device.
Bio:
From the Town of Gatineau, Gunner Jonathan Dion joined the Canadian Forces January 21st, 2005. Proud gunner, Jonathan was a member of 5 RÌ©giment d‰Ûªartillerie lÌ©gÌ¬re du Canada, based in Valcartier, Qc. Jonathan was 27 years old and he was on his first NATO mission.

GATINEAU, Qc - The family of private Jonathan Dion killed in service in Afghanistan on December the 30th 2007, wishes to make public the following declaration:

It is never easy for parents to lose a child. We are devastated by the death of Jonathan who, with dignity, gave up his life serving his country with honour and pride alongside his brothers in arms in Afghanistan. We are extremely proud of our son and of what he accomplished during his life including his career in the Canadian Armed Forces. It will be his distinctive smile and his joie de vivre which will remain in our minds as we think of him. He loved being a soldier and loved being in the company of brothers and sisters in arms.

Jonathan had found his rightful place in the Canadian Forces. He was maturing rapidly and showed that he was living life to the fullest and was developing his full potential. He was an example to all of his family and he was a great brother. Since he passionately believed in his mission in Afghanistan we supported him when he volunteered for this mission. Quite recently he was telling us he would like to return should there be a second tour.

Jonathan lived the major part of his life in the city of Gatineau. He loved his city, his small part of the country, and his neighbourhood. He wanted more than anything else to make a difference in the world around him. He died doing what he loved best, to be a soldier and serve his country.
