ServiceUnit: Alpha Company, 40 Commando Royal Marines
IncidentDetails: Mulvihill was killed by an explosive during combat in a joint ISAF ‰ÛÒ ANA patrol near Sangin.
Bio:
Corporal Damian 'Dee' Mulvihill was born on 5 June 1975 and was from Plymouth. He joined the Royal Marines on 20 September 1998 and completed commando training despite contracting septicaemia towards the end.  After passing out of recruit training, 'Dee' joined 42 Commando Royal Marines where he took part in numerous deployments around the world as well as taking part in OP PALLISER and OP SILKMAN in Sierra Leone and OP BANNER in Northern Ireland. 

During his time at 42 Commando he was promoted to Lance Corporal. He then joined Air Defence Troop in 2002 and completed his specialist training before being promoted to Corporal in December 2003. On completion of his service with the United Kingdom Landing Force Command Support Group, based at Stonehouse Barracks in his home town of Plymouth, he joined Alpha Company, 40 Commando Royal Marines in April 2006. 

'Dee' was a giant of a man who impressed all who met him. Ever cheerful, he would never allow problems to get him down. He always had a friendly word for anyone he met and his fantastic personality filled any room he walked into. He was an excellent listener and would always make time for others.

'Dee' loved his boxing and rugby and represented the Royal Marines at rugby union. He was also a keen water polo player and represented the Royal Navy and the Combined Services team at the sport. 'Dee' was a true character who will be fondly remembered by all who had the privilege to serve with him. Humorous, caring and a true friend, he will be sadly missed by all his comrades in 40 Commando Royal Marines and the wider Corps family. 

'Dee' leaves behind a loving fiancÌ©e and family of whom he talked about to anybody and everybody. He and his fiancÌ©e Lisa were planning to get married in the near future, and our deepest sympathies are extended to Lisa, his parents and all family and friends.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Yorkshire Regiment (Green Howards), Charlie Company
IncidentDetails: Lawrence died at Camp Bastion of wound suffered from an explosive in Kajaki.
Bio:
Corporal Damian Lawrence, aged 25, was born on 26 January 1983 in Scarborough, North Yorkshire, but had his roots firmly based in the town of Whitby. He enlisted into the Army on 28 October 1999 and on completion of his basic training joined the 1st Battalion The Green Howards, 10 Platoon Charlie Company then based in Warminster, Wiltshire. Initially in a rifle company, he spent his first year as a rifleman before being singled out to move to the Reconnaissance Platoon. He went on to complete a Junior Non-Commissioned Officers Cadre in 2005 whilst in 'A' Company and was noted for his diligence and enthusiasm.

Cpl Lawrence continued to develop his leadership and command skills and recently attended the Section Commanders Battle Course in Brecon where he achieved a high pass; he returned to complete pre-deployment training in time to deploy with the Battalion to Helmand Province. Cpl Lawrence's role was to train and mentor an Afghan National Army Platoon ‰ÛÒ a dangerous and difficult task that he performed outstandingly. 

Whilst on Op HERRICK 7, Corporal Lawrence served in Gereshk, took part in the recapture of Musa Qal'eh and conducted operations in Kajaki. A keen and enthusiastic soldier he had served with distinction in Northern Ireland, Kosovo and twice in Afghanistan; his future in the Army was bright. Corporal Lawrence leaves behind a daughter, Jessica.

IncidentDetails: The Army Operational Command says the 21-year-old soldier was killed late Sunday as his unit was getting ready for a drill outside the Danish camp in southern Afghanistan. The army says the shooting was accidental but is not releasing any other details.

ServiceUnit: 6th Military Police Detachment, 1st Battalion, 13th Aviation Regiment
IncidentDetails: Tabb died Feb. 5 in Sangin, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle struck an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Brigadier Gen. David Quantock described Donald T. Tabb as a leader who was always eager to share his knowledge and skills with his colleagues.
å¦   "Although his life was cut short, he lived a life full," Quantock said. "He continued to serve in some of the roughest climates known to man."
å¦   Tabb, 29, of Norcross, Ga., was killed by a roadside bomb Feb. 5 in Sangin. He was a 1998 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Rucker.
å¦   Tabb worked as a handler for a bomb sniffing dog, a 2-year-old black Lab called Bo, who survived the attack.
å¦   Tabb was born in New York City and moved to Georgia at age 18. He attended Fayetteville State University and was on his fifth tour which included Kosovo, Iraq and Afghanistan.
å¦   "He was a serious performer at work, but he had a great personality," Capt. Jay Massey said. "He was very social, a fun-loving guy with a contagious personality."
å¦   He is survived by his mother, Gloria Smith.
å¦   "There was an essential goodness to him and everything he did. He loved his profession, but he loved his family more and always attended to those around him," his family said in his funeral program.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 508th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: They died Mar. 3 in the Sabari District of Afghanistan, of wounds suffered during combat operations.
Bio:
Steven R. Koch was a high school student on Sept. 11, 2001. His older brother, William, was working near the World Trade Center.
å¦   In the agonizing hours he waited to hear from his brother, Steven decided he wanted to join the Army and to fight for his country, his family said.
å¦   "He loved his country. He said he would bleed on the American flag to keep the stripes red," said his mother, Christine Koch.
å¦   Koch, 23, of Milltown, N.J., was killed March 3 by a suicide bomber in Sabari District. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   "He was so determined to be the best," said his wife, Amy. "When he got to the top of something, he wanted to move on. He was going to try for Special Forces. I admired his determination."
å¦   Koch, an avid reader and writer, "always had a smile on his face," according to family members and neighbors. "He was a real jokester," his mother said. "I think that's how he got away from being afraid."
å¦   Koch also is survived by his 18-month-old daughter, Zoe. "She's all him," his wife said. "She's a go-getter. She'll go after something and try and try and try."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 508th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: They died Mar. 3 in the Sabari District of Afghanistan, of wounds suffered during combat operations.
Bio:
Robert T. Rapp had a love of country, a generous heart, an aptitude for sports _ and a mischievous streak.
å¦   "He was a pretty classic teenager," said his mother, Jennifer Rapp. "He was a rascal. Freshman year in high school, he ground up Ex-Lax, put it in his friend's sandwich and was promptly suspended."
å¦   Rapp, 22, of Sonora, Calif., was killed March 3 by a suicide car bomb in Sabari District. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   In high school, he was on the wrestling and cross country teams and on a race team at Dodge Ridge ski area from age 5 to 14. He also enjoyed hunting and golf.
å¦   "No matter where in the world he was, he would always send his mother flowers for Mother's Day and her birthday and Christmas," said his father, Ted.
å¦   Last year, he gave his family instructions for his funeral, including a ceremonial rifle volley and playing of the rock classic "Stairway to Heaven."
å¦   "Let the world know I died doing what I love," he wrote, "and dying for my country is the greatest honor I could ever receive."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 508th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Guzman died March 8 at Orgun E, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device in Gholam Haydar Kala, Afghanistan.
Bio:
While on a recent mission, Gabriel Guzman gave the platoon's radio telephone operator his last bit of water, knowing they still had miles to go.
å¦   "That is just the type of man that he was," said 1st Sgt. Derek Gondek, "his utmost concern was always his paratroopers."
å¦   Guzman, 25, of Hornbrook, Calif., was killed March 8 by a roadside bomb in Gholam Haydar Kala. He took classes at Diablo Valley College and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   On his MySpace page, Guzman wrote that he was an avid reader, reading for leisure and to learn. He said he was trying to read all the classics. Socrates, Confucius and Aristotle were listed among his heroes on the page, as were Bruce Lee and Arnold Schwarzenegger.
å¦   "He was kindhearted and funny, a little sarcastic sometimes, to the point where he came across as arrogant," said Noreen Saima, a friend. "But he was a good guy. He always told it like it was, and even if his friends were different or didn't agree with him, he accepted it."
å¦   "Don't forget him," said a sister, Anni Watson. "Next time you make a joke, think of him and how he found comedy in everything."
å¦   Guzman is survived by his daughter, Angela Haley, 7.

ServiceUnit: Company C, 3rd Battalion, 3rd Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Neil died Saturday in Sperwan Ghar, in Kandahar province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Col. William Hager described William R. Neil Jr. as a loyal, compassionate and fearless leader.
å¦   "His enormous generosity to put others' lives in front of his own drove him to great risks in his missions," Hager said.
å¦   Neil, 38, of Holmden, N.J., died March 22 in Sperwan Ghar when his vehicle struck an explosive. He was assigned to Fort Bragg and was on his second deployment to Afghanistan.
å¦   He graduated high school in 1987, enlisted in the Navy and served for four years. When he returned home, he worked for five years on Wall Street. But he eventually went back into the military, enlisting in the Army in 1998 as a supply specialist.
å¦   "He was always so encouraging and helpful to anyone, friend or not," said Monsignor Eugene Rebeck
å¦   He is survived by his parents, William and Patricia.
å¦   "Billy was a kind and generous person who loved both his family as well as serving his country," said Neil's parents in a statement. "He will be sorely missed by family, friends and his comrades still fighting for the cause Billy so dearly believed in. He is a true patriot who will never be forgotten."

ServiceUnit: 21st Special Tactics Squadron
IncidentDetails: Tech. Sgt. William H. Jefferson, Jr., 34, of Norfolk, Va., died March 22 near Sperwan Ghar, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
With a deep love of skydiving and scuba diving, William H. Jefferson Jr. entered the Marine Corps because he was able to do both.
å¦   "Everybody loved him," said his sister, Tammy Davis. "It didn't matter who he met, he just attracted people. He had a great sense of humor, just a big kid."
å¦   Jefferson, 34, of Norfolk, Va., died March 22 near Sperwan Ghar of wounds suffered when his vehicle struck an explosive. He was assigned to Pope Air Force Base.
å¦   Jefferson, who enjoyed playing Texas hold'em poker and video games, graduated from high school in 1991, where he was a member of the track and swim teams.
å¦   However, after getting married and realizing how much time he was away from his family, Jefferson left the Marines after four years to join the Air Force, where he spent the past 12 years.
å¦   He had earned his bachelor's degree and was working toward his master's. "He wanted to teach high school. He was leaning toward history or government," said Davis.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Kristy, and a daughter, Tyler, 8. Their second child, a daughter to be named Natalie, is due in May.

ServiceUnit: 782nd Brigade Support Battalion, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Robinson died March 19 in Nawa, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained when the vehicle he was repairing collapsed.
Bio:
Antione V. Robinson was renowned for his skill repairing faucets and other items. "Whatever broke down, he'd find a way to fix it," said his grandfather, Cornelius Abraham. "He always wanted to learn how to do different things."
å¦   Robinson, 20, of Detroit, died March 19 in Nawa when the vehicle he was repairing collapsed. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Robinson joined the Army in September 2005 and completed wheeled vehicle mechanic advanced individual training at Fort Jackson in 2005. He completed the basic airborne course at Fort Benning.
å¦   Robinson was "an outstanding Paratrooper, mechanic, son, and brother to us all," said Capt. Victor Diaz, his company commander. "We truly are going to miss his love for life and service to his country."
å¦   Robinson had planned on opening a shop after returning to the U.S. next year, Abraham said. "He was looking forward to doing quite a few things with his life. He was a very ambitious young man."
å¦   He is survived by his mother, Ginger L. Jhons, and his father, Emror Robinson.
å¦   "He was a beautiful person," Jhons said.

ServiceUnit: Marine Forces Reserve‰Ûªs 6th Engineer Support Battalion, 4th Marine Logistics Group
IncidentDetails: Canham died March 23 from a non-hostile incident in Djibouti.
Bio:
Dustin L. Canham grew up shagging baseballs for his brother, Mitch Canham, for hours on end.
å¦   "He hated baseball, but he'd do it every day without question, for 10 years," said Dustin's father, Mark Canham.
å¦   Mitch Canham was a baseball star and attracted scouts when he played for Oregon State University. He was drafted this year to the San Diego Padres.
å¦   Dustin saw his brother's success as a family victory. "Mitch, Dust and I raised each other," Mark Canham said. "When times were hard and their mother was gone, that's what we did."
å¦   Dustin Canham, 21, of Lake Stevens, Wash., died March 23 from a non-hostile incident in the African nation of Djibouti. He was assigned to Portland, Ore.
å¦   He graduated in 2004 from Lake Stevens High School, where he was a member of the Hi-Q academic team. He often had his nose in a science fiction or fantasy book.
å¦   His graphic arts skills were on frequent and high-profile display around campus. Each week during the season, he would design a T-shirt for the football team depicting how the Vikings were going to dismantle their next opponent.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Devyn.

BC-A Marine's Death
AP Exclusive: Corps investigation finds Marine who died at Africa base wasn't hazed or abused
å¦   SEATTLE (AP) _ A Marine was not being hazed or abused when he collapsed and died on a base in Africa, but his superiors broke rules when they had him exercise as punishment for slightly injuring another Marine, a commander concluded.
å¦   Lance Cpl. Dustin Canham chose to do push-ups and other exercises to avoid having a black mark on his record and his death March 23 was due solely to a heart condition, said Lt. Gen. Samuel T. Helland, commander of U.S. Marine Corps Forces Central Command, in a summary provided to Canham's father.
å¦   The Naval Criminal Investigative Service is investigating Canham's death separately, but the Marine report includes some statements other Marines made to NCIS.
å¦   Canham, 21, of Lake Stevens, Wash., and a Marine private had been playing catch with a rock that day at the U.S. base in Djibouti, according to the documents. The private told investigators he looked away just before Canham threw the rock, which hit him in the mouth. It chipped his tooth, but the injury did not require medical attention.
å¦   Platoon Sgt. Jesus Diaz, 24, of Bakersfield, Calif., informed a staff sergeant, who noted that putting the incident in Canham's record could hinder his promotion.
å¦   The staff sergeant recommended that Diaz give Canham a choice of receiving a mark on his record or performing physical training, and Canham chose the latter.
å¦   "(The staff sergeant) and I both felt LCpl Canham was a good Marine, and did not want to have to write him up for this incident," Diaz told an NCIS investigator in a signed statement.
å¦   The names of witnesses were redacted in the file, but The Associated Press independently identified Diaz and the other superior who brought Canham into the tent, Cpl. Richard Abril, 28.
å¦   With Diaz watching, Abril and Canham exercised together in a "daily seven" routine of 30 push-ups followed by leg lifts and other core-body work. Only three minutes after they started, Canham "stopped, went to his knees, sat back on his hips, leaned up against a rack and passed out," Abril wrote in a statement to investigators.
å¦   Diaz ran for help as Abril performed CPR until emergency responders arrived, they wrote. But he could not be revived. An autopsy found a mildly enlarged heart with a thickening of the left ventricular wall, which left Canham vulnerable to cardiac arrest.
å¦   The investigative file makes clear that the use of physical training was not authorized. "Extra military instruction" _ the assignment of extra tasks _ may be given to correct a Marine's shortcomings, but not as punishment, Helland wrote.
å¦   However, he wrote, the training was neither harsh nor abusive and was not the cause of death.
å¦   In letters shortly after Canham died, the Marines told his family he collapsed while exercising, but the letters didn't explain why he was inside the tent with two superiors. Canham's father, Mark, and widow, Devyn, suspected he might have been hazed or forced to work out until he died.
å¦   Mark Canham said he wants to see for himself if Diaz told the truth to investigators.
å¦   "If he could tell me to my face what happened in that tent, then I'd believe it," he said.

IncidentDetails:
COPENHAGEN (AP)--Denmark's military says a Danish soldier has been killed in Afghanistan. 
å¦   The Army Operational Command says another Danish soldier was wounded during the shootout near Gereshk in the volatile Helmand province.

ServiceUnit: Zulu Company, 45 Commando
IncidentDetails: It is with deep sadness that the Ministry of Defence must confirm the deaths of Lieutenant John Thornton and Marine David Marsh, both of 40 Commando Royal Marines, in southern Afghanistan on Sunday 30 March 2008.

ServiceUnit: Charlie Company, 40 Commando
IncidentDetails: It is with deep sadness that the Ministry of Defence must confirm the deaths of Lieutenant John Thornton and Marine David Marsh, both of 40 Commando Royal Marines, in southern Afghanistan on Sunday 30 March 2008.
Lance Corp. Christian Raaschou, 24, was killed in a battle with Taliban fighters north of Gereshk, in southern Afghanistan, during an operation with British troops in Helmand province.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 3rd Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Nicholas A. Robertson died April 3 at the Landstuhl Regional Medical Center in Landstuhl, Germany, of wounds suffered April 2 while conducting dismounted combat operations in the Zahn Khan District, Afghanista
Bio:
In a handful of high school band competition photos and those from a yearbook, Nicholas A. Robertson was wearing a hat in all but one picture.
å¦   "There was never a time when he didn't wear a hat," music teacher Brady Harris said. "It was part of his identity."
å¦   Robertson, 27, of Old Town, Maine, died April 3 at the Landstuhl Regional Medical Center of wounds suffered during combat operations in the Zahn Khan District. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Before joining the Army, Robertson graduated with highest honors from the University of Maine, where he focused on French and classical studies and was a member of the Phi Beta Kappa Society.
å¦   He was named outstanding philosophy student in his 2003 graduating class and then attended graduate school at Northwestern University in Illinois but left to join the Army in 2005.
å¦   Robertson got his first drum set when he was in eighth grade, according to a write-up in a yearbook. "You are the pulse of the band as a drummer; I like the control," Robertson was quoted as saying.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, David and Nancy.

IncidentDetails: In violence elsewhere Tuesday, a Polish soldier died and one was wounded when a NATO patrol hit a roadside bomb in Ghazni province, next to Zabul, Poland's Defense Ministry said.

ServiceUnit: 3 Squadron RAF Regiment
IncidentDetails: SAC Livingstone and SAC Thompson were both extracted to the field hospital at Kandahar Airfield, but sadly died as a result of their wounds.

ServiceUnit: No 504 (County of Nottingham) Squadron Royal Auxiliary Air Force
IncidentDetails: SAC Livingstone and SAC Thompson were both extracted to the field hospital at Kandahar Airfield, but sadly died as a result of their wounds.

ServiceUnit: Combat Logistics Battalion 24, 24th Marine Expeditionary Unit, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Both Marines died April 15 while conducting combat operations in Kandahar province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Maj. Craig Wiggers said Luke J. Mercardante was a leader who exemplified the Latin phrase "ductus exemplo" or leadership by example.
å¦   "He absolutely loved coming to work every day, and training and leading and mentoring those cadets," Wiggers said. "We have lost one of the best."
å¦   Mercardante, 35, of Athens, Ga., was killed April 15 in Kandahar province during combat operations. He was assigned to Camp Lejuene.
å¦   He graduated high school in 1990, earned an associate's degree from Campbell University in 2002 and a bachelor's in business administration from the University of Maryland in 2005.
å¦   He worked as an instructor at the Virginia Military Institute, where he was voted an Honorary Brother Rat of VMI's class of 2007 and Faculty Mentor of the Year 2005.
å¦   Mercardante, was "the glue that held us together," Maj. Keith Owens said. "He helped our small problems from becoming big problems."
å¦   Mercardante, whose right hand was disabled but didn't let that impair his drive and motivation, is survived by a fiancee, Kim Hull, and two children from a previous marriage, Cailin, 13, and Luke Jr., 9.

ServiceUnit: Combat Logistics Battalion 24, 24th Marine Expeditionary Unit, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Both Marines died April 15 while conducting combat operations in Kandahar province, Afghanistan. They were both assigned to Combat Logistics Battalion 24, 24th Marine Expeditionary Unit, II Marine Expeditionary Force, Camp Lejuene, N.C.
Bio:
People first noticed Kyle W. Wilks' height, 6 foot 2 inches, and his large smile. Then they noticed they were talking to him.
å¦   "I think a lot of kids that age have a hard time meeting people if they are not of their own age group, and he was able to talk to just about anybody," said Steve Wilks, an uncle.
å¦   Wilks, 24, of Rogers, Ark., was killed April 15 in Kandahar province during combat operations. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejuene.
å¦   "He was just an outstanding young man that my daughters and grandchildren looked up to," said Terry Mudd, another uncle.
å¦   Wilks worked at a Lowe's after graduation and was a server at Dixie Cafe while in high school. He played trombone in the Elmwood Junior High School band and played football his sophomore year at Rogers High School in 1999-2000.
å¦   "We talked a lot about how military experience would help him get a law enforcement job," said Rogers police Sgt. Kelley Cradduck, who knew Kyle Wilks from New Hope Fellowship Church in Springdale. "He was really looking forward to that opportunity."
å¦   He also is survived by his parents, Randall and Kathy.

ServiceUnit: Armoured Support Company Royal Marines, Queens Royal Lancers Regiment
IncidentDetails: Pearson was driving a vehicle that hit a suspected mine on the way to Camp Bastion.
Bio:
Trooper Robert "Chesney" Pearson, 22, from Grimsby, joined his local regiment, The Queen's Royal Lancers, in early 2007 where he became the driver of a Scimitar Reconnaissance vehicle. He was posted to A Squadron where he took part in Pre-Deployment Training in Viking all-terrain vehicles. He deployed to Afghanistan in January 2008 as part of the Armoured Support Company Royal Marines in support of 52 Infantry Brigade. 

Throughout his training and despite his youth and relative inexperience his potential had already been noted. Trooper Pearson leaves behind his father Paul, stepmother Gillian, and sisters Terrie, Alex and Alivia.

ServiceUnit: 28th Aircraft Maintenance Squadron
IncidentDetails: Jonathan A. V. Yelner, 24, of Lafayette, Calif., died April 29 near Bagram, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Caitlyn Morrow said Jonathan A.V. Yelner was one of the first people she met in South Dakota after moving there from Portland.
å¦   Morrow said she would miss "his uncanny ability to make me smile while telling me the brutal truth. He would tell me the truth in such a way that you couldn't help but smile, even if it hurt a little bit."
å¦   Yelner, 24, of Lafayette, Calif., died April 29 near Bagram when his vehicle hit an improvised explosive device. He was assigned to Ellsworth Air Force Base.
å¦   Yelner left for Afghanistan last December for a one-year mission. Prior to that, he volunteered to provide escort duty to contractors in Iraq. He also served in Guam as a weapons load crew member from late 2005 to early 2006.
å¦   Yelner volunteered for duty in Afghanistan to help locals rebuild and improve their infrastructure, his family said.
å¦   "I'm very proud of him," said his father, Bruce Yelner. "He was performing one of the more nobler duties of the military in Afghanistan. He did a lot of good for the local Afghanis."
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Yolanda Vega.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment
IncidentDetails: David L. McDowell, 30, of Ramona, Calif., died April 29 in Bastion, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked using small arms fire. He was assigned to the 2nd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment, Fort Lewis, Wash.
Bio:
David L. McDowell's conviction wasn't in question: He had been deployed seven times in Afghanistan and Iraq.
å¦   "Down to the last bone in his body, the guy believed in what he did," said Jesse Carlson, who went to high school with McDowell and played football with him.
å¦   "It's very unique to find someone with that kind of conviction," Carlson said. "You can't help but respect the guy and feel about as proud as you possibly can that he's your friend."
å¦   McDowell, 30, of Ramona, Calif., died April 29 in Bastion of wounds from small-arms fire. He was assigned to Fort Lewis.
å¦   Carlson said McDowell was doing military-style endurance training well before he officially joined the service. "He worked harder than anybody I've ever known at making his goals happen," Carlson said.
å¦   Becky McDowell said her brother's passion for military service started early.
å¦   "It was always Army from the time he could walk and talk," she said. "If you weren't talking about the Army, forget it. He didn't want to talk to you."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Joleen; son, Joshua, 11; and daughter, Erin, 3.

ServiceUnit: Household Cavalry Regiment, 5 SCOTS
IncidentDetails: His vehicle hit an explosive while providing protection during a routine patrol in the Nowzad area of northern Helmand.
Bio:
Trooper Ratu Sakeasi Babakobau, 29, from Fiji, joined the Army in 2004 to serve in the Household Cavalry Regiment. He deployed to Afghanistan in April 2008 serving under the command of 5 SCOTS. This was his first deployment on operations overseas. 

He is survived by his wife Camari and two sons, Ratu Seru, aged four, and Ratu Sakeasi Sucumailodoni Selamu, aged one.

ServiceUnit: 4th Battalion, 320th Field Artillery Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: They died May 7 in the Sabari District, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
FORT CAMPBELL, Ky. (AP) _ Two Fort Campbell soldiers killed by a roadside bomb were the first from the 101st Airborne Division to die in Afghanistan.
å¦   The Department of Defense said in a statement Thursday that Spc. Jeremy R. Gullett of Greenup, Ky., and Staff Sgt. Kevin C. Roberts, 25, of Farmington, N.M., were killed May 7 in Afghanistan's Sabari District.
å¦   Both were assigned to the 101st Airborne Division's Fourth Brigade Combat Team at Fort Campbell, a sprawling Army post on the Kentucky-Tennessee line.
å¦   Fifteen other soldiers assigned to tenant units at the post have died in Afghanistan, according to The Associated Press casualty database. They were mostly members of the 5th Special Forces Group or the 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment, known as the "Night Stalkers."
å¦   Gullett's mother, Cheryl Gullet, told The (Ashland) Independent that her son joined the Army in 2003 when he graduated from Greenup County High School.
å¦   "He always dreamed he'd go into the service, ever since he was 6 years old," Cheryl Gullett said.
å¦   The soldier was a member of the high school's Junior ROTC program.
å¦   His unit was deployed to Afghanistan in March, a week before Easter. He previously served 2 1/2 years in Korea.
å¦   Roberts entered the Army in November 2001 and arrived at Fort Campbell in April 2002. He is survived by his wife, Donnice; son, Keeghan; and daughter Caehlen all of Fort Campbell; and his parents, Milton and Gerri Roberts of Farmington, N.M.
å¦   Jeremy Gullet was married and had a 21-month-old daughter with his wife, Janeth, a native of the Philippines, his mother said. He was also adopting his wife's 6-year-old daughter.
å¦   An uncle, Ron Gullett, told the newspaper that the family had been told the soldier's remains would arrive in a week to 10 days.
å¦   The uncle said he will be buried in a family cemetery with military and firefighter rites.
å¦   The soldier had been a member of the Little Sandy Volunteer Fire Department.
å¦   Including Gullet and Roberts, a total of 36 soldiers from Fort Campbell have died in the latest deployments to Iraq and Afghanistan. Since the war started, 237 soldiers from the post have been killed.
å¦   ___
å¦   Information from: The Independent, http://www.dailyindependent.com

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 506th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: They died May 7 in the Sabari District, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
FARMINGTON, N.M. (AP) _ While on leave from his first tour of duty in the Middle East, Army Staff Sgt. Kevin Casey Roberts told those at home about building a playground at an Iraqi orphanage and receiving a warm welcome from several Iraqi citizens.
å¦   "A lot of people were happy," Roberts said in a 2004 interview with The Daily Times. "They would shake your hand and the kids would give you hugs. These were good signs we were there."
å¦   Roberts, 25, was one of two Fort Campbell soldiers killed by a roadside bomb on Wednesday in Afghanistan's Sabari District, according to the Department of Defense. The other soldier was identified as Spc. Jeremy R. Gullett, 22, of Greenup, Ky.
å¦   Both were assigned to the 101st Airborne Division's Fourth Brigade Combat Team at Fort Campbell, a sprawling Army post on the Kentucky-Tennessee line. They were the first from the 101st Airborne Division to die in Afghanistan.
å¦   After his first tour, Roberts _ who went by his middle name _ returned home for a year before being deployed to Iraq for another tour. In March, the former volunteer firefighter was deployed to Afghanistan.
å¦   Born in Farmington, Roberts graduated from Farmington High School in 2000 and entered the Army in November 2001. He arrived at Fort Campbell in April 2002.
å¦   Roberts left his volunteer post with the San Juan County Fire Department to enlist following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
å¦   "I was serving my community and I felt I served my community the best I could, so I thought now I'll serve my country," Roberts told the Daily Times in 2004.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Donnice; son, Keeghan; and daughter Caehlen all of Fort Campbell; his parents, Clayton and Gerri Roberts; and brothers Curby and Jerry all of Farmington.
å¦   "We are proud of his service," said his father, Clayton Roberts. "As a family, we believe in and support military action."
å¦   The family learned about Roberts' death in a phone call earlier this week.
å¦   "You always have that fear in your heart," Clayton Roberts said, "but I have to remember that Casey wouldn't have gone if he didn't feel it was the necessary thing to do."
å¦   Roberts was honored with the National Defense Service medal, the Iraqi Campaign medal and the Global War on Terrorism Service medal.
å¦   Services will be held in Shelbyville, Texas, with interment to follow at Hamilton Cemetery. A memorial service also was being planned in Farmington.
å¦   Including Roberts and Gullett, a total of 36 soldiers from Fort Campbell have died in the latest deployments to Iraq and Afghanistan. Since the war started, 237 soldiers from the post have been killed.
å¦   ___
å¦   Information from: The Daily Times, http://www.daily-times.com

ServiceUnit: 1st Squadron, 61st Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Deysie died May 9 in Paktia province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his unit came under rocket-propelled grenade fire.
Bio:
Ara T. Deysie talked about joining the military when he was just 4 years old, his mother said.
å¦   "Once he decided what he wanted to do, he made sure he got his way and got to do it, and that was to go into the military," said Lori Deysie.
å¦   Deysie, 18, of Parker, Ariz., died May 9 in Paktia province of wounds suffered from an explosive. He was a member of the Colorado River Indian Tribes and was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   Known as Tyler or T-Man, he was described as a quiet young man who was the diplomat in the household, who tried to keep peace with his four sisters. By age 14, he knew he wanted to volunteer for the military.
å¦   "Tyler loved his family with all his heart and would talk about them all the time," said his former girlfriend, Jasmine Delgado.
å¦   Delgado said even though they split up as a couple several years ago, they stayed close friends, and he leaned on her through the death of his father several years ago.
å¦   "I just remember his smile and the way he used to laugh at me," Delgado said. "I just want my love to be shared with everyone else that knew Tyler and loved him as much as I did and still do."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 506th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Palomarez died May 9 in Kapisa province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his patrol encountered an improvised explosive device and came under small arms and rocket-propelled grenade fire.
Bio:
Brett Sandford considered Isaac Palomarez one of smartest people he knew.
å¦   "He would pull out his engineering homework when we were watching 'Monday Night Football' and get it done in a quarter _ and get it right," Sandford said.
å¦   Palomarez, 26, of Loveland, Colo., was killed May 9 in Kapisa province by an explosive and small-arms fire. He was a 2001 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   Palomarez was bright in math and an avid reader who took a few classes at Colorado State University. But he never fully knew what he wanted to study.
å¦   Though smaller in stature, Palomarez played offensive tackle for the 2000 Loveland High School football state champion team. "He was a very intelligent kid," said Marty Gocken, a coach. "He was very team oriented."
å¦   One of Palomarez's passions was Colorado Avalanche hockey. His private e-mail address was "avs2001," commemorating their last Stanley Cup championship.
å¦   He is survived by his father, Candido, and mother, Elma.
å¦   During his last call home, Palomarez told his mother "If I don't get to talk to you again, happy Mother's Day."

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 321st Field Artillery Regiment, 18th Fires Brigade (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Pvt. Matthew W. Brown, 20, of Zelienople, Pa., died May 11 in Asadabad, Afghanistan, from injuries suffered in a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
Relatives and friends honored Matthew W. Brown's wish that they dress "festive" for his funeral and wore colorful shirts.
å¦   "I couldn't ask for a better friend. He also had a great sense of humor. That's why we're wearing these shirts," said Erik Wenzelburger, who spoke at the service.
å¦   Brown, 20, of Zelienople, Pa., died May 11 in Asadabad of injuries from a non-combat incident. He was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   "My son was probably one of the most decent people I have had the privilege to know," said his father, James Brown. "He told me he joined the service because he wanted to help people."
å¦   The last time Brown was home, he gathered a group of friends for a touch football game, writing a list of plays on his wrist band and wearing black tape under his eyes, said Allison Chandler, a friend.
å¦   "Matt was full of life. He had the best outlook on life," said Erik Wenzelburger, a longtime friend.
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Sandy Evans.
å¦   "We all have a little edginess in us, but he had no stitch of meanness in him," said his grandfather, Ron Brown.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 6th Marine Regiment, 2d Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Cooper died May 19 while supporting combat operations in Helmand Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
It was Christmas Eve when William J.L. Cooper told his father he was going to be a Marine.
å¦   "I remember telling him he needed to have a lot of thought before doing this. He felt his country needed him at the time more than he needed school," Alan Cooper said.
å¦   Cooper, 22, of Eupora, Miss., was killed May 19 during combat in Helmand province. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   "He had more friends than anyone I know. He was daddy's hero; now he's everyone's hero," said Alan Cooper.
å¦   He attended one year at Holmes Community College before joining the U.S. Marines in 2006. He served two tours in Iraq. Alan Cooper said he was told his son was one of the best scout snipers the Marines had seen in decades.
å¦   "Coop was that fun-loving, crazy guy everyone liked. He's the one you always wanted on your side because he is always going to take up for you," said Heather Burchfield, a friend. "Even in high school, he had a soldier's heart. He was a very loyal friend."
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Debra.

ServiceUnit: 48th Infantry Brigade Combat Team, Georgia Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Weaver died May 18 in Qalat, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Two weeks before he died, Davy N. Weaver's Humvee was hit and destroyed by an IED similar to the one that killed him. He and two other soldiers suffered minor injuries then.
å¦   "They all got out with scratches and bruises," said Weaver's mother, Patsy Rabuck.
å¦   Weaver, 39, of Barnesville, Ga., was killed May 18 in Qalat by a roadside bomb. He was assigned to Macon.
å¦   Weaver, a saxophone player, loved the outdoors. "Growing up, he was a Cub, Boy and Eagle Scout," said his wife, Susan. "Then he just fell in love with the military."
å¦   His mother said being a soldier was her son's passion. "He just said that he wanted to serve his country and help any way that he could," she said. "If it meant giving up his life, he would do it."
å¦   Weaver also is survived by a daughter, Ella, 2; and two sons from a previous marriage, Bradley Ashton Weaver and Malachi Jon Weaver.
å¦   Weaver spent two weeks in Alabama in January when his eldest son underwent a complicated ear surgery to correct deafness and underdeveloped motor skills.
å¦   "Call it a miracle in the making, but that child is walking and smiling now," Rabuck said.

IncidentDetails: He was patrolling on foot as part of operations in the Musa Qaleh area when he was caught in an explosion and tragically lost his life.

ServiceUnit: the 124th Wing, Idaho Air National Guard
IncidentDetails: Moore died Tuesday of natural causes in Djibouti.
Bio:
Joseph A. Moore's job as full-time chaplain was to counsel any soldier or airman with the Idaho National Guard who needed help or guidance, regardless of denomination _ a job he relished.
å¦   "Art was an outstanding human being," said Lt. Col. Tim Marsano. "He was our 'go-to guy' when a soldier needed help. He was very kind, discreet, caring, lighthearted and fun-loving."
å¦   Moore, 54, of Boise, Idaho, died May 20 of natural causes in Djibouti. He was assigned to Gowen Field, Idaho.
å¦   Marsano said Moore's official denomination was the Southern Baptist Convention faith, but it didn't matter what belief system an airman or soldier had, because Moore was always there to help.
å¦   "I never thought of him as being any specific denomination," Marsano said. "He was the guy you sought out if a buddy needed help."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Sandra, and daughters Rachel Croft and Christina Moore.
å¦   "He enjoyed life, and his family always came first. He loved his family, loved his career, loved Idaho and anybody who knew Art also knew he also loved fishing. We loved Art and we will miss him," a family statement said.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 103rd Armor Regiment, Pennsylvania Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Deprimo died May 20 in Ghazni, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Jeffrey F. Deprimo grew up in camouflage. As a child, he played with GI Joes, dragged his siblings outside to play Army and watched black-and-white war documentaries. One Valentine's Day, he asked his parents for an autobiography of Chuck Yeager.
å¦   Deprimo, 35, of Pittston, Pa., died May 20 in Ghazni of wounds suffered when his vehicle struck an explosive. He was assigned to Williamsport, Pa.
å¦   DePrimo's uncle Ronald Gitkos recalled how DePrimo earned the nickname "Mr. Excitement." As a young child, DePrimo was curious to see what the lever next to his mother's steering wheel did, so he proceeded to pull on it. The car went into a neighbor's yard.
å¦   A 1991 high school graduate, he went on study music at Marywood University, where he graduated cum laude in 1996.
å¦   Family members said they'll remember him as a brilliant, loving person who was dedicated to others and never sought the spotlight.
å¦   "He was so smart, but witty. He'd crack you up. You never were without a laugh or smile when he was around," said his sister, Jodi Calabro.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Joseph DePrimo and Helen Ann Gitkos DePrimo.

IncidentDetails: Gunfire also killed one NATO soldier from Lithuania and wounded another, but it was not clear who shot at them. The Lithuanian Defense Ministry identified the dead soldier as Sgt. Arunas Jarmalavicius, 35, the first Lithuanian soldier killed.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment
IncidentDetails: Lance Corporal James Bateman and Private Jeff Doherty, both of 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment, were killed in Helmand Province, Afghanistan on Thursday 12 June 2008.
Bio:
Private Jeff ‰Û÷Doc‰Ûª Doherty was born in Coventry on 10 June 1988. Joining the Parachute Regiment had long been his passion and he passed out with 699 Platoon from the Infantry Training Centre Catterick, joining 2 PARA in March 2006. 

His deployment with C (Bruneval) Company to Afghanistan on Op HERRICK 8 was his first operational tour. He lived in Southam, Warwickshire with his father at the family home. 

Private Doherty completed the Drill and Duties course for promotion to Lance Corporal in 2007 and given his very strong performance during the early months of the tour he was a firm contender for promotion on return from Afghanistan. 

He was an exceptionally fit and strong Paratrooper, proud in his profession and intent on making every moment count. He had boxed at an amateur level for the Company at light weight during inter company boxing where he had displayed his hallmark tenacity, strength, speed and courage. 

He had a passion for the Parachute Regiment, living life to the full and always living up to the motto Utrinque Paratus ‰ÛÒ he was truly ready for anything. Private Doherty was a morale tonic, he touched all he knew with his infectious sense of humour and ability to lift the veil of darkness from any bleak moment. 

He leaves behind a much-loved younger brother and three sisters.

ServiceUnit: Commander Navy Region Northwest
IncidentDetails: Navy Lt. Jeffrey A. Ammon, 37, Orem, Utah; died Tuesday, as a result of wounds suffered from an explosive in the Aband District, Afghanistan.
Bio:
In Afghanistan, Jeffrey A. Ammon worked to rebuild economic infrastructure through micro-loans. He helped small businesses with restocking, buying business equipment, repairing damage to shops and hiring employees.
å¦   "He felt like he was making a difference," said his mother, Kathleen Ammon. "He really wanted to try a little bit longer to make a difference."
å¦   Ammon, 37, of Orem, Utah, died May 23 of wounds suffered from an explosive in the Aband District. He was attached to Commander Navy Region Northwest and was on his second tour.
å¦   While in the Navy, he earned a degree in 2001 in nuclear engineering from Oregon State University. He enlisted in the Navy in 1988 and spent years as an engineer aboard the nuclear submarine USS Alabama.
å¦   Ammon was a loving, caring man who loved going hiking and camping and the outdoors, said Jim Edwards, Ammon's brother-in-law. Ammon was also a creative thinker whose hobbies were Lego building projects and computers, Edwards said.
å¦   "Give him a box of Legos and he could build you anything," he recalled.
å¦   He is survived by a wife and two children.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Troop of the Armoured Support Company, Royal Marines
IncidentDetails: Gostick was killed in action at the Sangin crossing of the Helmand River. The Viking he was driving struck a suspected mine.
Bio:
Marine Dale Gostick was known by his friends as "master chief general of the universe", which reflected his humorous and relaxed approach to life. He was 22 years old and from Oxford. He joined the Royal Marines in late 2004, and after successfully completing 32 weeks at the Commando Training Centre, he was passed for duty as a Royal Marines Commando.

After training, he joined Lima Company of 42 Commando Royal Marines, based in Plymouth. In 2006, after initially serving as a General Duties Marine, he successfully completed the Viking Operators Course based in Bovington and deployed to Afghanistan with the Armoured Support Company for Op HERRICK 5 with 3 Commando Brigade. During his two operational deployments to Afghanistan, Mne Gostick's support to the ground troops of 12 Mechanised Brigade, 52 Infantry Brigade and finally 16 Air Assault Brigade has been invaluable. 

Throughout his training and on each operational tour, Marine Gostick had demonstrated himself as a shining example of a Marine and he took great pride in being a diligent and dedicated Viking Operator.  He was clearly a man to watch, a man who had much potential to progress swiftly through the rank system.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment
IncidentDetails: Lance Corporal James Bateman and Private Jeff Doherty, both of 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment, were killed in Helmand Province, Afghanistan on Thursday 12 June 2008.
Bio:
James ‰Û÷Jay‰Ûª Bateman was born on 11 January 1979 and grew up in Staines, Middlesex where he went to school. He lived in Colchester with his wife Victoria to whom he was married in Salisbury Cathedral last year. Jay was a man of passions, dedicated to his wife, applying relentless enthusiasm to his job and fervent about West Ham United Football club. He was larger than life in every respect, a man of considerable physical presence; he was loud, vivacious and overflowing with life.

He joined the Parachute Regiment in 2001, and upon completion of his training was posted to 2 PARA in March 2002, initially to 9 Platoon, C (Bruneval) Company. 

On promotion to Lance Corporal he was posted to D Company. He had served with the Battalion in Northern Ireland and Iraq previously. It was just before deployment that he returned to 8 Platoon as second-in-command of 1 Section in the Company in which he began his career. Brimming with enthusiasm, he had his sights set on gaining a posting for 16 Air Assault Brigade‰Ûªs specialist Pathfinder Platoon.

Lance Corporal Bateman was a proud and honest Paratrooper, respected for being a gentleman as much as he was for his unbridled energy and professionalism. He was fit and had taken part in amateur boxing at company level. He barely stopped to pause, with unmatched staying power and a work ethic that put most to shame. C (Bruneval) Company was his spiritual home and his return to the company marked a new juncture in his career. 

He leaves behind his wife Victoria, whom he adored.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 118th Infantry, South Carolina Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. David L. Leimbach, 38, Taylors, S.C., was killed Sunday near Bala Baluk, Afghanistan, by small arms fire; assigned to the 1st Battalion, 118th Infantry, South Carolina Army National Guard, Fountain Inn, S.C., and attached to the 2nd Squadron,
Bio:
Sgt. Scott Sorgee said David L. Leimbach was all business when it mattered most.
å¦   "No matter what task he was given, he was always there and always gave it 100 percent," he said.
å¦   Leimbach, 38, of Taylors, S.C., was killed May 25 near Bala Baluk by small-arms fire. He was assigned to Fountain Inn, S.C.
å¦   "He was a good one," said Sgt. 1st Class Dain Donze. "We're all rather shook up. He was a good kid. He would do anything you ask."
å¦   "He would do anything you asked him to do and more," said Lt. Derek Hawkins. "He did for the Afghan people as well as his fellow soldiers."
å¦   Sorgee said Leimbach _ who also served the U.S. Marines from 1996 to 2000 _ was a soldier's soldier, teaching guys what he knew. "There wasn't a lot of downtime," he said. But when there was, he was teaching the soldiers "hand-to-hand combat."
å¦   When most of the state's Guardsmen returned in early May, Leimbach stayed behind in what was to be an extended tour of six months, soldiers he served with said. "It's what he loved," Sorgee said. "Other than his family, it's what he loved to do most."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Dawn.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, Royal 22e RÌ©giment
IncidentDetails: The two soldiers were killed at approximately 6:30 p.m. Kandahar time on January 6, when their Light Armoured Vehicle (LAV III) rolled over during a tactical move across difficult terrain. The incident occurred in Nalgham, in the Zhari District.
Bio: Born in Rimouski (Que.), Corporal Ìäric LabbÌ© joined the Regular Force of the Canadian Forces on September 14, 2001. Professional infantryman, Ìäric was a member of 2nd Battalion, Royal 22e RÌ©giment, based in Valcartier, Que. He was 31 years old and this was his second mission overseas as a member of the Regular Force.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Christopher Gathercole, 21, Santa Rosa, Calif., killed Monday in Ghazni, Afghanistan, by small arms fire
Bio:
Christopher Gathercole overcame a rough childhood as a ward of the state to graduate from high school and join the Army to make a better life for himself, said his older brother.
å¦   "He wanted to change himself, and he wanted to change the world around him," said Edward Gathercole. "In his opinion, he was doing the highest civic duty possible."
å¦   Gathercole, 21, of Santa Rosa, Calif., was killed May 26 in Ghazni by small arms fire. He was assigned to Fort Lewis.
å¦   The Gathercole brothers grew up in Santa Rosa, living primarily in foster homes from the time they were toddlers.
å¦   Christopher Gathercole spent his last year and a half in Santa Rosa at a treatment house for at-risk youth, where the staff said he had turned his life around.
å¦   "He was a tough kid, and I'm not surprised he went into the military," said Wes Anderson, who went to school with Gathercole. He recalled that his friend's road through childhood was rocky, "not having his parents around," but said "he made the best of what he had. "He was awesome."
å¦   He also is survived by his father Edward Gathercole, and his mother, Catherine Haines.

ServiceUnit: 1st Squadron, 61st Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: Army Pfc. Chad M. Trimble, 29, West Covina, Calif.; died Wednesday, near Gardez, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle struck an explosive
Bio:
Chad M. Trimble's mother said that after the terrorist attacks on New York on Sept. 11, 2001, her son started to take an interest in joining the Army.
å¦   After several years of growing interest, he signed up in 2007. "I think it was something he wanted to do since he was a little boy," Nancy Trimble said.
å¦   Trimble, 29, of West Covina, Calif., was killed by a roadside bomb May 28 near Gardez. He was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   He was know as a social guy. "This home was where all the kids would come," said Tim Trimble, his father. "It was incredible to see the energy of all those young people."
å¦   "He was the smallest boy in the neighborhood," said Gaye Wingfield, a neighbor. "He had the cutest giggle and would run around the neighborhood with a group of older boys."
å¦   Trimble's family and friends all said they were proud of the choices he made. "I hope all of America and the world will take a minute to pray for Chad," said his father. "He paid the ultimate price for us."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Rosanna, and two daughters, Steffani and Micaela.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Army Sgt. 1st Class David Nunez, 27, Los Angeles, Calif.; died Thursday in Shewan, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered from small arms fire.
Bio:
David Nunez would have received his associate's degree from Central Texas College. He got it _ but it was his fiancee, Cynthia Rivera, who accepted the degree in his honor.
å¦   Nunez, 27, of Los Angeles and a native of Mexico, was killed May 29 in Shewan by small-arms fire. He was assigned to Fort Bragg and was on his second deployment to Afghanistan.
å¦   He joined the Army in 1999 as an airborne infantryman, serving as an assistant team leader with the 82nd Airborne Division's 3rd Battalion, 504th Parachute Infantry Regiment. Nunez earned his green beret in 2005, and has been with the 7th Special Forces ever since.
å¦   Nunez also is survived by his sons, David Jr. and Julian.
å¦   He "fought with pride and honor to preserve the liberties of his fellow citizens," Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said in a statement. "We will forever remember his service and sacrifice given in the name freedom."

ServiceUnit: 173rd Special Troops Battalion, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: They died May 31 in Jalalabad City, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
James M. Finley was kindhearted, the kind of guy who was always reaching out to others to bring lost kids into the group.
å¦   "He's like a big teddy bear," said family friend Randy Sproat, who also was Finley's drama teacher. "He's got a big, warm heart."
å¦   Finley, 21, of Lebanon, Mo., was killed May 31 by a roadside bomb in Jalalabad City. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Bamberg, Germany.
å¦   "He was very goal-oriented," family friend Mike Palmer said. "He was always working hard to better himself. He always did what it took to get the job done."
å¦   Finley was about the only student in drama class who could effectively run the lights and sound, Sproat said. And although acting wasn't his focus, Finley and a friend did a hilarious version of the classic comedy routine "Who's on First?"
å¦   Like other former teachers and family friends, Rebecca Christal, who taught Finley in her Honors American History class, said he will be remembered for his kindness. "He was very, very nice," she said. "He was very polite and very caring."
å¦   Finley is survived by his parents, Wayne and Betsy.

ServiceUnit: 173rd Special Troops Battalion, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: They died May 31 in Jalalabad City, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
The last time Taylor Riggan saw fellow former fire department cadet Andrew J. Shields they were at a karaoke party at the fire station. Shields joked and sang all the songs well _ typical Andrew, Riggan said.
å¦   "He always had a smile on his face," Riggan said. "He made things fun just being around him."
å¦   Shields, 19, of Battleground, Wash., was killed May 31 by a roadside bomb in Jalalabad City. He was a 2007 high school graduate and was assigned to Bamberg, Germany.
å¦   Shields was affectionately nicknamed "Doc" by his peers, a term of an endearment bestowed upon particularly adept medics.
å¦   "He always liked the idea of jumping out of planes," his cousin Shawna Keyes, 19, said. "He lived for every extreme. When he did something, he didn't do halfway. He did it fully."
å¦   He wanted to follow his father by enlisting in the Army. After serving in the military, he planned a career in emergency services.
å¦   He was known to work his peers hard during physical training, always keeping them on task. "He was kind of a cheerleader of the class," said Capt. Abe Rommel, the teen's Clark County Fire District 11 instructor.

ServiceUnit: 451st Civil Affairs Battalion
IncidentDetails: They died June 3 in Zormat, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Scott A. Hagerty helped repair water wells in northern Uganda when he was stationed in Africa in 2006 and 2007, his pastor recalled.
å¦   "In Africa, he saw children. He fed them, gave them water, cared for them. He was making peace, not just keeping peace," said the Rev. Henry Siems.
å¦   Hagerty, 41, of Stillwater, Okla., was killed June 3 when his vehicle hit a roadside bomb in Zormat. Hagerty was assigned to Pasadena, Texas.
å¦   He was a 1984 graduate of Stillwater High School and a 1993 graduate of Oklahoma State University, with a bachelor's degree in political science. He was employed by National Standard, an industrial wire manufacturer.
å¦   Army Command Sgt. Maj. Steve Roberts said Hagerty "was a guy whose actions spoke louder than words. "He was doing exactly what he wanted to do. He truly loved soldiers, trusted soldiers. Selfless sacrifice _ that's Scott in a nutshell," Roberts said.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Daphne, and two sons, Jonathan, 10, and Samuel, 20 months. Samuel is named after a civilian contractor Hagerty worked with in Iraq who was later killed by a bomb.

ServiceUnit: 228th Brigade Support Battalion, Pennsylvania Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: They died June 3 in Zormat, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Sgt. 1st Class Timothy Horner said he fondly remembered his first encounter with Derek D. Holland.
å¦   "As we talked that day, I don't think I've been called 'Sergeant' so many times," Horner said. "I told him 'Horner' was fine and he replied 'Yes, Sgt. Horner.'"
å¦   Holland, 20, of Wind Gap, Pa., was killed June 3 when his vehicle hit a roadside bomb in Zormat. He was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Bethlehem, Pa.
å¦   "In him I saw a young man who would grow in time to be a leader in this company and would be an asset for many years to come," said Capt. Robert Stein. "Sadly this was not to be."
å¦   Teacher Andra Groller recalled how Holland came to school one day after enlisting with his shaggy black hair buzzed off. "He just blossomed. He just grew," she said.
å¦   Holland was described as quiet by some teachers and commanding officers. For those who knew him best, he was bright, thoughtful and, above all, hilarious.
å¦   "You'd yell at him if he did something wrong, and the next thing you knew he had you laughing," said Sgt. Jamey Yurkonis.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Kathy L. Andreas and David G. Holland.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, Princess Patricia‰Ûªs Canadian Light Infantry
IncidentDetails: Captain Leary was killed June 3, 2008, in a fire fight after the foot patrol he was leading came under small arms fire from insurgents in the Panjwayi District in Afghanistan.

ServiceUnit: 12e RÌ©giment blindÌ© du Canada
IncidentDetails: Tpr Renaud was killed at approximately 7:15 a.m. Kandahar time on January 15, when the armoured vehicle he was in struck a suspected Improvised Explosive Device (IED). The incident occurred in the Arghandab District.
Bio: Born in Alma, QuÌ©bec, Corporal Richard Renaud joined the Canadian Forces on October 6, 2004. Cpl Renaud served as an armoured soldier in the 12e RÌ©giment blindÌ© du Canada, based in Valcartier. He was 26 years old and was on his first tour overseas.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, Princess Patricia‰Ûªs Canadian Light Infantry
IncidentDetails: Captain Snyder was killed Saturday, June 7, after falling into a well while conducting a night time security patrol in Zhari District, Afghanistan.

ServiceUnit: 96th Aviation Support Battalion, 101st Combat Aviation Brigade, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: They died June 5 at Kandahar Army Airfield, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained when the Kiowa helicopter they were in went down during a test flight.
Bio:
Andre D. McNair Jr.'s father said his son never backed away from a challenge.
å¦   "If something got the best of him the first time, he'd always go back and try again. When he took a test recently for a pilot's license, he scored a 96; but he needed a 105 to pass. I asked him what he was going to do, and he said, 'I'm gonna study harder, go back and take it again.'
å¦   "I guarantee you," Andre McNair Sr. added, "if he had had a chance, he would have gotten that 105."
å¦   McNair, 20, of Fort Pierce, Fla., was killed June 5 when his helicopter went down in Kandahar during a test flight. He was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   "He was the kind of child you want your child to be with. He was so determined to be something in life. It's hard to find kids like him these days," said Jackie Chester, family friend.
å¦   Since childhood, McNair had been good with his hands, helping his father with renovations at home, drawing cartoon characters on denim jeans and making repairs to his 1988 Chevrolet Caprice, a gift from his father.
å¦   "We never took a car to the shop," said his mother, Pam.

ServiceUnit: 96th Aviation Support Battalion, 101st Combat Aviation Brigade, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: Carter, 42, of Montgomery, Ala., was killed June 5 when his helicopter went down in Kandahar.
Bio:
James Carter's wife said he served as a mentor to many of his fellow soldiers during his more than two decades in the Army.
å¦   "He was always a trainer. He took them under his wings and pushed them," Avis Carter said.
å¦   Carter, 42, of Montgomery, Ala., was killed June 5 when his helicopter went down in Kandahar. He was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   Last year, he completed a master's degree from Murray State University in Kentucky, said Walter Carter, his older brother.
å¦   His sister, Angela Gilchrist, described James Carter as "a very loving person."
å¦   "He was basically the one that kept the family together. Even though he was far away, he kept the family together," she said.
å¦   Carter graduated high school in 1983 and played in the marching band and participated in the Army JROTC program. Shortly after graduation, he enlisted.
å¦   Despite the danger, he always loved what he did, his family said. He served tours in Germany, Bosnia, Iraq and Afghanistan.
å¦   "Once he got into the military, that was it for him, everything revolved around that," Gilchrist said.
å¦   He also is survived by two sons, Caleb and Joshua, and a daughter, Jedrice.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion the Parachute Regiment
IncidentDetails: At approximately 1100 hours local time, the soldiers were on a routine foot patrol 1km west of their Forward Operating Base in the Upper Sangin Valley, when their patrol suffered a suicide explosive device.
Bio:
Private Charles David Murray, 'Dave' to his friends and colleagues, was serving as a rifleman and Assault Engineer with 4 Platoon, B Company, 2 PARA when he was killed in action by a suicide device in Helmand Province, southern Afghanistan. 

Private Murray, 19, was born in Dumfries on 7 January 1989, but grew up in Carlisle. He began his military career early. Having left school at the age of 16 he attended the Army Foundation College in Harrogate in September 2005, where his passion and skill for rugby league saw him represent the college during a tour to Australia. 

His slight stature belied a standard of fitness and robustness that set the standard in his platoon. His love of soldiering, and admiration for his Section Commander, led him to choose a career in The Parachute Regiment. 

Having successfully completed his initial training he attended the Infantry Training Centre in Catterick, North Yorkshire. It was here that he completed his training, passing the physically demanding Pre- Parachute Selection Course, P Company, as the champion recruit. He became eligible to serve with The Parachute Regiment and subsequently earned his military parachute wings at RAF Brize Norton.

He joined the 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment in December 2006 as his platoon was preparing to be held on standby for High Readiness tasks within 16 Air Assault Brigade. He quickly fitted in due to his naturally relaxed and outgoing nature. It did not take long for him to demonstrate his soldiering ability and he undertook specialist training as an Infantry Assault Engineer within a year of joining the battalion, a course usually reserved for soldiers of greater experience. 

Private Murray had come into his own during the first two months of the battalion's tour of duty in Afghanistan. Always putting his team-mates and colleagues first, his technical competency and professionalism shone brightly in Afghanistan. He worked tirelessly despite soaring temperatures and was totally committed to his job. It is often said and never truer, he was a rising star, and a future leader.

ServiceUnit: 4 Platoon, B Company, 2 PARA
IncidentDetails: At approximately 1100 hours local time, the soldiers were on a routine foot patrol 1km west of their Forward Operating Base in the Upper Sangin Valley, when their patrol suffered a suicide explosive device.
Bio:
Private Daniel Gamble was serving as a rifleman and Pashto linguist with 4 Platoon, B Company, 2 PARA when he was killed in action by a suicide device in Helmand Province, southern Afghanistan. Private Gamble deployed to Afghanistan in March 2008.  Employed as the platoon linguist, he had gone forward with typical enthusiasm and professionalism to speak with a local Afghani when his platoon was attacked. 

Private Gamble, 22, was born on 25 June 1985 and grew up in Uckfield, East Sussex. After a short period working in a variety of jobs upon leaving school, he applied to join The Parachute Regiment and completed his basic training at the Infantry Training Centre in Catterick, North Yorkshire. 

It was during this time that he passed the demanding Pre-Parachute Selection Course, known as 'P Company', and became eligible to serve with The Parachute Regiment. He joined 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment in October 2006 having earned his parachute 'wings' at RAF Brize Norton. 

Upon arriving at 2 PARA, he joined 4 Platoon B Company and instantly made an impression. Bright and determined, he showed true grit during the battalion's High Readiness exercises and marked himself as a man with the potential to go further.

It was during the initial phases of planning for the deployment to Afghanistan that Private Gamble was tested to assess his aptitude to learn a foreign language. Out of the 150 Private soldiers that were tested, he was one of 10 soldiers who showed the best aptitude to learn the language of the Afghan locals, Pashto.  

Bright, determined and always positive, he completed the 40-week full-time language course, motivated by his eagerness to get out to Afghanistan and make a difference. His positive approach, friendship and humour helped the others on the course to stay focussed and upbeat. 

He was confident too, willingly standing up in front of 300 soldiers and delivering a presentation on Pashto culture as part of pre-deployment training. His ability to speak the language of the locals of Helmand Province made a remarkable difference in the two months he spent in Afghanistan. 

His skill and charisma ensured that he was always at the forefront of any patrol, his enthusiasm for his chosen profession was both relentless and infectious.

ServiceUnit: 4 Platoon, B Company, 2 PARA
OccupationJobTitle: Machine Gunner and Infantry Assault Engineer
IncidentDetails: At approximately 1100 hours local time, the soldiers were on a routine foot patrol 1km west of their Forward Operating Base in the Upper Sangin Valley, when their patrol suffered a suicide explosive device.
Bio:
Private Nathan Cuthbertson was serving as a Machine Gunner and Infantry Assault Engineer with 4 Platoon, B Company, 2 PARA when he was killed in action by a suicide device in Helmand Province, southern Afghanistan. 

Private Cuthbertson, aged 19, was born in Sunderland on 5 January 1989. He began his military career aged just 16. Having left school he chose not to wait until he was old enough for adult service and attended the Army Foundation College in Harrogate in October 2005. Whilst at the Army Foundation College he stood out as a soldier and chose to join The Parachute Regiment. Upon completing his initial training he moved on to the Infantry Training Centre in Catterick where he completed his basic training and passed the physically demanding Pre-Parachute Selection, P Company.

Once he had earned his military parachute wings he joined 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment in December 2006. With typical energy and drive he quickly embraced the spirit of the Regiment and in under a year had undertaken and passed the technically challenging Infantry Assault Engineers course, usually reserved for more experienced soldiers. 

During pre-deployment training and deployment to Afghanistan he again excelled operating the platoon's specialist weapon, the general purpose machine gun. He handled the responsibility with characteristic aplomb and was hugely proud to be the section gunner. 
Rarely seen without a smile, he could be depended upon to cheer up the platoon, even in the most adverse conditions from the Northumberland rain of pre-deployment training to the heat of the Afghan summer.

ServiceUnit: 2 Battalion, Royal 22e RÌ©giment
IncidentDetails: The two soldiers were killed at approximately 6:30 p.m. Kandahar time on January 6, when their Light Armoured Vehicle (LAV III) rolled over during a tactical move across difficult terrain. The incident occurred in Nalgham, in the Zhari District
Bio: Born in Alexandria, in Egypt, Warrant Officer Hani Massouh joined the Canadian Forces on September 27, 1990. Career infantryman, Hani was a member of 2 Battalion, Royal 22e RÌ©giment, based in Valcartier, Quebec. Hani was 41 years old and was on his sixth mission overseas.

ServiceUnit: NATO Allied Land Component Command Headquarters
IncidentDetails: During the early morning of August 29, Major Raymond Ruckpaul was found suffering from the wound in his living quarters located within the secure compound of the ISAF Headquarters in Kabul.
Bio: Major Raymond Ruckpaul was based at the NATO Allied Land Component Command Headquarters in Heidelberg, Germany, and was serving in Kabul, Afghanistan with the International Security Assistance Force Headquarters.

ServiceUnit: 62nd Engineer Battalion, 36th Engineer Brigade
IncidentDetails: Buxbaum, 23, South Portland, Maine, died Monday in Kushamond, Afghanistan, in a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
Justin L. Buxbaum had talked about eventually becoming an elementary school teacher _ and it showed,
å¦   "He was the kindest, most genuinely warm and loving young man," said Laurie Wood, an aunt. "You'd have a family picnic and he'd be the one playing catch with the little kids, and dragging three of them around on his shoulders."
å¦   Buxbaum, 23, of South Portland, Maine, died May 26 in Kushamond in a non-combat related incident. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   In high school, Buxbaum ran track, played football through his junior year and participated on the math team. "Nothing would get him down. He'd be in here late in the afternoon working on something, and then be back early in the morning," said Jeanne Crocker, his principal.
å¦   Buxbaum deployed to Iraq for the first time in 2005. He was driving a specialized armored vehicle called a Buffalo, searching for hidden bombs.
å¦   "It is a very rewarding feeling knowing that the job that we perform may save someone's life so that they can go back home to their families," Buxbaum said in an article then.
å¦   He is survived by his mother, Julie A. Buxbaum.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Marines, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: All four Marines died June 14 while supporting combat operations in Farah Province, Afghanistan
Bio:
Michael Robert Patton was in Jim Hegger's Spanish class and the two played "Halo 2" many a night online together.
å¦   "I'm deeply saddened by this whole turn of events, but I'm honored to know that I knew this great man, this hero amongst men," Hegger wrote on an online bulletin board.
å¦   Patton, 19, of Fenton, Mo., was killed June 14 in a roadside bombing in Farah province. He was a 2007 high school graduate and was assigned to Twentynine Palms.
å¦   Patton's mother, Teresa, said her son knew he wanted to be a member of the armed forces ever since he was 5. He was deployed to Afghanistan in April.
å¦   "He had talked about joining the military since he was about 5 years old," said a sister, Rebecca Patton. "He was willing to follow his dream, even though it cost him his life."
å¦   She said he had played on the varsity soccer team in high school and was popular among his classmates. He also was known for his infectious smile, she said. "He had two huge dimples on the side of his face that came out when he smiled," she said.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Amy.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Regiment
IncidentDetails: All four Marines died June 14 while supporting combat operations in Farah Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Dawid Pietrek came to the U.S. from Poland at about age 21 on a green card with dreams of going to college and becoming a police officer.
å¦   A trained medical caregiver, he lived with two families while helping with their elderly family members. He also wanted to become a citizen, which likely spurred his decision to enlist.
å¦   "I loved him so much. He was like my son," said Janina Filleborn, who hired Pietrek about four years ago when he came to the U.S. to work as a caregiver for the homebound elderly. "Dawid was the best. He was smart and kind and worked so hard."
å¦   Pietrek, 24, of Bensenville, Ill., was killed June 14 in a roadside bombing in Farah province. He was assigned to Twentynine Palms.
å¦   "He was doing what he wanted to do," said Bill Rohn, whose family Pietrek lived with while caring for Rohn's father-in-law. "He wanted to be a Marine."
å¦   Thousands of miles away, in Poland, Dorota Pietrek asked that those in the country her son adopted as his own remember him, too, as one of their own. "Thank you for keeping him in your hearts and your minds," she wrote.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Marines, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: All four Marines died June 14 while supporting combat operations in Farah Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Layton Bradly Crass' mother recalled her laughter when, as a child, Layton loudly imitated pterodactyl calls and mimicked comedian Jim Carrey's strut in "Ace Ventura" movies while the two of them ran errands together.
å¦   "I couldn't help but laugh at the kid," Lynne Crass said.
å¦   Crass, 22, of Richmond, Ind., was killed June 14 in a roadside bombing in Farah province. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Twentynine Palms.
å¦   He was an avid rollerblader _ he'd be gone for "hours and hours" in the park, his mom said _ and paintball lover had aspirations for law enforcement. He was active in the Richmond Police Youth Cadet Program.
å¦   Crass was only 16 when, after the World Trade Center attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, he sought to enlist. His age, in addition to his parents' reservations, stood in the way.
å¦   Crass had served an eight-month tour in Iraq before deploying about six months ago to Afghanistan, where he trained Afghan police units.
å¦   "He loved life and wanted to make sure you knew it," said Donald Crass, his father. "If he was in the room right now, you'd know it," his mother added.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Marines, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: All four Marines died June 14 while supporting combat operations in Farah Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Michael Toussiant-Hyle Washington's dad was pulling duty as a firefighter when Marine casualty notification officers tracked him down and broke the news.
å¦   "This loss is obviously personal and my family is grieving, but I want the city and the country to know we lost somebody pretty special," he said. "My son was just a good guy _ a kid who would cut elderly people's yards when they were sick and couldn't cut it themselves."
å¦   Washington, 20, of Tacoma, Wash., was killed June 14 in a roadside bombing in Farah province. He was assigned to Twentynine Palms and was known as "Little Mike" at his dad's fire station.
å¦   He graduated from high school in 2005 and joined the Marines, just like his father and his grandfather. He served a tour in Iraq and was twice commended for his bravery, tactical abilities and quick action with a machine gun _ honors he never mentioned to his parents.
å¦   "He is a great Marine," said Master Gunnery Sgt. Marc Williams, a family friend. "Wherever he has gone, he has been recognized."
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Michael and Grace.

ServiceUnit: Royal Canadian Dragoons (RCD)
