IncidentDetails: Trooper Mark Andrew Wilson was killed October 7, 2006, at approximately 5 a.m. (Afghanistan time), when the RG-31 he was travelling in was hit by an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) in the Panjwayi area, approximately 25 km West of Kandahar, Afghanistan.

ServiceUnit: Intelligence Corps
IncidentDetails: Meanwhile, the British Ministry of Defense said four British soldiers were killed when an explosive was detonated against their vehicle during a patrol in neighboring Helmand province on Tuesday. At least one soldier was wounded.
Bio:
Corporal Sarah Bryant of the Intelligence Corps was a member of 15 (United Kingdom) Psychological Operations Group based in Chicksands, Bedfordshire. She deployed to Afghanistan on 15 March 2008 with 152 DELTA Psychological Operations Effects Team in support of the Helmand Task Force within the PSE, serving with the Headquarters of 16 Air Assault Brigade as the Target Audience Analyst.

Corporal Sarah Bryant was born on 17 December 1981 in Liverpool and joined the Army on 21 January 2002 as a member of the Intelligence Corps. On completion of training, she was appointed to 11 MI Sect in Herford Germany, and later served on operations in Iraq. She was married to Carl, also a soldier in the Intelligence Corps, upon whom she doted.

Utterly professional, Sarah was tenacious and reliable. She was an excellent operator able to turn her hand to any task. Highly competent at both combat Intelligence and Security, she was at ease with her peers and officers alike and was held in high regard. Her professionalism, exceptional trade knowledge and confidence ensured effective liaison with other units, especially on security inspections and investigations. 

Everyone she encountered noted her as a friendly, reliable and professional soldier. She had been marked out for potential commissioning but indicated that she wanted to go through the ranks. Her clear potential was highlighted by the fact that she had been pre-selected for promotion to Sergeant on her first look. This is testament to her determination and dedication to the Intelligence Corps, and to life in general.

IncidentDetails: Meanwhile, the British Ministry of Defense said four British soldiers were killed when an explosive was detonated against their vehicle during a patrol in neighboring Helmand province on Tuesday.
Meanwhile, the British Ministry of Defense said four British soldiers were killed when an explosive was detonated against their vehicle during a patrol in neighboring Helmand province on Tuesday.

ServiceUnit: Royal Signals
IncidentDetails: Meanwhile, the British Ministry of Defense said four British soldiers were killed when an explosive was detonated against their vehicle during a patrol in neighboring Helmand province on Tuesday.

ServiceUnit: Provincial Reconstruction Team Sharana
IncidentDetails: Two sailors died Wednesday of wounds suffered from a rocket attack in northern Paktika province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Marc A. Retmier was a swimmer, surfer and motocross rider and looking forward to skydiving. He had three years left in the Navy, then planned to attend Cal State Long Beach and study medicine.
å¦   "His passion was always to be where the action was," said his father, Steve Retmier. "He could have stayed at Bethesda Naval Hospital and been a corpsman. My son believed in what he was doing and he kept volunteering. He didn't have to be there."
å¦   Retmier, 19, of Hemet, Calif., was killed June 18 in a rocket attack in northern Paktika province. He was assigned to Provincial Reconstruction Team Sharana in Afghanistan.
å¦   "He was one of the most popular kids in town," said Dale Powers, the grandfather whom Retmier called "Papa." "He's going to be missed by a lot of people."
å¦   Powers, a decorated Korean War veteran, said the teenager wanted combat experience on his resume. "He used to follow me around like a little shadow; I practically raised him," he said. "I took him everywhere. I took him camping and fishing. He was sort of in charge of the family."
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Joy.

ServiceUnit: Provincial Reconstruction Team Sharana
IncidentDetails: Two sailors died Wednesday of wounds suffered from a rocket attack in northern Paktika province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Lt. Commander George Degener, Ross L. Toles III's executive officer for 10 years, said Toles was tapped for an assignment in Afghanistan for one reason _ he was the best.
å¦   "He's been one of my top sailors," Degener said. "He's one of the people I looked towards and always asked to go with me on any training event anywhere we were asked to go. He was always a hard charger _ a performer. Everywhere we went, he was asked to come back."
å¦   Toles, 37, of Davison, Mich., was killed June 18 in a rocket attack in northern Paktika province. He was assigned to Provincial Reconstruction Team Sharana in Afghanistan.
å¦   He joined the Navy in 1989, initially serving aboard the USS Saint Louis in Sasebo, Japan. After eight years as a Navy Seabee, Toles switched over to the Navy Reserve, where he stayed for the next 10 years. He worked at GM's Pontiac Assembly Center.
å¦   "He had a heart the size of the state of Michigan," said Senior Chief Petty Officer Rex Roach, who served with him at Selfridge Air National Guard Base.
å¦   He is survived by his wife April, and their sons, Shawn, 14, Jake, 10, and Ryan, 5.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Marine Regiment, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Whitacre died June 19 while conducting combat operations in Farah Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
From the front lines in late April, Andrew Francis Whitacre wrote to thank Americans for their help.
å¦   "The support of the citizens of the country we fight and die for is all that we ask. We don't need, nor want to be treated like heroes, although I have seen many young men who are worthy of the title," he wrote. "All we need is to know that we have not been forgotten."
å¦   Whitacre, 21, of Bryant, Ind., was shot and killed June 19 while on patrol in Farah province. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Twentynine Palms.
å¦   Even before he enlisted, Whitacre was known to fight battles, standing up for the bullied kids at school. And as an adult, he would do the same for his fellow Marines, who nicknamed him "Whit."
å¦   "Even if he had nothing to do with them, he would fight their battles," said his fiancee, Casey McGuire.
å¦   Whitacre was always willing to lend a helping hand. "He was real community oriented," said his father, Ernie. "He loved his town, he loved Indiana. He was always ready to stand up for somebody."
å¦   He also is survived by his stepmother, Norma, and mother, Susan Nunly.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Marine Regiment, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Terhune died June 19 while conducting combat operations in Farah Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
The tone of Eric Daniel Terhune's phone calls and e-mails from Afghanistan was sober, said his uncle, David Terhune.
å¦   An unusually long and detailed e-mail to cousins three days before his death included this wry advice: "Don't come to Afghanistan on a sightseeing tour."
å¦   Terhune, 34, of Lexington, Ky., was killed June 19 in Farah province. He was assigned to Twentynine Palms and had already served two tours of duty in Iraq.
å¦   He served four years in the Marines after high school, traveling to the far East, South America and Europe as a reconnaissance sharpshooter. After being honorably discharged, he used his GI Bill benefits and graduated with honors from Morehead State University, where he competed on the varsity rifle team. Then he rejoined the Marines.
å¦   "He really believed we are in a fight with evil, and he saw Afghanistan as the source of the Twin Towers attack," said David Terhune. "He felt he was protecting his little cousins."
å¦   He was even "born a Marine," in Quantico Naval Hospital in Virginia, while his father, Paul, a single parent, was stationed at the Marine base there.

ServiceUnit: Military Transition Team, 1st Brigade, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: They died June 21 in Kandahar City, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device and small arms fire.
Bio:
James J. Walton was an enthusiastic paratrooper, logging more than 5,000 jumps. His wife, Sarah, shared her husband's love of athletics.
å¦   The two met at a fitness club five years ago, dating a year before they married. His father-in-law, Joseph Moschler, approved of him instantly.
å¦   "I thought he was the most wonderful young man I have ever known in my life," he said. "I loved him just like my own."
å¦   Walton, 41, of Rockville, Md., was killed June 21 in an ambush in Kandahar. He graduated from West Point in 1989 and was assigned to Fort Riley.
å¦   Walton was deployed twice during his marriage, and he and his wife made the most of their time together, often going hiking and running. The two loved animals, volunteered at animal-rescue facilities and had a pet cat and a dog, a mutt named Hannibal that they had rescued from abuse.
å¦   He was a standout on the diving team at West Point, and was always trying something adventurous, from rock climbing and rappelling to flying.
å¦   "What everyone remembers about Jim is, he was larger than life," said his sister Diane Jewell. "He's exactly what you'd think of when you think of a hero."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Squadron, 101st Cavalry (Reconnaissance, Surveillance and Target Acquisition), New York Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: They died June 21 in Kandahar City, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device and small arms fire.
Bio:
When Anthony L. Mangano rejoined the New York Army National Guard last year, his unit had already filled all its slots for its planned deployment to Afghanistan.
å¦   So he sought out another unit to go overseas. "It speaks highly of the kind of guy he was," said Sgt. Paul Hoovler. "That alone shows the patriotism that he had."
å¦   Mangano, 36, Greenlawn, N.Y., was killed June 21 in an ambush in Kandahar. He was assigned to Geneva, N.Y.
å¦   He had an associate degree from upstate Columbia-Greene Community College and first served in the National Guard from 1991 to 1999.
å¦   Hoovler described Mangano as a confident, outspoken jujitsu expert known for a thick Long Island accent, who put aside a solid construction business to rejoin the Guard.
å¦   "It was just him wanting to do his part and serve his country," said Hoovler said. "In his mind, he could do anything."
å¦   He also enjoyed scuba diving and one of his prize possessions was his Harley Davidson motorcycle. "He never took it out unless there wasn't a speck of dust on it," said his mother, Constance.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Tatiana.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Squadron, 101st Cavalry (Reconnaissance, Surveillance and Target Acquisition), New York Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: They died June 21 in Kandahar City, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device and small arms fire.
Bio:
Nelson D. Rodriguez Ramirez always wanted to play the red Power Ranger as a kid. He loved to dance salsa, especially the music of Jerry Rivera. And he could bring a smile to everyone's face.
å¦   "Any time you looked down, he would always make you happy," said his brother, Ricardo Rodriguez.
å¦   Rodriguez Ramirez, 22, of Revere, Mass., was killed June 21 when the truck he was riding in struck a roadside bomb in Kandahar. He was assigned to Geneva, N.Y.
å¦   "We have our hearts very broken," said his aunt, Mirna Rodriguez. "I feel proud of him, but it's a hard situation to go through."
å¦   Born in Puerto Rico, he was known as "Bebo" to friends and family and loved the Yankees. He joined the Job Corps in Chicopee and earned his GED.
å¦   He loved Six Flags and flying in airplanes and doting on his daughters, Ariana, 4, and Kiara, born in January. When he came home, he wanted to join the Coast Guard and study to be a pilot.
å¦   "He's always thinking about everybody else before he thinks of himself," said his wife, Moraima. "He would always send me flowers to make sure I knew he was appreciative of me waiting for him."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Marine Regiment, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Matthew E. Mendoza died Friday during combat in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Matthew E. Mendoza joined the Marines in 2004, becoming a pistol and rifle instructor at Twentynine Palms and training fellow soldiers in anti-terrorism tactics.
å¦   "He was good at slowing them down, making them relax and helping them qualify on the shooting range," said his father, Raul. "He was proud that he helped some of the females qualify. He got one shooting at expert level with the rifle."
å¦   Mendoza, 24, of San Antonio, Texas, was killed June 20 during combat in Helmand province. He was assigned to Twentynine Palms.
å¦   "He had a wonderful 24 years of life here that was cut short way too early," said his father. "As a sergeant his goal was to get all the men from his platoon back home. That was his No. 1 goal; he was going to do everything it took to make sure that happened. It took everything he had."
å¦   Football came naturally to Mendoza, who played in a Pop Warner youth league as a boy. He was a linebacker and running back in high school, and later coached in Pop Warner as an adult.
å¦   Mendoza also is survived by his wife, Valerie; 6-year-old son, Matthew.

IncidentDetails: To the east, a Polish soldier from the separate NATO-led force died when a bomb hit his patrol after midnight in Paktika province. Jacek Poplawski, a Polish military spokesman in Warsaw, Poland, said four other soldiers were wounded.

ServiceUnit: First Marine Division Detachment
IncidentDetails: He died June 20 while conducting combat operations in Farah Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
When young men and young women in far-western Arizona join the military, people often come together for a send-off rally. That's what happened when Dustin Kelby Burnett went to war.
å¦   Debbie Nuchols remembers her son's speech like it was yesterday. "He said he wanted to fight for our freedoms. But more than that, he wanted to give the people over there the same freedoms he had."
å¦   Burnett, 19, of Fort Mohave, Ariz., was killed June 20 in Farah province. He was a 2007 high school graduate and was assigned to Twentynine Palms.
å¦   He played football for the Fort Mohave Thunderbirds for four years. His cousin remembers him as a happy and energetic young man. "He was always smiling," said Rachel Nuchols. "I can't really picture him any way except full of life."
å¦   Burnett was a medic attached to a Marine division. "Everybody over there called him Doc," his mother said. "He loved the idea that he would be taking care of people."
å¦   He also is survived by his father and mother, Donald and Debra Nuchols. In the past school year, his 13-year-old brother Devin was given an assignment to write about his hero. He wrote about his older brother.

ServiceUnit: 4th Battalion The Parachute Regiment
IncidentDetails: Whittaker, a reserve soldier who was attached to 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment, was killed by a suspected Improvised Explosive Device.
Bio:
Private Joe Whittaker was born on 11 January 1988. He attended Warwick School and then Stratford Upon Avon College. He played hockey for Stratford Hockey Club and ran for Stratford Athletic Club. Joe joined the TA in Stratford in 2005. 

He eventually joined 4 PARA in October 2007, after transferring from 37 Signal Regiment, having completed his basic training with the Royal Signals in June 2006. He was highly regarded throughout his time with them and was considered to be one of their top recruits. He was a particularly fit soldier; able to complete the one and a half mile run in a time of 8.09 minutes. His field craft and personal skills were considered the best in the platoon. 

Joe had a wicked sense of humour and was usually the ringleader in the fun and games out of working hours. His natural ability and enthusiasm for adventure and challenge channelled his aspirations towards applying to join the Parachute Regiment Reserve. He completed the Combat Infantryman Course and P-Company with 4 PARA in November 2007. He gained a strong pass after working extremely hard on the course. 

Joe Whittaker operated from 10 Company, 4 PARA based in London. He established himself quickly and it did not take him long to volunteer to serve with the Regiment on operations in Afghanistan. He mobilised in April 2008 and after completing all the necessary training joined 2 PARA in May.

Joe Whittaker was an outstanding young soldier who possessed all the qualities that one would expect from a young paratrooper. He had a flair for life, was fun and had a great sense of humour. His fitness was astonishing, and he possessed the courage, discipline and loyalty of a man many years his age. 

In the time he spent with 4 PARA it was clear that Joe Whittaker had a bright future and he had the intellect and character for great things. Joe Whittaker was a kind and considerate soldier and he will be sadly missed by all his friends and colleagues in 4 PARA.

ServiceUnit: 173rd Special Troops Battalion, 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Spc. Connolly died June 24 in Khogyani, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle struck a suspected landmine.
Bio:
After the terrorist attacks of 9/11 and while attending Solano Community College, Ryan J. Connolly really thought about joining the military.
å¦   "He felt strongly about protecting American soil," said Robin Nelson, his mother. "What could I do? I didn't want him to go, but he wanted to do it."
å¦   Connolly, 24, of Vacaville, Calif., was killed June 24 by a land mine in Khogyani. He was assigned to Bamberg, Germany.
å¦   As a combat medic, he saw a lot of disturbing things while deployed. "People don't understand exactly what goes on over there," said his mother. "Ryan liked to help and wished he could help more."
å¦   He played on Little League all-star baseball teams as a child, and shifted his interest to automobiles in high school. He purchased a 1970 Chevy Nova, which he was planning to restore.
å¦   "He's a hero," said Robert Nelson, his stepfather. "He died from something he couldn't control."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Stephi, and a 1-year-old daughter, Kayla. "They were a good match," said his stepfather. "He had a great time with Kayla. He was going to be a good father."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Squadron, 101st Cavalry (Reconnaissance, Surveillance and Target Acquisition), New York Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: They died June 21 in Kandahar City, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device and small arms fire.
Bio:
Andrew Seabrooks' friend said he did a tour in Iraq and volunteered in January to go to Afghanistan to save his family's home from foreclosure with his pay.
å¦   "He wanted to keep our family together. He was a loyal man. Whatever he did, he was loyal to it," said Gloria Hedges who lived with Seabrooks and their 4-year-old son, Xavier.
å¦   Seabrooks, 36, of New York City, was killed June 21 when his vehicle hit a roadside bomb and he came under small-arms fire at Kandahar. He was assigned to Geneva, N.Y.
å¦   Neighbors remembered Seabrooks, known on the block as Drew, as a friendly, family-oriented man who loved to tinker with Volkswagens.
å¦   "We all kind of groaned when he went to Afghanistan, but not Drew," said his friend Kelvin Willks. "He loved what he was doing."
å¦   Another son, Andrew, said his dad was a role model who made sure he and his friends walked the straight and narrow. One of his favorite memories is of playing handball with his father. "He loved that game," the 15-year-old said, "He was a great father. He was a wonderful guy."
å¦   He also is survived by a wife and two children, who all live in Newport News, Va.

ServiceUnit: 1st Marine Logistics Group, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Staff Sgt. Strickland died June 25, while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Ron Dunbar, who coached Christopher D. Strickland in high school football, said he had a tremendous work ethic and was a good example for teammates.
å¦   "Chris really just stood out as a young man that was always willing to do whatever it took to help others," he said.
å¦   Strickland, 25, of Labelle, Fla., died June 25 during combat in Helmand province. He was a 2000 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Pendleton.
å¦   Strickland was on his second combat assignment in Afghanistan. He also served on tour in Iraq and would have celebrated his ninth year in the Marines on July 23, 2008.
å¦   "To him, to tell people he was a Marine was one of the proudest things to roll off his tongue," said his high school friend, Whitney Chapman.
å¦   In addition to playing football, Strickland also wrestled and played the saxophone and bass drum in the marching band. His mother, Beth Church, will remember her son as a protector, someone willing to stick his neck out for others.
å¦   "He wanted to make everyone proud and look up to him," she said.
å¦   He is survived by his wife and 3-year-old son.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment (2 PARA)
IncidentDetails: WO2 Michael Williams was killed during a firefight. He was on a deliberate operation against the Taliban in the Upper Sangin Valley when he was fatally wounded.
Bio:
Sergeant Major Michael Williams was born on 28 November 1967 and grew up in Cardiff, where his unbridled and ever-present love for Cardiff City Football Club originated. 

Known affectionately by his many friends as Mark, or Weasel, he was a small man with huge depths of physical courage and stamina, and a giant personality. Beneath his kindness and sense of fun and adventure was the most professional soldier, who was loved and respected by the whole Battalion, not least those under his command.

Mark Williams joined the Army in 1986. After completing training, he joined the 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment, starting his long career in 11 Platoon, D Company. Over the next 22 years he served with distinction as a rifleman in B and D Companies (including on Operations in Northern Ireland) and as a Lance Corporal in B Company. 

In 1998 he moved to the Machine Gun Platoon in Support Company, where he served as a Detachment Commander and Platoon Sergeant on Operations in Macedonia and Afghanistan. In 2004 he was posted to the Infantry Training Centre in Brecon as a Machine Gun Instructor, where he relished passing on his expertise, and living in Wales. 

Promoted to Colour Sergeant, he returned to 2 PARA as Company Quartermaster Sergeant of Support Company and deployed to Iraq, before being promoted to Warrant Officer 2nd Class and becoming the Company Sergeant Major of A Company. He had deployed to Afghanistan with 2 PARA in March 2008, initially running the Battle Group's in-theatre training in Bastion before taking up his role as the Fire Support Group Commander in C (Bruneval) Company, based out of Forward Operating Base GIBRALTAR in the Upper Sangin Valley.

Mark Williams was one of the most experienced, popular and well respected soldiers within 2 PARA, with whom he spent almost all of his 22 year career. He loved his Battalion, soldiering, and his men, whom he led with compassion and constant encouragement. His other love was for Cardiff City Football Club, of whom he was the most fanatical supporter. 

He had organised his leave from Afghanistan especially early in the tour so that he could attend the FA Cup Final. Mark Williams' death leaves a huge hole in the hearts of the entire Battalion.

IncidentDetails: The Defense Ministry says one Romanian soldier was killed in Afghanistan when the vehicles in which they were riding came under attack. The soldiers were on patrol on a highway between Kabul and Qalat, a town near Kandahar.
Hungary's Defense Ministry says a soldier has been killed in Afghanistan while trying to disarm a roadside bomb. He was killed in Baglan province Tuesday.

ServiceUnit: B Company, 5th Battalion The Royal Regiment of Scotland
IncidentDetails: Johnson was killed while part of a vehicle checkpoint patrol operating in the Lashkar Gar area on Saturday 28 June 2008.
Bio:
LCpl James ("Jimmy") Johnson was born in Scotland on 3 June 1977 and grew up in Chatham, Kent. He joined the 1st Battalion the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders in 1997. He quickly found his niche in the Army and once he gained experience in a Rifle Company he joined the Assault Pioneer Platoon. 

Seeking a challenge, he put himself forward for a demanding Close Observation Platoon (COP) course in July 2001, showing himself to be an extremely fit man who put others to shame with his ability to burn the candle at both ends and still perform. 

He served a very successful tour with the COP in Belfast from 2001 to 2003. On the Battalion's re-rolling to 16 Air Assault Brigade LCpl Johnson volunteered for a Sniper Course and qualified as a Sniper Section Commander in December 2003. 

His skills as an infantryman were second to none and he revelled in his role as a sniper, testing himself and those in his section. Since then he served again with the COP for a tour of Bosnia in 2005, the Sniper and Recce Platoons and latterly with the Heavy Machine Gun Platoon before transferring to B Company for Op HERRICK 8.

ServiceUnit: 13 Air Assault Support Regiment of the Royal Logistic Corps.
IncidentDetails: Britain's Defense Ministry says one of its soldiers was killed and two others injured when their patrol vehicle overturned in Afghanistan.
Bio: WO2 Shirley was born on 1 December 1975 and grew up in his hometown of Leicester. He enlisted in the Army in August 1992, joining 2nd Battalion the Parachute Regiment. He later joined the Army Physical Training Corps in April 2004 and arrived at 13 Air Assault Support Regiment Royal Logistic Corps in June 2006.

ServiceUnit: 425th Infantry Regiment, Michigan Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: They died from wounds suffered June 26 near Forward Operating Base Shank, Afghanistan, when their convoy encountered improvised explosive devices, small arms fire and rocket-propelled grenades.
Bio:
å¦   Matthew L. Hilton had worked with the Lathrup Village Police Department in Michigan since 2001 and, before that, with the Detroit Police Department.
å¦   "He's a hard worker and always very conscientious," said Lathrup Police Chief Robert Jones said, adding that Hilton was always more reserved. "It took a minute to get him to open up, but he was fun."
å¦   Hilton, 37, of Livonia, Mich., was killed June 26 by explosive in Logar province. He was a 1989 high school graduate and was assigned Selfridge, Mich.
å¦   Hilton has been a reservist for 18 years. He served in Iraq in 2005 and volunteered for this most recent mission to Afghanistan, which began in January. His wife, Mary, also a reservist, has also served in the Middle East.
å¦   "Service to their country meant a great deal to both of them," said Lathrup Mayor Frank Brock.
å¦   Sharon Hilton, Hilton's stepmother, called her stepson "a great man" and "a good father" to his two stepchildren.
å¦   "He enjoyed life, but he was very serious about doing what he could for his country," she said. "I couldn't have asked for a better son if I'd given birth to him."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Squadron, 101st Cavalry Regiment (Reconnaissance, Surveillance and Target Acquisition), New York Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: They died from wounds suffered June 26 near Forward Operating Base Shank, Afghanistan, when their convoy encountered improvised explosive devices, small arms fire and rocket-propelled grenades.
Bio:
Joseph McKay just happened to be born on the Fourth of July.
å¦   He "used to laugh and say, 'Everyone celebrates my birthday in this country,'" said Newton Baptiste, his best friend.
å¦   McKay, 51, of New York City, was killed June 26 when his convoy was attacked June 26 in Logar province. He was assigned to Jamestown, N.Y.
å¦   "He was one of a kind, a real gentle person. When he was at Fort Hamilton, he would take leftover Army food out to the homeless in Brooklyn," McKay's sister-in-law, Diana Coleman said.
å¦   McKay, an avid biker, leaves behind a wife and three children. He also served in Iraq from 2004 to 2005.
å¦   McKay, who joined the New York Army National Guard in 1977, signed up full-time after Sept. 11. He guarded Grand Central Terminal and Penn Station in the days following the attack, earning a New York State Defense of Liberty Medal, which was given to Guard members for service in New York City following the 9/11 attacks.
å¦   Coleman said her brother-in-law would give his Army meals to homeless people in the rail stations, prompting one homeless man to send him a Christmas card.
å¦   "It was truly heartrending," Coleman said.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Squadron, 101st Cavalry Regiment  (Reconnaissance, Surveillance and Target Acquisition), New York Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: died from wounds suffered June 26 near Forward Operating Base Shank, Afghanistan, when their convoy encountered improvised explosive devices, small arms fire and rocket-propelled grenades.
Bio:
Mark Palmateer's daughter said he was a really happy-go-lucky person.
å¦   "He made the best out of every situation," Stephanie Palmateer said. "I just thought about how much he loved me and loved his family and everybody around him."
å¦   Palmateer, 38, of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was killed June 26 when his convoy was attacked June 26 in Logar province. He was assigned to Jamestown, N.Y.
å¦   He decided to join the National Guard after the 2001 attack on the World Trade Center, enlisting in 2003, just before his 35th birthday.
å¦   "He wanted to serve his country all his life, he always wanted to serve his country," said Charles Palmateer, his father.
å¦   Sgt. Patrick Donovan said he and Palmateer became friends in 2004. "He just wanted to do his part," Donovan said. "He wasn't eager to go to war, but he said, 'If they need me, I'll go.'"
å¦   Terry Jones, who was Palmateer's boss at Dunmore Corp., said Palmateer was an outstanding employee who was loved by everyone. "He can make anyone smile," he said.
å¦   "Anyone who met him instantly became his friend," said Gary Palmateer, one of Mark Palmateer's eight siblings. "He was just a likable guy."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Staff Sgt. Travis K. Hunsberger, 24, of Goshen, Ind., died on June 27 of wounds suffered from an improvised explosive device while on combat patrol near Tarin Kowt, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Travis K. Hunsberger was a "genuinely good young man" who always had a smile on his face, said Brad Duerksen, his former soccer coach, and could've done anything he wanted _ and did
å¦   "No one was surprised when he joined the military," Duerksen said. "He was a very self-sacrificing kind of man.
å¦   Hunsberger, 24, of Goshen, Ind., was killed June 27 by an explosive near Tarin Kowt. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   The 2002 high school graduate enlisted just over four years ago after two years at Ball State University. He was on his second tour of duty in Afghanistan and had been injured twice.
å¦   "Serving in the military for his country is what brought him his greatest happiness," Associate Pastor Kent Norr said. "He was a very fine and upstanding young man, strong in his faith."
å¦   Hunsberger had been married for less than two years. He and his wife, Hannah, invited his parents to Fort Bragg last Christmas to witness a re-enactment of their wedding. Travis and Hannah had a small private wedding before his first deployment.
å¦   "It was a special, special ceremony," said his father, Steve.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: They died June 29 in Khosrow-E Sofla, Afghanistan, from injuries sustained when their vehicle rolled into a canal.
Bio:
During his years of junior ROTC training, James M. Treber led his teams against much larger foes in physical fitness contests _ and won every single match.
å¦   "He worked the kids really, really hard, but in a way that they loved him," said his instructor, John Strait. "He worked hard, a fantastic work ethic."
å¦   Treber, 24, a Green Beret from Imperial Beach, Calif., was killed June 29 when his vehicle rolled into a canal in Khosrow-E Sofla. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Treber was born in Hawaii, the son of a career Navy sailor. He always liked sports, said his brother, Gordon Treber, but he found his niche in JROTC, a high school program in which students exercise, drill and wear uniforms.
å¦   "That was kind of a steppingstone for him," his brother said.
å¦   As team captain, Treber placed in the top six nationally in the Youth Physical Fitness competition during his senior year in 2002. A high school apprenticeship program landed him a slot in the merchant marine straight out of high school.
å¦   "He was just a really, really fine young man, doing what he wanted to do," said Strait.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Tamila.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: They died June 29 in Khosrow-E Sofla, Afghanistan, from injuries sustained when their vehicle rolled into a canal.
Bio:
å¦   Shawn E. Simmons entered the Army as a power generator repairman in 1992 and worked his way up the ranks, despite some who said he couldn't do it, recalled his wife, Tricia.
å¦   "I remember a couple of people telling him, 'you are a generator mechanic _ you know nothing about combat,'" she said. "I remember telling my husband, 'When you put your mind to something, you can accomplish it.'"
å¦   Simmons, 39, of Ashland, Mass., was killed June 29 in Khosrow-E Sofla when his vehicle rolled into a canal. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Simmons was born in Boston in 1969, but relocated to Florida with his mother as a child. He attended Tallahassee Community College and Wesley College before studying at the University of Massachusetts in Boston.
å¦   In 1997, he began the Special Forces qualification course and earned the Green Beret in 1999. He became an instructor at the John F. Kennedy Special Warfare Center and School. He returned to his current unit last December. He also served in Germany before serving a previous tour in Afghanistan.
å¦   He also is survived by two children, Justin, 11, and Erin, 12.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: They died June 29 in Khosrow-E Sofla, Afghanistan, from injuries sustained when their vehicle rolled into a canal.
Bio:
å¦   Jeffrey M. Rada Morales entered the Army in April 1995 as an animal care specialist.
å¦   He was initially assigned as a veterinary technician at Patrick Air Force Base, where he served for 14 months. In 1996 he moved to the 248th Medical Detachment at Fort Bragg. Then, in 1999, he went to Aberdeen Proving Grounds for three years.
å¦   "Jeff was a fun and exciting person to be around," wrote friend Chris Wright. "I won't ever forget you, and that took me to my first NASCAR race down in North Carolina. I had so much fun down there."
å¦   He moved back to Fort Bragg, to the John F. Kennedy Special Warfare Center and School, in 2002, first to be an animal care instructor, then as a student, training as a Special Forces medical sergeant. In 2007 he earned the coveted Green Beret.
å¦   Rada Morales, 32, of Naranjito, Puerto Rico, was killed June 29 in Khosrow-E Sofla when his vehicle rolled into a canal. He was assigned to Fort Bragg and was on his second deployment to Afghanistan.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Amanda; a stepson, Andrew; and a daughter, Jessica.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Marine Special Operations Battalion, U.S. Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command
IncidentDetails: Heredia died June 26 while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   As a child, Edgar A. Heredia often insisted on joining his brother, Sam, and his friends when they were deep into GI Joe war game scenarios.
å¦   Once, Sam Heredia recalled, he had kept his younger brother out of their game, but he was lurking close by. At the height of the imaginary attack, Edgar Heredia showed up with his toy tanks and yelled: "My friends will help you!"
å¦   Heredia, 28, of Houston, died June 26, 2008, during combat in Farah province. He was a 1998 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejeune. He was on his third tour of duty.
å¦   The son of immigrants from Mexico, Heredia and his brother wanted to give back to his adopted country. "We have a loyalty to this country, and we feel as though we have to repay it," his brother said. "He chose the Marines, and I went into Border Patrol."
å¦   He also is survived by his parents, Alejandro and Rosie.
å¦   His brother remembered Edgar as a man who always helped others. "He never wanted to be the bad guy," said Sam Heredia. "He always wanted to help everyone, and that's how he grew up to be."
å¦   He added: "Even though he's my little brother, I looked up to him."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 506th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: Turner died Wednesday at the National Naval Medical Center, Bethesda, Md., of wounds suffered on Saturday in Malikheyl, Afghanistan, when his vehicle struck an explosive.
Bio:
å¦   When the Army raised the age limit to 42, Estell L. Turner knew it was his last chance to return to the service.
å¦   Turner, know as "Lee," looked forward to being deployed to Afghanistan _ his first tour in the war on terror. But he knew the potential dangers of his convoy missions.
å¦   "He never seemed to be worried about it," said his wife, Leah. "This is something he believed in. He thought it was right."
å¦   Turner, 43, of Sioux Falls, S.D., died July 2 at the National Naval Medical Center of roadside bomb wounds suffered in Malikheyl. He was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   Turner spent six years with the Army until 1989 and then became a mechanic in Fayetteville, N.C., and later an installer for DirecTV. He and brother John raced and fixed cars together, and Lee also played guitar.
å¦   "That's how I remember him," said Mary Turner, his sister-in-law. "He and his friends would get around and play guitar."
å¦   He had a "go get it" attitude and loved being in the military, said his mother, Gloria Turner. "He had a great personality," she said. "He was always looking out for the next guy."
å¦   He also is survived by a daughter, Lyda.

ServiceUnit: 27th Infantry Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Farkas died on July 4 of injuries suffered from a non-hostile incident in Kabul, Afghanistan (Camp Phoenix).
Bio:
å¦   On long runs, Daniel Farkas would always be one of the first to finish _ and then double back to cheer on the stragglers, said Spec. Jose Miranda.
å¦   "There was one time I fell behind and he ran with me," Miranda said. "I wanted to give up, but he wouldn't let me."
å¦   Farkas, 42, of New York City, died July 4 of injuries suffered in a non-hostile incident in Kabul. He was assigned to Syracuse, N.Y.
å¦   He was a New York police officer assigned to Forest Hills, Queens.
å¦   "He served his city and his nation in the most honorable ways possible," Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly said, "as a police officer and as a soldier."
å¦   Capt. Gurpreet Singh had a running joke with Farkas that he outranked him as a cop but not as an Army officer.
å¦   Singh recalled greeting Farkas as "Sir" when he was still in training to receive his Army commission. Fellow officers asked him why he gave a lowly cadet such respect, and Singh laughed, explaining, "That's my boss in the NYPD!"
å¦   "He was just so friendly and polite, and always took a minute to smile and say 'Hello' whenever our paths crossed," said neighbor Jane Durning.
å¦   Farkas is survived by his mother, Mirjam.

ServiceUnit: Special Troops Battalion, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Bull died July 8 at Bagram Air Field, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered in Chow Kay Valley, Afghanistan, when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device during a mounted patrol.
Bio:
å¦   Kevin Welles, one of Douglas J. Bull's high school English teachers, remembers Bull being among a group of students he spoke to prior to graduation.
å¦   "I remember speaking to seniors and telling them how many males and females would be crying at graduation. They said, 'No, get out of here. We can't wait to get out of here.' He's someone I remember looking at during graduation and there were tears in his eyes," Welles recalled. "I don't think he thought he'd be as emotional as he was."
å¦   Bull, 29, of Wilkes Barre, Pa., died July 8 at Bagram Air Field of wounds suffered when his vehicle struck an explosive in Chow Kay Valley. He was a 1997 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   He enlisted after graduation, traveled the world and completed a yearlong tour of duty in Iraq between 2005 and 2006.
å¦   "Everybody loved him. He was well-known. He had a great personality," said his mother, Mary Rambus. She said he enjoyed playing paintball and football with friends.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Tera, and two children, 6-year-old daughter Arianna and 3-year old son Jaden.

ServiceUnit: Special Air Service Regiment
IncidentDetails: Australian officials said one of their soldiers was killed by a roadside bomb while on patrol Tuesday in Uruzgan province. Signaler Sean McCarthy, 25, was the sixth Australian soldier to die in Afghanistan.
Bio:
SIG Sean Patrick McCarthy was born on 5 January 1983 in Auckland, NZ.
 Sean enlisted into the Australian Defence Force on the 10 July 2001.  After initial recruit training and completion of mandatory courses, Sean posted to 7 Sig Regt on the 14 July 2003.
Sean posted to SASR on the 15 January 2007 and has been an active member of the Regiment ever since.

 

Sean‰Ûªs Operational service includes deploying as part of the Special Operations Task Group (SOTG V) in 2007; Operation Astute in East Timor in 2008 before redeploying to Afghanistan as part of his most recent deployment.

 

For his service in East Timor and Afghanistan, Sean was awarded the Australian Defence Medal, the International Coalition Against Terrorism Clasp, the Afghanistan Campaign Medal, the NATO Medal and the Return from Active Service Badge.

 

Sean was the recipient of a SOCAUST commendation awarded on the 20 June 2008 for his actions in Afghanistan in 2007 as part of SOTG Rotation V.  Sean was awarded this for his excellent application of battle craft in a complex, dangerous and confusing situation.

 

Sean was an avid rugby union fan. He was a respected member of his Troop and well liked by his colleagues.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 294th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: They died July 10 in Babo Kheyl, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered when their vehicle was struck by an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Maely Villagomez, Brian S. Leon Guerrero's stepdaughter, said one of the things she will remember most about her stepfather is his humor. "Every time in the car, we'd tickle his underarm, and he'd laugh funny," said Maely Villagomez.
å¦   Leon Guerrero, 34, of Hagatna, Guam, was killed July 10 in Babo Kheyl when his vehicle was struck by an explosive. He was assigned to Barrigada and was on his third deployment.
å¦   Reflecting on her husband, Leon Guerrero's wife, Emely, said he was not only a loving husband, but also a loving father and dedicated to his job.
å¦   "He loved his country very much, and he loved his family very much," she said. He worked full time as a security guard at Andersen Air Force Base.
å¦   Their first child together is due Aug. 5. They had already picked the name for the boy, Jude. "I'm OK," she said. "I have to be strong for the baby."
å¦   Leon Guerrero also is survived by two sons, Karl and Brian; a daughter, Karian; and a stepson, Julian.
å¦   Leon Guerrero's daughter said she will always love her father. "I'm proud of him for what he did, and he is my hero," Karian said.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 294th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: They died July 10 in Babo Kheyl, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered when their vehicle was struck by an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Abraham Mora Sr., Samson A. Mora's father, said his strength came from his children. All graduated from college, except Samson, the youngest. He couldn't help himself, his father said. The young man from Guam kept spending his money and time on cars.
å¦   "When he bought his Honda Civic and converted it for a car race, he said nobody could beat him on the island," Mora said. "He spent all his money on his car. This boy was so spoiled," he added, lovingly.
å¦   Mora, 28, of Dededo, Guam, was killed July 10 in Babo Kheyl when his vehicle was struck by an explosive. He was assigned to Barrigada.
å¦   Mora was featured in a 2004 Pacific Daily News "Cruising" article, having transformed his 1997 Toyota Tacoma into a car-show winner.
å¦   Mora's cousin, Charlita Harper, wanted the people of Guam to know that Samson Mora also was a member of the Honor Guard, those responsible for giving fallen soldiers a proper military burial. "That was very prestigious to him," she said.
å¦   "He was a good guy," said Agnes Mora, his sister-in-law. "We love him very much and we miss him."
å¦   Mora was engaged to be married to Rosanna Castro.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503d Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: They died of wounds suffered when their outpost was attacked by small arms fire and rocket propelled grenades from enemy forces in Wanat, Afghanistan, on July 13.
Bio:
å¦   Maj. Ed Leo, executive officer of the University of Hawaii Army ROTC program, said Jonathan P. Brostrom in his senior year was in the top 20 percent of the 4,000 university Army ROTC cadets enrolled in 270 universities.
å¦   "He was one of the very rare students," Leo said, "who during the summers was able to graduate from the Army's air assault, airborne and dive school."
å¦   Brostrom, 24, of Aiea, Hawaii, was killed July 13 by small-arms fire and explosives in Wanat. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   Brent Limos, admissions director at Brostrom's high school, described him as "a good student, hard worker. He was a very personable guy and made friends very easily. He was respectful to his teachers and administrators."
å¦   Brostrom played golf and competed in tours held by the Hawaii State Junior Golf Association and the Oahu Junior Golf Association.
å¦   "Jon was a great asset to the team. He was absolutely a fun-loving guy. He was a character," said his former golf coach, Jim Weicking.
å¦   Brostrom is survived by his parents, David and Mary Jo, and 5-year-old son, Jase.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503d Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: They died of wounds suffered when their outpost was attacked by small arms fire and rocket propelled grenades from enemy forces in Wanat, Afghanistan, on July 13.
Bio:
å¦   Israel Garcia, who loved soccer and horses, always wanted to join the Army, serve his country and be remembered.
å¦   "He always said he wanted the world to remember him as a hero, and that's all we ask," said his sister-in-law, Hilda Revolorio. "He fought and trained so hard for this nation."
å¦   Garcia, 24, of Long Beach, Calif., was killed July 13 by small-arms fire and explosives in Wanat. He was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   "There are no words to describe him. He was loved by everyone," said Revolorio. "We will miss his smile, his great sense of humor. He will be truly missed."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Lesly. "They met at the Belmont Plaza Pool the summer before their senior years of high school," said Revolorio. "He was the love of her life."
å¦   Hundreds gathered at his family's church to honor the soldier. "The service was amazing. It was exactly how he would have wanted," Revolorio said. "I know he was looking down saying, all these people came through for me. My sister said that her husband would have been happy about how things went and how he was honored."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503d Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: They died of wounds suffered when their outpost was attacked by small arms fire and rocket propelled grenades from enemy forces in Wanat, Afghanistan, on July 13.
Bio:
å¦   Jonathan R. Ayers loved Jeff Foxworthy, of whom he did a mean impersonation, and loved the blue-collar crew of comedians.
å¦   He focused on joy and bringing it to others. "He didn't like sadness. He didn't like people to be unhappy," said his father, Bill.
å¦   Ayers, 24, of Snellville, Ga., was killed July 13 by small-arms fire and explosives in Wanat. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   Ayers had many interests _ soccer, bowling, ice skating _ and he loved the Atlanta Thrashers, even working at the rink where they practiced.
å¦   He became commander of Junior ROTC, earning in 2002 Georgia's "most impressive commander" honor and, that same year, shepherding his group to win the state championship.
å¦   He played soccer as a young kid and continued through high school. When he was only 4, the coach took him out on the field and outlined the area that he was supposed to defend.
å¦   "Jon was very, very strong, and he would not let anyone through that box," his father said. "He pretty much always played defense, which is pretty much what he was doing 'till the day he died."
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Suzanne.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503d Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: They died of wounds suffered when their outpost was attacked by small arms fire and rocket propelled grenades from enemy forces in Wanat, Afghanistan, on July 13.
Bio:
å¦   Carlene Cross recalled when her son, Jason M. Bogar, was 5 or 6, he jumped off a couch and complained that his foot hurt. Nearly a week later, it still bothered him.
å¦   "When he jumped, there was a needle on the carpet. He had a needle in his foot. He was tough as a rock, even as a child," Cross said. "He was so full of energy, he just couldn't sit still."
å¦   Bogar, 25, of Seattle, was killed July 13 by small-arms fire and explosives in Wanat. He was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   Bogar served first in Iraq, then volunteered for two tours in Afghanistan. In both countries he often trained his camera on fellow soldiers as well as children. "He was always slipping them candy, even money. He really loved those kids," said Cross.
å¦   Bogar joined the Job Corps and earned a graduate equivalency diploma while becoming an electrician apprentice.
å¦   His father remembers a skinny kid who was often a trickster. "Jason could be a pain, but there was never any malice," said the Rev. Michael Bogar.
å¦   In the military, he found discipline, along with a love of travel, photography and the people he encountered. "He was artistic, he had a creative side," Bogar said.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503d Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: They died of wounds suffered when their outpost was attacked by small arms fire and rocket propelled grenades from enemy forces in Wanat, Afghanistan, on July 13.
Bio:
å¦   Jason D. Hovater enlisted in the Army both out of a sense of duty and because "he wanted to have some discipline in his life," said his sister, Jessica Davis.
å¦   "He was dedicated to it, and he believed in it," Davis said. "He said he wanted to be a part of it."
å¦   Hovater, 24, of Clinton, Tenn., was killed July 13 by small-arms fire and explosives in Wanat. He was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   "Jason Hovater was about as good as they get," said his wife, Jenna. "As far as character and integrity, he was so loyal to me, to his family, to his friends, to his job. He was a soldier, but that is only a fraction of the goodness he brought to this world."
å¦   Hovater was a church leader who had taken missionary trips in recent years, one to Russia and the other to Guatemala. He and his siblings performed on spiritual CDs.
å¦   "Jason never met a stranger," said Vickie Pettitt, a church administrator. "He had a warm smile that would warm your heart."
å¦   "This was a fine young man," said Vernon Davis, a family friend who said Hovater often worked in his yard before entering the service. "He always had a smile."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503d Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: They died of wounds suffered when their outpost was attacked by small arms fire and rocket propelled grenades from enemy forces in Wanat, Afghanistan, on July 13.
Bio:
å¦   Eve Phillips and Matthew B. Phillips met in April 2006 when introduced by one of her college roommates, Sara Shanks. Shanks grew up next door to Phillips and his family.
å¦   "It was love at first kiss," Eve said. "We dated about six weeks before we decided that we wanted to get married."
å¦   Phillips, 27, of Jasper, Ga., was killed July 13 by small-arms fire and explosives in Wanat. He was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   "Matt is an example of all that is right with our country," said Brig. Gen. Tim Crosby
å¦   Phillips' sister, Mary Nix, gave birth to a son the day before she learned of her brother's death. She renamed the baby Matthew after hearing the news.
å¦   "He was passionate and he loved what he did, and I am confident that when he died he was proud of what he did and was loving what he was doing," Eve Phillips said.
å¦   Michael Phillips said his son was confident about his assignment before he deployed, though he knew he was going into a dangerous area.
å¦   "We're finding out things that occurred that he was involved in that we had no idea at the time," he said. "He was one brave young man, and I'm honored to have him as a son."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503d Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: They died of wounds suffered when their outpost was attacked by small arms fire and rocket propelled grenades from enemy forces in Wanat, Afghanistan, on July 13.
Bio:
å¦   Jeff Terrell, a former youth leader at Glen Hope Baptist Church, said Pruitt A. Rainey was a big brother to many of the girls in the youth group. He's sure Rainey was a big brother to his fellow soldiers as well.
å¦   "He was willing to fight for his friends and family whether here or in Afghanistan," he said.
å¦   Rainey, 22, of Haw River, N.C., was killed July 13 by small-arms fire and explosives in Wanat. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   In high school, he was a member of the wrestling team where he competed in two state tournaments. He joined the Army in 2005 to help further his education after a short stint at Campbell University.
å¦   "He always had a big, goofy smile that made you smile," said Army Spc. Tony Tucker. "He loved what he did."
å¦   Rainey, described by friends as a gentle giant, had planned to go back to school to become a teacher after completing his service. "He had a lot of strength but was a great guy," said Jeff Terrell. "Big, but gentle."
å¦   He is survived by his mother, Rinda Riggins, and father, Frankie Gay.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503d Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: They died of wounds suffered when their outpost was attacked by small arms fire and rocket propelled grenades from enemy forces in Wanat, Afghanistan, on July 13.
Bio:
å¦   Kurt Zwilling will never forget the last time he saw his son, Gunnar.
å¦   "He just said to me, 'I would like to tell you something, Dad.' He said, 'If something happens to me, I want you all to go on. I want you to live a happy, long life.' And he looked at me and he said, 'You remember this,'" the elder Zwilling said.
å¦   "He said, 'My last thoughts before I die will be of you.' And he kissed me. He hugged me and he turned around and walked onto the plane."
å¦   Zwilling, 20, of Florissant, Mo., was killed July 13 by small-arms fire and explosives in Wanat. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   "He was a dedicated military man," said his aunt, Lisa Zwilling. She described him as a "wild man" who loved to play the guitar. She said her nephew decided to join the military for the opportunity to serve the nation and travel the world.
å¦   "He wanted to be free," she said. "He wanted to serve our country. He thought it was the right thing to do."
å¦   He grew up in Huntington Beach, Calif., and lived in Nashville, Tenn., for several years before moving to Florissant.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 503d Infantry Regiment (Airborne), 173rd Airborne Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: They died of wounds suffered when their outpost was attacked by small arms fire and rocket propelled grenades from enemy forces in Wanat, Afghanistan, on July 13.
Bio:
å¦   Sergio S. Abad excelled at karate. He had a lot of energy and a knack for teaching children.
å¦   "He was really athletic and could knock out hundreds of push-ups with no problem," said Marybeth Klock-Perez, a friend. "He always had something positive or funny or naughty to contribute."
å¦   Abad, 21, of Morganfield, Ky., was killed July 13 by small-arms fire and explosives in Wanat. He was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   Abad was a bright, funny, hyperactive 7-year-old when the Florida Department of Children & Families removed him from an abusive home and placed him with a relative.
å¦   For a youngster who had "been dealt really unfair cards in life, he was absolutely never bitter," said Klock-Perez, who ran a martial-arts studio. "He never used excuses or acted like the world owed him."
å¦   Abad would have become a father in December. He died not knowing his child is a girl. Fiancee Christina Parra plans to give her the name that Abad chose: Lorelai Rocio Abad _ in part after Christina's mother.
å¦   He wanted a daughter, said Krystine Flagg, a friend. "He wanted to give her the life he never had. A mother and father who stayed together."

ServiceUnit: Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Young died on July 13 of wounds suffered when his vehicle struck an improvised explosive device in Kajaki Sofla, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   In a letter written to the Clayton News Daily on July 4, 2007, Mitchell W. Young took a few paragraphs to put down his thoughts about service, sacrifice and respect.
å¦   "If you are unable to thank a vet, say thanks to either the parents or the spouse of a vet, because they are the ones who worry the most, while the service member is away, protecting your freedoms," he wrote.
å¦   Young, 39, of Jonesboro, Ga., died July 13 when his vehicle struck an explosive in Kajaki Sofla. A member of Special Forces, he was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   He was on his third tour of duty in Afghanistan and had also served a tour in Iraq. He had attended North Georgia College and joined the Army in 1991, at the beginning of the Gulf War.
å¦   "Ninety percent of people struggle to find what they want to do, what they want to be when they grow up," said Brent Young, Mitch's younger brother. "Mitch wasn't like that. He was doing exactly what he wanted to do."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Robyn.
å¦   "He was tough," his brother said, "but at the same time that covered a very gentle soul. He was sympathetic and cared a lot for a lot of people."

ServiceUnit: 1 Field Ambulance
IncidentDetails: A Canadian soldier suffered critical injuries and later died when an explosive device detonated near a dismounted security patrol in Panjwayi District.

ServiceUnit: 17 Wing Detachment
IncidentLocation: Support Element in the Gulf Region
IncidentDetails: On July 4, a Canadian Forces member was found dead in an accommodation room in the Theatre Support Element compound in the Gulf region. He was deployed to provide  aviation technical and logistics support services to Joint Task Force Afghanistan.

ServiceUnit: st Battalion, 6th Marines, 24th Marine Expeditionary Unit, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine 1st Lt. Jason D. Mann, 29, Woodlynne, N.J., died Thursday from a non-hostile incident in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Jason D. Mann hoped to finish 20 years in the Marine Corps and then, using his leadership skills and educational background in finance, become chief executive officer of a company.
å¦   "He was a leader in the Marines and wanted to be a leader afterward," said his brother, William Mann. "He wanted to buy a house someday for his family."
å¦   Mann, 29, of Woodlynne, N.J., died July 17 when the roof of a building collapsed on him in Helmand province. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   He graduated from the University of South Carolina with a finance degree and from his Marine Corps officer's class with top honors.
å¦   Mann _ described as a shy, chubby high schooler _ found himself in the military. "It was a complete transformation," said William Mann, himself an Iraq veteran.
å¦   Mann enlisted in 1997 and became an officer in 2005. It was his second deployment in the last two years, following a stint in Iraq from September 2006 to May 2007. He left for Afghanistan in March.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Shannon, and the couple's 2-year-old daughter, Isabella.

ServiceUnit: 173rd Brigade Support Battalion (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Army Pfc. Willington M. Rhoads, 23, Las Vegas, Nev.; died Wednesday in Bagram, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered from a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
å¦   Willington M. Rhoads was the kind of guy that Spc. William S. Baxter always could count on.
å¦   "What stands out in my mind most was that one night back in '04 when I was stranded in Fayetteville in the middle of the night," Baxter wrote on an online bulletin board. "I called you, and without hesitation, you came and got me."
å¦   Rhoads, 23, of Las Vegas, died July 16 in Bagram of injuries suffered from a non-combat incident. He was assigned to Vicenza, Italy.
å¦   He was a member of Otterbein United Methodist Church of Paris, and had participated in Boy Scouts as well as in basketball and baseball leagues. He attended Paris High School through his junior year and was a member of the school's Marching Tigers. He graduated high school in Las Vegas in 2003.
å¦   Rhoads enlisted in the Army on July 31, 2003. He first served in Iraq, and was currently serving his second deployment in Afghanistan as a part of the HHC, 173rd BSB.
å¦   Baxter went to his friend's funeral. "I know you would have been there for me, so there was no way I wasn't going to be there for you," he wrote.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Sarah.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 506th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: Dewhirst died July 20 in the Qalandar District of the Khost Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Susan Dewhirst noticed that her son, Nick A. Dewhirst, might have an itch to become a soldier from an early age. She used to babysit Nick and Nick's friend, and she remembers the 5-year-olds out in the yard doing military maneuvers.
å¦   "They would pretend they were Navy Seals," said his mother. "Way back then he was interested in doing something in the Army or military."
å¦   Dewhirst, 25, of Onalaska, Wis., died July 20 of wounds suffered during combat in Khost province. He was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   After a year at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University in Daytona Beach, Fla., Dewhirst went to the U.S. Military Academy at West Point and was commissioned in 2006.
å¦   An Eagle Scout, Dewhirst was a 2001 high school graduate and was a member of the National Honor Society. "He was an excellent leader," said Jill Lyche Kulig, who was on the student council with Dewhirst. "He cared about everyone."
å¦   Tracy Miller, a childhood friend and neighbor, said Dewhirst liked being outdoors and was good-natured. "He was always fun to be around," she said. "He always had a smile on his face."
å¦   Dewhirst also is survived by his father, Randy.

ServiceUnit: Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers , 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment
IncidentDetails: Cpl Barnes was driving a Vector ambulance vehicle when it hit a suspected Improvised Explosive Device.
Bio:
Following his death the Commanding Officer of 2 PARA, Lieutenant Colonel Joe O'Sullivan, paid the following tribute:

"Late in the evening of 22nd July, Kajaki Company deployed forward from their base to counter the Taliban's attempts to influence the local population in nearby villages, and prevent them from firing mortars and rockets at the base and the Kajaki Dam.
 
"Cpl Barnes was an armourer and part of 2 PARA's REME Light Aid Detachment. His job was to maintain the company's weapons in the base, but often took a turn driving the Vector ambulance vehicle in support of the company's operations. 

"When another member of the company was seriously injured in an explosion the ambulance was needed, and after a successful evacuation of the seriously injured soldier by helicopter Cpl Barnes was driving the ambulance back towards the base when it was struck by an explosive device.
 
"Cpl Barnes had been with 2 PARA only a short time, but he had already spent three months at Kajaki and had also served in Iraq; he knew how dangerous the company's operations were but wanted to do as much as he could. He died helping others when he could have taken an easier path, and in doing so demonstrated the commitment and bloody-minded determination that runs so deeply through the battalion.
 
"Cpl Barnes was a promising NCO with a bright future. 2 PARA will again mourn the loss of a brave young man, and the grief it brings to his wife and family; then we will continue to show what can be achieved by men like Cpl Barnes in northern Helmand."

"Cpl Barnes, 25, from Exeter, was born on 27 May 1983. He joined the Army in December 1999 and chose to follow a career in the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers as an Armourer, maintaining the Army's weapon systems. Following initial training at the Army Apprentice College in Arborfield, he learnt his specialist trade at the School of Electrical and Mechanical Engineering in Bordon.
 
"He completed his training in October 2001 and took up his first posting with the 1st Battalion, The Princess of Wales's Royal Regiment, with whom he deployed on his first operational tour to the Balkans in 2002. In November 2003 Cpl Barnes was posted to the 1st Battalion The Scots Guards, with whom he deployed to Iraq in late 2004. In May 2005 he was posted to 657 Squadron Army Air Corps at RAF Odiham.
 
"He arrived at 2 PARA in February 2008 and within weeks had deployed to northern Helmand in Afghanistan. Cpl Barnes had been promoted for the tour and very quickly impressed his colleagues. He had spent his whole career supporting the fighting units of the Army, which he relished. He was married to Diana, and they had recently moved to Colchester, the home of 2 PARA."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Marines, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Pfc. Ivan I. Wilson, 22, of Clearlake, Calif., died July 21 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Ivan I. Wilson was intelligent, had a wry sense of humor, and loved spending time in the library, reading and asking questions, said Lori White, one of Wilson's high school teachers.
å¦   "He thought outside the box," she said. "I really liked Ivan."
å¦   Wilson, 22, of Clearlake, Calif., was killed July 21 by a roadside bomb in Helmand province. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Twentynine Palms. He had also served in Iraq.
å¦   White said Wilson's favorite genre of books were science fiction, adventure and philosophy. His favorite sporting activity was wrestling. On his MySpace page, he listed his parents as his heroes and said he enjoyed music, concerts and surfing.
å¦   Francisco Velasquez, a fellow Marine, wrote that Wilson was well respected. He said Wilson _ nicknamed "Willie" and "Juggernaut" _ helped him on hikes in infantry school "when my little short legs would try to quit on me."
å¦   "He would say, 'Just hold onto my backpack and I'll help you,' which I did a few times," the man wrote.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Chris and Denise Wilson.

ServiceUnit: Royal Army Veterinary Corps, attached to 2nd Battalion the Parachute Regiment
IncidentDetails: Britain's Ministry of Defense said the soldier from the Royal Army Veterinary Corps was hit by small arms fire during a patrol in the Sangin area of Helmand province on Thursday.
Bio: LCpl Ken Rowe joined the Army in Newcastle on 7 March 2005. He successfully completed his Phase 1 training at ATR Winchester in June 2005, and his Phase 2 dog training in July 2005. He quickly went on to establish himself as a dog handler and trainer of the highest order, deploying to Northern Ireland. He deployed to Afghanistan in March 2008.

ServiceUnit: Jutland Dragoon Regiment
IncidentDetails: Denmark's army said a Danish soldier was killed and three others were wounded Friday when their armored vehicle hit an explosive device, also in Helmand province.

ServiceUnit: The Highlanders, 4th Battalion, The Royal Regiment of Scotland
OccupationJobTitle: mentor and trainer to the developing Afghan Army
IncidentDetails: In violence Monday, British officials said a British soldier was killed while patrolling in the Marjah area west of Laskhar Gah, capital of Helmand province in southern Afghanistan.
Bio:
Sergeant Jonathan 'Jon' Mathews was born in Edinburgh on 6th September 1972. At the age of 21 he decided to join the 1st Battalion The Royal Scots (The Royal Regiment) and on completion of basic training was posted to Fort George, Inverness. 

A few years later, he moved to Glencorse where he met his wife Shona, later marrying her in Edinburgh Castle. A proud Scottish warrior, he climbed the ranks swiftly, undertaking demanding military courses at Brecon and Warminster along the way. 

Quickly singled out as a man with significant potential, Jon was selected for training as a Sniper and a reconnaissance soldier. With experience on operations in Northern Ireland, Bosnia and Kosovo behind him, he moved to The Infantry Training Centre in Catterick as a recruit instructor, a job for which he was tailor-made. 

In July 2006 he was posted to The Highlanders in Fallingbostel as a rifle platoon sergeant in D Company. He made immediate impact, quickly earning a strong reputation as a capable soldier with a compassionate touch. 

When the call came for the Battalion to provide mentors to serve alongside the Afghan Army as part of the 1st Battalion The Royal Irish Regiment Battle Group, Sergeant Mathews was quick to step up. He knew the importance of the role and was determined to employ his now vast experience and play his part; his enthusiasm was unstoppable. He died doing the job he loved, leading others by example. 

Beyond the Army he was a keen sports parachutist, a canoeist and a hill walker, all sports that captured his love of the outdoors and his sense of adventure. But more than anything else, Jon was a family man who was passionate about Edinburgh, his wife and his family.

ServiceUnit: 62nd Engineer Battalion, 36th Engineer Brigade
IncidentDetails: Spc. Seteria L. Brown, 22, of Orlando, Fla., died July 25 in Sharana, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained in a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
å¦   Seteria L. Brown's younger brother, Keiwan Harris, said he had been unable to talk his sister out of joining the Army.
å¦   "It was something she really wanted to do," he said. "She was always an independent person."
å¦   Brown, 22, of Orlando, Fla., died July 25 in Sharana from a gunshot wound to the chest. She was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   Her mother, Michelle Harris, said her daughter re-enlisted after her initial four-year contract expired recently. Brown was a few months into her second overseas deployment.
å¦   She had a 7-year-old daughter, Harris said.
å¦   "She was such a sweet person," Harris said. "Everybody liked being around her. She always kept a smile on her face."
å¦   Brown entered the military in July 2004 as a food service specialist and was assigned to the 62nd Engineer Battalion, 36th Engineer Brigade, since February 2008.
å¦   Exactly how Brown died isn't clear to her family. "I was shocked and devastated,' Harris said. "I still can't believe it. I had spoken to her on the phone just a week before."

ServiceUnit: Special Troops Battalion, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Friday in Chowkay Valley, Afghanistan, from wounds sustained when their vehicle struck an explosive.
Bio:
David John Badie's sister, Kassandra Badie, said her brother changed his life around since enlisting two years ago.
å¦   Before joining the Army, Badie said her brother "sowed some wild oats." When he visited in June, she noticed a change.
å¦   "My brother and I talked about everything," Badie said. "He was really my best friend. He seemed more focused when he came home. He had goals. He wanted to go to college when he got out of the Army."
å¦   Badie, 23, of Rockford, Ill., was killed Aug. 1 when his Humvee drove over an improvised explosive device in Chowkay Valley. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   His mother, Netha, described her son as a jokester who liked to laugh and who enjoyed life. "If given the opportunity to do anything at least once, he was going for it, even if it were dangerous," she said.
å¦   Badie had aspirations of going to college and becoming a history teacher.
å¦   Badie was born in Mesa, Ariz., and lived there until he was about 14. He moved with his family to the Midwest and attended Milton High School in Milton, Wis., and later received a general equivalency diploma.
å¦   He also is survived by his stepfather, Daniel.

ServiceUnit: Special Troops Battalion, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Friday in Chowkay Valley, Afghanistan, from wounds sustained when their vehicle struck an explosive.
Bio:
å¦   William J. Mulvihill's family and friends were joined at his funeral by hundreds of riders from the Kansas Patriot Guard, an organization of bikers work to honor those who serve.
å¦   They didn't know Mulvihill, who would have turned 21 in just a couple weeks. "People stop and pay attention and it's what we should all do when we see an American flag and a ribbon around a tree. It's not about politics. It's about people who serve our county and patriotism," Liz Wheelihan with the Patriot Guard said.
å¦   Mulvihill, 20, of Leavenworth, Kan., was killed Aug. 1 by a roadside bomb in Chowkay Valley. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   "Spc. Mulvihill dedicated himself to serving and protecting our country," said Gov. Kathleen Sebelius. "A decorated solider, he served with honor and valor."
å¦   Mulvihill was a graduate of Leavenworth High School, where he was a member of the Junior Guard and the Leavenworth R.O.T.C. program. After graduation, he joined the U.S. Army, just like his older brother.
å¦   Mulvihill is survived by his mother, Pam Mulvihill; his father, Charles Raney; and his biological father, John Mulvihill.

ServiceUnit: Special Troops Battalion, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Friday in Chowkay Valley, Afghanistan, from wounds sustained when their vehicle struck an explosive.
Bio:
Although only a sophomore, Michael R. Girdano was a "key component" of his high school football team's undefeated season, said John Simon, a coach.
å¦   "He had an incredible will to win," Simon said. "He had intensity and leadership."
å¦   Girdano, 23, of Kiski Township, Pa., was killed Aug. 1 by a roadside bomb in the Chowkay Valley. He was a 2007 West Point graduate and was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   "He was among a rare exceptional few," said Army Maj. Gen. Don T. Riley.
å¦   In high school, Girdano was captain of the football team, played second base for the baseball team, was a member of the National Honor Society, and participated in many club activities such as German Club, Ski Club and Quiz Bowl. He was nominated to West Point by Rep. John Murtha.
å¦   Girdano scored high marks on his West Point Military Academy entrance exam, which rates numerous qualities such as confidence and appearance. He scored 46 out of 50 on the exam.
å¦   "He's still an 'A,' Michael is," said retired Marine Col. John Hugya. "I'm proud of him all over."
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Robert and Cynthia Girdano.

ServiceUnit: 6th Squadron, 4th Cavalry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Friday in Chowkay Valley, Afghanistan, from wounds sustained when their vehicle struck an explosive.
Bio:
In the Army, Jair De Jesus Garcia was happy. Even though family members had tried to talk him out of enlisting last year, his enthusiasm infected them.
å¦   "You should have seen his face. And you could see it on his pictures if you could only see them," said his mother, Maria Luisa Avneri. "He was very, very proud of what he was doing."
å¦   Garcia, 29, of Chatsworth, Calif., was killed Aug. 1 by a roadside bomb in Chowkay Valley. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   "He really believed in what he was doing as far as being in the military," said Eddie Garcia, one of his three siblings. "We were very supportive of him. We understood that this is what made him the happiest."
å¦   Named after a Brazilian soccer star, Garcia was once an assistant soccer coach at Fulton College Preparatory in Van Nuys, said Eddie Garcia, who also coached the team.
å¦   He believed in the kids, and did everything he could to mentor them. "The kids loved him, he loved the kids," he said. "The guys had a lot of respect for him, aside from being in the military. He had a lot of friends."
å¦   He is survived by a wife, Gabriella, and a 9-year-old son, Noah.

ServiceUnit: 4th Battalion, 320th Field Artillery Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: Baumann died Aug. 1, on Route Alaska, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Ryan P. Baumann had one last message for his fiancee, Lauren Smith. When he joined the Army, he gave her a gift and told her to open it if he died.
å¦   "So I opened the present and Ryan had written me a note that says I love you so much now and forever, yours forever," she said. "And that brings me peace because I feel that he loved me and he still loves me."
å¦   Baumann, 24, of Great Mills, Md., died Aug. 1 when his vehicle struck an explosive. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   He survived a tour of Iraq and was in the middle of a tour in Afghanistan when he died.
