å¦   While in high school, Baumann played and refereed soccer and enjoyed cars and racing. He also developed his interest in photography
å¦   "He was a hero and anything he did, he did it right," said Smith. "If he didn't get it right the first time, he would go back and do it again, and he loved this country and he loved what he was doing and he was proud of it. And I want people to understand that."
å¦   Baumann also is survived by his mother, Cindy Lohman; his father, Robert Baumann; and stepfather Gary Lohman.

ServiceUnit: 436th Chemical Company, Texas Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Gonzalez died Aug. 3 in Kabul, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered when his vehicle encountered a mine.
Bio:
Jaime Gonzalez Jr.'s wife said she was drawing strength from his faith, and that her trust in God had not been shaken, despite the tragedy of her husband's death.
å¦   "I have my own little WWJD (What Would Jesus Do?) now. It's What would Jaime do?" said Erica Gonzalez. "He would never let me be mad or upset about anything. If I woke up in a bad mood, he just wouldn't let me stay mad. He was full of life, and so positive."
å¦   Gonzalez, 40, of Austin, Texas, was killed Aug. 3 in Kabul of injuries suffered when his vehicle encountered a mine. He was assigned to Laredo.
å¦   Gonzalez joined the Navy in 1989 and served six years before enlisting in the Navy Reserve. He joined the Texas Army National Guard in 2006 and volunteered to go abroad
å¦   "He just felt like it was the right thing to do. And that gives me comfort, knowing that he knew this could happen, but he just knew that he was doing right. And he died with honor."
å¦   He also is survived by his a son, Jaime; a daughter, Samantha; stepsons, Jacob and Christopher Villarreal, and Robert Garcia; and a stepdaughter, Missy Villarreal.

ServiceUnit: U.S. Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command
IncidentDetails: Lawton died Aug. 4 while supporting combat operations in Herat province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Those who eulogized Garrett T. Lawton spoke of his compassion, his dedication to his friends and family, and his sense of humor, which included a story from a college friend who spoke of frequent hallway fire-extinguisher battles and the time when Lawton requested that someone punch him in the face to ensure that he was tough enough for the Marines.
å¦   "He was the best human being I've ever known," said his sister, Kenna Hubai. "It seems like everyone always has wonderful things to say about people when they die, even if they're not all true, but it is true for Garrett."
å¦   Lawton, 31, of Charleston, W.Va., died Aug. 4 during combat in Herat province. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   Lawton, who also served in Iraq, graduated from the University of West Virginia in 1999 with degrees in aerospace and mechanical engineering.
å¦   Lawton's grandmother, Beatrice Sampson, said she has a picture of her grandson as an 8-year-old wearing a full Marine uniform. "He was doing what he wanted to do."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Trisha, and two sons, Ryan, 6, and Caden, 4. "He was the type of man who always gave me everything I needed," his wife said.

ServiceUnit: 527th Military Police Company, 709th Military Police Battalion
IncidentDetails: Army Sgt. Errol M. James, 29, of St. Croix, Virgin Islands, died Aug. 4 at Forward Operating Base Torkham, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained in a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
Errol M. James was an enthusiastic dancer, recalled Spc. Jacob Adams.
å¦   "He used to say he had a gift for dancing. It didn't matter what kind of song it was, he would dance to it. The dance always looked the same to me," said Adams.
å¦   James, 29, of St. Croix, Virgin Islands, died Aug. 4 at Forward Operating Base Torkham of injuries suffered in a non-combat related incident. He was assigned to Grafenwoehr, Germany.
å¦   James deployed to Iraq as a combat medic in March 2003 and went to Afghanistan as a trauma specialist in February 2005. He left for his second tour to Afghanistan earlier this year.
å¦   James was born in Anguilla and is a graduate of the Albina Lake Hodge Comprehensive School in The Valley, Anguilla. He moved to St. Croix, where he joined the Army.
å¦   Ashley King, a former soldier who served with James, was under the misapprehension that he was a great driver.
å¦   "I saw him go through two cars due to accidents. He always had an explanation about how it wasn't his fault, but we all knew the truth," she said.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Eva, who is pregnant, and 1-year-old son, Elijah.

ServiceUnit: Naval Hospital Corps School
IncidentDetails: Carbullido died Aug. 8, in Sangatesh, Afghanistan, from injuries suffered when his vehicle hit an explosive.
Bio:
Kevin Diego, a friend of Anthony M. Carbullido, said he will always remember Carbullido's upbeat demeanor, especially at social functions.
å¦   "Tony is the kind of guy that never had a bad day," he said. "Not a care in the world. Everyone has their ups and downs; Tony's were almost always up."
å¦   Carbullido, 25, of Agat, Guam, died Aug. 8 in Sangatesh from injuries suffered when his vehicle struck an explosive. He was assigned to the Naval Hospital Corps School in Great Lakes, Ill. He had previously been deployed to Iraq.
å¦   "He was a real doer," said Austin Carbullido, the sailor's brother. He said his brother always approached challenges head-on and that he enlisted in the military because he wanted to be a doctor.
å¦   "He was an honest to goodness good person," said Darrell Crone, a retired corpsman. "He put the command and his students first. Always had a smile on his face and never negative."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Summer, and his daughter, Lexie.
å¦   "He was fun to be around," said Jermaine Alerta, a longtime friend. "He was a great guy, just a great guy."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry
IncidentDetails: A Canadian soldier died of his injuries following an engagement involving coalition forces, insurgents and security personnel from a civilian convoy in the Zharey District.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, Princess Patricia‰Ûªs Canadian Light Infantry
IncidentDetails: On 18 July 2008, during the conduct of operations in the Panjwayi District, Cpl James Hayward Arnal was killed as a result of an improvised explosive device strike.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion Princess Patricia‰Ûªs Canadian Light Infantry
IncidentDetails: One Canadian soldier was killed today and another was injured in the Panjwayi District at about 5:30 am Kandahar time.
In the northwestern province of Faryab on Monday, a bomb attack killed a Latvian soldier and wounded three, that country's Defense Ministry said.

ServiceUnit: 6th Squadron, 4th Cavalry, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Mattox died Aug. 10 at Forward Operating Base Bostick, Afghanistan, from injuries sustained in a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
John A. Mattox's best friend and fellow serviceman, Marine Cpl. Lance Waller, walked through the cemetery after the service for Mattox, stopping every so often to talk with other mourners.
å¦   "He was just a good person, a loving person," said Waller, Mattox's friend since fifth grade. "He made everyone around him better."
å¦   Mattox, 23, of Daingerfield, Texas, died Aug. 10 at Forward Operating Base Bostick from injuries in a non-combat related incident. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   "Alex was always drawn to the Army," said his mother, Judy Mattox. "He said he was going to be in the infantry and said 'Mom, somebody has got to do it.'"
å¦   "He loved music. He was the king of music in Northeast Texas. He could copy more compact discs than I could count and shared his music with his friends," his mom said. "He also loved Chevy pickups, he had two different ones."
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Mike.
å¦   "He was more than a brother to all of us," said Brandon Morris, who spoke during a eulogy. "He held us together; he was our rock. He wanted to be remembered for who he was, not what he did."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment
IncidentDetails: Pte Cowton had been seriously wounded by a blast after leaving Forward Operating Base Gibraltar.
Bio:
Private Peter Joe Cowton, aged 25, was born on 24th October 1982 and grew up in Basingstoke, where he attended John Hunt of Everest School. Whilst working at a golf club, he joined The Royal Rifle Volunteers (RRV) in January 2004 in search of a career with adventure, lured by the ability to travel to far-flung parts of the world. After completing two tours of Iraq, he enlisted as a regular soldier in 2007. 

Pte Cowton attended recruit training at the Infantry Training Centre, Catterick, after which he was posted to the 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment (2 PARA), arriving at C (Bruneval) Company in September 2007 as pre-deployment training for Operation Herrick 8 was commencing. He deployed to Afghanistan in March 2008. 

Outside of the Army, Pte Cowton loved playing and watching football and golf, reading books and following horse racing. He leaves behind his parents, one brother and one sister.

ServiceUnit: 16 Signal Regiment
IncidentDetails: The attacker rammed his vehicle into the patrol and detonated an explosive device, which wounded Signaller Bland and two further soldiers from 16 Signal Regiment.
Bio:
Signaller Wayne Bland, 21, was a passionate football player and fan, supporting Leeds, where he lived and had grown up. He was single and had no children. His family have issued the following statement:

"Wayne was a much-loved son, grandson, brother and uncle who served his country with distinction and sadly paid the ultimate price. He was our true hero."

ServiceUnit: Battalion, 26th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Staff Sgt. Kristopher D. Rodgers, 29, of Sturgis, Mich., died Aug. 16 in Korengal, Afghanistan, when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Football was such a part of Kristopher D. Rodgers' life that his family asked if he could be given full military honors on the same football field where he was a star more than a decade ago.
å¦   "He would rise to the occasion and sacrifice for the team," said Keith Thompson, a social-studies teacher and head football coach. "When it was time to compete," former teammate T.J. Schneider added, "he turned it on."
å¦   Rodgers, 29, a native of Howe, Ind., and lately of Sturgis, Mich., was killed Aug. 16 in the Korengal Valley when an explosive detonated near his vehicle. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   He was a 1998 high school graduate and was an extreme Chicago Bears fan, loved the Notre Dame Fighting Irish and cheered for the Detroit Red Wings.
å¦   "He was kind of quiet, but he liked to have fun, too," said Kathryn Wiard, Rodgers' mother. "He knew how to have fun. He liked to joke around."
å¦   He is survived by his wife Selina; and 3-year-old son Kaden Dan Rodgers. "He was the most honorable and loving man I ever knew," said his wife. "He loved his family, first and foremost."

ServiceUnit: Royal Highland Fusiliers, 2nd Battalion Royal Regiment of Scotland
IncidentDetails: A British soldier was killed Monday by an IED during a dismounted patrol in the region of Forward Operating Base Attal, in the Gereshk area of Helmand Province.
Bio: Corporal Barry Dempsey was 29 and from Ayrshire. He lived with his wife Shelly, a son, Charlie, aged two, and daughter Andie, aged four, at the battalion‰Ûªs base in Penicuick near Edinburgh.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Combat Engineer Battalion, 3rd Marine Division, III Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Lance Cpl. Jacob J. Toves, 27, of Grover Beach, Calif., died Aug. 14 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Lance Padilla, Jacob J. Toves' childhood friend, saw Toves the day before he left for basic training, and said his friend believed in what he was going to do as a soldier.
å¦   "I definitely think he felt he was doing a good thing," Padilla said.
å¦   Toves, 27, a combat engineer from Grover Beach, Calif., was killed Aug. 14 in Helmand province. He was a 1999 high school graduate and was assigned to Okinawa, Japan.
å¦   "Joining the Marines was something very personal for him," said Yoni Tamaki, who had been friends with Toves since both were 3. "He wanted to make the world a better place."
å¦   He was born in Brookings, Ore., and listed his interests as anything with a board _ skate, snow, surf, wake _ and music. He also wrote that he was interested in neuroscience, bioengineering, etiquette, the arts, electronics, doctorates and philosophical theology.
å¦   "He had a quiet strength and confidence around him," said Arroyo Grande High School teacher Randy Fiser. "He was quiet and polite, not rowdy or boisterous like most teenage boys."
å¦   He is survived by his father, Joe Toves.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Marine Regiment, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails:
The following Marines died Aug. 14 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan:
Cpl. Anthony G. Mihalo, 23, of Naperville, Ill. 
Lance Cpl. Juan Lopez-Castaneda, 19, of Mesa, Ariz.
Bio:
Anthony G. Mihalo earned three Purple Hearts before his death, but hardly ever talked about them.
å¦   "He would be upset with me for talking about that because to him, those were not important wounds," said his stepfather, Bill Wolfe. "Tony is the type who plays off his injuries like they're nothing."
å¦   Mihalo, 23, of Naperville, Ill., died Aug. 14 in combat in the city of Sargin. He was a 2004 high school graduate, on his third combat tour and was assigned to Twentynine Palms.
å¦   "We called him our little dream child because every time he called home he had a new dream," said Mihalo's fiancee, Megan Allen. "He was just full of life."
å¦   Mihalo enrolled in the Marines while still a high school student. He played as a defensive lineman on the football team and played basketball and wrestled.
å¦   He was just a few credits shy of an associate's degree and wanted to earn a bachelor's degree in law enforcement and pursue a career as a police officer.
å¦   "Tony wanted to be the first on the ground, the point of the spear," said his stepfather. "Unfortunately, spear points get nicked."
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Debbie Wolfe.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Marine Regiment, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails:
The following Marines died Aug. 14 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan:
 
Cpl. Anthony G. Mihalo, 23, of Naperville, Ill. 
 
Lance Cpl. Juan Lopez-Castaneda, 19, of Mesa, Ariz.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 506th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: They died Aug. 15 in Wardak Province, Afghanistan, when their vehicle struck an improvised explosive device and then received small arms and rocket-propelled grenade fire.
Bio:
Janice Martin, a Spanish instructor who taught Donald C. Carwile in high school and Northwest Community College, said she'd seen a protective streak even when he was a youth.
å¦   "He went out of his way to be a friend to students who weren't as gifted as some," she said.
å¦   Carwile, 29, of Oxford, Va., was killed Aug. 15 when his vehicle was struck by a roadside bomb and attacked by insurgents in Wardak province. He was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   Wanting to follow his father, grandfather and uncle into law enforcement, he was leaving the Army just as the terrible events of 9/11 unfolded.
å¦   Too far into his discharge to reverse course, he soon was attending the Mississippi Law Enforcement Academy and began as a patrol officer with the Batesville Police Department, and later Oxford Police Department.
å¦   Carwile is survived by his wife, Jennifer, and daughters Reese, 5, and Avery Claire, 3.
å¦   "He cared so much about the men in his platoon," Jennifer Carwile said. "He always said his first goal was to bring his men home, and his second was to come home himself."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 506th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: They died Aug. 15 in Wardak Province, Afghanistan, when their vehicle struck an improvised explosive device and then received small arms and rocket-propelled grenade fire.
Bio:
Born with a small hole in his heart, Paul E. Conlon Jr. had to be delivered during an emergency C-section. He was born "legally dead," his mother said.
å¦   "The odds were stacked against him," said Maria Conlon.
å¦   Conlon, 21, of Somerville, Mass., was killed Aug. 15 by a roadside bomb and assault in Wardak province. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   His catch phrases, goofy poses, sometime mohawk haircuts and interesting hair colors, led family and friends to refer to his "Paulsonality."
å¦   His mother said her son received a generous scholarship to Franklin Pierce University in New Hampshire. "He got it based on his writing ability," she said. "He was the warrior poet."
å¦   Conlon began his tour of duty in Afghanistan in April. He was injured in June and received a Purple Heart but continued serving.
å¦   He played the guitar, loved skateboarding and made friends easily wherever he went. "Paul was a very unique person and he always stood out _ he'd light up a room," said his aunt Victoria Baron.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, John Borges.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 109th Infantry, Pennsylvania Army National Guard
IncidentLocation: Forward Operating Base Mehtar Lam, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: Pfc. Jonathan L. Luscher, 20, of Scranton, Pa., died Aug. 17 at Forward Operating Base Mehtar Lam, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained in a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
å¦   Jonathan L. Luscher left a profound impression on teacher Carol Rubel.
å¦   "Still waters run deep," Rubel said. "He didn't talk a lot, but when he did speak, he had a good sense of humor, and his comments were always very perceptive."
å¦   Luscher, 20, of Scranton, Pa., died Aug. 17 at Forward Operating Base Mehtar Lam from injuries that appear to be self-inflicted. He was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Scranton.
å¦   His brother, Dano, said Luscher was motivated after he completed basic training. "He was smiling a lot more. He was a changed person," he said.
å¦   "He had a purpose in life," said his mother, Johanna Gotay.
å¦   Luscher enlisted with the Army to make enough money to finish a technology degree from McCann School of Business and Technology and to increase his already deep proficiency with computers. He once built a computer that exceeded the capability of personal computers on the market and had an eye toward someday designing electronic games.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Robert. "His passing is a great loss to the city and to this nation, as well as to his family and friends," he said.

IncidentDetails: Three Polish soldiers were killed Wednesday when a roadside bomb exploded in the central province of Ghazni, Polish Defense Ministry spokesman Jacek Poplawski said Thursday.
Three Polish soldiers were killed Wednesday when a roadside bomb exploded in the central province of Ghazni, Polish Defense Ministry spokesman Jacek Poplawski said Thursday.
Three Polish soldiers were killed Wednesday when a roadside bomb exploded in the central province of Ghazni, Polish Defense Ministry spokesman Jacek Poplawski said Thursday.

IncidentDetails: In the southern Kandahar province, meanwhile, a roadside blast Wednesday killed three Canadian soldiers, Canadian officials said.

ServiceUnit: Afghan Regional Security Integration Command-West
IncidentDetails: Sgt. 1st Class David J. Todd Jr., 36, of Marrero, La., died Aug. 20 in Bala Morghab, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his unit was attacked by enemy forces using small arms fire.
Bio:
David J. Todd Jr. had worn Army colors since he was a boy, when his mother bought him fatigues at an Army surplus store. His father, David Todd Sr., served with the Air Force in Vietnam. His mother said that over time, Todd believed in sacrificing to make life better for others.
å¦   "It's better to let 10 soldiers die than 1,000 innocent people," he'd tell his teenage son, according to his mother, Mary.
å¦   Todd, 36, of Marrero, La., was killed Aug. 22 in Bala Morghab by small arms fire. He was assigned to Herat, Afghanistan and had served in Kuwait during Desert Storm.
å¦   He was a former Army ROTC instructor at Tulane University and was proud of his San Antonio roots _ he often wore a cowboy hat and boots.
å¦   As an adult, he put his children at the center of his life, calling them "little gifts" from God, his mother said. He'd take them fishing or boating, or to Mardi Gras.
å¦   After Hurricane Katrina damaged the New Orleans area's schools, he sent two of his children, Kandace Todd, now 18, and David S. Todd, now 16, to live with his parents in St. Hedwig. His other three children, 15, 12 and 2, live with his wife, Tianne, in Louisiana.

ServiceUnit: 720th Explosive Ordnance Disposal Company, 28th Transportation Battalion, 18th Military Police Brigade
IncidentDetails: Staff Sgt. Brian E. Studer, 28, of Ramsey, Minn., died Aug. 22 in Ghazni, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when the improvised explosive device he was attempting to deactivate detonated.
Bio:
Brian E. Studer _ who earned the nickname "The Ogre" for his large frame and quiet disposition _ became friends with a goat while at war.
å¦   Another unit had the animal, but didn't adequately care for it. So he and another soldier stole the goat and brought it to their own compound.
å¦   "The Ogre would then go out every night and water and talk to his goat and then bring it inside if it rained," according to Sgt. 1st Class Jay Wilson. "This is the kind of man Staff Sgt. Brian Studer was _ caring, compassionate and honorable."
å¦   Studer, 28, of Ramsey, Minn., died Aug. 22 in Ghazni of wounds from an explosive. He was a 1999 high school graduate and was assigned to Mannheim, Germany.
å¦   After high school, he passed on college to go into the Army. said his brother, Philip Studer. "He wanted to see the world and do some good."
å¦   Studer planned to use his military experience by joining HALO Trust, a nongovernmental organization that specializes in removal of war debris, including mines. "He wanted to use his experience in a nonmilitary way," his bother said.
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Ellen Hanson, and father, Gene Studer.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 26th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Army Staff Sgt. David L. Paquet, 26, Rising Sun, Md.; died Wednesday at Combat Outpost Vegas, Afghanistan, of undetermined causes while conducting a patrol.
Bio:
å¦   A year after he joined the service, David L. Paquet and his future wife were set up on a date by a friend. Katie Paquet said she was drawn to her future husband's blue eyes and that they enjoyed watching sports and traveling. The couple married in 2002.
å¦   "As for his personality, all that I can say is he's one in a million," she said. "There'll never be another Dave."
å¦   Paquet, 26, of Rising Sun, Md., died Aug. 20 at Combat Outpost Vegas of undetermined causes while conducting a patrol. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   "He didn't suffer, he didn't have breathing problems. It was just his time," Katie Paquet said. "The Army has done everything possible and is answering my questions. But it's just hard for me to understand why he just collapsed."
å¦   The son of longtime harness horseman Fern Paquet and his wife Dawn, Paquet was a seasoned Army veteran who had also served tours of duty in Iraq and Kuwait.
å¦   "He always gave advice, told them what to do," Katie Paquet said of his soldiers. "He had a big heart and was there for people when they needed him. And then, on the other side, he was a completely funny guy."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 4th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: Pvt. Tan Q. Ngo, 20, of Beaverton, Ore., died Aug. 27 in Kandahar, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered in Zabul Province, Afghanistan, when his mounted patrol received small arms and rocket-propelled grenade fire.
Bio:
One of Tan Q. Ngo's hobbies was cooking. He could turn anything, even potatoes and eggs, into a meal as long as it was super spicy, said his brother.
å¦   "He could put anything together and make it taste good," Timmy Ngo said.
å¦   Ngo, 20, of Beaverton, Ore., was killed Aug. 27 by small-arms and rocket-propelled grenade fire in Zabul province. He was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Hohenfels, Germany.
å¦   "He wanted to protect his country. He didn't want another 9/11," said his mother, Binh Thanh Sam. "He said, 'This is our home now, I want to take care of it.'
å¦   He walked his younger brothers to school. He volunteered through Key Club at school and spent a year in the Job Corps, working to become a chef and then as a house painter. He also liked video games, including Grand Theft Auto and Halo.
å¦   "He always said, 'Mom, I love you,'" Sam said. "He was a big boy, but a little kid at heart."
å¦   He liked nothing better than playing pickup basketball or football, or playing cards with friends. "He had lots of moms, he was a neighborhood boy," Sam said.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Ut Quoc Ngo.

ServiceUnit: temporarily forward deployed from his assignment at Naval Special Warfare Development Group
IncidentDetails: Petty Officer 1st Class Joshua Harris, 36,of Lexington, N.C., died Aug. 30 from injuries sustained while conducting combat operations in Afghanistan.
Bio:
Call Joshua Harris a warrior-artist. In addition to being a Navy Seal, he was an accomplished artist whose paintings were once displayed in New York City.
å¦   "His art had a great deal of force and darkness," said Jim Moon, founder of Asolare Fine Arts Academy in North Carolina. "It was extraordinarily strong and powerful."
å¦   Harris, 36, of Lexington, N.C., drowned Aug. 30 after being swept away by turbulent waters while conducting a river crossing during combat operations. He was assigned to Dam Neck, Va.
å¦   Harris, an all-county and all-conference football player, graduated from Davidson College in 1994 with a degree in studio art and pursued a master's degree in architecture from the University of North Carolina at Charlotte.
å¦   Harris' artwork has been on display at several shows on the East Coast including the Lincoln Center in New York City. He is survived by his parents, Evelyn and Dr. Sam Harris.
å¦   "There are not enough words to say about a son like Josh," his mother said. "He was the most generous spirit you have ever met. He respected everyone who had a goodwill about them."

ServiceUnit: Second Battalion, Princess Patricia‰Ûªs Canadian Light Infantry
IncidentDetails: Three Canadian soldiers were killed and five injured after an insurgent attack on their armoured vehicle while they were conducting a security patrol in Zharey district.

ServiceUnit: Second Battalion, Princess Patricia‰Ûªs Canadian Light Infantry
IncidentDetails: Three Canadian soldiers were killed and five injured after an insurgent attack on their armoured vehicle while they were conducting a security patrol in Zharey district.

IncidentDetails: Three Canadian soldiers were killed and five injured after an insurgent attack on their armoured vehicle while they were conducting a security patrol in Zharey district.

ServiceUnit: K-9 unit of the 527th Military Police Company, 709th Military Police Battalion, 18th MP Brigade
IncidentDetails: Rodriguez died Tuesday of wounds suffered in Ana Kalay, Afghanistan, of small arms fire.
Bio:
Gregory A. Rodriguez was a former football player and wrestler who sought to keep order both before joining the Army and while he was in it, said his sister.
å¦   "My brother liked to be the law," said Lisa Dombrowski. "He liked justice. If it wasn't right, he made it right."
å¦   Rodriguez, 35, died Sept. 2 of wounds suffered in Ana Kalay when his mounted patrol came under small-arms fire. He was a 1991 high school graduate and was assigned to Ansbach, Germany.
å¦   "Rod," as he was known to his Army buddies, was a Red Wings fan who loved to hassle fans of other hockey teams he met during his military career, said his wife, Laura Rodriguez.
å¦   "Greg loved to push everyone's buttons and get people going with his rare, unique sense of sarcasm," she said. At the same time, her husband, a military police dog handler whose dog Jacko survived the fatal ambush, was "a very committed, loyal individual and could be counted on whenever needed."
å¦   He had been stationed in Hawaii, Missouri, Alaska and Texas.
å¦   Rodriguez also is survived by three children: 8-year-old Gregory Jr., 7-year old Zachary and 3-year-old Malory.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion The Royal Irish Regiment
IncidentDetails: Ranger Cupples was killed early Thursday while on a foot patrol in Sangin town, northern Helmand.
Bio:
Ranger Cupples was born in the United States on 29 July 1979. He served with the US Navy during Operation Iraqi Freedom. His family lived in Miami before moving to County Cavan in the Republic of Ireland, where he met his wife Vilma. He began training in Infantry Training Centre Catterick in February 2007. On completion of his training he joined The 1st Battalion The Royal Irish Regiment and in September 2007 he was posted to 7 Platoon C Company. 

Known as 'Cups' to his friends, Ranger Cupples went to Kenya and took part in Exercise Grand Prix where he performed outstandingly from the outset. He immediately showed himself to be a strong soldier. During the Op HERRICK 8 pre-deployment training, Ranger Cupples showed he had a gift for languages and was an obvious choice for the Operational Language Training Course. He developed his skill for Pashtu and used this to great effect on all patrols. Often the platoon was able to deploy without an interpreter as he was more than capable of communicating with the locals. 

Ranger Cupples was a quiet but well spoken individual, enthusiastic and very mature. Motivated and showing all the fine characteristics typified of Irish soldiers, Ranger Cupples was a popular member of Ranger Company and impressed his commanders from the start. He was well known to his comrades as a team player who always put others before himself. He was a proud member of Ranger Company and a great friend to us all. Ranger Cupples will be sorely missed by his commanders and comrades alike.

ServiceUnit: Second Battalion, Princess Patricia‰Ûªs Canadian Light Infantry
IncidentDetails: A Canadian soldier was killed when his armored vehicle struck a roadside bomb in the Panjwayi district of Kandahar province.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 26th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Army Pvt. Michael R. Dinterman, 18, Littlestown, Pa.; died Sept. 6 at Outpost Restrepo, Kunar Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when he received enemy fire while on dismounted patrol.
Bio:
A little boy's death changed the direction of Michael R. Dinterman's life.
å¦   He enlisted in the Army in January because he wanted to do something with his life after the death of his 3-month-old nephew, Noah.
å¦   "He came home for that and just decided that life was too short and he wanted to do something with his," said Dinterman's mom, Lora Martin. "It changed him to say, 'What do I want in life?'"
å¦   Dinterman, 18, of Littlestown, Pa., died Sept. 6 in Kunar province of wounds from small-arms fire. He was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   He enjoyed all types of sports including football, baseball, basketball and especially enjoyed going to the beach. He was taking classes at Harrisburg Area Community College.
å¦   Alan Staub, who coached Dinterman in baseball, recalled the young man as being the first one to practice, eager to learn and competitive.
å¦   "He knew when to have a good time and when to be serious," said Matthew Meakin, his former athletic director.
å¦   He is survived by his parents and stepparents, Lora Martin and Michael A. Martin, and Richard Dinterman and Misty Stonesifer.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 2nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Pvt. Vincent C. Winston Jr., 22, St. Louis, Mo.; died Sept. 4 in Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Vincent C. Winston Jr. always knew he wanted to follow in his father's military footsteps.
å¦   "He was different from most kids; he was more serious, he stayed determined," said his father, Vincent Cortez Winston Sr.
å¦   Winston Jr., 22, of St. Louis, died Sept. 4 after his vehicle struck an explosive. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   Army Maj. Gen. Charles Cartwright told mourners of Winston's dedication, big smile and love of family. "He asked nothing for nothing," Cartwright said.
å¦   His father, an Army veteran of Desert Storm, often told his oldest son of the realities of Army life. "I told him the Army was a great career, but it wasn't for everyone," Winston Sr. said.
å¦   He signed up for the Job Corps in St. Louis after going to high school in Tennessee. Then he went into the Army.
å¦   "He wanted to get off the streets and that's why he wanted to go _ he wanted to make something of himself," said his mother, Angie Little.
å¦   Relatives hope Winston will be remembered as a leader, a role model and a good man. His aunt Betty Little said, "I want them to remember the smile, to remember Vincent as Vincent."

ServiceUnit: Combat Logistics Battalion 37, 3rd Marine Logistics Group, III Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: 1st Lt. Nicholas A. Madrazo, 25, of Bothell, Wash., died Sept. 9 while supporting combat operations in Parwan province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Nicholas A. Madrazo told his family about the joy he found in giving candy to Afghan children. Later, after learning about the lack of dental care, he worried about the children getting cavities and started giving them pens, pencils and paper.
å¦   "He cared about the people there," said Jenny Madrazo, his mother. "The kids were really excited to see Nic."
å¦   Madrazo, 25, of Bothell, Wash., was killed Sept. 9 by a roadside bomb in Parwan province. He was a 2001 high school graduate and was assigned to Okinawa, Japan.
å¦   He played soccer in high school and received a degree in business from Seattle Pacific University in 2005. On the soccer field, he was known as a tough competitor.
å¦   "He was aggressive, but always kept his smile on the field," said William Frankhouser, a classmate. "He was the guy who was always friendly and smiling and willing to befriend anyone."
å¦   Madrazo was a great listener and a good friend, said Beth Flansburg, a friend. "He wanted to make things better for people," she said. He lived to tell jokes and impersonate movie stars.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Joel.

ServiceUnit: Headquarters Battery, 12th Marines, 3rd Marine Division, Marine Corps Base Hawaii
IncidentDetails: Capt. Jesse Melton III, 29, of Randallstown, Md., died Sept. 9 while supporting combat operations in Parwan province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
After attending attended boot camp at Parris Island, Jesse Melton III's family instantly saw a change.
å¦   "It literally changed his life," said his younger sister, Jenine Melton, a captain in the U.S. Army. "He used to be very messy _ the way, most of the time, boys' rooms aren't so neat. But when I went to see him in Parris Island, you could bounce a quarter off his bed."
å¦   Melton, 29, of Randallstown, Md., was killed Sept. 9 during combat operations in Parwan province. He was assigned to Kaneohe Bay.
å¦   After graduating high school in 1996 _ he played lacrosse and baseball _ Melton attended Messiah College in Grantham, Pa., where he studied communications and graduated in 2000.
å¦   "He would say, 'I am willing to take a bullet for my country and my men,'" said Melton's mother, Janice Chance. "'If I need to give my life for my Marines, I will take a bullet for them.'"
å¦   Melton was always concerned with helping others, said his family. He always tried to lead by example and he always looked for the good in everyone. "He would say that if I can save one person that would be worth it," said Chance.

ServiceUnit: Military Transition Team, 1st Brigade, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died March 14 at Brooke Army Medical Center, San Antonio, Texas, of wounds suffered Jan. 2 in Khowst Province, Afghanistan, when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Justin Bowen said his brother, Collin J. Bowen, often asked friends and family to send him candy, pencils and paper for Afghan children.
å¦   "As a father of three, it was very important to him to be an ambassador to the children," Justin Bowen said.
å¦   Bowen, 38, of Millersville, Md., died March 14, 2008, at Brook Army Medical Center. He was critically injured Jan. 2 in a roadside bombing in Khowst province.
å¦   Bowen, with his eyes sewn shut and a breathing tube down his throat, wasn't able to speak after the attack. On good days, he would shrug his shoulders or wiggle his toes with a "yes" or "no" to questions.
å¦   Bowen graduated in 1988 from high school in Indiana, and earned a degree in computer science at University of Maryland, Baltimore County. He is survived by his wife, Ursula, their daughter, Gabriela, 3, and two stepdaughters, Erin, 13, and Katelyn, 10.
å¦   He was serving in the National Guard when he was sent, at his request, to Afghanistan in January 2007, family members said.
å¦   "He felt like it was his calling to train other soldiers," said a brother, Shelby Bowen. "He really believed in what the U.S. was doing there, and he really enjoyed it."

ServiceUnit: Naval Special Warfare Development Group
IncidentDetails: Chief Petty Officer (select) Jason Richard Friewald, 30, of Armada, Mich., died Sept. 12 from injuries sustained while conducting combat operations in Afghanistan Sept. 11.
Bio:
Jason Richard Freiwald had one brother who also is a Navy SEAL, another training to become one and a third who is in college.
å¦   "Their whole family makes everyone in this area quite proud," said Nancy Moegle, a physical education teacher at Armada High School.
å¦   Freiwald, 30, of Armada, Mich., died Sept. 12 from injuries sustained while conducting combat operations. He was temporarily deployed from his assignment at Naval Special Warfare Development Group.
å¦   Freiwald's initial duties were with SEAL teams in California where he completed qualifications to prepare him for combat including sniper training, Arabic, and tactical rock climbing.
å¦   Freiwald is one of four brothers all of whom have strong athletic backgrounds, especially in wrestling. Their father, Richard, is the former president of the Armada Athletic Boosters.
å¦   "They are a very close family, no doubt, just real good people," said Ken Keding, a longtime area resident, who visited the Freiwald family to pay their respects along with his wife.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Stacey, and a daughter, Jasmine.

ServiceUnit: Naval Special Warfare Development Group
IncidentDetails: Senior Chief Petty Officer Wayne Marcum, 34, of Flushing, Mich., died Sept. 12 from injuries sustained while conducting combat operations in Afghanistan Sept. 11.
Bio:
Wayne Marcum was destined to go into the military, according to one of his high school administrators. The two had many conversations about his chosen career path.
å¦   "He wanted to have some active role in some branch of the military," said Archie Bailey. "I believe it offered something that met his needs. He was a patriot."
å¦   Marcum, 34, of Flushing, Mich., died Sept. 12 after being shot in battle. He was temporarily forward deployed from his assignment at Naval Special Warfare Development Group.
å¦   "Marcum was "the kind of kid that could light up your day," said Bailey, now Genesee County commissioner. "What a loss. He was a wonderful, wonderful kid."
å¦   His military career included multiple combat deployments in support of joint U.S. Army and NATO operations, according to a statement from the military. His long list of awards includes four Bronze Stars with combat "V."
å¦   Family friend Martha Wellisley said she knew Marcum all his life. "Everybody's just heartbroken," she said. "He had a real good personality."
å¦   Marcum's survivors include his wife Cynthia and a daughter, Madison.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment
IncidentDetails: Private Jason Lee Rawstron was killed when his patrol were engaged in an exchange of fire with the Taliban near Forward Operating Base Gibraltar on 12 September 2008.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Parachute Regiment
IncidentDetails: Lance Corporal Mason, 26, died as a result of an explosion while on patrol near Kajaki, in Helmand province, the cause of which is being investigated.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 26th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Marques I. Knight, 24, San Juan Capistrano, Calif.; died Saturday in Aliabad, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered from small arms fire.
Bio:
å¦   During his first tour of duty, Marques I. Knight was known as the soldier who didn't get care packages. He was estranged from his biological family.
å¦   "He was always embarrassed that he didn't have anyone," said Kathi Conroy, whose son served with Knight in Iraq and who took him in for more than a year. "This was not a soldier who was loved and cared for."
å¦   Knight, 24, of San Juan Capistrano, Calif., died Sept. 6, 2008, in Aliabad of wounds from small-arms fire. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   Richard Santana was Knight's team leader in Mosul. The soldier he described was efficient and cool under pressure.
å¦   Santana said Knight "always made sure where the enemy was at; he was always keeping me informed, even when he was being shot at."
å¦   Knight re-enlisted for another four years in 2007, hoping to use the re-signing bonus to build a future as a personal trainer or a psychologist.
å¦   Victor Birdseye III, Knight's platoon leader in Iraq, remembered Knight as a quiet, well-liked soldier who enjoyed listening to rap music.
å¦   On his off time, Knight was almost never without his MP3 embedded sunglasses. "I don't know how he heard anything," said Birdseye, laughing.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 17th Cavalry Regiment, 101st Combat Aviation Brigade, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: Chief Warrant Officer Michael Slebodnik, 39, of Gibsonia, Pa., died Sept. 11 at Bagram Airfield, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered near Forward Operating Base Nagil, Afghanistan, when the aircraft he was piloting received enemy fire.
Bio:
Michael Slebodnik was a loving father and a voracious eater, but first and foremost he was a soldier.
å¦   "He's been in almost 22 years, and he could have easily gotten out," said his wife, Tanja. "He never chose that option. It's like a complete mission _ you don't leave until your mission is complete."
å¦   Slebodnik, 39, of Gibsonia, Pa., died Sept. 11 after the aircraft he was piloting received enemy fire near Forward Operating Base Nagil. He was a 1987 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   He was a talented artist and a math whiz. He was fascinated by the Civil War and battle strategy and developed a strong bond with his grandfather who served in World War II. He planned to attend college and become a teacher.
å¦   He had served five tours in Iraq since 2003 and was a veteran of Operation Desert Storm. "He loved the military. He wanted to fly. He loved being a soldier," said his mother, Patricia Slebodnik. "He died on 9/11 _ so appropriate."
å¦   He also is survived by four children and two stepsons: Jake, Ginger, Spencer, Ben, Dylan and Michie.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 6th Field Artillery Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Pvt. Michael W. Murdock, 22, of Chocowinity, N.C., died Sept. 11 at Bagram Airfield, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered at Combat Outpost Lybert, Afghanistan, when he was struck by enemy fire.
Bio:
å¦   Michael W. Murdock joined the military after his grandmother died, seeking direction in his life, said his mother, Jennifer Tripp.
å¦   "Michael was a mild-tempered, sweet, brave young man. He showed perseverance many times over," said Tripp. "He loved his family and friends. He loved four-wheelers, playing basketball and hanging out with his friends."
å¦   Murdock, 22, of Chocowinity, N.C., was fatally wounded by enemy fire Sept. 11, 2008, at Combat Outpost Lybert and later died at Bagram Airfield. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   "His base was attacked, and he was shot while preparing for his fighting position," said his mother.
å¦   Michael was her only son. "You couldn't have met a better person," she said. "This has been really hard."
å¦   Murdock enlisted in June 2006, completing basic training in October 2000 at Fort Leonard Wood. He completed additional training at Fort Sill.
å¦   Walter Murdock said his son had plans to go back to school after leaving the military and wanted to be an architect or engineer.

ServiceUnit: Combat Service Support Det. 36
IncidentDetails: Navy Hospital Corpsman 3rd Class Eichmann A. Strickland, 23, Arlington, Wash.; died Sept. 9 from injuries suffered when his vehicle struck an explosive in Afghanya Valley, Afghanistan
Bio:
å¦   Eichmann A. Strickland's career flourished in the Navy, allowing him to serve in myriad medical postings. While at Camp Pendleton, he worked with infants. A year later, he was assisting wounded during live-fire exercises at Camp Fuji, Japan. Comrades called him "Doc."
å¦   Strickland, 23, of Arlington, Wash., died Sept. 9, 2008, from injuries suffered when his vehicle struck an explosive in Afghanya Valley. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Iwakuni, Japan.
å¦   "He was a compassionate guy, dedicated to helping others," said Chris Sheppard, Strickland's cousin. "He put his training to good use."
å¦   He was given the opportunity to receive an early discharge in June 2008, which he declined. Instead, he extended his term of service to go to Afghanistan.
å¦   "He gave his all," said his mother, Yolly Strickland. "A very quiet boy, never in trouble. He always smiled. He was that kind of person."
å¦   He hoped for a career in the medical field, perhaps as a physician assistant. He aspired to join a medical mission to Africa.
å¦   He also is survived by Ken Strickland, his adopted father.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion 122nd Field Artillery, Illinois Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Wednesday in Gerdia Seria, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered with their vehicle struck an explosive.
Bio:
Jason A. Vazquez's girlfriend said he was very involved with his family and was focused on his career.
å¦   "I watched him achieve everything he wanted in these past three years," said Genevieve Gonzalez. "He made my life so much happier. He was more than just a partner, he was my best friend."
å¦   Vazquez, 24, of Chicago, was killed Sept. 17 when his vehicle struck an explosive in Gerdia Seria. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Sycamore, Ill.
å¦   Vazquez was the type of son who would hang his grandmother's curtains, plant flowers in her garden and visit his grandparents regularly, relatives said. Even in Afghanistan, he found a way to talk to them every day. He last asked for his Chicago Bears and Cubs hats to be sent.
å¦   He and Gonzalez, who planned to marry on Labor Day in 2009, met on a MySpace Web site about three years ago. Vazquez helped his girlfriend raise her 8-year-old daughter. "He was her world, she keeps asking: "Where is my Jason?'"
å¦   "I just sent out three care packages" to him in Afghanistan, Gonzalez said. "He asked for his Chicago Bears and Cubs hats. I know he probably never received them."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 11th Infantry
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Wednesday in Gerdia Seria, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered with their vehicle struck an explosive.
Bio:
Those who knew Mohsin A. Naqvi said he hoped his Muslim faith and heritage could help bridge cultural divides, but he often struggled against people who questioned his patriotism.
å¦   "We were really proud of him joining the forces," said Aziz Ahsan, who is active in the Muslim community. "He's the most patriotic person I've known, and he sacrificed his life for all Americans, not just Muslim Americans."
å¦   Naqvi, 26, of Newburgh, N.Y., was killed Sept. 17 by a roadside bomb in Gerdia Seria. He was assigned to Fort Benning.
å¦   He fought in the invasion of Iraq in 2003, and re-enlisted for a tour of Afghanistan. The 2006 graduate of the State University at Geneseo, deployed a day after his wedding.
å¦   "He was always cracking jokes," said New York Army National Guard Sgt. 1st Class Eric Hunt.
å¦   Naqvi, who was born in Pakistan and came to the U.S. with his family as a child, became a naturalized U.S. citizen when he was 16.
å¦   "He made it a joy to come to work, very dedicated and a true patriot to the core," said Capt. Carl Purgerson, his boss at Fort Benning.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Raazia.

ServiceUnit: Wyoming Joint Forces Headquarters, Wyoming Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Wednesday in Gerdia Seria, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered with their vehicle struck an explosive.
Bio:
Col. Greg Porter, chief of staff for the Army and Air Guard, said Bruce E. Hays was very quiet and soft spoken.
å¦   "A good person. A good man. A good soldier," Porter said.
å¦   Hays, 42, of Cheyenne, Wyo., was killed Sept. 17 by a roadside bomb in Gerdia Seria. He graduated high school in New Mexico in 1984 and was assigned to Cheyenne.
å¦   He joined the Army after graduating and served for eight years, including service in Desert Storm. Hays then went on to attend New Mexico State University, during which he worked at the Army Research Lab at White Sands Missile Range.
å¦   He graduated in 1996 and went on to work as a surveyor with the USDA Soil Service. Hays was an active duty member of the Army National Guard of Wyoming at the time of this death.
å¦   "He was very well-respected and known throughout the organization as highly technical and competent. And perhaps more importantly, a very decent person who exemplified the army values of honor, integrity and service," said Brig. Gen. Olin Oedekoven.
å¦   Hays is survived by his wife Marie, and his children, Bethany Hays, Eleanor Hays, John Vance III, Alfonso Vance and Genevieve Vance.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion 122nd Field Artillery, Illinois Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Sept. 17 in Gerdia Seria, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
It was a lifelong dream of Joshua W. Harris' to serve in the military and he enlisted with the National Guard while he was still in high school.
å¦   Don Gillingham, executive director of Walther Lutheran High School, remembered Harris as the kid who always wore a smile but felt a deep sense of purpose.
å¦   "He felt like he was doing something important," Gillingham said of Harris' military aspirations. "He had that. His life had purpose. His life had meaning."
å¦   Harris, 21, of Romeoville, Ill., was killed Sept. 17 when his vehicle struck an explosive in Gerdia Seria. He was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Robbins, Ill.
å¦   Harris loved history and once visited the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Museum on a trip to Springfield. He was enthralled by the Civil War exhibits.
å¦   He was a member of a Boy Scout drum and bugle corps, and continued in the military, often playing taps on the bugle at the funerals of fallen comrades.
å¦   He is survived by his father and stepmother, Bill and Jean Harris, and his mother, Mille Harris-Hickey.
å¦   "He died in the line of duty doing what he chose to do," said Harris' father.

ServiceUnit: nd Battalion, 7th Marine Regiment, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine Sgt. Jerome C. Bell Jr., 29, of Auburn, N.Y., died Sept. 19 while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Jerome C. Bell Jr. enlisted in the Marines in 1996 and served one tour of duty in Iraq. He left in 2004. When his daughters were old enough for school, he asked his mother for permission to re-enlist.
å¦   "He missed it so much," Tammy Bell said. "He asked me if I minded if he went back in. He had enough respect to ask me if I minded. I knew he never wanted to get out. How do you tell a 27-year-old Marine, a married man, he didn't need his mother's permission?"
å¦   Bell Jr., 29, of Auburn, N.Y., died Sept. 19 during combat operations in Farah province. He was assigned to Twentynine Palms.
å¦   "He was my hero long before this _ long, long before this," said lifelong friend, Donald Wilson.
å¦   He played football in high school and loved to hunt. Superintendent William Speck said he remembered Bell as a good student who was in the construction trades program, particularly heavy equipment repair and operations.
å¦   "He was a really good kid, he did very well academically," Speck said. "He was a very good citizen for us.
å¦   He is survived by his wife Melissa, daughters Katrazyna, 9, and Taylor, 8, and a son, Jerry III, 3.

ServiceUnit: 27th Brigade Combat Team, New York Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Wiley died Sept. 18 at Bagram Airfield, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained in a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
About a year ago, James L. Wiley decided to don fatigues again and become a soldier for one final tour in Iraq.
å¦   "While he was there, he really became a humanitarian," said his mother, Ruth Wiley. "He collected clothing for the children. He told me, 'Mom, we can fight as many wars as we want, but when we get the children believing in us, that's when we will get the wars to stop.'"
å¦   Wiley, 46, of North Bend, Ore., died Sept. 18 at Bagram Airfield of injuries from a noncombat-related incident. He was a 1979 high school graduate and was assigned to Syracuse, N.Y.
å¦   He earned degrees in math and chemistry as well as marketing and management from the University of Oregon. He also was a member of the Oregon National Guard during college.
å¦   Wiley then earned a law degree from Willamette Law School and enlisted in the Army as a captain. His father, Jim Sr., pinned his bars on his son.
å¦   His law degree led to a posting with the government as a military attorney in Germany. When it was time to return home, the government asked him to stay as chief legal counsel.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Theresa, and three daughters.

ServiceUnit: 11 Explosive Ordnance Disposal Regiment Royal Logistic Corps
IncidentDetails: Warrant Officer Class 2 Gary 'Gaz' O'Donnell GM died from injuries sustained from an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) in Musa Qaleh, Helmand province.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 26th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Staff Sgt. Brandon W. Farley, 30, Grand Prairie, Texas, died Sept. 18 at Bagram Airfield, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained Sept. 17 when his patrol was attacked by small arms fire and rocket-propelled grenades in Able Monti, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Brandon W. Farley loved guns and shooting, going four-wheeling and being social. "But one thing he didn't like was getting dirty," said his father, Wade. "He enjoyed the finer things in life _ the best of whatever he could afford."
å¦   Farley, 30, of Grand Prairie, Texas, died Sept. 18 from small-arms fire and rocket-propelled grenades in Able Monti. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   Farley "was always interested in the military and military history," said Victor Balagbagan, a social sciences teacher. "Brandon has given all. People like Brandon is what being a hero is all about."
å¦   Out of high school, Farley joined the Marines and did one tour of duty. He then enlisted in the Oklahoma Army National Guard and later enlisted in the active-duty Army. He also saw duty in Iraq.
å¦   Farley's brother, Corey, also described his brother as a fun-loving person. "He loved serving his country," Corey Farley said. "He was a go-getter who had talked about joining the military ever since he was 16."
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Sherry Farley.
å¦   "He was a good kid," his father said.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 26th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers died Sept. 20 in the Korengal Valley, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Nathan M. Cox was known to care about his men, knowing they were young and away from home for the first time.
å¦   "He'd run with guys on his own time that needed to lose a little weight. He'd take the time to talk to guys who had broken up with their girlfriends or something. Everybody was at their house all the time," said his mother, Jane Cox.
å¦   Cox, 32, of Walcott, Iowa, was killed Sept. 20 when his vehicle struck an explosive in Korengal Valley. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   Cox entered the Army and served three years in Bosnia in the mid-1990s before deciding at 29 to re-enter the Army and make it his career. He served a year in Iraq prior to his Afghanistan deployment.
å¦   "He was very special," said his mother. "He was an amazing young man who had so much time left."
å¦   One reason Cox rejoined was so he could explore new places. Jane Cox said that's why he liked describing the countries where he was stationed. "He's very, very interested in foreign affairs," Cox said. "He said the country was beautiful over there."
å¦   Cox is survived by his wife, Annie, and 5-year-old daughter, Sophia.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 26th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers died Sept. 20 in the Korengal Valley, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when their vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Whenever Joseph F. Gonzales Jr. visited his family, he would point to a picture of himself as a toddler dressed in combat fatigues.
å¦   "He would look at it and say, 'It's fate.' It was something that he was meant to do," said his father, Joseph Gonzales Sr.
å¦   Gonzales, 18, of Tucson, Ariz., was killed Sept. 20 when his vehicle struck an explosive in Korengal Valley. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   He considered his enlistment in the Army in Phoenix at age 17 his birthday gift to himself, his father said. Gonzales Sr. and his wife gave their permission so their son didn't have to wait another year.
å¦   Gonzales Sr. said his own brother served in Kuwait but that neither he nor Gonzales Jr.'s mother, Ana, wanted their son to go to war. "We were trying to go the opposite way with him," he said. "But we couldn't stop it so we went with him" and supported his military commitment."
å¦   He wanted to be a Tucson Police SWAT officer once his Army commitment was fulfilled, said Laura Garcia, a friend. "I am very proud of him and thank him so much for serving his country," she said.

ServiceUnit: 86th Construction & Training Squadron
IncidentDetails: Maj. Rodolfo I. Rodriguez, 34, of El Paso, Texas, died Sept. 20 in Islamabad, Pakistan, of wounds suffered from an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Rodolfo I. Rodriguez was the son of immigrant parents and earned selection to the Air Force Academy. He was proud of going from a child who learned English as his second language to being commissioned an officer.
å¦   The wide range of experiences meant Rodriguez could relate to airmen of any rank. "He wasn't afraid to get his boots dirty," said Maj. Andrew Sheehan.
å¦   Rodriguez, 34, of El Paso, Texas, killed by a terrorist bomb in Islamabad, Pakistan on Sept. 20. A civil engineering officer, he was assigned to Ramstein Air Base.
å¦   After graduating from the academy in 1998, Rodriguez went on to serve in civil engineer units, including a tour at Vandenberg Air Force Base. The deployment to Pakistan was Rodriguez's third lengthy assignment since 2001, including six months at Kirkuk Air Base, Iraq in 2006.
å¦   Repeatedly described as a quiet man, Rodriguez listened much more than he spoke. "For those of us who have a tendency to perhaps say a few too many words, we are quick to be quiet when Rod is speaking because there is wisdom in his words," Sheehan said.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Caryn.

Prefix: Cryptologic Technician Third Class Petty Officer
ServiceUnit: Navy Information Operations Command Maryland
IncidentDetails: Navy Cryptologic Technician Third Class Petty Officer Matthew J. O‰ÛªBryant, 22, of Duluth, Ga., died September 20 in the bombing of the Marriott Hotel in Islamabad, Pakistan.
Bio:
Matthew J. O'Bryant was known for his ability to make people smile.
å¦   "He was the nicest person you'd ever know. He got along with everybody. He was friendly, he was a real good person," said Roger O'Bryant, Matthew's uncle.
å¦   O'Bryant, 22, of Duluth, Ga., died Sept. 20 in a bombing in Islamabad, Pakistan. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Meade.
å¦   O'Bryant's commanding officer, Capt. Richard Bodziak said, "He was exactly the kind of sailor we want in the Navy."
å¦   O'Bryant, who was a cryptologic technician, was "first in his class," Bodziak said. He said the sailor exhibited "honor, courage and commitment."
å¦   Just prior to a funeral service, Lawrence O'Bryant told everyone who came up to him how proud he was of his brother. He noted that four members of the family _ the two brothers and two of their cousins _ were all serving in the Navy at the same time.
å¦   "There were four of us in the Navy," he said. "Well, there's three now." He paused, then added, "I guess there will always be four of us because he will always be in the Navy."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Bridgette.

ServiceUnit: Joint Forces Headquarters, Element Training Team, Oregon Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Capt. Bruno G. Desolenni, 32, of Crescent City, Calif., died Sept. 20 in Kandahar, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
Oregon National Guard Capt. Dominic Oto described Bruno de Solenni as smart, kind and with a steel core that made him the best officer on the team.
å¦   "He loved the Afghans, and in combat never was there a better operator or leader," said Oto. "The man was absolutely fearless."
å¦   De Solenni, 32, of Crescent City, Calif., was killed by a roadside bomb Sept. 20 in Kandahar. He was a 1994 high school graduate and was assigned to the Joint Forces Headquarters.
å¦   Before being stationed in Afghanistan for the past nine months, the Oregon National Guardsman had served in Egypt and Iraq, where he had a previous brush with death.
å¦   "He was on patrol when he had a mortar _ it turned out to be a dud _ drop right between his legs," said his father, Mario. "We always thought Bruno was invincible."
å¦   He had labored as a crab fishermen and a logger and was working toward his bachelor's degree from Southern Oregon University in Ashland.
å¦   "He was always one to inspire people, no matter where he was, he was able to bring out the good qualities in people," said his brother Gino.
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Cali Martin.

ServiceUnit: 1st Squadron, 61st Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: Sgt. William E. Hasenflu died Sept. 28 in the Jaji District, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered when his unit was ambushed by enemy forces using small arms fire.
Bio:
Michael Mendoza said William E. Hasenflu stood "side-by-side" with him as he was rehabilitated from a traumatic head injury sustained in a military training exercise in 1993.
å¦   Mendoza spent years relearning common activities and finding another way to put food on the table, and Hasenflu was there throughout to help, he said.
å¦   "Bill helped tutor me during my community re-entry programs and years of life coaching," said Mendoza. "He always helped people focus on what they could do and not what they couldn't do."
å¦   Hasenflu, 38, of Bradenton, Fla., was killed Sept. 28 by small-arms fire in the Jaji district. He was assigned to Fort Campbell and his was on his fourth tour in Afghanistan.
å¦   Hasenflu enlisted in the Navy as soon as he graduated high school in Meadville, Pa., where he grew up, Mann said. He also served in the Navy Reserves and the National Guard before joining the Army in May 2005, his family said.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Judith, and daughters Savannah, Ashley and Veronica. He and his wife home-schooled the girls, always vacationed as a family and loved singing old-time Christmas carols together.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Cliff died Sept. 29 in Yakhchal, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device during mounted operations.
Bio:
Richard G. Cliff Jr. spent as much time in the water as a dolphin, swimming and surfing with his brother. The two boys, born only 16 months apart, had a special bond.
å¦   "It was just him and me," Eddie recalled. "He was my big brother, and I looked up to him."
å¦   Cliff, 29, of Mount Pleasant, S.C., was killed Sept. 29 in an explosion in Yakhchal. He was a 2002 graduate of Appalachian State University and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   He wrestled in high school and college and did two tours in Iraq. Before his 2006 deployment ended, Cliff was called home and invited to take the Special Forces Qualification Course.
å¦   Cliff was so serious about his duty that he spent his time in Charleston at the family's house on Folly, running up and down the beach with a 70-pound rucksack on to get ready for his training. He earned the Green Beret in July.
å¦   Cliff had come home for the Sept. 4 birth of his son and returned to Afghanistan a week later. "He was about as happy as I'd ever seen him," said Eddie Cliff. "He was a very proud father."
å¦   Cliff also is survived by his wife, Stacy, and son, Richard.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Nicholas died Sept. 29 in Yakhchal, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device during mounted operations.
Bio:
The signs in Jamie S. Nicholas' hometown of Clay County, W.Va., said it all.
å¦   "In Our Prayers, the Nicholas Family, God Bless America," said one at Maysel Missionary Baptist Church. "Jamie Nicholas, Our Fallen Hero," read another at Go Mart.
å¦   Nicholas, 32, of Hope Mills, N.C., died Sept. 29 in an explosion in Yakhchal. He was a 1994 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Nicholas, a senior weapons sergeant, had been in Afghanistan since May. It was his second deployment to the country.
å¦   "Jamie died doing what he wanted to do. He wasn't concerned about going over there this time, but I had asked him if he felt we should be there," said his mother, Karen Nicholas.
å¦   "He was adamant," she said. "He said if we are not there, they will be in America. That gives me comfort. We support America."
å¦   Nicholas was the second of six children in his family. And he was not the only one to serve in the military. Another son served for ten years, also stationed at Fort Bragg. His sister-in-law also serves.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Michelle; stepson, Brenton Troup; and stepdaughter, Sharise Troup.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Vasquez died Sept. 29 in Yakhchal, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device during mounted operations.
Bio:
People would tell Gary J. Vasquez that they were sorry each time he was sent back into a war zone.
å¦   "He would say, 'What do you mean. I can't wait,'" said his brother, Barry DuHasek.
å¦   Vasquez, 33, of Round Lake, Ill., was killed Sept. 29 in an explosion in Yakhchal. He was assigned to Fort Bragg and was on his third tour in Afghanistan.
å¦   He received a bachelor's degree in drama from Illinois State in 1996. Theater professor Sandra Zielinski recalled Vasquez as "a delightful student" and "a very positive young man."
å¦   "His personality was larger than life," said DuHasek. "He was probably one of the funniest people I've ever met. He was my best friend and my brother."
å¦   He enlisted about nine years and enjoyed reading and spending time with his dogs, Smash and Medea.
å¦   "He loved his job. He was happy to be doing what he was doing," said DuHasek. "He basically indicated that he always wanted to be a soldier."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Sarah, who with her husband would have celebrated their second anniversary on Oct. 14.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Squadron, 101st Cavalry Regiment, New York Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Jason E. von Zerneck, 33, of New York City, died on Oct. 2 of injuries suffered from a vehicle rollover in Qara Bagh Karez, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Before he left for Afghanistan in January, Jason E. von Zerneck told a newspaper that leaving his family behind was "definitely the hardest thing."
å¦   "Some of the soldiers in this unit come from the poorest neighborhoods," he said. "These are the people who are putting their lives on the line for the city and the country and sometimes that is forgotten."
å¦   Von Zerneck, 33, of New York City, died Oct. 2 after his vehicle overturned in Qara Bagh Karez. He was assigned to Jamestown, N.Y.
å¦   Von Zerneck, a compliance officer with Bank of America, was a "die-hard Yankees fan" and loved watching New York Rangers games.
å¦   His mother, Barbara, said she hoped that her son would be remembered by Americans as a brave soldier. "I don't think there's enough attention paid to the sacrifices of our soldiers," she said. "That's something that angers me."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Stephanie, 30, and three children _ daughter Raina, 9, and sons Joseph, 6, and Noah, 3.
å¦   His father, Richard, said his son recently e-mailed him to thank him for helping to plan Noah's birthday party.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Marine Regiment, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Cpl. Jason A. Karella, 20, of Anchorage, Alaska, died Oct. 9 while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
At the Alaska Military Youth Academy, Jason A. Karella earned the highest leadership rank a cadet can achieve at the school. In boot camp, he became a squad leader.
å¦   "He had a way of making people follow his lead because of how he carried himself," said his father, Kevin Karella.
å¦   Karella, 20, of Anchorage, Alaska, died Oct. 10 in a vehicle accident in Farah province. He was assigned to Twentynine Palms.
å¦   He enjoyed playing hockey in his youth, as well as snowboarding and snowmachining. An avid outdoorsman, he loved camping, hunting and fishing.
å¦   His son had already seen his share of scrapes in Afghanistan, Kevin Karella said. Two or three weeks before his death, a man shot him twice with an AK-47.
å¦   Karella planned to leave the military in a year and marry his fiancee, and the couple hoped to live in Alaska. Photos sent home from Afghanistan show a beaming Karella speaking with an Afghan child.
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Anne-Marie Kitchens, stepfather, Bill Anklewich, and stepmother, Dawn-Marie.
å¦   Jason once said if anything happened to him he wanted his family to toast him with glasses of Jameson Irish whiskey.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 172nd Infantry Regiment (Mountain), New Hampshire Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Pfc. Scott G. Dimond, 39, of Franklin, N.H., died of wounds suffered when his vehicle struck an IED and his patrol was engaged in a small arms fire attack.
Bio:
Scott G. Dimond's uncle, Jean Dimond, said his nephew was fearless and up for any challenge, such as being the only child in the neighborhood brave enough to ride a friend's red wagon down a hill.
å¦   "He had such a wonderful outlook on life," Jean Dimond said.
å¦   Dimond, 39, of Franklin, N.H., died in an ambush Oct. 13 in Kandahar. He was a 1987 high school graduate and was assigned to Milford, N.H.
å¦   Initially, he had planned to enter the Marine Corps but the Marines wouldn't take him because of a football injury, so he took a job with the Franklin Police Department.
å¦   He started as a dispatcher, then moved up to special officer, then full-time officer, retiring as a sergeant after 18 years of service.
å¦   "He didn't have a mean bone in his body," said Bill Athanas, his old principal.
å¦   He was lately taking pre-med courses, planning to earn a nursing degree and work alongside his mother caring for aged and injured veterans.
å¦   "I can't say enough about him. I wish I had had five more just like him," said former Franklin Police Chief Doug Boyd.
å¦   Dimond is survived by his wife, Jennifer, and his four children, Luke, Ashlee, Alexis and Madison.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 26th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Spc. Cory J. Bertrand, 18, of Center, Texas died Oct. 14 in Qazi Bandeh, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Cory J. Bertrand's teenage years were spent playing in the front yard of a white frame house owned by his step grandparents.
å¦   His grandfather, Johnny Allen recalls the quality time they spent together. "We shot guns together and we walked the place here together. I do some mechanic work and he enjoyed being with me while I was doing that."
å¦   Bertrand, 18, of Center, Texas, died Oct. 14 in Qazi Bandeh when his vehicle struck an IED. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   "He felt like he was doing his job to protect not only his family, but his country and he saw a purpose for his life," said his grandmother, Lillian Allen.
å¦   The country boy decided to join the Army at age 17. His young age, required his mother, Charlotte Allen, to sign the enlistment papers. She agreed so her son could have the future he wanted.
å¦   "His face seemed to have that look of being, 'I'm serious about what I'm doing' and I really know he had come to realize that his purpose in life was fulfilled in being in the military," said pastor Charles Boster.
å¦   Bertrand also is survived by his stepfather, Matt Allen, and father, Ernie Nelams.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 26th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Spc. Stephen R. Fortunato, 25, of Danvers, Mass. died Oct. 14 in Qazi Bandeh, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Stephen R. Fortunato was the oldest of three children, and his younger siblings were at their mother's side to offer memories of their brother.
å¦   "I don't even want to believe this is true. He was my role model, my hero," said Anthony, 20, the youngest. "I loved him so much that I really, really hope that wherever he is, he knows that."
å¦   Fortunato, 25, of Danvers, Mass., died Oct. 14 in Qazi Bandeh when his vehicle struck an IED. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   "My son Stephen was very affectionate and a loving kid," Betty Crawford said. "He was the jokester, all the time. But he was also a dedicated soldier. He went into the Army like anyone else, a kid. He came home as a man."
å¦   He tried studying graphic arts at North Shore Community College, but decided he was not ready for college. He enlisted, choosing the Army because he wanted to be in combat.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Sherri.
å¦   "He had brown hair, green eyes, and the biggest smile in the world," she said. "He was a loving person. He loved his family. He loved his mother. He stayed strong for them. He was a hero."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 26th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Sgt. Preston R. Medley, 23, of Baker, Fla. died Oct. 14 in Qazi Bandeh, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Preston R. Medley's love of guns may have started at his grandfather's side, when, as a little boy, they would go hunting.
å¦   His grandfather remembered how the little boy had tried to hard to "hunt like Peepaw," but usually ended up falling asleep in a warm spot before the outing was over.
å¦   "He never did get better," Jesse Medley said. "He'd fall asleep too quick. I'd find him in the dog box sometimes asleep with the dog."
å¦   Medley, 23, of Baker, Fla., died Oct. 14 in Qazi Bandeh when his vehicle struck an IED. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   In high school, he played football and was involved in the broadcasting program. He often served as the talent in front of the screen but was also willing to get his hands dirty behind the scenes.
å¦   "He was always ready to do a gag reel and was never afraid of what people would think of his performance in front of the camera," said Rich Colburn, Baker's television class instructor.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Sarah, and a 1-year-old daughter, Raelynn. The couple is expecting a son Dec. 14, who will now be named after his father.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 26th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Sgt. John M. Penich, 25, died Oct. 16 in Karangol Village, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered from indirect fire.
Bio:
After witnessing the 2001 terror attacks, John M. Penich told his family he wanted to serve his country. But his career took a detour managing a hotel, a banquet hall and then a nightclub before enlisting.
å¦   "He kind of ignored his calling and bounced around," said his older brother Jeff Penich. "But he had no regrets of joining the Army. It was a calling to him in 2001, and it didn't catch up with him until later."
å¦   Penich, 25, of Beach Park, Ill., died Oct. 16 in Karangol Village of wounds suffered from indirect fire. He was a 2001 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   Penich enjoyed the outdoors, especially hunting, mountain biking, riding four-wheelers and Harleys, and playing paintball.
å¦   When sending care packages to him in Afghanistan, Jeff said his brother used to ask for things for his fellow soldiers.
å¦   "It was never 'I would like this.' Never, 'I want this.' It was always, 'What can I get for my guys?' He always put everyone before himself, including his country," Jeff said.
å¦   Penich is survived by his mother, Kathy Garross; his stepfather, Mike Garross; his father, James Penich; and his stepmother, Diane Penich.

IncidentDetails: A suicide bomber killed two German soldiers and five children in Kunduz province to the north, said Mohammad Omar, the provincial governor.
A suicide bomber killed two German soldiers and five children in Kunduz province to the north, said Mohammad Omar, the provincial governor.

ServiceUnit: 416th Civil Affairs Battalion, 351st Civil Affairs Command
