IncidentDetails: Sgt. Federico G. Borjas died Thursday in Bermel District Center, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered from small arms fire during a dismounted patrol.
Bio:
Federico G. Borjas was someone who lived with a single-minded determination to give of himself at every level, whether for family, community or country.
å¦   "He was very driven to be a protector," San Diego Police Chief William Lansdowne said. "He told me personally that he wanted to make sure everyone had the same chances that he'd had, and that you had to fight to make that happen."
å¦   Borjas, 33, of San Diego, Calif., died Oct. 16 in Bermel District Center of wounds from small-arms fire. He was assigned to San Diego.
å¦   Borjas joined the Marines at 18, then joined the San Diego County Sheriff's Department and later was a corrections deputy in Otay Mesa. Then he joined the San Diego Police Department, eventually joining the SWAT team and color guard. He most recently served as a patrol officer in the department's central division.
å¦   "He touched everyone he worked with and worked around. He was the sort of guy who really left an impression on people," San Diego police Capt. Chris Ball said. "We all respected him for who he was as a person and as a man."
å¦   Borjas leaves behind a daughter, Yvette.

ServiceUnit: 91st Civil Affairs Battalion, 95th Civil Affairs Brigade (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Capt. Robert D. Lindenau died Monday in Charbagh, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when a rocket-propelled grenade struck his vehicle.
Bio:
Robert D. Lindenau studied classical guitar while he was at the University of Idaho, and was involved in a rock band that played at venues in Idaho.
å¦   "After college when he told me he was going to join the Army, I told him that he did not seem to be the 'Army type,'" said his uncle, Mike Bloom. "In ways he wasn't, and in other ways, he was perfect for the Army, bringing his refined ways and behavior to the ranks as an example."
å¦   Lindenau, 39, of Camano Island, Wash., died Oct. 20 in Charbagh when a rocket-propelled grenade struck his vehicle. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   "People looked up to him," said Bloom. "Little kids were drawn to him."
å¦   He held bachelor's and master's degrees in music. He joined the Army in 1996 as a mechanic and was commissioned an officer in 1999.
å¦   Bloom recalls the day his father died over 10 years ago. "He brought his guitar into his hospital room and played soothing music for him, which I could tell helped my dad have a more peaceful passing," said Bloom.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Tonya, and their four children, Rachael, 12, Gabe, 10, Sarah, 8, and Hannah, 6.

ServiceUnit: 27th Infantry Brigade Combat Team, New York Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: A roadside bomb killed three U.S. coalition members in western Afghanistan on Wednesday.
Bio:
Deon L. Taylor, of New York City, went to Maine as an 8-year-old participant in the Fresh Air Fund program, which brings city youths to rural towns.
å¦   "I could see things differently through his eyes. He had never seen stars like ours, never wild animals. He wanted to know who let them out of the zoo. I always missed him when he left and was glad to see him when he came back," said to Rose Church, whose family hosted Taylor.
å¦   Taylor, 30, of New York City, died Oct. 22 in Bela Beluk of wounds from a roadside explosion. He was on his second deployment to Afghanistan and was assigned to Syracuse, N.Y.
å¦   He graduated from Old Westbury College in Long Island with a degree in sociology and criminology. He joined the NYPD in 2005 as a transit cop and then was promoted to the narcotics division in Brooklyn.
å¦   He is survived by his 8-year-old son, DaRue, and fiancee, Caitlin Casey.
å¦   He was a huge fan of the Yankees, the Knicks and the Giants.
å¦   "Deon was the apple of my eye," said his grandmother, Shirley Taylor. "I'm going to miss that big smile and that big bear hug he used to give me. But no more, no more."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Marine Regiment, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: A roadside bomb killed three U.S. coalition members in western Afghanistan on Wednesday.
Bio:
Adrian Robles was recalled as a man with an electric smile. Gunnery Sgt. Trent Kuhlhoff, who served with Robles, said he never knew anyone who laughed and smiled more than Robles.
å¦   "It was hard for me to get mad at him for anything," Kuhlhoff said.
å¦   Robles, 21, of Scottsbluff, Neb., died Oct. 22 during combat in Helmand province. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Twentynine Palms.
å¦   Robles knew he wanted to be a Marine before he graduated from high school. His senior year, he went out for the soccer team, even though he'd barely played the sport before.
å¦   His coach, Pedro Sulu, said Robles told him he wanted to play because the conditioning would give him a head start on what the Marines would expect from him.
å¦   "We had to help him learn some of the skills, and he became one of our goalkeepers," Sulu said. "He was always willing to learn, and very enthusiastic."
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Cesar and Yolanda.
å¦   "This is all he wanted to do, be a Marine. He did it. He got to be what he wanted to be," said Julie Morrison, a city councilwoman. "God bless him for that."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 7th Marines, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: A roadside bomb killed three U.S. coalition members in western Afghanistan on Wednesday.
Bio:
San Sim could crack a joke or quote a movie, even in the worst situations. His fellow soldiers knew him as Simba _ a nickname that stuck after someone caught him watching "The Lion King" on his cot.
å¦   "He was just a big ball of fun," said Lance Cpl. Dylan Morgan. "He was an all-around good guy."
å¦   Sim, 23, of Santa Ana, Calif., died Oct. 22 from enemy gunfire in Helmand province. He also had done two stints in Iraq and was assigned to Twentynine Palms.
å¦   Sim was in the process of gaining his citizenship.
å¦   "He was proud of what he did," said sister Serene Sim. "He felt like he was really doing something. After what happen on 9-11, he wanted to go out there and put in his own effort."
å¦   Sim was born in a refugee camp in the Philippines, the youngest of 11 children in a family fleeing Cambodia. He grew up in Santa Ana, loved to fish and wrestled in high school.
å¦   "We came to this country to escape war. And now he's died in war," said another sister, Yasmine Sim. "Our thoughts, prayers and wishes go out to the troops still out there."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Karla, and son, Donovan.

IncidentDetails: Army Sgt. Nicholas A. Casey, 22, Canton, Ohio, died Monday in Baghlan, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when a suicide bomber detonated explosives.
Bio:
By 10th grade, Nicholas A. Casey was starting to listen to service recruiters. Because of a lack of jobs in the area, Casey started to see the military as a way of life.
å¦   "That's what he wanted to do," said his father, Samuel. "He didn't never give up on nothing that he started."
å¦   Casey, 22, of Canton, Ohio, died Oct. 28 in Baghlan province of wounds from a suicide bomb attack. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   In high school, he played baseball and football. His son was no more than an average athlete, Samuel Casey said, but he played the games the best he could.
å¦   "When he was young, he was always in his own little world," his father said. "He was a happy kid. We had a broken marriage, but whether he was at his mother's or father's, he was happy."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Rachelle, and two sons, Nicholas II, 3, and Curtis, 2.
å¦   His grandmother, Audrey Wendling, said the boys dressed up as soldiers for Halloween.
å¦   "It was the cutest thing and we were so proud of the two boys," she said. "Their father was their hero and he died a hero. Nick will always be their hero. Nothing can ever change that."

ServiceUnit: 122nd Field Artillery, Illinois Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Sgt. Kevin D. Grieco, 35, Bartlett, Ill., died Monday in Baghlan, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when a suicide bomber detonated explosives.
Bio:
Kevin D. Grieco met his future wife in 2003 after returning from a deployment to Spain. They met while line dancing.
å¦   "As soon as he walked in, I said, 'I'm going to dance with this man,'" said Rashmi Grieco. "I asked him to dance, and he said, 'No, I don't think so.' And then he saw me dancing with his best friend, and he said, 'OK, maybe I'll try.'"
å¦   Grieco, 35, of Bartlett, Ill., died Oct. 28 in Baghlan of wounds from a suicide bomb attack. He was assigned to Sycamore, Ill.
å¦   "He was extremely dedicated to his military career," his wife said. "He would keep telling me that even if he could die for his country, he would love to. And he would not hesitate to die twice, three times."
å¦   He was a 13-year Navy veteran. Wanting to become an officer and see more action, he enlisted in the Illinois Army National Guard in 2006.
å¦   Grieco was an avid outdoorsman and worked as a contractor for a lawn-mowing company. In 2004, he earned a degree in recreational park administration from Aurora University.
å¦   He also is survived by two children, Joshua, 4, and Angeli, 2.

ServiceUnit: 5th Marine Regiment, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: 1st Lt. Trevor J. Yurista, 32, of Pleasant Valley, N.Y., died Oct. 27 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Trevor J. Yurista's dad called his son "wild," and recalled a time he, with the help of eight friends, rode a motorcycle through the halls of his high school as a senior prank.
å¦   Ronald Yurista also recalled Trevor using hundreds of donated soccer balls to teach Iraqi children how to play. Trevor's latest tour was optional.
å¦   "He didn't have to go with them," Ronald Yurista said. "That's who he was."
å¦   Yurista, 32, of Pleasant Valley, N.Y., died Oct. 27 during combat operations in Helmand province. He got his bachelor's from Jay College of Criminal Justice and was assigned to Camp Pendleton.
å¦   He was a soccer and a Little League coach.
å¦   Curtis Moore, a former principal, described him as someone who was loyal and respectful. Moore and Yurista kept in touch through e-mail up to the time of Yurista's death.
å¦   "He never gave anybody trouble in school," Moore said. "He was always quietly respectful of authority, but he never feared authority and was never hesitant to question authority. He was always loyal to his friends and family, to a fault."
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Donna.

ServiceUnit: 201st Engineer Battalion, Kentucky Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Sgt. Daniel W. Wallace, 27, of Dry Ridge, Ky., died Oct. 31 in Badin Kheyl, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his unit using small arms fire.
Bio:
Daniel W. Wallace's mother said her son loved being in the military and helped his unit's chaplain. Karen Wallace said her son had asked her to write to other soldiers who had not recently received letters of their own.
å¦   "Danny had a lot, a lot of sympathy for people," she said. "Danny's my fallen hero."
å¦   Wallace, 27, of Dry Ridge, Ky., died Nov. 3 in Badin Kheyl of wounds from small-arms fire. He was a 2001 high school graduate and was assigned to Cynthiana, Ky.
å¦   "Sgt. Daniel Wallace was a true patriot," Kentucky Adjutant General Edward Tonini said. "One who stood up and answered the call to serve his nation in a time of need."
å¦   "I am proud of my brother," said Alex Wallace, a medic in the Kentucky Army National Guard. "I'm going to keep carrying on. I know he wants me to serve my full time, which is what I'm going to do."
å¦   Wallace leaves behind two children, Abigail Wallace and Cody Mardis. "He was a fun-loving guy," said Paula Fields, a friend of 20 years. "And his children meant everything to him."

ServiceUnit: 927th Engineer Company (SAPPER), 769th Engineer Battalion, Louisiana Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Spc. Jonnie L. Stiles died Thursday in Jalalabad, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
Jonnie L. Stiles' interests slanted heavily toward the outdoors. One famous family photo shows Stiles fishing in 20-degree-below zero temperatures.
å¦   "He would go fishing in a blizzard," said his father, Lynn Stiles.
å¦   Stiles, 38, of Highlands Ranch, Colo., died Nov. 13 in Jalalabad of wounds from a roadside bomb. He was assigned to Baton Rouge.
å¦   Stiles spent nearly 13 years in the Marines after high school. He then spent more than two years in the Army before helping with his father's printing equipment business.
å¦   Stiles joined a National Guard unit in Colorado slated for deployment to Iraq. When those plans were postponed, Stiles moved to a unit in Louisiana scheduled for Afghanistan.
å¦   In October, Stiles injured his vocal cords and lungs, but managed to help rescue three others who were more severely injured in a bombing.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Launa.
å¦   Stiles had volunteered for years in the honor guard, presenting U.S. flags to relatives of dead soldiers. "He understood that these guys who served before us deserved to have somebody fold the flag and present it to the next of kin," said Staff Sgt. Leonard Fahrni.

ServiceUnit: 42 Commando Royal Marines
IncidentDetails: Marine Tony Evans and Marine Georgie Sparks had been conducting a foot patrol to the north-west of Lashkar Gah in Helmand province.

ServiceUnit: 42 Commando Royal Marines
IncidentDetails: The Ministry of Defence must confirm the deaths of Marine Tony Evans and Marine Georgie Sparks, both of J Company, 42 Commando Royal Marines, on Thursday 27th November 2008.

ServiceUnit: 6th Squadron, 4th Cavalry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Capt. Robert J. Yllescas, 31, of Lincoln, Neb., died Dec. 1 at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., of wounds suffered Oct. 28 when an improvised explosive device detonated near his unit at Combat Outpost Keating, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Esther Schott remembers her grandson playing with toy soldiers in his room in her house. He set up the plastic toys meticulously along the carpet and looked out for his crew as if they were real.
å¦   "He had his toy soldiers _ the little green men _ and he would line that up and, boy, nobody wanted to mess with his army," Schott said.
å¦   Robert J. Yllescas, 31, of Lincoln, Neb., died Dec. 3 of wounds suffered Oct. 28 when an explosive detonated near his unit. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   "He was a very special boy to all of us," said Schott, "because he was the oldest of 19 grandchildren. He was always kind of their leader and their hero."
å¦   Born in Guatemala, he was a 2001 graduate of the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and had previously been in Iraq twice, in 2003 and 2005.
å¦   "The things I'll probably miss the most are his sound judgment and his leadership. He was fearless in combat," said 1st Lieutenant Kaine Meshkin.
å¦   On Nov. 10, President George W. Bush presented him with the Purple Heart.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Dena, and two daughters: Julia, 7, and Eva, a newborn.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 2nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade, 1st Infantry Division, Fort Hood, Texas
IncidentDetails: Pvt. Colman J. Meadows III, 19, of Senoia, Ga., died Dec. 16, at Forward Operating Base Ramrod, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained from a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
On Dec. 18, Northgate High School's wrestling team took time out to recognize Colman J. Meadows III, their former classmate. Then they won the Coweta County wrestling championship for the eighth time.
å¦   "We want the Meadows family to know we are thinking of them," said coach Adrian Anderson. "This terrible news put things in perspective for us."
å¦   Meadows, 19, of Senoia, Ga., died Dec. 18 in a non-combat incident at Forward Operating Base Ramrod. He was a 2007 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   Meadows was an active member of Northgate High's drama club and considered performing to be an act of service for others and a way for him to spread laughter and joy.
å¦   "Joseph Meadows was a high spirited student who was still a definite part of the Northgate family, and we will miss him terribly," said Northgate Principal Dr. Therese Reddekopp.
å¦   Meadows joined the Army on Jan. 22 and completed his basic training at Fort Leonard Wood. He worked in military intelligence and deployed to Afghanistan on Nov. 4, 2008.
å¦   He is survived by his mother, Kelley Hooper and her husband Michael; and his father, Coleman Meadows Jr.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 506th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: Cpl. Charles P. Gaffney Jr., 42, Phoenix, Ariz.; died Wednesday in Paktika, Afghanistan, when his combat outpost received enemy rocket fire.
Bio:
Charles P. Gaffney Jr. was a man who loved his family, his country and the occasional adrenaline rush. Racing motorcycles became a big part of his life.
å¦   Gaffney Jr., 42, of Phoenix, died Dec. 24 in Paktika when his combat outpost was hit by enemy rocket fire. He was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   Gaffney joined the Army in the mid-'80s. He served about six years, spending most of that time in Germany, and then returned to Tucson. He worked at several auto shops and moved to Las Vegas after a while and worked for a Porsche dealership there.
å¦   Several years ago, he decided he needed to serve his country again.
å¦   "I won't say I was upset he was going back, but I didn't want him to," said his father, Charles Sr. "He told me it was for people's rights around the world, for them to say what they want to say without other people beating them down."
å¦   Gaffney went to Iraq in 2006-07 and was part of security forces outside Baghdad, his father said. He joined up again and was sent to Afghanistan in October.
å¦   Gaffney also is survived by his wife, Latticia, and his twin 4-year-old daughters, Cara and Mia.

ServiceUnit: 1 Troop, D Squadron, the Household Cavalry Regiment
IncidentDetails: Munday was conducting a routine patrol approximately 23km north of Forward Operating Base Delhi when he was killed by a contact explosion.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Royal Gurkha Rifles
IncidentDetails: While working alongside a fellow Gurkha, Rifleman Rai received a gunshot wound from enemy fire.
Bio:
Rifleman Rai, aged 28, came from the Khotang district in eastern Nepal. Following in the footsteps of his uncle, he joined the British Army in January 1999. On completion of his recruit training, he joined the 2nd Battalion The Royal Gurkha Rifles in Brunei.

In 2000, Rifleman Rai was posted to D (Gurkha Reinforcement) Company, the 1st Battalion The Royal Irish Regiment, where he served with distinction for two-and-a-half years. His soldiering skills were widely recognised and his career was characterised by a number of successful operational tours including to Iraq on Operation TELIC 1, Sierra Leone, Bosnia, and a previous tour in Afghanistan during Operation HERRICK 4.

Rifleman Rai was an avid sportsman who enjoyed all competition, but his real passion was for football, at which he represented B Company. This enthusiasm for the game extended to his support for Manchester United FC.

He was one of B Company's more senior Riflemen. He acted as a mentor for the younger men in the Company, often impressing them with his fitness and stamina. Most recently he was employed as the Company storeman, where his attention to detail, care to ensure that the men received the correct administrative support, and constant diligence were immensely respected.

He had been eager to deploy back to Afghanistan, his selfless attitude once again coming to the fore when he volunteered to deploy with 5 Platoon to replace another rifleman who had fallen ill.
"Rifleman Yubraj was a truly outstanding Rifleman with an extraordinary personality. As the most senior Rifleman he never failed to set the example to the other Riflemen. He loved his job and performed extremely well in every aspect of it."

Corporal Bigendra Limbu, 3 Section Commander, 5 Platoon

Rifleman Rai supported his mother, sister and three brothers as the family's main earner.

ServiceUnit: UK Landing Force Command Support Group
IncidentDetails: Dunstan killed by an explosion in the Garmsir District of southern Helmand, at 1647 hrs local time, while operating as part of Task Force Helmand's Information Exploitation Group.

ServiceUnit: Operation Herrick 9 with the Brigade Reconnaissance Force (BRF), United Kingdom Landing Force Command Support Group
IncidentDetails: McKibben was killed by an explosion in the Garmsir District of southern Helmand while operating as part of Task Force Helmand's Information Exploitation Group.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Royal Gurkha Rifles
IncidentDetails: Colour Sergeant Dura was taking part in a road move in the Musa Qaleh district of Helmand when the Warrior Infantry Fighting Vehicle he was travelling in was struck by an explosive device.

ServiceUnit: 45 Commando Royal Marines
IncidentDetails: Marine Lucas was killed by an enemy Improvised Explosive Device.

ServiceUnit: Landing Force Support Party (LFSP), Commando Logistic Regiment
IncidentDetails: He was killed as a result of a suspected suicide bomb attack south of Sangin, Afghanistan.

ServiceUnit: Company HQ, X-Ray Company, 45 Commando Royal Marines
IncidentDetails: Manuel was killed as a result of a suspected suicide bomb attack south of Sangin, Afghanistan.

ServiceUnit: 6 Troop, X-Ray Company Royal Marines
IncidentDetails: Birch was killed as a result of a suspected suicide bomb attack south of Sangin, Afghanistan.

ServiceUnit: Whiskey Company, 45 Commando Group Royal Marines
IncidentDetails: 1 Troop Whiskey Company was conducting a foot and vehicle patrol in the Green Zone south of Forward Operating Base Jackson when a Jackal vehicle struck an improvised explosive device in the Helmand River Wadi.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Lance Cpl. Alberto Francesconi, 21, of Bronx, N.Y., died Jan. 1 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Alberto Francesconi graduated high school in 2005 and then got a job with Bank of America. At 18, he was a personal banker.
å¦   "But he always wanted to be a pilot and 'What better foundation than the military' he used to say," said his wife, Cynthia Francesconi. "He always wanted to strive a little bit more _ to make it easier for his family."
å¦   Francesconi, 21, of New York City, died Jan. 1 during combat operations in Helmand province. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   He and his wife, teenage sweethearts who grew up two blocks from each other, were married in December 2006. They planned to start a family when he returned home from his second tour this June, ending four years of combat duty. Francesconi saw action in Iraq for six months in 2007.
å¦   "He will be missed," said Marine Cpl. Alfonso Matos, who served with Francesconi in Iraq. "He was motivated, dedicated. He loved what he did. He was a good kid."
å¦   "This is especially hard for me, losing Albert, because he pretty much followed in my footsteps," said Robert Rivera, Francesconi's older brother and a Navy reservist. "We did everything together."

ServiceUnit: 29 Commando Regiment Royal Artillery
IncidentDetails: Lt Lewis was fatally wounded when the gun position he was commanding came under attack. He was flown to hospital in Kandahar but died shortly after arrival.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion The Rifles
IncidentDetails: Nash was wounded as he was covering comrades from a compound rooftop while working as part of the 1 RIFLES Operational Mentoring and Liaison Team (OMLT) Battle Group.

ServiceUnit: Commando Logistic Regiment Royal Marines
6th Battalion The Rifles
IncidentDetails: Sergeant Chris Reed of 6th Battalion The Rifles (6 RIFLES) was killed in action in the Garmsir District of Helmand Province.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Lance Cpl. Jessie A. Cassada, 19, of Hendersonville, N.C., died Jan. 6 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Retired Air Force Lt. Col. Robert Clark said it was the Marines or bust for Jessie A. Cassada.
å¦   "No other branch of service was going to satisfy him. It was hard for him to finish his education, but he did it because he was determined to get in the Marine Corps," said Clark, Cassada's JROTC instructor.
å¦   Cassada, 19, of Hendersonville, N.C., died Jan. 6 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province. He was a 2007 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   "He would give his right arm for anyone," said a friend, Todd Garren.
å¦   He is survived by his stepfather, Carroll London and mother, Patricia Cassada.
å¦   "He was outgoing, he loved fishing and loved his family he loved everyone," his mother said. "He didn't have a bad bone in his body."
å¦   On a visit home last spring, the young Marine spoke to a few classes and gave them advice. "Pay attention to what teachers tell you because it's not as easy you might think it is out there," Cassada told them.
å¦   "He was a fine young man and I would like the world to know that he was always a patriot and a good kid," said Joyce Pruitt, a teacher.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 2nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Spc. Keith E. Essary, 20, of Dyersburg, Tenn., died Thursday in Maywand, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained when his dismounted patrol was hit by an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Sgt. 1st Class Robert Lipker recruited Keith E. Essary and they remained friends afterward.
å¦   "He was the greatest kid you will ever meet," said Lipker. "He made the perfect soldier and had a big heart. He would give you the shirt off his back. He would rather be with the folks he loved than sleep or eat."
å¦   Essary, 20, of Dyersburg, Tenn., died Jan. 8 in Maywand when his dismounted patrol was hit by an improvised explosive device. He was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   "He was my best friend," said Jonathan Pope, who was in JROTC with Essary. "He was big-hearted, and you could have called him anytime you needed something. He always kept the mood light."
å¦   Essary had a fondness for motorcycles and liked to go riding with his father, Chuck Hall. "Every time we talked, that's what we always talked about," he said.
å¦   He also is survived by his grandmother, Anita Essary; his mother, Mary Beth Franks and her husband, Tony; and his stepmother, Sheri.
å¦   "He was a good guy," said Terry Wilson, a friend.
å¦   "He wanted us to be proud of what he was doing," said Keith's uncle, Monty Essary.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 2nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Sgt. Joshua L. Rath, 22, of Decatur, Ala., died Thursday in Maywand, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained when his dismounted patrol was hit by an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
Joshua L. Rath's 12-year-old sister, Julia, told mourners that her brother would do anything for her, even attend her choral concert during a recent visit home.
å¦   "He would act tough and cool, but I saw him take off that big, tough shell," she said.
å¦   Rath, 22, of Decatur, Ala., died Jan. 8 in Maywand when his dismounted patrol hit a bomb. He was a 2004 high school graduate and assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   He loved football, basketball and soccer. "He was an Auburn fan," said his dad, Leroy. After leaving the Army, his plans were to go to college.
å¦   Rath's fiancee, Kimberly Taylor, described her boyfriend as having "the biggest heart" and as someone who was "so willing to love everyone."
å¦   She said the athletic Rath was adventurous and often daring. He loved to rock climb and cliff dive, and he cherished life.
å¦   "He had a heart of gold," said Rath's older sister, Joy Jitter. "We never imagined we'd wear a gold star to commemorate that."
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Darlene.
å¦   "He was well-rounded," said cousin Bruce Miller. "He had become quite a leader. He was a likable and a good churchgoing kid."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 4th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: Cpl. Jason R. Parsons, 24, of Lenoir, N.C. died Friday in the Zabul Province of Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle in Jaldak.
Bio:
Jason R. Parsons, who was obsessed with cars, liked being stationed in Germany because of the Autobahn _ a freeway on which people drive at high speeds.
å¦   "He liked it because you get to go fast," said Ken Pritchard, Parsons' stepdad.
å¦   Parsons, 24, of Lenoir, N.C., died Jan. 9 of wounds suffered when a bomb detonated near his vehicle in Jaldak. He was assigned to Hohenfels, Germany.
å¦   High school was when Parsons first actively pursued the military, although he'd been interested in it most of his life.
å¦   "He had a great recruiter," said Brittney Pritchard, Parsons' sister. "They made you do 20 push-ups to get a T-shirt, and he'd do 80 just to get it. He wanted to prove he was the best."
å¦   An aunt, Brenda Piper, said Parsons was a classic, all-American boy who always smiled from the heart. "I remember his warm smile and outlook on life," Piper said. "He didn't let anything hold him down or hold him back."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Ellie, and three stepchildren: Manuel, 12, Jasmine, 11, and Daniel, 5.
å¦   "He was a prankster, and so full of life," said his uncle, Gene Bristol. "We miss him terribly now."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 4th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: Spc. Joseph M. Hernandez, 24, of Hammond, Ind. died Friday in the Zabul Province of Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle in Jaldak.
Bio:
Joseph M. Hernandez was an animal lover. He once saw a dog fall through a frozen lake, so he jumped in and saved it. At one point, he and his wife shared a two-bedroom apartment with four cats and three dogs.
å¦   Hernandez, 24, of Hammond, Ind., died Jan. 9 of wounds suffered when a bomb detonated near his vehicle in Jaldak. He was assigned to Hohenfels, Germany.
å¦   He studied mechanical engineering and biology at Purdue University for two years. In 2002, he surprised his friends and family when he announced he was joining the Army.
å¦   "He said it was something he felt he had to do," said his wife, Alison. "He never had anything bad to say about the military. He just decided to join. He felt it was his duty."
å¦   Hernandez also is survived by his sons, Jacob, 2, and Noah, 9 months.
å¦   He enjoyed working on old cars and teaching his older son how to fly mini model airplanes.
å¦   When Hernandez was younger, he badly wanted to play piano. The family finally bought one, and he started playing it as it was being carried into the house. His mother asked him how he knew to play, and he said he had been practicing on paper.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 4th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: Maj. Brian M. Mescall, 33, of Hopkinton, Mass., died Friday in the Zabul Province of Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle in Jaldak.
Bio:
Brian M. Mescall was an avid cyclist with a big heart.
å¦   A friend, Keith Tode, recalled the time when an uninsured motorist, a man from Laos, hit Mescall when he was riding his bike. Rather than report the incident, Mescall worked to try to get the man a job as a court translator.
å¦   "He was such a sweetheart," Tode said. "He was so nice that you wouldn't think he would want to go into the military, but he was so patriotic."
å¦   Mescall, 33, of Hopkinton, Mass., died Jan. 9 when a bomb detonated near his vehicle in Jaldak. He was a 1997 graduate of The Citadel and was assigned to Hohenfels, Germany.
å¦   Friends described him as a happy-go-lucky guy whose constant smiles, rosy cheeks and reddish blond hair earned him the nickname "Howdy Doody." He would eat MREs while working at a supermarket, saying he wanted to get used to the "bad food" because that's what he planned to eat for the rest of his life.
å¦   Mescall was stationed in Korea and served several tours of duty in Iraq before he was transferred to Germany.
å¦   "Brian was an aggressive warfighter and a magnificent trainer. He never backed down from a mission," said Army Maj. Kevin Poole.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Chiun, and his son, Nathan.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine Lance Cpl. Daniel R. Bennett, 23, Clifton, Va.; died Sunday as a result of a non-hostile incident in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Daniel R. Bennett rooted for the Boston Red Sox and the Nationals. He also was a Civil War buff. "He could tell you what general went where and all about the battles," said his mother, Veronica Bennett.
å¦   Bennett, 23, of Clifton, Va., died Jan. 11 after a non-hostile incident in Helmand province. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   "Dan loved the outdoors as a kid and spent much of his time fishing, hiking and playing team sports for local youth organizations," said his brother, Dave.
å¦   In high school, he lettered in varsity lacrosse, football and wrestling. He was named the Most Improved Lacrosse Player in 2003 and was a Second Team All-League goalie. He also worked on the tech crew in the school's drama department.
å¦   He served one tour in Iraq. "He was an expert marksman and was proud to carry on his family's military tradition," said Dave Bennett.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, James.
å¦   Before deploying for Afghanistan, Danny asked his girlfriend, Nicolle DiPasquale, to marry him. They became engaged in front of the Washington Monument on the National Mall.

ServiceUnit: 1st Maneuver Enhancement Brigade
IncidentDetails: Army Staff Sgt. Carlo M. Robinson, 33, Lawton, Okla.; died Saturday in Bagram, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle in Kabul.
Bio:
Carlo M. Robinson's grandmother said he was the only member of his generation of the family to join the military, but he was undaunted by the reservations of some of his kin.
å¦   "There's danger everywhere, I know, but over there, your life is in God's hands," said Martha Witherspoon. "And he's in God's hands now."
å¦   Robinson, 33, of Lawton, Okla., died Jan. 17 after a roadside bomb detonated near his vehicle in Kabul. He was a 1993 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Polk.
å¦   His grandmother said he was "the quiet type" and enjoyed playing sports through high school. She described him as a patriot and said he re-enlisted in the military many times, even though it made his family nervous.
å¦   Robinson went to Afghanistan in June and was on his first overseas deployment. Friends often referred to him as "the dentist" because he could always make people smile.
å¦   His fellow servicemen and women also remembered Robinson as the "quiet type" who was "strong as an ox, yet gentle as a kitten."
å¦   Robinson is survived by his daughter, Carneshia, 11, and son Da'Karia, 10.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 26th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Ezra Dawson, 31, Las Vegas, Nev.; died Saturday in Konar Province, Afghanistan when the Chinook helicopter he was in made a hard landing under combat conditions.
Bio:
å¦   Ezra Dawson joined the Army to improve his life, said his ex-wife, Felicia Tucker. He had been working as a waiter.
å¦   "He wanted to better himself, so he figured that would be the way," Tucker said.
å¦   Dawson, 31, of Las Vegas, died Jan. 17 in Konar Province when the Chinook helicopter he was in made a hard landing under combat conditions. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   Dawson joined the Army Reserve in late 1999 as a supply specialist. Five years later, he kept the job but switched to active duty.
å¦   Dawson left the military and rejoined in mid-2007. He served as a junior scout and sniper team member, and a leader for a reconnaissance team in the Korengal Valley.
å¦   "He would give you the shirt off of his back if you were in need," said Sgt. 1st Class Lenneth Kim. "Even under attack and enemy fire, he laid next to his fallen soldier and administered aid to him, which ultimately saved his life."
å¦   Dawson grew up and attended school in Oklahoma before moving to Las Vegas as a young man. He was a sometime rapper and stand-up comedian.
å¦   Dawson is survived by his wife, Starlia Dorsey-Dawson, and a daughter, Diamond.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine Lance Cpl. Julian T. Brennan, 25, Brooklyn, N.Y.; died Saturday while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
Julian T. Brennan and his father were playing dominoes and drinking beer a few years ago when the younger man said, "I have something to tell you."
å¦   "And when a 23-year-old says that, it could be anything," said Bill Brennan. "But we did not expect, 'I joined the Marines.'"
å¦   Brennan, 25, of New York City, died Jan. 24 while supporting combat operations in Farah province. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   Brennan graduated from the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in Manhattan in 2006, got his Screen Actors Guild card and began lining up acting gigs while working as a carpenter on Martha Stewart's show.
å¦   He had always been interested in the military. His grandfather earned the Navy Cross at Iwo Jima during World War II, and he nearly enlisted after Sept. 11, 2001.
å¦   Thya Merz, his mother, last spoke to him on Inauguration Day _ he was a Barack Obama supporter _ and he expressed a "deep empathy" for the Afghan people.
å¦   His father called him a "happy and ethical warrior."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Bettina Beard, whom he secretly married before he shipped out to Afghanistan in November.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: The following Marines died Jan. 27 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan: Sgt. David W. Wallace III, 25, of Sharpsville, Pa.
Bio:
David W. Wallace III loved sports, particularly football and wrestling, and hunting and fishing.
å¦   "He was fun-loving," said his mother, Carol Wallace. "He was a jokester. Pranks were not beneath him."
å¦   "He was just a goofball," said Derek Songer, a friend. "He was silly. He always made you smile."
å¦   Wallace, 25, of Sharpsville, Pa., was killed Jan. 27 by a bomb blast in Helmand province. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   He served two tours in Iraq, from September 2004 to April 2005 and July 2007 to January 2008. He also served in Bangladesh, Dubai and other parts of the world.
å¦   Wallace worked hard and gave 100 percent, said John Napotnik, who was his defensive line coach and taught him psychology in his senior year.
å¦   Off the field, Wallace impressed people with his quiet friendliness. "I really liked the kid. He was a great kid," Napotnik said.
å¦   Wallace leaves behind his wife, Erica, a 5-year-old stepson, Landon, and a 2-year-old daughter, Brooklyn.
å¦   "He was a real American hero," said a friend, Ron Haywood. "He was the type of guy, whatever he did, he did 110 percent."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: The following Marines died Jan. 27 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan: Sgt. Trevor J. Johnson, 23, of Forsyth, Mont.
Bio:
Trevor J. Johnson's fellow Marines had nicknamed him "Hollywood," in part because he had been called up on stage during a USO show in Iraq that featured the Dallas Cowboys cheerleaders.
å¦   Johnson's grandfathers had both served in the military, and he decided he would follow in their footsteps while still a young boy.
å¦   That future was sealed after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. After that day, his father, Thomas Johnson, said his son adopted a personal slogan: "I can defend those who can't defend themselves."
å¦   Johnson, 23, of Forsyth, Mont., was killed by a bomb blast Jan. 27 in Helmand province. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   Terry Taylor, a Vietnam veteran, had counseled Trevor on life in the military before he shipped off to boot camp.
å¦   "He was, in my opinion, the perfect Marine," Taylor said. "He had the chiseled good looks, he had the athletic ability, he had the intelligence, he had the courage and he had the heart to do it."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Nicole, a 3-year-old stepson, Landan, and the couple's 8-month-old daughter, Aspyn.

ServiceUnit: 38th Operational Support Airlift Detachment
IncidentDetails: Army CW4 Milton E. Suggs, 51, Lockport, La.; died Friday at Camp Lemonier, Djibouti, of injuries sustained from a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
å¦   Milton E. Suggs was known for his love of flying. Other aviators called him more than able and said that part of his mission in Djibouti was flying a plane described as a "VIP transport," intended for dignitaries such as members of Congress and high-ranking officers.
å¦   "He was an exceptional aviator," said Keith "Doc" Dockery, base manager at Air Logistics in Galliano, where Suggs worked and was a friend for more than 20 years.
å¦   Suggs, 51, of Lockport, La., died Jan. 30 at Camp Lemonier, Djibouti, of injuries from a non-combat incident. He was assigned to Hammond, La. He was an avid aviator who owned his own Piper aircraft.
å¦   "He was very knowledgeable and very skillful, probably the best," Dockery said. "He was dedicated to anything he undertook. If he told you he was going to do something, he would take it to the bank. If he gave you his word, it was."
å¦   Suggs and his wife, Kim, were married in 1994 in the living room of their Lockport home. Both have long reputations for civic involvement in Lockport. He also is survived by one daughter, Sophia Suggs, and one grandchild, Erica Hurst.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 130th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers died Sunday in Kabul, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered from an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   While serving in Iraq, Sgt. Derek Hahn came to know Jason E. Burkholder as a person who could always make any situation seem better or brighter.
å¦   "You could be mad at the world and in two minutes he'd have you laughing and having a good time," Hahn said.
å¦   Burkholder, 27, of Elida, Ohio, was killed Feb. 8 in Kabul of wounds from an improvised explosive device. He was a 2000 high school graduate and was assigned to Marion, Ill.
å¦   He also served in the Marine Corps from 2000 until 2004. In all, Burkholder served three combat missions in Iraq and Afghanistan and two non-combat missions, according to friends who served with him.
å¦   "He enjoyed life as much as anybody possibly could," Spc. Dylan Devitte said. "Nothing will be the same without him."
å¦   Burkholder was a loyal friend with an infectious smile and an enthusiastic personality, his friends said. "He always had your back in any situation," said Hahn. "You knew he was there for you."
å¦   Burkholder loved serving his country and being a soldier, said his widow, Amanda. "He wouldn't have chosen any other way," she said.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 130th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers died Sunday in Kabul, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered from an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Lt. John Bennett of the Charleston Police Department drew a few laughs at Jared W. Southworth's funeral when he related how, during his training, Southworth volunteered to be subjected to Taser testing.
å¦   "It was situations such as those that proved Jared would do whatever it takes," he said. "He was the embodiment of the warrior spirit. To truly honor him, we must keep his legacy alive."
å¦   Southworth, 26, of Oakland, Ill., was killed Feb. 8 in Kabul of wounds from an improvised explosive device. He was assigned to Marion, Ill.
å¦   Southworth was a member of the Oakland Police Department. He earned an associate's degree in criminal justice from Lake Land College and a bachelor's degree in general studies from Eastern Illinois University in 2006.
å¦   "He was always in a good mood and always had that infectious smile on his face," Bennett said.
å¦   The Rev. Tony Crouch told of Southworth's love of baseball. In one game, he hit home runs in his first three at-bats and followed that with a "ringing double" in his fourth.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Chrissy, and children Logan, 7; Owen, 6; Carly, 3; and Ally, 2.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine Lance Cpl. Kevin T. Preach, 21, Bridgewater, Mass.; died Saturday from wounds suffered Jan. 24 while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Kevin T. Preach's shyness didn't define him.
å¦   "He was quiet at first, but that is not at all who he was," said Dan Linehan, who met Preach in middle school. "He was outgoing, friendly. He was a very, very unselfish kid. He just wanted to be in the Marines to show that he could do something to help."
å¦   Preach, 21, of Bridgewater, Mass., died Feb. 7 from wounds suffered Jan. 24 while supporting combat operations in Farah province. He was a 2007 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   Preach's family and friends said he always wanted to be a Marine since he was a young child, perhaps because his father had been one as well.
å¦   "He knew what it entailed, and he never complained or talked about how dangerous it was," said Brianna Kelliher, Preach's girlfriend. "He once said that he wasn't afraid to die, he was just afraid of what it would do to all the people around him."
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Laurie.
å¦   "He was the funniest person I have ever met," said Kelliher. "He would always make sure that everyone around him was comfortable, so he would always tell jokes."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 506th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: A bomb struck a NATO convoy Tuesday, killing two soldiers and wounding one. The majority of NATO troops in Khost are American, though the spokesman for NATO's International Security Assistance Force would not confirm the troops' nationalities.
Bio:
å¦   Jason R. Watson wanted to go fishing with his father when he came home.
å¦   "I had bought a new boat and I was showing him the pictures on the Internet. And he said, 'Daddy that's a nice boat. When we come home, I want you to carry me fishing,'" Bobby Watson said.
å¦   Watson, 19, of Many, La., was killed Feb. 10 after his vehicle struck an explosive in Salerno. He was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   Watson joined the Army in September 2007 and arrived at Fort Campbell in February 2008. He also is survived by his mother, Cynthia; stepfather, Tim; and stepmother, Sheilah.
å¦   Geri Erwin-Ammons knew Watson as "Rambo."
å¦   "I would always have to stop and think of his real name. We rode the same school bus and most of the time sat together," he wrote on an online bulletin board.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 506th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: A bomb struck a NATO convoy Tuesday, killing two soldiers and wounding one. The majority of NATO troops in Khost are American, though the spokesman for NATO's International Security Assistance Force would not confirm the troops' nationalities.
Bio:
å¦   Peter J. Courcy's best friend, Otto Bauer, laughed as he remembered meeting Peter in 2001 on a school bus.
å¦   "He was one of a kind, and we just hit it off right away and quickly became close," Bauer said. "He was always a goofy kid and had a strong personality."
å¦   Courcy, 22, of Frisco, Texas, was killed Feb. 10 by a suicide car bomb in Salerno. He was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   Courcy's former principal remembers his upbeat presence and fervor for life. "He was a good student, but he was an even better person," Rick Burnett said. "That was reflective in the fact that he served his country."
å¦   After graduating in 2004, he played amateur hockey for the Dallas Ice Hawks while taking classes at community colleges until enlisting in 2006.
å¦   "We always knew that's what he wanted and needed," said his father, Chris. "He needed to be in the Army just as much as the Army needed him, and he thrived there."
å¦   He was a Dallas Cowboys nut and signed on for another five years of service, hoping to join the Special Forces.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Mara, and their 5-month-old son Anthony.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 3rd Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Staff Sgt. Marc J. Small, 29, of Collegeville, Pa., died Feb. 12 at Faramuz, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his unit using a rocket-propelled grenade launcher and small arms fire.
Bio:
å¦   As a boy, Marc J. Small was the rambunctious type who wasn't afraid to get dirty, said grandmother Louella Wagner. He was always very helpful, she said, and it was only fitting he'd become a medic in the Army.
å¦   "He was a fine young man. He had good goals, he had good intentions," she said. "I just was really impressed with the way he turned out."
å¦   Small, 29, of Collegeville, Pa., died Feb. 12 in Faramuz of wounds suffered from rocket and small-arms fire. He was a 1997 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg. He earned his green beret in 2007.
å¦   "Marc was fondly regarded by all who knew him as mischievous, playful, and possessing the biggest, most giving heart of anyone they know," his family said in a statement.
å¦   "He had it all. He was funny, he was a good athlete, he was good looking," said Murray Small, a family friend.
å¦   He was fan of the Grateful Dead and Allman Brothers. He would tailgate at Philadelphia Eagles games any chance he got.
å¦   He is survived by his father and stepmother, Murray and Karen; his mother and stepfather, Mary and Peter MacFarland; and fiancee Amanda Charney.

ServiceUnit: Marine Wing Support Squadron 171, Marine Wing Support Group 17, 1st Marine Air Wing, III Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine Staff Sgt. Daniel L. Hansen, 24, Tracy, Calif.; died Saturday while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Daniel Hansen was chosen early on to be trained as an elite Marine, quickly rose through the ranks and bested his competition, eventually earning the skills and a security clearance to guard then-President Bush at Camp David.
å¦   From there, Hansen was hand-picked to guard a pair of generals, the second of whom, Gen. Richard Zilmer, took Hansen with him to Iraq as a personal security guard and to train other security guards in Fallujah.
å¦   Once that stint ended, Hansen headed to Florida to train to learn how to defuse bombs, after which he was sent to Afghanistan.
å¦   "He strived to be the best in everything," said Matthew Hansen, his brother. "He just had such a passion for everything he did. He truly was the embodiment of the Marine Corps ethos: honor, courage and commitment."
å¦   Hansen, 24, of Tracy, Calif., died Feb. 14 while supporting combat operations in Farah province. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Iwakuni, Japan.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Delbert and Cheryll, and a fiancee Emily Campbell.
å¦   "He held his morals high and self-expectations higher," said his brother.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 506th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: Army Sgt. 1st Class Raymond J. Munden, 35, Mesquite, Texas; died Monday at Forward Operating Base Tillman in Paktika Province, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained when insurgents attacked his unit using indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   Raymond J. Munden joined the Army in August 1991, only three months after graduating from high school. Growing up in a military family, he and his brother, Brad, both set their sights on serving their country at a young age.
å¦   Raymond joined the Army, and Brad joined the Navy.
å¦   "We both knew growing up that that's what we wanted to do," said Brad Munden. "He's always had that passion."
å¦   Munden, 35, of Mesquite, Texas, died Feb. 16 in Paktika province after insurgents attacked his unit. He was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   His second tour in Afghanistan was his sixth overall, and he was hoping to work as an instructor at West Point until retirement after returning home. He also served in Somalia and Haiti.
å¦   "We were thinking he would never have to go back to war again," said Dwaine Clark, the soldier's stepfather.
å¦   Munden loved to play sports and participated on football and softball teams. He enjoyed spending time outdoors, especially with his family.
å¦   Munden is survived by his wife, Kelly; their daughters, Sydney, 6, and Kailey, 2; and two sons from a previous marriage, Gaven, 13, and Garrett, 12.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 3rd Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Army Master Sgt. David L. Hurt, 36, Tucson, Ariz., died Friday, in Kandahar, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered during the same incident
Bio:
å¦   David L. Hurt loved the Army. Even as boy he loved playing with toy soldiers. Years later, after he had joined the Army, his mother would walk into his home and see the small plastic soldiers spread across a table _ this time being used to plan out real-life tactics.
å¦   "He always loved the Army. Oh God, he loved it," said his mother, Bonnie Hurt.
å¦   Hurt, 36, of Tucson, Ariz., was killed Feb. 20 in Kandahar by a roadside bomb and enemy fire. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Hurt was born in Oak Park, Ill., but moved to Tucson when he was 3 years old. He joined the Army in 1992 after graduating high school and went on to join the Green Berets and won numerous awards, including the Bronze Star with two Oak Leaf Clusters.
å¦   He always signed off telling his mother he loved her. The last time they talked, "He said, 'I've got to go, I love you,'" she recalled.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Kelly, 11-year-old daughter, Avery, and 5-year-old son, Wyatt.
å¦   "He was a very loving, caring husband," Bonnie Hurt said. "He loved doing things with his kids. He took his kids everywhere."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 3rd Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Army Staff Sgt. Jeremy E. Bessa, 26, Woodridge, Ill., died Friday, in Khordi, Afghanistan, when his vehicle was struck by an explosive, followed by small arms fire
Bio:
å¦   Jeremy E. Bessa recently became a dad. He was home when his son, Carson, was born on Dec. 4.
å¦   "He was so touched with his child, his boy, and the prospect of being a father," his father Ted said.
å¦   Bessa, 26, of Woodridge, Ill., died Feb. 20 in Khordi when his vehicle was struck by an explosive and small-arms fire. He was a 2000 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Bessa was born at the Tripler Army Medical Center in Honolulu. He lived with his grandmother while he finished high school in the United States, said his father, a sergeant major in the Army who was stationed in Italy at the time. He also was able to graduate from the same high school that his mother had graduated from.
å¦   Bessa spent one semester at Southern Illinois University before being inspired to join the military after the 9/11 attacks.
å¦   Bessa was sent to Afghanistan in January for his second deployment. He joined the Army in April 2002 and became a Green Beret in 2007.
å¦   "He was a wonderful little child and grew into a very wonderful man," his mother Julie said.
å¦   Bessa is also survived by his wife, Lindsey.

ServiceUnit: 23rd Special Tactics Squadron
IncidentDetails: Air Force Staff Sgt. Timothy P. Davis, 28, Aberdeen, Wash.; died Friday near Bagram, Afghanistan, when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Matt Mensch said he and Timothy P. Davis were paired up in training in the Air Force. It was hard on him, Mensch said, because Davis was so good at everything. And while at first he thought Davis was something of a blowhard, he learned to respect his fellow soldier.
å¦   "There's a difference between being cocky and being competent," Mensch said. "Whatever he did, he did it right."
å¦   Davis, 28, of Aberdeen, Wash., died Feb. 20 near Bagram when his vehicle hit a roadside bomb. He was a 1999 high school graduate and was assigned to Hurlburt Field, Fla.
å¦   "He was, mentally, the strongest person I have ever known," said Jesse Huggins, Davis' best friend since Little League. "There are things that in life are so difficult, no one else is willing to volunteer for. He would."
å¦   One of those things was the 800 meter race in track, which is notorious for being tough and was Davis' preferred event. Huggins recalled seeing Davis throw up after many races, because he had pushed himself so hard.
å¦   Davis, who had previously earned a Purple Heart, is survived by his wife, Meagan, and year-old son Timmy Jr.

ServiceUnit: 27th Infantry Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Tuesday in Kandahar, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Tim Simpson, director of admissions at Brian "Bubba" Bunting's high school, described him as a man dedicated to three things _ family, friends and country.
å¦   "You see pictures of him with a big, goofy smile on his face, and that was Bubba 99 percent of the time," Simpson said. "Whoever came in contact with him felt that positive energy and what a unique and special individual he was."
å¦   Bunting, 29, of Potomac, Md., was killed Feb. 24 by a roadside bomb in Kandahar. He was a 1998 high school graduate and was assigned to Syracuse, N.Y.
å¦   Bunting graduated from the U.S. Military Academy at West Point with a degree in civil engineering in 2002, and also played lacrosse and intramural football.
å¦   Bunting, who was on his first combat tour as a ready reservist, was stationed in Korea for two and a half years and was later stationed at Fort Knox, serving as a company executive officer and commander.
å¦   "He's just a great guy," said his sister-in-law, Sue Bunting. "He just made everyone feel welcome and at ease."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Nicki, and his son Connor, 1.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Squadron, 106th Cavalry Regiment, 33rd Infantry Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Tuesday in Kandahar, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Schuyler B. Patch was known as very outgoing. "He would talk to anybody," said Julie Morland, Patch's aunt. "He was very lovable and affectionate. Every time I'd see him, he'd give a hug or a kiss on the cheek and ask how I was doing."
å¦   Patch, 25, of Galva, Okla., was killed Feb. 24 by a roadside bomb in Kandahar. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Kewanee, Ill.
å¦   Morland said Patch was "very outdoorsy."
å¦   "He loved fishing and hunting and did a lot of that with his dad," she said.
å¦   Patch enlisted in the Oklahoma National Guard in March 2005, then transferred to the Illinois Army National Guard in November 2007. He was on his second deployment to Afghanistan.
å¦   "We are all very proud of him for even going over the first time and then volunteering to go over," Morland said. "It takes a special person to even join the Guard in the first place. To go there and fight as a volunteer, it takes a special person."
å¦   Patch is survived by his parents, John and Amy.
å¦   "He heard freedom's call. He paid freedom's price, so that we all might enjoy the benefits of freedom," said Capt. Jon Prain.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 130th Infantry Regiment, 33rd Infantry Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Tuesday in Kandahar, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   When Scott B. Stream wasn't deployed, he worked as an electrician or buried himself in a book or his thoughts.
å¦   "He had a huge brain and a huge soul," childhood friend Mary Wilt said. "When he had free time, he thought. He just thought about things, and then he wrote about them."
å¦   Stream, 39, of Mattoon, Ill., was killed Feb. 24 by a roadside bomb in Kandahar. He was assigned to Effingham, Ill.
å¦   His mother, Gayle Stream, proudly described him as "artsy-fartsy," his military bravery tempered by a willingness to play with his girls and let them give him a makeover.
å¦   He deployed to Afghanistan in the fall on the day his youngest daughter started kindergarten, but he made sure he was able to drop her off that morning. He was on his third deployment in the past six years _ the first had been to Germany; the second to Iraq.
å¦   He graduated from Davis County High School in Bloomfield, Iowa, in 1987 and then continued his education at Drake University in 1989. He also attended Lake Land College in 2008, where he was on the President's List.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, wife, Rasa, and two daughters, ages 5 and 16.

ServiceUnit: 715th Military Police Company
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Tuesday in Kandahar, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Daniel J. Thompson met his fiancee, Maria Steinke, in college.
å¦   "He sat in front of me in class, so he could turn around and talk to me," Steinke said. "He gave me a note with his number on it. He was obviously good looking, very nice and would do anything for anybody. He was just a good person in and out."
å¦   Thompson, 24, of Madison, Wis., was killed Feb. 24 by a roadside bomb in Kandahar. Thompson was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Melbourne, Fla.
å¦   "He was just a really good guy, someone you'd want to be around all the time," said Nick Konzel, a friend. "I feel empty inside."
å¦   Thompson earned a degree in criminal justice and law enforcement from Madison Area Technical College in 2006 and worked for security company in Madison. He joined the Wisconsin National Guard while still in high school.
å¦   He loved cars, playing hockey, his motorcycle, family and friends (and an occasional handful of Gummi Bears). "I was proud of my baby. He never disappointed me, he always smiled. I'm very proud of him," said his mother, Lisa Thompson.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Bob.

ServiceUnit: 634th Brigade Support Battalion of the Illinois Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Army Sgt. Simone A. Robinson, 21, Dixmoor, Ill.; died Sunday at Brooke Army Medical Center, San Antonio, Texas, of wounds sustained when an improvised explosive device detonated near her security post on Jan. 17 in Kabul, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   On the night Simone A. Robinson departed for war, she held her 2-year-old baby Nyzia on her lap. She played with her until the last moment, then handed her to her mother, who would care for the girl while Robinson was away.
å¦   "She said, 'Hurry and put her in the car,'" said her mother, Regina Byther. "She tried to be tough, but she was hurt to leave her baby."
å¦   Robinson, 21, of Dixmoor, Ill., died March 1 at Brooke Army Medical Center of wounds from an improvised explosive device that detonated near her security post on Jan. 17 in Kabul. She was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Crestwood, Ill.
å¦   "She kept me laughing and others around her," said Amanda Manson, a friend since eighth grade. "She would help you when you came to her if you had problems with your work. I don't think she ever got bad grades."
å¦   Her father, Charles Robinson, remembered the way she made him laugh and how she sang in the choir at St. Luke Baptist Church, and the time she corrected the way he pronounced "aromatherapy."
å¦   "A go-getter. Always wanted to accomplish this and accomplish that," he said. "My baby girl."

ServiceUnit: 40th Cavalry Regiment 4th Brigade Combat Team (Airborne), 25th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Pfc. Patrick A. Devoe, II, 27, Auburn, N.Y.; died Sunday in Kandau Kalay, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle was struck by an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Patrick A. DeVoe II loved eating and he loved preparing dishes. Devoe even loved food enough to briefly study culinary arts before joining the U.S. Army.
å¦   "He could take cottage cheese and burgers, mix them together, and make it sound good," said his mother, Susan-Kealoha Capone.
å¦   DeVoe, 27, of Auburn, N.Y., died March 8 in Kandau Kalay when his vehicle was struck by an improvised explosive device. He was a 2000 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Richardson.
å¦   DeVoe joined the Army last year and was planning to make a career of it, said his father, Patrick DeVoe. "He wanted to be a lifer. He loved it. He said it was the best thing that ever happened to him," he said.
å¦   DeVoe loved collecting baseball cards and enjoyed playing goalie on youth soccer teams and camping with his family as a youngster. He was working construction when he decided to enlist.
å¦   "He was really kind, smart and funny. He could always make you laugh. No matter what, he could always make you smile," said Kimberly Harkness, the soldier's aunt.
å¦   He also is survived by his stepmother, Karen, and a 16-month old daughter, Jazzibell.

IncidentDetails: Staff Sgt. Timothy L. Bowles, 24, Tucson, Ariz.; died Sunday near Kot, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   As a youngster growing up on base, Timothy L. Bowles took a special interest in elderly veterans who attended chapel services on Sundays.
å¦   He made a point of paying attention to them and assisting them if they needed help, said his father, Air Force retiree Louis Bowles. "He was loving and loyal, a son you could trust."
å¦   Bowles, 24, born in Anchorage, Alaska, and raised in Tucson, Ariz., died March 15 near Kot after his vehicle encountered an improvised explosive device. He was assigned to Elmendorf Air Force Base and volunteered for his final mission to take an ill colleague's place on patrol.
å¦   "That was Tim," Air Force retiree Louis Bowles said of his son's offer to fill in for someone. "He was always unselfish, wanting to help people any way he could."
å¦   Bowles graduated from Tucson High School in 2002 and attended Pima Community College before joining the Air Force.
å¦   "Raised in a military family, he knew the cost of freedom. He did not falter and he did not fail," said Col. Richard Walberg.
å¦   He also is also survived by his mother, Lisa.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 178th Infantry Regiment, 33rd Infantry Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Norman L. Cain III, 22, Oregon, Ill.; died Sunday of injuries sustained in Kot, Afghanistan, when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   While in Afghanistan, Norman L. Cain III helped rebuild roads, schools and hospitals. He was a mechanic at home and carried a lot of those skills with him overseas.
å¦   "Not only was he an active driver for our team, but the platoon. If they were down a driver, he'd volunteer to go help," said Cain's team leader, Richard Davis.
å¦   Cain, 22, of Oregon, Ill., died March 15 after a roadside bomb detonated near his vehicle in Kot. He was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Woodstock, Ill.
å¦   "I want him to be remembered not only as a hero, which he was, but also as a devoted husband and father. He was our world," said his wife, Brigette.
å¦   "He was amazing. He was always there if you ever needed him, he'd be there and if he couldn't be there he'd try talking you through stuff if you're down or anything," said Cain's cousin, Pfc. David Pfile.
å¦   He also is survived by a son, Toryn, 1, and Brigette's daughter, Fallon Speilman, 3.
å¦   "He was always the one that wanted to have a good time and never wanted to be down. He'll be loved and remembered honorably and with respect," said Pfile.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 178th Infantry Regiment, 33rd Infantry Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Sgt. Robert M. Weinger, 24, Round Lake Beach, Ill.; died Sunday in Jalalabad, Afghanistan of injuries sustained in Kot, Afghanistan, when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Robert M. Weinger was a high-energy guy who lived on Monster energy drinks and would keep cases of the beverage stashed with his belongings, said 1st Sgt. Andrew Fowles.
å¦   "He's the guy we turned to train our younger soldiers," Fowles said. "A lot of younger guys looked up to him."
å¦   Weinger, 24, of Round Lake Beach, Ill., was killed March 15 by a roadside bomb in Kot. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Woodstock, Ill.
å¦   He had been deployed in Iraq and was one of the soldiers chosen to guard Saddam Hussein until Hussein was turned over to the Iraqi government. After returning from Iraq, Weinger volunteered to deploy with an infantry unit to Afghanistan.
å¦   "Robert was an energetic, very excellent soldier," said Capt. Matthew Garrison, who served with Weinger in Iraq in 2007. "He was an extremely loyal soldier, very dedicated to his mission."
å¦   Weinger is survived by his father, Howard, and mother Sue.
å¦   "He was always nice and always was willing to put other people before himself," said longtime friend Heather Simmons. "He would do anything for anyone he knew."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 178th Infantry Regiment, 33rd Infantry Brigade Combat Team
IncidentDetails: Sgt. Christopher P. Abeyta, 23, Midlothian, Ill.; died Sunday in Jalalabad, Afghanistan of injuries sustained in Kot, Afghanistan, when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Christopher P. Abeyta was a three-sport athlete in school, excelling in track, football and wrestling. Bremen High School athletic director Jim Matlon remembered Abeyta being an excellent student as well as polite and respectful of others.
å¦   "He was always a top-notch student. He was so task- and goal-oriented. That's why he was such a good person for the service. When you gave him a challenge, he was always a taskmaster and detail oriented," Matlon said.
å¦   Abeyta, 23, of Midlothian, Ill., was killed by a roadside bomb March 15 in Kot. He was on his second deployment in Afghanistan and was assigned to Woodstock, Ill.
å¦   Abeyta graduated from high school in 2003, having already enlisted in the Guard. He soon spent a year in Iraq, ending in 2005. Between tours, Abeyta graduated in 2007 from Harold Washington College in Chicago with an associate degree.
å¦   Abeyta was a self-described writer, who had kept a journal since he was 11. He read a lot, and listened to music. He cheered up his friends with a goofy sense of humor.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Paul and Barbara.

ServiceUnit: France
IncidentDetails: killed by rocket fire during a clash with insurgents in Afghanistan

ServiceUnit: 2nd Intelligence Battalion, II MEF Headquarters Group, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Staff Sgt. Archie A. Taylor, 37, Tomball, Texas; died Saturday as a result of a non-hostile incident in Kabul province, Afghanistan.

ServiceUnit: Incident Response Regiment
IncidentDetails: killed trying to defuse a makeshift device

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Lance Cpl. Daniel J. Geary, 22, Rome, N.Y.; died Friday while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Della Pray, who got to know Daniel J. Geary when she served as his Air Force ROTC instructor, said he had many friends.
å¦   "Quiet wasn't in his vocabulary," she said. "He was a prankster. We were always playing jokes on each other."
å¦   Geary, 22, of Rome, N.Y., died March 20 while supporting combat operations in Farah province. He was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   "Daniel was proud of his roots and proud of his family," Rome Mayor James Brown said. "The people of Rome will never forget Daniel Geary."
å¦   Geary was 18 when he joined the military and has been described by his father, Michael, as a "frisky, young juvenile prankster." He had planned to marry his fiancee once his current tour ended, and possibly take some college courses.
å¦   He was on his second tour; his first was in Iraq.
å¦   Geary made news in March 1995, when the then-8-year-old was credited with helping save his 4-year-old sister Elise after she accidentally started a bedroom fire while playing with a lighter.
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Aggie.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Pfc. Adam J. Hardt, 19, Avondale, Ariz., died Sunday, at Forward Operating Base Airborne in Wardak Province, of injuries suffered from a non-combat related incident.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Cpl. Anthony L. Williams, 21, Oxford, Pa.; died Sunday while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Cpl. Kyle Kusko remembered the time he and Anthony L. Williams tried to quit smoking.
å¦   "Every time he'd quit, I'd have a pack of cigarettes and come by his room to see if he wanted to smoke, and vice versa. One day he stopped by my room and said, 'You wanna grab a smoke?' I said, 'Man, I've quit.' He said, 'No one likes a quitter.'"
å¦   Williams, 21, of Oxford, Pa., died March 22 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province. He was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   Williams, who was born in Honolulu, had a characteristic sense of humor and was well-liked by all the Marines with whom he served, Kusko said.
å¦   "No one had a quarrel with him," Kusko said. "No one."
å¦   Kusko recalled a time when Williams pulled his armored vehicle so close to Kusko's that their side mirrors hit.
å¦   "I said, 'You hit me.' He said, 'No I didn't. You hit me.' I said, 'How could I have hit you? I wasn't even moving.' And he said, 'Yeah you were. You just don't know it yet.'"
å¦   Williams is survived by his father, Willie Lee Williams Jr., and his stepmother, Lisa McDonough-Williams.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Cpl. Michael W. Ouellette, 28, Manchester, N.H.; died Sunday while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Marine Lance Cpl. Christopher Escher watched as Michael W. Ouellette became a team leader and then a squad leader.
å¦   "He was always a leader, even as a junior guy," Escher said, adding that his friend didn't even have to go on his last deployment, but "the guys under him didn't have combat experience." Ouellette, he said, wanted to make sure they were taken care of.
å¦   Ouellette, 28, of Manchester, N.H., died March 22 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province. He was a 1999 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   He had gone to culinary school in California after graduating. He deployed twice to Iraq: first from March 2006 to September of that year and then from July 2007 to January 2008.
å¦   Alan Ouellette said that his brother "was always a role model for myself and others," and that he hoped that "we can make his legacy as big as his life."
å¦   "He was one of the few kids that would actually come and talk to us and have a conversation with us," said Arthur Adamakos, his former principal. Most kids don't."
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Leonard and Donna.

ServiceUnit: Combined Security Transition Command - Afghanistan at Camp Shaheen
IncidentDetails: Lt. Florence B. Choe, 35, of El Cajon, Calif., and Lt. j.g. Francis L. Toner IV, 26, of Narragansett, R.I., died March 27 when an insurgent posing as an Afghan National Army soldier opened fire
Bio:
å¦   Florence B. Choe was serving as a medical administration and logistics mentor to the Afghan National Army.
å¦   "She was a professional naval officer who was extremely smart and extremely pleasant," said Sonja Hanson, a hospital spokeswoman who knew Lt. Choe.
å¦   Choe, 35, of El Cajon, Calif., was killed March 27 when an insurgent posing as an Afghan National Army soldier opened fire. She was based at the Naval Medical Center San Diego, where she was born.
å¦   She earned a bachelor's degree in biology from the University of California at San Diego in 1997, and a master's degree in public health and health care administration in 2001 from San Diego State University. She was commissioned as a Medical Service Corps member in the Navy on Feb. 21, 2002.
å¦   "She always had a smile on her face, and everyone admired her. All of us at the Naval Medical Center are proud of her, and we are grieving for her," said Hanson.
å¦   She is survived by her husband, Lt. Cmdr. Chong "Jay" Choe, a urology resident at the medical center, and her daughter, Kristin, 3.

ServiceUnit: Combined Security Transition Command - Afghanistan at Camp Shaheen
IncidentDetails: Lt. Florence B. Choe, 35, of El Cajon, Calif., and Lt. j.g. Francis L. Toner IV, 26, of Narragansett, R.I., died March 27 when an insurgent posing as an Afghan National Army soldier opened fire
Bio:
å¦   A standout football player and homecoming king, Francis L. Toner IV had a smile for everyone at his high school.
å¦   "The kid was pure goodness," said Christina Harrison, who taught him U.S. government.
å¦   Toner, 26, of Westlake Village, Calif., was killed March 27 when an insurgent posing as an Afghan national army soldier opened fire in northern Afghanistan. He was based at Pearl Harbor.
å¦   He attended the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy _ where he earned a degree in Marine Engineering and Shipyard Management _ after graduating from high school in 2001. He was a running back for the school's championship football team.
å¦   "He would call home all the time and we'd ask if he needed anything _ ChapStick, or other things _ or we'd ask him if he was hot or cold. He'd say to send children's-size socks or coloring books _ never anything for himself. He just thought about other people," said his aunt, Linda Moosekian.
å¦   He tried to teach soldiers and children how to play softball. "He'd send us these videos and it was kind of funny because they thought you were supposed to hit people with the ball," Moosekian said.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Brooke.

ServiceUnit: 48th Civil Engineer Squadron, Royal Air Force
IncidentDetails: Staff Sgt. Phillip A. Myers, 30, Hopewell, Va.; died Saturday near Helmand province, Afghanistan of wounds suffered from an explosive.
Bio:
å¦   When Phillip A. Myers decided to join the Air Force, his father didn't expect him to choose bomb technician as his specialty.
