å¦   "That was the biggest thing that surprised me," said his father, Eddie Myers. The younger Myers half-jokingly told his father that he took on the job because it paid more, but he wound up loving the work.
å¦   "If there's anything we can find comfort in, it's knowing that he died doing what he loved to do," his father said. "That is without a doubt. He was just so enthused about it."
å¦   Myers, 30, of Hopewell, Va., died April 4 near Helmand province of wounds suffered from an explosive. He was assigned to Royal Air Force Lakenheath in the United Kingdom.
å¦   Eddie Myers said his son looked out for the people serving under him. "If he thought a job was too dangerous, he would get out and check it out himself," he said. "That might be why we don't have Phillip here today. But to me, that's admirable."
å¦   He graduated from high school in 1996 and worked at the Riverside Regional Jail in Hopewell before joining the military.
å¦   Phillip also is survived by his wife, Aimee, and their two children, Dakotah, 6, and Kaiden, 3.

ServiceUnit: Special Troops Battalion, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Adam M. Kuligowski, 21, Arlington, Va.; died Monday in Bagram, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered in a non-combat incident.
Bio:
å¦   In high school, Adam M. Kuligowski made his mark on a 2004 trip to China when he climbed on a camel's back and was photographed wearing his signature cowboy hat.
å¦   "Adam was a unique individual," said John Barry, one of his former teachers. "He wasn't one for formality or going by the rules. He had a spirit of adventure, for sure. He was the only kid who dared to get up on the camel in China."
å¦   Kuligowski, 21, of Arlington, Va., died April 6 in Bagram of injuries from a non-combat incident. He was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   The son of a foreign service officer, he grew up living in U.S. embassies in Asia, Africa and the Middle East.
å¦   He was born weighing nearly 11 pounds and was a curious child who didn't speak until after his first birthday, but then always spoke in complete sentences.
å¦   At his funeral, Kalia Kuligowski read excerpts from an essay her brother wrote. "Adam always saw things deeper than just face value," she said. "Adam wrote, 'I may not be a grade-A student, or a star athlete, but I always thought I understood the big picture better than most."
å¦   He also is survived by his parents, Michael and Tracie.

ServiceUnit: 42 Armoured Infantry Battalion of the Limburg Hunters
IncidentDetails: In neighboring Uruzgan province Monday, insurgents fired rockets at the Dutch main base, killing a soldier and wounding five others, said Gen. Peter van Uhm, the Dutch defense chief.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine Lance Cpl. Blaise A. Oleski, 22, Holland Patent, N.Y.; died Wednesday while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   From the mountains of Afghanistan, Blaise A. Oleski wondered what he would do when his enlistment period was up in a year. He talked of becoming a firefighter or perhaps a rock-climbing instructor. He wanted to hike the Adirondack Trail.
å¦   In one of his last calls, Blaise told his mom of all of his plans. "He said Mom, I'd need five lifetimes to do all the things I want to do,'" Theresa Oleski said.
å¦   Oleski, 22, of Holland Patent, N.Y., died April 8 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   Those who knew Oleski described him as a kind and compassionate young man who joined the military out of principle. A wristband he wore at the time of his death read "fighting for freedom."
å¦   They also spoke of how easily he made friends and the emotional support he so often provided to those around him.
å¦   "You're not allowed to have a breakdown," he told friend Amanda Santamour once during his deployment. "I need you to be resilient. But if you really need me, I'm on my way. I just need to find a camel."
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Paul.

ServiceUnit: 712th Air Support Operations Squadron
IncidentDetails: Airman 1st Class Jacob I. Ramsey, 20, Hesperia, Calif.; died Friday of wounds suffered from a non-combat related incident in Kabul, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Jacob I. Ramsey's above-average work ethic got noticed.
å¦   Often, his buddies would jokingly criticize him for his extra efforts because he out-shined them. Ramsey practically refused to take time away from work, showing up for extra duty even when on leave following his first deployment to Afghanistan.
å¦   "He showed up everybody," Senior Airman Thomas Rentschler said.
å¦   Ramsey, 20, of Hesperia, Calif., died April 10 of wounds suffered from a non-combat related incident in Kabul. He was a 2005 high school graduate _ graduating early, of course _ and was assigned to Fort Hood. He was on his second tour.
å¦   "He had a great personality. Happy go lucky, easygoing," said Luke Chappell, who taught Ramsey printing and graphics for two semesters in 2005. "He did some very extraordinary work in the classroom."
å¦   "Jacob was a very diligent student, a simply nice guy, respectful and considerate," said Hesperia High English teacher Connie Moore, who taught Ramsey during his junior year.
å¦   "It would take more than a few words to express the amount of love he shared with all of us," said Senior Airman Joseph Whitmarsh.

ServiceUnit: 82nd Sustainment Brigade, XVIII Airborne Corps
IncidentDetails: Cpl. Francisco X. Aguila, 35, of Bayamon, Puerto Rico, died April 14 in Kabul, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained from a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
å¦   Maj. James Dobrinska, executive officer for the 82nd Sustainment Brigade, said Francisco X. Aguila's competence and leadership were critical to the success of Bravo Detachment's mission.
å¦   "He ensured that every trooper in the task force received their proper pay and benefits while serving our nation in combat," Dobrinska said.
å¦   Aguila, 35, of Bayamon, Puerto Rico, died April 14 in Kabul of wounds suffered from a non-combat incident. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Aguila was assigned as a finance specialist in the 82nd Finance Company of the 82nd Sustainment Brigade of the 18th Airborne Corps in March 2007. He deployed to Afghanistan in July 2008.
å¦   Aguila is survived by a wife and two daughters who live in Bayamon.
å¦   Aguila joined the Army in March 2000 and had been assigned to Fort Sam Houston in Texas and Camp Humphreys in South Korea.
å¦   "Cpl. Aguila was a dedicated family man, soldier and leader whose motivation and positive attitude left a lasting impression on all that knew him. He was invaluable to his company, to the brigade and to his fellow troopers. Cpl. Aguila will be missed by us all. We are devastated by his loss," Dobrinska said.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 26th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: PFC Richard A. Dewater, 21, of Topeka, Kan., died April 15, of wounds sustained from an improvised explosive device, while on a dismounted patrol near Korengal Valley, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   The last time Richard A. DeWater and his father spoke on the phone was right after April 10. Rick seemed "jazzed" about something, his father said.
å¦   "He said he couldn't talk about it," Bob DeWater said. "But he also said he was looking forward to coming home. Too many of them look forward to coming home, and they don't."
å¦   DeWater, 21, of Topeka, Kan., died April 15 of wounds suffered from an explosive near Korengal Valley. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   "He was amazing. He had a personality that would draw you in. He loved fishing. He loved guns. He loved what he was doing. He dedicated himself to it," said his father.
å¦   DeWater moved to Topeka with his father in May 2007. He was born in San Diego. His father said his son was 4 when he first said he wanted to be in the military: "It lit a spark in him. It was a dream of his."
å¦   Ryan Burge said he and several of Rick's friends met at Echo Cliff near Dover to remember their friend. "He was a great guy," Burge said. "He was always set on going into the military. It is a shock that he is gone."
å¦   He and his wife, Valerie, were married in Topeka in June 2008.

ServiceUnit: Special Troops Battalion, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Army Sgt. James D. Pirtle, 21, Colorado Springs, Colo.; died Friday of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his unit using direct fire in Konar Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   James D. Pirtle graduated from high school in 2006 and immediately enlisted in the Army, despite his mother's fears.
å¦   "Coming from a military family, I was very proud of him, but my first response was, 'Why can't you wait until it's peace time?'" Patricia Pirtle said.
å¦   She said he was very patriotic and an enthusiastic soldier who quickly worked his way up to sergeant. In Afghanistan, he often volunteered for missions that he knew would be dangerous.
å¦   Pirtle, 21, of Colorado Springs, Colo., died May 1 when insurgents attacked his unit in Konar province. He was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   He was known to have a smile on his face, was a constant joker and was also the butt of many jokes. Once, teachers and students duct-taped him to a tree because he said it couldn't be done.
å¦   "It took two full rolls," said teacher Jan Songer. "We left him out there for a while."
å¦   He also is survived by his father, James.
å¦   "He just wanted to be part of something bigger than himself," said Andrew Thurn, one of his best friends. "He was OK dying if he was serving his country."

ServiceUnit: Special Troops Battalion, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Army Spec. Ryan C. King, 22, Dallas, Ga., died Friday of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his unit using direct fire in Konar Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   To Brittney Peters, it seems just like yesterday she and Ryan C. King and their friends were all hanging out and goofing off in the neighborhood.
å¦   "I bring myself to tears when I think of all the fun memories we had. I wish there could have been one last goodbye, there are so many things I would have said. Thank you for the memories that will make all of us remember you," she wrote on an online bulletin board. "I never got the chance to tell you, I am so proud of you and what you have done."
å¦   King, 22, of Dallas, Ga., died May 1 when insurgents attacked his unit in Konar province. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Hood.
å¦   A few months after graduation, he enlisted in the Army, something he had wanted to do since he was a child. He went to basic training at Fort Sill. After he completed his training, he was stationed in Korea for a year, where he met his wife, Sgt. Rachel King.
å¦   At a memorial, Spc. Gregory Landgraf read stories of King publishing a newspaper lampooning the soldiers in his unit and a time when King tied his arm behind his back and took on a sergeant during a combative match.

ServiceUnit: Fort Riley
IncidentDetails: Army Staff Sgt. William D. Vile, 27, Philadelphia; died Friday when insurgents attacked his unit in Konar province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   On his first tour in Iraq, William D. Vile was a gunner on a Humvee that was struck and turned over by a roadside bomb.
å¦   He told his fiancee Heather Jackson, "I popped right back up," but the Army thought his wound deserved a Purple Heart.
å¦   Then during his first tour in Afghanistan, he was watching as a helicopter landed with troops. As soon as it landed, the surrounding hills "lit up with enemy fire," he told her.
å¦   He ran to get his flak vest out of his tent and took a bullet in the arm. He pretty much fought off the medics trying to attend to him.
å¦   "I need something to stop the bleeding," he told them. "I have work to do here."
å¦   Vile, 27, of Philadelphia, died May 1 when insurgents attacked his unit in Konar province. He was assigned to Fort Riley and was on his fourth tour of duty.
å¦   "I never met anybody who was so honest," said Jackson. "He never put on a mask. He was never anyone but himself. Bill was larger than life."
å¦   He enlisted in 1998 after graduating high school. He had two Purple Hearts for wounds in combat in both countries.
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Donna.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 178th Infantry Regiment, Illinois Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Lukasz D. Saczek, 23, Lake in the Hills, Ill., died Sunday in Nangarhar Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered from a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
å¦   Lukasz D. Saczek and Michal Ambrozewicz became close after a tragedy: The death of Ambrozewicz's little brother.
å¦   "He came to the funeral and not really being very close at the time, it was a great sign of respect. I realized that I should be friends with a guy like that."
å¦   Saczek, 23, of Lake in the Hills, Ill., died May 10 in Nangarhar Province of wounds suffered from a non-combat related incident. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Woodstock, Ill.
å¦   Saczek, who grew up on the northwest side of Chicago, was married to Kathryn with a 6-week-old daughter, Emily. He briefly attended Wilbur Wright College before enlisting in the National Guard in July 2006.
å¦   After his parents moved to Lake in the Hills, Saczek would drive down to visit friends every chance he could, even if it was only for a couple of hours.
å¦   Samantha Klausing said she met him at a New Year's party when she was dating one of his friends. When they broke up, Saczek was supportive.
å¦   "He was very honest, very outspoken," Klausing said. "He was good to talk to, and he offered good advice on anything that bothered me."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Army Staff Sgt. Esau I. De la Pena-Hernandez, 25, La Puente, Calif.; died Friday at Forward Operating Base Shank, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his patrol was attacked by enemy forces using small-arms fire in Chak, Afghanistan
Bio:
å¦   Esau Ivan De La Pena-Hernandez poured his whole heart into his military service, family members said.
å¦   He was a fan of military-themed video games and movies and knew the film "Full Metal Jacket" word-for-word. His love for soccer was a close second.
å¦   "He used to always call me and ask `Are you proud of me?'" said his father, Mario De La Pena. "I told him `You are my hero.'"
å¦   De La Pena-Hernandez, 25, of La Puente, Calif., died May 15 after his patrol was attacked in Chak. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   The oldest of three children, he was born in Mexico and moved to America with his family when he was 11. Previously a legal resident, he had recently earned his citizenship.
å¦   Family members were shocked to discover after his death that he had earned nearly 20 decorations during his service.
å¦   "He wasn't a flashy person," said sister Denise. "We never knew he had all these medals."
å¦   De La Pena-Hernandez previously deployed to the Philippines in 2002, to Kuwait in 2004, to Iraq from December 2004 to March 2005 and to Afghanistan from September 2006 to May 2007.
å¦   He also is survived by his wife.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Army Sgt. Carlie M. Lee, III, 23, Birmingham, Ala.; died Friday at Forward Operating Base Shank, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his patrol was attacked by enemy forces using small-arms fire in Chak, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   The two things Carlie M. Lee III loved in his life were low-riding trucks and his mother. No less an authority than his mother, Norma Lee, said so.
å¦   "He loved me more than anything," she said. "He was my heart."
å¦   Lee, 23, of Birmingham, Ala., died May 15 after his patrol was attacked by enemy forces using small-arms fire in Chak. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Lee had only recently undergone surgery on his appendix and had not been out of the hospital for more than two weeks when he went back into combat, his mother said.
å¦   She said her son joined the Army two weeks after graduating from home-schooling. She said her son was a mother's best friend.
å¦   "He was just full of life," she said. "He loved everybody. He didn't judge nobody."
å¦   Lee was a graduate of the Combat Life Savers Course and had previously deployed to Afghanistan from October 2006 to May 2007. He had re-enlisted in the Army in December and was scheduled to return home in July.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Carlie.

ServiceUnit: Headquarters,  Pacific Air Forces Command
IncidentDetails: Air Force 1st Lt. Roslyn L. Schulte, 25, St. Louis, Mo.; died Wednesday near Kabul, Afghanistan of wounds suffered from an explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Robert Schulte remembers how his daughter, as a young girl, organized a group of her peers on the first day of summer camp to perform a play. In high school, Roslyn L. Schulte also captained the lacrosse team and became an all-American lacrosse player.
å¦   "She wanted to be in charge. And she was," he said.
å¦   Schulte, 25, of St. Louis, died May 20 near Kabul of wounds suffered from an explosive. She was assigned to Hickam Air Force Base.
å¦   Friends remembered how some had questioned her about the idea of working in a group made up mostly of men. "Do you think they are going to bully me?" she would defiantly respond.
å¦   At the Air Force Academy, Roslyn Schulte majored in political science, interned for former Sen. Alan Allard, R-Colo., became a group commander _ one of the academy's highest positions _ and captained the lacrosse team, said her mother, Suzie Schulte.
å¦   Schulte graduated in 2006 and went into military intelligence instead of aviation. She went to Afghanistan in February.
å¦   "She knew how to talk to chiefs of staff, to generals, to privates, and they listened," Robert Schulte said. "And that's what we needed, a great leader of people."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 82nd Combat Aviation Brigade, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Chief Warrant Officer (3) Brent S. Cole, 38, Reedsville, W. Va.; died Friday, when his helicopter went down in Tarin Kwot, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Brent S. Cole was a man who never failed to let his wife, son, friends and family know how much he loved them.
å¦   Even to the point that with a house brimming with people mourning his memory, a Father's Day card arrived in the mail for his dad, Jack Cole.
å¦   His son had sent it early from Afghanistan.
å¦   Cole, 38, of Reedsville, W.Va., died May 22 when his helicopter went down in Tarin Kwot. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   He joined the Army in 1987 as a military policeman and was selected in 1998 to the Army's Warrant Officer Flight Program. He excelled as an Army aviator and began flying the AH-64 Apache helicopter.
å¦   "He was a loving, dedicated husband and father who adored his family to the highest degree. As a military officer, he was a consummate professional who always led by example and was revered by his peers and leaders alike," Cole's wife Vanessa said.
å¦   "His loss is a tragedy that words cannot adequately describe. Brent was an exceptional Army Aviation professional who died doing what he loved, flying Apache helicopters while answering his nation's call to duty," Col. Paul W. Bricker.
å¦   He also is survived by his son, Carson.

ServiceUnit: Joint Staff, Pentagon
IncidentDetails: Airman Lt. Col. Mark E. Stratton II, 39, Houston, Texas; died Tuesday near Bagram Air Field, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered from an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Mark E. Stratton II was a superb but humble leader, said his friend, Lt. Col. Clark Risner. "He wouldn't have wanted any media spotlight on him," Risner said. "He would want it on his team."
å¦   "It sounds cliche but Mark was the most patriotic person I've ever met, just a model airman in every way," he said. "He put the airmen that he was supervising or leading first, every step of the way."
å¦   Stratton, 39, of Houston, died May 27 near Bagram Air Field of wounds from an improvised explosive device. He was assigned to Pope Air Force Base.
å¦   "He was a very, very God and country kind of guy, very into the Air Force and democracy and the United States," said his brother, Frankie Little. "People just couldn't help but like him."
å¦   After graduating from high school in 1987, Stratton went on to graduate from Texas A&M University. He had previously served on the staff at U.S. Strategic Command at Offutt Air Force Base.
å¦   Stratton was commander of the Panjshir Provincial Reconstruction Team. The group was building a road in the Panjshir Valley in north central Afghanistan.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Jennifer, and her three children.

ServiceUnit: 43rd Logistics Readiness Squadron
IncidentDetails: Senior Airman Ashton L. M. Goodman, 21, Indianapolis, Md.; died Tuesday near Bagram Air Field, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered from an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   If Ashton L.M. Goodman had a choice of driving a sedan or a 40-foot tractor-trailer, she'd pick the tractor-trailer.
å¦   "She was a work-hard, play-hard girl," said a friend, Airman 1st Class Vrajhi Brisby. "She didn't care if she broke a nail, got greasy, got sweaty. If she messed up her hair, she didn't care. Even if you were sitting in the truck, she got dirty."
å¦   Goodman, 21, of Indianapolis, died May 27 near Bagram Air Field of wounds from a roadside bomb. She was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Pope Air Force Base.
å¦   She mentored Panjshir's female Afghan leadership, advancing the economic and social development of women in the province. On May 18, she helped deliver much-needed food and house supplies to more than 100 poor women.
å¦   "Her vivacious spirit, zest of life, and eagerness to experience it all will forever be remembered by our team," said Capt. Stacie N. Shafran.
å¦   In high school, she was member of the Japan Club and participated in the Zoo Teen Club, in which she volunteered at the Indianapolis Zoo. She was training to become a biologist.
å¦   She is survived by her parents, Vicki Goodman and Mark Goodman, and stepmother, Chasity.

ServiceUnit: 426th Civil Affairs Battalion
IncidentDetails: Army 1st Sgt. Blue C. Rowe, 33, Summers, Ark., died Tuesday in Panjshir Province, Afghanistan, when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Blue C. Rowe, who was named after his great-uncle, was a University of Arkansas football fan. He wore Razorback shirts even while stationed in California.
å¦   "He lives and breathes all things Razorbacks," family friend Vera Sliger said.
å¦   Rowe, 33, of Summers, Ark., died May 26 in Panjshir province when a bomb detonated near his vehicle. He graduated high school in 1994 and was assigned to Upland, Calif.
å¦   "Blue was always looking for a direction with his life, and when I found out that he chose the military as a career, I knew it was a great fit for him. He overcame a lot to become the man he was," said Steve Avery, his football coach.
å¦   He served as a military policeman in South Korea, Germany and Bosnia-Herzegovina. He served in Iraq from September 2004 through July 2005. In Afghanistan, he was in a Civil Affairs Battalion.
å¦   "I told him that working in Civil Affairs was going to be an easy job," said classmate Chris Livesay. "He was supposed to be 'in the rear with the gear' but Blue just wasn't that kind of person. He wanted to be where he could be the most help to those people."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Cindy, and son, Andrew, 8.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Four American troops died Monday in two separate roadside bomb attacks in Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   As a child, Jeffrey A. Hall frequently coerced his parents into playing Army with him.
å¦   "He was the sergeant, and I was the cook," said Hall's mom, Annette.
å¦   "And I was the private," added his father, Charles.
å¦   He attached handmade parachutes to his pet hamster and dropped them off his bunk bed, playing out his dream of being an Army Ranger.
å¦   "But he dropped them on a pillow," his father said. "Nobody got hurt, but they were probably surprised."
å¦   Hall, 28, of Huntsville, Ala., died June 1 in Nerkh when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle. He was assigned to Fort Drum and had done two tours in Iraq.
å¦   "In his 28 years, he experienced everything he wanted," said his mother. "Scuba diving, jumping out of airplanes, hot motorcycles, fast cars, fine wine, good cigars, beautiful women. He was a Tasmanian devil, a whirl of energy, pushing everything to the edge."
å¦   Hall, who was slated to become a Ranger trainer at Camp Merrill, would have celebrated his second wedding anniversary with wife, Allison, on July 7. They have a 1-year-old daughter, Audrey Faith Hall.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Four American troops died Monday in two separate roadside bomb attacks in Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   While deployed, Matthew D. Ogden didn't ask his family to send his favorite snacks. Instead, he requested food for the animals he cared for.
å¦   "He was concerned with the underfed, flea-ridden dogs over there," said the Rev. Greg Hackett. "He requested dog food and flea control."
å¦   Hackett said that before Ogden died, he was caring for a baby turtle in a bowl, waiting for it to grow up so he could return it to the wild.
å¦   Ogden, 33, of Corpus Christi, Texas, died June 1 in Nerkh when a roadside bomb detonated near his vehicle. He was a 1994 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   The soldier worked a variety of construction jobs and at a floral shop, before a brush with the law led him to the military to turn his life around.
å¦   "Matthew was on the right track," said A.C. Gilmore Jr., owner of Blossom Shop Florist, where Ogden worked for more than three years.
å¦   He learned floral arrangements, delivered bouquets and helped with handyman work at the shop, Gilmore said. "He came to see me before he went overseas and he'd turned into a fine fellow."
å¦   He is survived by his mother, Charlotte, and his father, Michael.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Four American troops died Monday in two separate roadside bomb attacks in Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Ashlynn Wilson said that while she was pregnant, her husband, Matthew W. Wilson, always knew how to comfort her when she wasn't feeling well.
å¦   "He came home and if he said anything, it always made me smile," she said.
å¦   Wilson, 19, of Miller, Mo., died June 1 in Nerkh when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Wilson went into foster care at the age of 13. His mother died in 2003, and his father had a stroke and could no longer care for him.
å¦   Friend Lisa Jester said Wilson had a penchant to volunteer to help around the house, even when the family told him he didn't need to. "He took it upon himself to help us out without anyone asking him to," she said.
å¦   Ashlynn Wilson said after having a rough childhood, her husband was proud to serve his country and be a father to their newborn son Matthew Gunnar.
å¦   "Every time we spoke he said, 'How's my little man?'" Ashlynn Wilson said. "He was a proud father."
å¦   She said she's reminded of her husband every time she looks at her son. "He has his nose," she said. "He pretty much has everything from me, but he has his nose and his feet."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Four American troops died Monday in two separate roadside bomb attacks in Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Demei Obakrairur said what he will miss most about his son is his smile.
å¦   "Every time you call his name, he smiled before he said anything," Jasper K. Obakrairur's father said.
å¦   Obakrairur, 26, of Hilo, Hawaii, died June 1 in Nerkh of wounds suffered when an explosive detonated near his vehicle. He was a 2000 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Known as "Jazz" by island friends, and as "Sgt. O.B." by fellow soldiers, he was a former computer science student at the University of Hawai'i-Hilo and a native of Palau. He had been previously deployed to Afghanistan from January 2006 to May 2007.
å¦   He also is survived by his mother, Florence Kambalang.
å¦   His father said joining the Army had been something Jasper had talked about for a while. "What I told him was that you're old enough to make your own decision," he said. "I was proud of him for his decision."
å¦   At the soldier's funeral, President Johnson Toribiong addressed Obakrairur's parents and sister. "To say thank you is not enough," he said. "But we sincerely appreciate your giving up a son, a Palauan son."

ServiceUnit: 549th Military Police Company, 385th Military Police Battalion, 16th Military Police Brigade (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: A soldier died Tuesday during an insurgent attack in eastern Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Roberto A. Hernandez II's mother, Paulina Campbell-Richards, described her son as a happy-go-lucky young man who loved life and got along with everyone.
å¦   "He didn't like the fighting and killing," she said. "He was always the referee, pulling people apart when they fought. He was always looking out for other people."
å¦   Hernandez, 21, of New York City, died June 2 in Paktya when his mounted patrol was attacked with an improvised explosive device and small-arms fire. He was assigned to Fort Stewart.
å¦   Hernandez attended Tuskegee University in Alabama. A third-generation military member, he enlisted in September 2007, volunteering for Afghanistan immediately after basic training.
å¦   "The Army requested volunteers to go to Afghanistan, and my nephew stood up and said, 'I am willing to go,'" said his uncle, Ricardo Tomlinson, himself an Army veteran.
å¦   Brigadier Gen. Rodney Johnson recalled the soldier's ability to "keep his unit laughing" despite imminent danger.
å¦   "Rob was a special person that can never be replaced," said Samuel Hill, who grew up with Hernandez.

ServiceUnit: Marine Aviation Logistics Squadron 31, Marine Aircraft Group 31, 2nd Marine Aircraft Wing
IncidentDetails: was killed May 31 as a result of a non-hostile incident in Khandahar province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Matthew G. Reza's family said he was known for his engaging personality, singular independence, exceptional sense of humor and kind heart.
å¦   To many he was a loyal friend and capable mentor, proficient at handling difficult situations with either his resourceful mind or engaging smile.
å¦   To older family members, Matthew was the first grandchild, an "old soul" of exceptional intelligence who often discussed topics beyond his years.
å¦   Reza, 27, of Austin, Texas, died May 31 after a non-hostile incident in Khandahar province. He was assigned to Marine Corps Air Station Beaufort.
å¦   He attended Austin Community College and worked at Hope House, a residential facility for children with special needs, often speaking about advancing his education and career in social work after his tour of duty.
å¦   After meeting in San Diego, Matthew wed Sarah Benway on February 16, 2008. The newlyweds led an active life in California, North Carolina, and South Carolina until Matthew's deployment in March 2009.
å¦   His younger sister, Stephanie Peek, especially loved him. To her, he was a genuinely loving person who often put her needs, and those of many others, before his.

ServiceUnit: 425th BrigadeSpecial Troops Battalion, 4th Brigade Combat Team (Airborne), 25th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Spc. Jarrett P. Griemel, 20, of La Porte, Texas, died June 3 at Forward Operating Base Gardez, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered from a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
å¦   Jarrett P. Griemel joined the Army in 2006 after graduating with honors from high school, where he was a member of the swim team and the surf club.
å¦   "He wanted to see the world," said his brother Chase Schallert. "He wanted to travel and be adventurous."
å¦   Griemel, 20, of La Porte, Texas, died June 3 at Forward Operating Base Gardez of injuries suffered from a non-combat related incident. He was assigned to Fort Richardson.
å¦   In February 2008, Griemel returned home and married his high-school sweetheart, Candice, at a small ceremony in front of a justice of the peace.
å¦   "When we got there, I asked him, 'Are you nervous?' and he said, 'You know I'm never nervous,'" said Candice Griemel. "But in some of the pictures, he looked nervous."
å¦   With his bright red hair and infectious smile, family members said Griemel could light up any room with his charming personality and wonderful sense of humor.
å¦   "He would give these big hugs that would just fill your heart up with joy," said his sister-in-law, Crystal Schallert. "He would just hold onto you and you knew that he meant it."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 108th Reconnaissance, Surveillance and Target Acquisition Squadron, 48th Infantry Brigade Combat Team, Georgia Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Three soldiers died June 4 near Kapisa, Afghanistan of wounds suffered from an from an improvised explosive device and small arms fire.
Bio:
å¦   Georgia Army National Guard Adjunct General Terry Nesbitt said a few months prior to Kevin M. Jenrette's deployment in Afghanistan, he approached a superior and asked for the assignment.
å¦   "He said he felt a need to go and serve in the field with the soldiers," Nesbitt said. "And when he got to Afghanistan, he did what good leaders do. He led from the front."
å¦   Jenrette, 37, of Lula, Ga., was killed June 4 near Kapisa of wounds suffered from an explosive and small-arms fire. He was a graduate of North Georgia College and was assigned to Calhoun, Ga.
å¦   Jenrette seemed destined to be an Army officer. He graduated from Lyman Ward Military Academy in Alabama, where his father, Col. Albert Jenrette was the commandant. He became a Ranger and went on to serve in the Guard's recruitment program.
å¦   "So many people thought so much of him and there's a lot of people reaching out to us and to his family," said his father.
å¦   "I don't know a better person than Kevin," said Alvin Burns, pastor of the Timber Ridge Baptist Church. "He was exceptional."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Shannon, and children Corey, 7, Brody, 5, and Megan, 1.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 108th Reconnaissance, Surveillance and Target Acquisition Squadron, 48th Infantry Brigade Combat Team, Georgia Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Three soldiers died June 4 near Kapisa, Afghanistan of wounds suffered from an improvised explosive and small arms fire.
Bio:
å¦   John C. Beale served in the Army during Operation Desert Storm in 1991. After the Sept. 11 attacks, he was compelled to rejoin, said his wife, Crystal.
å¦   But their daughter, Calye, was a newborn at the time, so Crystal prevailed on him to hold off joining the Guard.
å¦   "But it kept calling him," said his wife, who finally relented.
å¦   In 2005, Beale joined the Guard. "You could see it go back through him. It was a fulfillment. He's been that way since he was a child."
å¦   Beale, 39, of Riverdale, Ga., was killed June 4 near Kapisa of wounds suffered from an explosive and small arms fire. He was assigned to Calhoun, Ga.
å¦   Beale worked for the Clayton County Water Authority, where his wife also works. He also was very involved with the authority's youth programs and liked to participate in career days at local schools.
å¦   "He really loved kids and did a great job reaching out to them in our public education efforts," said authority spokeswoman Suzanne Brown. "It has been a very sad day for all of us."
å¦   He also is survived by his son, Christopher.
å¦   "John was a true American hero," said the Rev. Tom Dowdy, Beale's friend and pastor.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 108th Reconnaissance, Surveillance and Target Acquisition Squadron, 48th Infantry Brigade Combat Team, Georgia Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Three soldiers died June 4 near Kapisa, Afghanistan of wounds suffered from an an improvised explosive device and small arms fire.
Bio:
å¦   Jeffrey W. Jordan met his wife-to-be at a party and later told relatives she was "like a movie star" and a "Barbie doll."
å¦   "He told me later that the minute he met me, he wanted to marry me," said his widow, Lacey. "When we got married, he was strutting down the aisle, he was so happy."
å¦   Jordan, 21, of Rome, Ga., was killed June 4 by an improvised explosive device and small-arms fire near Kapisa. He was assigned to Calhoun, Ga.
å¦   "People need to know Jeffrey was a good man. I just want to make sure they know how good a man he was and how proud we all are of him," said his mother, Mary Lou Dowdy.
å¦   Jordan, who as a civilian was employed by the Floyd County Prison, also had a son, Tailor. He died on Tailor's first birthday.
å¦   "This is really a tragedy," said Barbara White, Jordan's grandmother. "He was a terrific kid."
å¦   From childhood, Jordan had a knack for fixing things and served in the military to put his skills to work and provide a good life for his family, said his cousin, Bill Fortenberry.
å¦   "He wasn't afraid to go," Fortenberry said. "He was confident in his own skills and in the skills of those who would be working with him."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 3rd Marine Regiment, 3rd Marine Division, III Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine Lance Cpl. Joshua R. Whittle, 20, Downey, Calif., died Saturday while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Joshua R. Whittle's mother, Crystal Vincent, said his desire to serve in the Marines sprang from the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.
å¦   "I always wanted him to be a fireman," said Vincent, but she said he became a "true-blue Marine."
å¦   Whittle, 20, of Downey, Calif., died June 6 when he stepped on a land mine in Helmand province. He was assigned to Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii.
å¦   One of Whittle's best friends, Kyle Cooper, said, "He was the best friend anybody could ask for _ an all-around good person.
å¦   "We called him 'Joshie.' The only way I can deal with what's happened is knowing he was doing what he wanted. I will miss him forever."
å¦   Another longtime friend, Sean Gonzales, said, "He was a great individual _ shy, very caring, fun-loving _ truly a privilege to know. I will always remember his smile."
å¦   He also is survived by Carl Matson, his mom's boyfriend and who helped raise Whittle.
å¦   "He was an American," said Matson. Matson had been in the Army, and when he asked Whittle why he chose the Marines, Whittle responded, "I want the toughest branch."

ServiceUnit: 3rd Marine Regiment, 3rd Marine Division, III Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Army Maj. Rocco M. Barnes, 50, Los Angeles, died Thursday in Afghanistan of injuries sustained during a vehicle roll-over.
Bio:
å¦   Rocco M. Barnes had served as a bodyguard to Arnold Schwarzenegger on the sets of "True Lies" and "Collateral Damage" before the actor became governor.
å¦   Friends say he was driven by his passion for both the military and the movie business. "He loved Hollywood but always, always stuck to his military guns," said Nina Ratterree, an actress and longtime friend.
å¦   Barnes, 50, of Los Angeles, died June 4 in a vehicle rollover. He served two tours in Iraq and two in Afghanistan.
å¦   Barnes was chief operating officer for Fishman Productions, a company based at the studios of Paramount Pictures.
å¦   He wrote the screenplay for an action film called "Trajectory," which is to go into production next year, according to Jeff Fishman, the company's chief executive.
å¦   Barnes also was developing TV reality shows, including one focusing on bodyguards for the rich and famous.
å¦   "He was just a huge hero," said his friend and collaborator Kent Moyer. "But he was very low-key. He never bragged about himself."
å¦   A fitness buff, Barnes studied such martial arts as krav maga, an Israeli self-defense discipline.
å¦   He is survived by his mother, Grace Barnes-Filo.

ServiceUnit: 563rd Aviation Support Battalion, 159th Combat Aviation Brigade, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Eduardo S. Silva, 25, Greenfield, Calif., died Tuesday at Bagram Airfield, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered in a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
å¦   Victoria Zieber was Eduardo S. Silva's teacher in middle school and his band instructor since fourth grade. He played the drums.
å¦   "He was a gentleman and respectful," she said. "He would come to me and ask, 'Can I help you with anything after class?'"
å¦   Silva, 25, of Greenfield, Calif., died June 9 at Bagram Airfield from wounds suffered in a non-combat related incident. He was a 2002 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Campbell
å¦   He entered the Army in August 2006 and spent about six months in Iraq, said his mother, Sara Silva.
å¦   Enrique Silva described his brother, who served as an Army cook in Bagram, as a loving person. "There was no other guy like him," he said.
å¦   Ten years ago, Zieber was about four months pregnant with her son and couldn't think of a name.
å¦   Zieber said she thought about her best students. She thought of Eduardo, she said.
å¦   "I named my son after him," she said, "That's how incredible he was."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Rosalinda.
å¦   "He was such a good kid," said Josie Montoya, one of Silva's aunt by marriage. "God must have needed him."

ServiceUnit: 9th Engineer Support Battalion, 3rd Marine Logistics Group, III Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine Chief Warrant Officer 2 Ricky L. Richardson Jr., 33, Franklin, Mo., died Wednesday while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Ricky L. Richardson Jr. enjoyed living in the country: hunting, fishing and being on the river.
å¦   "He just loved being outdoors," said his father, Rick Richardson Sr. "He was so darn competitive. He always wanted to see who could catch the most fish or who could shoot best with a gun."
å¦   Richardson, 33, of Franklin, Mo., was killed June 10 by a roadside bomb in Delaran. He was assigned to Okinawa, Japan.
å¦   By his senior year in high school, he had become one of the top defensive ends in the Four Rivers Conference, leading in fumble recoveries and finishing second in quarterback sacks.
å¦   Richardson joined the Corps in 1996 as a machine gunner. From there he became an explosive ordinance disposal technician, and finally a gunnery sergeant. In 2007, Richardson was appointed as a warrant officer and was deployed to Afghanistan in February. This was his sixth combat tour.
å¦   "The best thing I can say about Rick is that he was a great kid but he grew up to be an even better man," said football coach Guy McClure.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Jenny, and a son, Cole, 8.

ServiceUnit: 549th Military Police Company, 385th Military Police Battalion, 16th Military Police Brigade (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Jonathan C. O‰ÛªNeill, 22, Zephyrhills, Fla., died Monday at Brooke Army Medical Center in San Antonio, Texas, of wounds suffered June 2 in Paktya, Afghanistan, when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   After he graduated high school and worked at several big-box stores, Jonathan C. O'Neill realized he wanted to do more with his life and see places other than the small town where he was raised, said his aunt, Jennifer Watkins.
å¦   "That's the type of man he was. He needed something to work for and something to take pride in," Watkins said. "He needed more, and by getting more he sacrificed his life."
å¦   O'Neill, 22, of Zephyrhills, Fla., died June 15 at Brooke Army Medical Center of wounds suffered during combat in Paktya on June 2. He was a 2004 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Stewart.
å¦   O'Neill wanted to work in law enforcement and figured joining the U.S. Army's Military Police was the best way to jump-start a career, said friend Brandyn Errickson.
å¦   O'Neill was in the junior ROTC in high school and was a fan of the Dallas Cowboys and the Tampa Bay Lightning and Rays, Errickson said. WWE wrestling star John Cena was his favorite.
å¦   "I'll miss his honesty on any and all subjects," Errickson said. "I'll miss seeing one of my best friends."
å¦   He also is survived by his parents Bob and Jackie.

ServiceUnit: 79th Troop Command
IncidentDetails: Sgt. 1st Class Kevin A. Dupont, 52, of Templeton, Mass., died June 17 at Brooke Army Medical Center in San Antonio, Texas, of wounds suffered March 8 in Kandau, Afghanistan, when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Kevin A. Dupont, who suffered burns over more than 65 percent of his body and damage to his lungs, wasn't supposed to make it home alive.
å¦   "They didn't expect he was going to survive the trip to the United States he was so badly burned," said lifelong friend Bruce Socha. "He had a tremendous will to live. He just kept going. That's the way he was with his training. He's going to leave a big gap."
å¦   Dupont, 52, of Templeton, Mass., died June 17 at Brooke Army Medical Center of wounds suffered during combat March 8 in Kandau Kalay. He was assigned to Rehoboth, Mass.
å¦   Socha said Dupont joined the Marine Corps out of high school in 1976, racing out of class to catch a recruiter who was about to leave for the day.
å¦   "We had a lot of good feelings about our country," Socha said. "We were celebrating our founding fathers. That year we were celebrating our nation and our freedom."
å¦   After eight years, Dupont spent a couple of years as a civilian, then joined the National Guard, where Socha said he worked training soldiers and many state employees in rappelling and sniper tactics.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Lisa.

IncidentDetails: Died Saturday of non-hostile causes aboard the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower in the North Arabian Sea.
Bio:
å¦   When Jeffrey J. Garber was asked for his help, guidance or assistance _ regardless of the subject or task _ he would always respond, "Easy day."
å¦   "I will always remember his infectious smile, his cordial greetings each and every time he passed anyone, and his simple response to everyone who asked something of him, 'Easy day,' meaning, I have got it _ and he did," Master Chief John Louvat said.
å¦   Garber, 43, of Hemingford, Neb., died June 20 of non-hostile causes aboard the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower in the North Arabian Sea.
å¦   Capt. Craig admired how Garber undertook his duties. "Tons of responsibility he handled with ease. He did all of this every single day, constantly on the move around the ship talking, teaching and advising sailors and senior leaders alike. And all with a smile," he said.
å¦   His mother, JoAnn Kuester, said he loved to play guitar and sing to his kids. She said he was persistent in remodeling the family home, teaching himself everything he needed to know to do the work himself, and to do it well.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Amy, and his three children, Tayler, 17; Paige, 15; and Josh, 13.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Squadron, 106th Cavalry
IncidentDetails: two soldiers were killed in Kandahar, Afghanistan of wounds sustained when their vehicle was hit by an explosive device. They were Illinois Army National Guardsmen.
Bio:
å¦   Paul G. Smith's daughter, Sarah, remembers her father as a "MacGyver" type, a person who loved the challenge of fixing things.
å¦   "He would never give up," she said with a choked laugh. "Once he started, he wouldn't stop until he finished the job."
å¦   Smith, 43, of Peoria, Ill., was killed June 19 when his vehicle was hit by an explosive device in Kandahar. He was assigned to Aurora, Ill.
å¦   Smith, a 1984 graduate of the community high school, enlisted in the Army in 1993 and was a tank gunner for most of his career.
å¦   "He was a quiet soldier, always willing to do what was needed to get the job done," Staff Sgt. Johnathan Brewer said. "It's a great loss. It's hard to find people like him, people who never say no, who never ask why, who do whatever is asked of them."
å¦   His wife, Kim, said the family had been all over the world, spending time in Germany, Texas and finally Fort Riley before Smith had enough of active duty. He transferred into the National Guard, and the family moved back to East Peoria in 1996 to live in Paul's childhood house.
å¦   He also is survived by a son, Ben, 20.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 130th Infantry
IncidentDetails: two soldiers were killed in Kandahar, Afghanistan of wounds sustained when their vehicle was hit by an explosive device. They were Illinois Army National Guardsmen.
Bio:
å¦   The body of Joshua A. Melton was wheeled into St. Boniface Catholic Church in Illinois. His wife, Larissa, who had walked down the same aisle to marry him less than three years ago, followed, with dozens of family members and the couple's 16-month-old daughter Aubrey behind her.
å¦   "He was an ordinary man from Clinton County who served his country with extraordinary courage," said Monsignor Jim Buerster said. "We remember Josh in our hearts, and our prayers, and then we let him go."
å¦   Melton, 26, of Carlyle, Ill., was killed June 19 in Kandahar when his vehicle was hit by an explosive device. He was assigned to Marion, Ill.
å¦   Melton enlisted in 2001, a year before graduating high school. He was on his second deployment; his first was to Iraq, from December 2004 to March 2006. He had been in Afghanistan since October and his unit worked to protect training teams.
å¦   He loved fishing, hunting and remote-control cars. At his funeral, many people wore bright orange shirts, ties and ribbons to remember Melton's favorite color.
å¦   Melton's brother, Dustin, said Melton's "dream was to be a hero, and now he is one."

ServiceUnit: 710th Brigade Support Battalion, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Rodrigo A. Munguia Rivas, 27, Germantown, Md., died Sunday in Bagram, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his unit was attacked by indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   Rodrigo A. Munguia Rivas was dedicated to serving the country he came to love, said his mother, Rosa Isabel Castillo, who moved to the U.S. from El Salvador in 1993, her son joining her in 1995.
å¦   "He loved the United States. He wanted to be there not out of necessity, not out of obligation," she said. "He did it because he wanted to go."
å¦   Munguia Rivas, 27, of Germantown, Md., died June 21 in Bagram when his unit was attacked by indirect fire. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   He trained at Fort Sill, the White Sands Missile Range and Fort Leonard Wood. He deployed to Afghanistan around January.
å¦   He joined the U.S. Navy after graduating from high school in 2000. He served in the Navy for four years, including a tour in Iraq, Castillo said.
å¦   Cpl. Diego Jara described his friend as quiet and easygoing. He liked soccer, cars and had a motorcycle. He liked playing baseball with Jara's young sons.
å¦   "Every time I'll think of him, I'll think of him hanging out at the house, sitting around, having a beer or something," Jara said.
å¦   Munguia Rivas' father lives in El Salvador.

ServiceUnit: 1st Maneuver Enhancement Brigade
IncidentDetails: Army Sgt. Ricky D. Jones, 26, Plantersville, Ala., died Sunday in Bagram, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when his unit was attacked by indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   Long before he became a running back on the high school varsity football team, Ricky D. Jones was known for his speed. He earned the nickname "Mojo."
å¦   "I don't know how he got the name Mojo," said his mother, Shelia McCrary. "I was young when I had him. His grandmother and grandfather must have given him that name. Maybe because he moved so fast."
å¦   Jones, 26, of Plantersville, Ala., died June 21 in Bagram when his unit was attacked by indirect fire. He was a 2001 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Polk. He served as Range Control and Reenlistment NCO.
å¦   Sgt. First Class Revon Spain recalled Jones' love of motorcycles. "Sgt. Jones would always talk about motorcycles and four wheelers, and how his 4-year-old son just loved to ride a four-wheeler," Spain said.
å¦   Jones had come home in March on a two-week leave to help his mother as she recovered from hip surgery. While he was home, he also visited his father, Willie Tyus.
å¦   "He was feeling good," Tyus said. "He told me he loved it."
å¦   He also is survived by his wife, Fredda, and four sons, Kenderrick, Marius, I'Kemeyon and Jemerius.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 121st Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: Army 1st Sgt. John D. Blair, 38, Calhoun, Ga., died Saturday in Mado Zayi, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when a rocket-propelled grenade struck his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   John D. Blair was described as having a sadistic sense of humor and he didn't discriminate between the old guys and the new. He rode everyone hard and they loved him for it.
å¦   "I ain't been scared of much in my life," said Spc. Robert Love. "But that 5-foot-7, 150-pound guy was scary."
å¦   Blair, 38, of Calhoun, Ga., died June 20 in Mado Zayi when a rocket-propelled grenade struck his vehicle. He was a 1990 high school graduate and was assigned to Lawrenceville, Ga.
å¦   "He was the meanest, kindest person you'd ever meet," said Pfc. Justin Campbell. "If he didn't cuss at you, he didn't like you."
å¦   Blair enlisted in the Kentucky Army National Guard in 1989 and later transferred to the Georgia Army National Guard. He worked for the Gordon County Sheriff's Office as a deputy and member of the drug task force for many years.
å¦   "He believed in leading by example, leading from the front, and that's how he died," said Therrell Goswick, former Calhoun police chief.
å¦   "He was the real deal, practiced tough love and was respected because of it," said Matt Smith, Blair's commander in Afghanistan.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Donna.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Staff Sgt. Joshua R. Townsend, 30, of Solvang , Calif. , died Jan. 16 in Tarin Kowt, Afghanistan , of injuries sustained in a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
å¦   While at basic training or later trying to make the Special Forces, Joshua R. Townsend wouldn't _ couldn't _ give up.
å¦   "While many guys were quitting because of the absence of comfort, Josh pushed through the pain and completed the course," said Rusty Whitt, a fellow soldier.
å¦   Townsend, 30, of Solvang, Calif., died Jan. 16 in Tarin Kowt of wounds from non-combat related causes. He was a 1997 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   In his Facebook profile, Townsend wrote that he enjoyed playing with his three Pug dogs, going to the movies, working on his house and "most of all, spending time with my wife Rachel."
å¦   He loved to listen to his wife singing and playing the guitar, enjoyed Play Station 3 and was a fan of the History Channel.
å¦   "He was a fearless, red-bearded Viking with a devil-may-care attitude who was proud and motivated to serve his country," said Whitt.
å¦   Townsend attended Santa Barbara City College and Hancock Community College. He joined the Army in 2003, was a Special Forces weapons sergeant and earned his Green Beret in 2005.
å¦   "He kept us laughing constantly," said Whitt.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 501st Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Airborne Brigade Combat Team, 25th Infantry Division,
IncidentDetails: died Thursday in Kheyl, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle
Bio:
å¦   Brian N. Bradshaw was always very happy when his parents sent packages. What he asked for was things to give away to local children.
å¦   "When they were out on patrol they would take crayons, colored pencils and books and toys to give to the children," said his father, Paul.
å¦   Bradshaw, 24, of Steilacoom, Wash., died June 25 when his vehicle struck a bomb in Kheyl. He was a 2007 graduate of Pacific Lutheran University and was assigned to Fort Richardson.
å¦   During high school he served as a member of Pierce County Search and Rescue and was a counselor during summers at Camp Don Bosco, a Catholic Youth Organization camp in Carnation, where he had once been a camper himself.
å¦   Paul Bradshaw described his son as "very athletic, an outdoors and very action-oriented person. He bicycled, was a backcountry skier and climbed mountains."
å¦   Bradshaw came from a military family. His father is a retired National Guard helicopter pilot. His mother, Mary, is a retired Army nurse.
å¦   "He could make people feel better," the elder Bradshaw said. He could also be very funny, he added: "He has a great sense of humor."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 12th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Army Pvt. Steven T. Drees, 19, Peshtigo, Wis., died Sunday at Landstuhl Regional Medical Center, in Landstuhl, Germany, of injuries sustained Wednesday in Konar Province, Afghanistan, when insurgents attacked his unit using small arms fire.
Bio:
å¦   Steven T. Drees' love for hunting and fishing seemed to run in the family. He joined his grandfather, father, uncles and cousins each year at their deer camp in Wisconsin to have a big deer drive the day after Thanksgiving.
å¦   "We don't care what they get for the first deer, but after the first one they have to get a buck. Steven got his share," said his grandfather, Henry Drees. "Deer hunting camp will be different this year."
å¦   Drees, 19, Peshtigo, Wis., died June 28 at the Landstuhl Regional Medical Center in Germany. He was shot in the head two days earlier when his unit was ambushed in Afghanistan. He was assigned to Fort Carson.
å¦   His parents, Dawn Bayer and Paul Drees, and his twin brother, Charlie, were there when he died, according to his cousin.
å¦   One of his platoon members sent the family an e-mail to explain what happened.
å¦   "They were so happy he stayed with his gun when they were ambushed. He saved their lives," his grandfather said.
å¦   Drees joined the Army in August 2008, shortly after graduating from Peshtigo High School, and deployed on his 19th birthday.
å¦   "Before Steve left, he told everyone that if anything happened to him he wanted them to be proud, not sad," said James Meeks, 17, a high school friend.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Army Pfc. Peter K. Cross, 20, Saginaw, Texas, died Friday at Combat Outpost Carwile, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained during a vehicle roll-over.
Bio:
å¦   On the day he died, Peter K. Cross had gone to get food for his unit, which was on patrol. He was returning when he rounded a corner on a mountainous road, saw children herding sheep and swerved to avoid them.
å¦   "His last act in life shows what kind of man he was _ selflessly thinking of others," said his father, Mike Cross.
å¦   Cross, 20, of Saginaw, Texas, died June 26 when his vehicle crashed at Combat Outpost Carwile. He was a 2007 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Mike Cross said his son had purchased a cell phone and called about 30 times since being deployed. Father and son last talked on Father's Day.
å¦   "He really had a heart for the Afghani people," Mike Cross said. "He used to hand out candy, and pens and papers, and anything else he could spare for the kids when they came around the guys. He was a fun guy. A godly guy."
å¦   He had wanted to be a missionary and had traveled on mission trips to Fiji, Finland, Cameroon and Zambia while in middle school and high school. He attended Moody Bible Institute in Spokane, Wash., for a year before enlisting.
å¦   He also is survived by his mother Kerry Kahler and stepmother Susan Cross.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Squadron, 71st Cavalry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Army Sgt. Terry J. Lynch, 22, Shepherd, Mont., died Monday in Wardak Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Terry Lynch, determined and serious about serving his country, had a handshake so firm one friend called it "bone-crushing."
å¦   Mark Johnson also said Lynch was fun-loving and modest.
å¦   "I was struck by how modest Terry was, as he told about his promotion to sergeant, his new responsibilities and duties and how he looked forward to being these young men's boss," Johnson said.
å¦   Lynch, 22, was killed June 29 by a bomb that detonated near his vehicle in Wardak Province. He was based in Form Drum, N.Y.
å¦   A funeral procession through Shepherd, Mont., the small town Lynch called home, passed farmland and a high school before reaching the town's graveyard, where he was buried in a grave next to his mother, Robyn, and older brother, David.
å¦   Lynch graduated from Shepherd High School in 2005 and joined the Army at age 18.
å¦   "I wanted to give back to my country," he said told the Billings Gazette newspaper before leaving for basic training.
å¦   He is survived by his father, Charlie, and his sister, Kristin, and her husband, Frank.
å¦   "We as a family, we as a community, and we as a nation are forever grateful," Johnson said.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 130th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: died July 7 in Shindad, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Christopher M. Talbert enjoyed his work with the Illinois Army National Guard, so much that he volunteered outside of his home unit to deploy overseas.
å¦   "He loved Afghanistan," said friend Ashley Lamb.
å¦   Talbert, 24, of Galesburg, Ill. died July 7 in Shindad, Afghanistan, of wounds caused when a bomb detonated. He was based in Marion, Ill.
å¦   He graduated from Galesburg Christian School in 2003 and joined the National Guard four years later as a combat medic. He had worked at Galesburg Cottage Hospital and completed training as an emergency medical technician.
å¦   It was serious work, but he found ways to laugh.
å¦   "He had a great sense of humor and enjoyed practical jokes and working on automobiles with his friends," said Elisa Cecil, a family friend.
å¦   Another friend, Susan Powell, said he loved children and was "Uncle Chris" to her young daughter. She said Talbert didn't answer when she asked why he wanted to join the Army, but believed he did it to "show everyone that he could do it. He wanted to turn his life around, and make his parents proud."
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Terry and Amanda, and two brothers.

ServiceUnit: 704th Brigade Support Battalion, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died July 8 at Bagram, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained elsewhere in Afghanistan, when enemy forces attacked his unit using small arms fire
Bio:
å¦   Gregory J. Missman's 4-year-old son, Jack, doesn't quite understand the significance of his dad's death.
å¦   Yet his words are mature: "Dad was a strong soldier," Jack said as he ran into the arms of his mother, Brooke. "He loved us. We loved him."
å¦   Missman was wounded by a roadside bomb and was awarded the Purple Heart before he died of his injuries July 8. He enlisted in the Army after graduating from Amelia High School in 1993, serving for more than three years. He then worked as a computer consultant before re-enlisting. He was assigned to Fort Carson.
å¦   "I don't know who I'm going to get to fix my computer," said his father, Jim.
å¦   The soldier was a hero to his family long before his death.
å¦   "He's always been a hero of our family," said his sister Dawn Waggoner. "I remember several Thanksgivings we spent together where he was down volunteering in homeless shelters, feeding people who had no place to go or eat."
å¦   He is survived by his father, Jim; his mother, Donna Missman Turner; his son; a brother, Michael Missman; and a stepsister, Dawn Puccini.

ServiceUnit: USS Iwo Jima
IncidentDetails: died of non-hostile causes July 8 at Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan.  He was assigned to the USS Iwo Jima, and deployed as an Individual Augmentee to Combined Security Transition Command - Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Darren Ethan Tate was a bodybuilder, a cook and an aspiring pilot rolled into one friendly guy.
å¦   "We clowned around a lot," said his uncle, Wayne Tate. "Just had a great time. He was one terrific young man."
å¦   He said his nephew had wanted to go to Afghanistan in place of another man who'd recently become a father.
å¦   "It broke my heart, but I was proud that he was man enough to take on the responsibility he volunteered for," Wayne Tate said. "He was willing to take on the danger himself."
å¦   Darren Tate, 21, of Canyon, Texas, died of pneumonia July 8 at Bagram Air Base. He had joined the Navy in 2006 after graduating from Canyon High School and was assigned to the USS Iwo Jima.
å¦   "You can tell by the size of this crowd that he was loved," said another uncle, John Stratton, who officiated at Tate's funeral in Texas.
å¦   He was born in California, and that was his nickname when he worked at the Skate Plex in Amarillo, where he also worked and trained at a tae kwon do institute.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Larry and Barbara; a brother, Keith; and a sister, Sarah.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 106th Cavalry Regiment
IncidentDetails: One of four soldiers killed Monday in Konduz, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive detonated near their vehicle
Bio:
å¦   Derwin Williams was a correctional officer and worked as a drill instructor in the Cook County Sheriff's Boot Camp, a strict detention program based on military discipline in Chicago.
å¦   But he had a soft spot, not only for his own children but for some of the men in the program.
å¦   The boot camp's executive director, John Harrington, said Williams often became a father figure for the inmates, some of whom never had relationships with their own fathers.
å¦   "His kindness and soft-spoken manner had a great impact on everyone here," Sheriff Thomas Dart said. "He will be greatly missed."
å¦   Williams, 41, of Glenwood, Ill., died July 6 when his vehicle hit a roadside bomb in Afghanistan. A member of the Illinois Army National Guard based in Dixon, Williams had served a yearlong tour in Iraq in 2004 and was slated to return from Afghanistan in August, his wife said.
å¦   Felicia Williams said her husband would often take three of his girls paintball shooting and to amusement parks. He also was nearby when homework help was needed.
å¦   "They talked to him a lot, they went to him for anything, they could talk to him about anything," his wife said. "They were very close."
å¦   Along with his wife, Williams is survived by two stepdaughters, ages 18 and 22; two daughters, who are 9 and 19; and an 8-year-old son.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 121st Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: One of four four soldiers were killed Monday in Konduz, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   There were two sides to Brock H. Chavers: The loving jokester who would give people whatever they needed, and the consummate leader who followed in his brothers' footsteps to become a soldier.
å¦   "He would give you anything. I don't care if it was new or, you know, he had it, if you needed it, he would say well I'll get another one," said his mother, Loice Chavers.
å¦   The 25-year-old National Guardsman of Bulloch, Ga., was killed July 6 in Konduz when a roadside bomb detonated near his vehicle. He was assigned to Americus, Ga.
å¦   Chavers was remembered by Bill Rogers, who taught him in the Junior ROTC program at Portal High School, as "an outstanding young man."
å¦   "He was one of my leaders," Rogers said. "He volunteered for additional stuff, duties. He wanted to make the unit better and he wanted to be better."
å¦   April Holmes said Chavers was "more like a brother" who taught her how to shoot pool. At Chavers' funeral she handed a pool cue to Chavers' son, Brock Jr.
å¦   Chavers is survived by his wife, who was in his National Guard unit, and a 3-year-old son.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 106th Cavalry Regiment
IncidentDetails: one of four soldiers were killed Monday in Konduz, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Chester W. Hosford loved being a soldier, said Brendee Roberts, a close friend. Patriotism had a lot to do with it, but he also liked to meet new people and travel to exotic places like Egypt.
å¦   She described him as a fun-loving guy, especially among those he knew. "He protected his family and his friends, especially the ones that were very close to him," Roberts said.
å¦   Hosford, 35, of Hastings, Minn., died July 6, 2009, in Konduz when an improvised explosive detonated near his vehicle. He was assigned to Dixon, Ill.
å¦   Friends and family said Hosford, known as Wayne, was a loyal friend who was always kind and selfless.
å¦   "He would give you the shirt off his back if he thought that you needed it worse than he did," said Eloise Simmons, his grandmother with whom he came to live when he was 14 after his mother was killed.
å¦   He graduated from high school in Peyton, Colo., in 1993 and enlisted in the Marines. He later moved to Minnesota to be near his sister.
å¦   He joined the Minnesota Army National Guard as a cavalry scout in 2006 and then transferred to the Illinois Army National Guard in 2008.
å¦   Hosford is survived by a son, Tristyn.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 108th Reconnaissance, Surveillance and Target Acquisition Squadron
IncidentDetails: One of four soldiers were killed Monday in Konduz, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive detonated near their vehicle:
Bio:
å¦   Isaac L. Johnson sat down with his family at Mikata Japanese Steakhouse in Columbus, Ga., just before he deployed to Afghanistan in April.
å¦   "We had a big dinner, laughed and had a lot of fun with the family," said his cousin, Marine Staff Sgt. Charles Jackson.
å¦   About 30 members of his family were there when his body was flown back to the U.S. _ not far from where they shared that meal.
å¦   Johnson, 24, of Columbus, Ga., was killed July 6 in Konduz when a roadside bomb detonated near his vehicle. Some of his relatives wore T-shirts as they awaited his coffin's arrival noting "sunrise" _ Johnson's birthday on Dec. 8, 1984 _ and "sunset," the day he died.
å¦   The Army was a perfect fit for Johnson, who would help someone even if it meant putting himself in danger, Jackson said. Jackson said he always kept in touch with his cousin _ if only so they could rib each other about their rival military branches.
å¦   "He loved the discipline and liked the order," Jackson said. "Everything has a plan and a reason. Work hard, and you get promoted."
å¦   Johnson is survived by his mother and father, two sisters and two brothers.

ServiceUnit: Explosive Ordnance Disposal Mobile Unit Eight
IncidentDetails: died July 6 in an improvised explosive device attack on his convoy in northern Afghanistan. Was assigned to Explosive Ordnance Disposal Mobile Unit Eight, Sigonella, Italy, and was deployed with his platoon to Joint Task Force South
Bio:
å¦   Tony Michael Randolph was tough. He was a three-year starter, all-district lineman on Henryetta High School's football team and was involved in champion-class power lifting.
å¦   Randolph was so determined that he once refused to stop running around the track because he didn't want to say "yes, sir" when football coach Kenny Speer asked whether he'd had enough. Randolph finally said those two words _ but in Spanish.
å¦   "You're not going to find a kid that would work harder than he worked," Speer said. "He knew what direction he wanted his life to go toward."
å¦   Randolph, 22, of Henryetta, Okla., died July 6 after the vehicle he was riding in struck a roadside bomb in northern Afghanistan. The demolitions expert was based at Sigonella, Sicily.
å¦   He graduated in 2005 and joined the Navy the following year. The Rev. Jim Paslay, who officiated at his funeral, said he'd recently read the Navy's creed, and three words _ honor, courage and commitment _ stood out.
å¦   "That's what the Navy is all about," Paslay said, "and that's what Tony was all about."
å¦   Randolph is survived by his parents, Fred and Peggy Randolph of Weleetka, along with two stepbrothers and two stepsisters.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 4th Infantry Regiment, Joint Multinational Readiness Center
IncidentDetails: died July 6 in Argandab District, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Mark A. Garner couldn't peel his eyes off the pages of encyclopedias as a kid, and kept his nose buried in travel books as an adult as he planned the next expedition for "Team Garner."
å¦   "On a weekend, we would jump in the car and travel to different countries," said his wife, Nickayla, who described herself and her husband as "Team Garner."
å¦   "Mark visited 52 countries in 12 years, most of which I was a part of," she said. "His dream was to see the world."
å¦   Garner, 30, of State Road, N.C., was killed July 6 in Argandab District when a roadside bomb exploded near his vehicle.
å¦   Nickayla Garner said she and her husband were known for throwing dinner parties and low-country shrimp boils, and a friend said his reputation as a party-thrower developed when he was a teenager.
å¦   "Birthday parties at Mark's house were the best. There were epic basketball games on his asphalt pad," said childhood friend Dennis Burton, who remembered as many as 15 boys coming out to play backyard football and driveway basketball in the spring.
å¦   Garner, a graduate of the West Point military academy, had been stationed in Germany. He is survived by his wife and three children.

ServiceUnit: 1st Squadron, 40th Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team (Airborne), 25th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died July 6 at Forward Operating Base Salerno, Afghanistan, of injuries suffered earlier that day in Paktya, Afghanistan, when insurgents attacked his unit using small arms and rocket-propelled grenade fires.
Bio:
å¦   A month before he died, Nicolas Gideon proposed to his high school sweetheart, Wendy Herman, and the two began planning the life they would share.
å¦   They talked about how many kids they wanted to have and which rooms in their future home would be painted green, Gideon's favorite color.
å¦   "You were my world, my best friend and my total and complete opposite," Herman said during Gideon's service. "We were water and oil, but it worked for us."
å¦   Gideon, 20, of Murrieta, Calif., died July 6 of injuries suffered when insurgents attacked his unit in Paktia province. He was based in Fort Richardson, Alaska.
å¦   Gideon met Herman while attending Chapparral High School in Temecula, Calif. He played football, hockey and the saxophone, said his mother, Carol. He also liked skydiving and riding motorcycles.
å¦   "I always enjoyed listening to you play on the sax," she said at his service. "I remember how encouraging and patient you were when you tried to teach me to play. Fearless Nick describes you well."
å¦   A photo of Gideon with his mother, stepdad and siblings, as well as a saxophone, hemp rosary and certificate for a 12,500-foot parachute drop were displayed at his service.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 509th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team (Airborne), 25th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: One of two soldiers who died July 4 at Combat Outpost Zerok, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked the outpost using small arms and indirect fires.
Bio:
å¦   When he was younger, Justin Casillas was a daredevil who liked sliding down stairs on a mattress in his family's home, said his father, Chuck Casillas.
å¦   At 17, Justin Casillas wanted only one job when he enlisted in the military: infantryman. But his father, whose approval was needed for Casillas to join the military before turning 18, said another job preference would have to be listed on his application. Chuck Casillas had read that an infantryman's life expectancy in combat zones is just six months.
å¦   "If you won't sign this now," the elder Casillas recalled his son answering, "I'll just come back when I turn 18."
å¦   Casillas, 19, of Dunnigan, Calif., died July 4 when his combat post in Paktika province was bombed. His friend from boot camp, Pfc. Aaron E. Fairbairn, also was killed in the attack.
å¦   Casillas was based at Fort Richardson, Alaska.
å¦   "I can only remember Justin as a hero," his father said. "He stopped the bomb before it could reach the other soldiers."
å¦   Chuck Casillas said his son never complained about waking up at 5 a.m. or doing push-ups in the rain.
å¦   "I supported him 100 percent," said his mother, Donna Casillas. "I'm proud of Justin."

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 509th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team (Airborne), 25th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: one of two soldiers who died July 4 at Combat Outpost Zerok, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked the outpost using small arms and indirect fires.
Bio:
å¦   Aaron Fairbairn wasn't yet sure what he wanted to do with his life after the service but was leaning toward mechanics, said his stepfather, David Masters.
å¦   The 20-year-old liked riding his dirt bike and four-wheeling in his truck.
å¦   "He was just glad to be over there making a few extra bucks so he could pay off his truck," Masters said.
å¦   Fairbairn, of Aberdeen, Wash., died July 4 when insurgents attacked his combat post in Paktika province. His friend, Pfc. Justin A. Casillas, also was killed.
å¦   "They killed my son, Aaron," Masters wrote on Twitter after hearing the news. "He was minding his own business BS-ing with an Officer on base in Afghanistan."
å¦   Fairbairn seldom left the base, Masters said. Instead, he spent much of his free time watching DVDs his family sent him.
å¦   Fairbairn graduated from Weatherwax High in Aberdeen. He was the youngest son in a Brady Bunch-like family brought together by his mother, Shelley, and Masters, each the parents of three.
å¦   "At first I didn't believe it," Beau Beck said about learning of his brother's death. "The first thing that rushed to my mind is that he's so young and such a good kid."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails:
died July 2 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.

U.S. Marines suffered their first casualties of a massive new military campaign Thursday as they engaged in sporadic gunbattles in southern Afghanistan
Bio:
