ServiceUnit: 336th Fighter Squadron
IncidentDetails: Capt. Thomas J. Gramith, 27, Eagan, Minn. died Friday in a F-15E crash near Ghazni Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Thomas J. Gramith lives in his mother's memory as a young man with his eyes on the sky who eventually reached those heights as an Air Force navigator.
å¦   "Keep watch over us as we live under your blue skies," Patricia O'Kane-Trombley said during a memorial service for her son.
å¦   Gramith, 27, of Eagan, Minn., died July 17 when his fighter jet crashed in eastern Afghanistan. He was assigned to Seymour Johnson Air Force Base. He graduated from North Dakota State University in 2005.
å¦   His mother reminded mourners that they'd lost a man who was dedicated not only to serving his country but to taking care of friends and adoring his wife, Angie, and twin daughters Stella and Eva. She said her son adored his family, and his antics always brought a smile.
å¦   Known to his fellow airmen as "Lag," his friends said Gramith was excellent at what he did.
å¦   "Tom never had anything bad to say and he was always in good spirits," said his friend, Capt. Brian Davis. "He embodied the ethic and warrior mentality of a fighter pilot, but never let his Air Force dream overshadow being a family man and friend."
å¦   Besides his wife and daughters, Gramith is survived by his parents, two sisters and a brother.

ServiceUnit: 336th Fighter Squadron
IncidentDetails: Capt. Mark R. McDowell, 26, Colorado Springs, Colo., died Friday in a F-15E crash near Ghazni Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Mark McDowell was a 4.0 student, the MVP on his high school soccer team and the usual winner in the golf games he played against his brother.
å¦   When he decided he wanted to attend the U.S. Air Force Academy, he was accepted and graduated in 2005 with a degree in physics.
å¦   "He was always good at everything," said his wife, Katie McDowell. "If we did something, he always learned quickly, or was always better at it than everyone."
å¦   Mark McDowell, 26, of Mooresville, N.C., died July 17 when the F-15 he was piloting went down near Ghazni Province. He was based at Seymour Johnson Air Force Base in Goldsboro, N.C.
å¦   "He loved flying. He loved being a part of the community that was doing what they're doing," his wife said.
å¦   The couple met while attending the Air Force Academy. Katie McDowell was deployed to Iraq in June.
å¦   Mark McDowell graduated from South Iredell County High School in Statesville, N.C.
å¦   He is survived by his wife; stepfather and mother, Bill and Barbara Thomas; father and stepmother, Stan and Karen McDowell; and brothers Joseph McDowell and Bill Thomas.
å¦   "He was a great brother. I always looked up to him. He used to push me around a lot, but then I got to be bigger than him," Joseph McDowell said.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Rifles
IncidentDetails: killed as a result of an explosion that happened whilst on a foot patrol
Bio:
Corporal Etchells, or "Etch" to his mates, was born on 23 March 1987.  He joined the Army in December 2003, and on successful completion of his infantry training at Army Foundation College, Harrogate, was posted to 2nd Battalion The Royal Regiment of Fusiliers later that year.  He was always eager and proud to be a Fusilier and Infantryman. 

On arrival in the Battalion, Cpl Etchells joined B Company 6 Platoon in Palace Barracks, Belfast subsequently moving to with the Battalion Cyprus.  Whilst in Cyprus he deployed with A Company Group to Now Zad, Afghanistan in 2006 as a Fusilier in 6 Platoon.  He returned to Cyprus from Afghanistan and in June 2007 he passed his Junior NCO cadre moving to A Company on promotion. 

Whilst in Cyprus he represented the Battalion and Garrison side at cricket and was an active member of the Battalion cross country team.  In late 2007 Cpl Etchells deployed to Jordan on Exercise Saffron Sands and showed huge potential for the future in his Army career.  On the Battalion's return from Cyprus to UK he secured a place on the Section Commander's Battle Course in June 2008 a course he passed with ease and was promoted to Cpl soon after.

When called on to deploy to Afghanistan again, he was the ultimate professional ensuring his Section were fully prepared for their role in Helmand.  His dedication and loyalty to his men was evident from the moment he took over his Section. Cpl Etchells was an enthusiastic and dedicated individual who loved his job, cared about his men and was the consummate professional.  He will be sorely missed.

ServiceUnit: 4th Battalion, 25th Field Artillery (STRIKE), 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Pfc. Dennis J. Pratt, 34, Duncan, Okla., died Monday in Wardak Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle followed by an attack from enemy forces.
Bio:
å¦   Dennis J. Pratt was a third-generation soldier and 34-year-old father of three who was called "the old man" among comrades in his unit.
å¦   "He had found his niche in life in the military," said his mother, Sinnamon Pratt.
å¦   Dennis Pratt, of Duncan, Okla., was killed July 20 when a roadside bomb exploded near his vehicle in Wardak province, days before he was scheduled to head home for two weeks of down time.
å¦   "Dennis wasn't supposed to be at that place at that time, but he always told us that the Army and serving his country was where he wanted to be," his mother said.
å¦   He had graduated high school in Southington, Conn., and was assigned to Fort Drum, N.Y.
å¦   His calls home to Oklahoma always ended with him saying, "I've got your back. You can sleep in peace," his mother said.
å¦   He is survived by his three children; his wife, Michelle; his parents; and two brothers.
å¦   Duncan residents stood along the road with American flags to honor their hometown hero as his family drove to the funeral at Fort Sill. Lt. Gov. Jari Askins, who attended the services, praised Pratt as "a beloved son" of Duncan.

ServiceUnit: 4th Battalion, 25th Field Artillery (STRIKE), 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Spc. Andrew J. Roughton, 21, Houston, Texas., died Monday in Wardak Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle followed by an attack from enemy forces.
Bio:
å¦   Andrew J. Roughton was known by his friends as "Tuna," and for good reason.
å¦   "Whenever he went to a friend's house, he would leave an unopened can of tuna fish behind, sometimes in a closet, sometimes in a bathroom," said his father, Mark Roughton. "I have no idea why, it was just sort of his signature."
å¦   Roughton, 21, of Houston, died July 20 in Wardak province when a roadside bomb exploded near his vehicle. He was assigned to Fort Drum, N.Y.
å¦   He was an athlete at Spring Woods High School and graduated in 2006 with dreams of proving that a small guard could make it on the college gridiron. But he put that dream aside, left a scholarship at Trinity Valley Community College and joined the Army to support his young wife, Heather, when she became pregnant. Despite a miscarriage, he didn't second-guess the decision, his father said.
å¦   Friends say Roughton always tried to be positive and keep people smiling.
å¦   "If you knew Andrew, he was a cutup," his father said. "If you didn't know Andrew, he'd make you his friend."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, his father and a stepbrother.

IncidentDetails: Spc. Anthony M. Lightfoot, 20, Riverdale, Ga., died Monday in Wardak Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle followed by enemy fire.
Bio:
å¦   Anthony M. Lightfoot could always be spotted glued to a television set, playing video games.
å¦   He beat the Super Mario Bros. game at when he was 4, and from there his passion for gaming, animation and drawing blossomed.
å¦   "Ever since then, you couldn't move him from the TV," said his brother, Steven Lightfoot, 29. "Everything he touched he tried to master, and that was an awesome quality about him."
å¦   Lightfoot, 20, of Riverdale, Ga., died July 20 when a roadside bomb exploded near his vehicle in Wardak province. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Lightfoot was familiar with the military at an early age _ he was born in Germany while his mother, Lyvonne Lightfoot, was stationed there. He grew to love his own role in the army, and a sergeant told his family Anthony was "really loved by his unit."
å¦   "He felt so good about himself and so good about his mission and so good about his life," Steven Lightfoot said. "He was happy and valorous about his service."
å¦   He still wanted to develop a career, though. Anthony Lightfoot's family said he loved to draw and hoped to one day design a video game.
å¦   He is survived by his mother, brother and a sister, Nija.

ServiceUnit: 4th Battalion, 25th Field Artillery (STRIKE), 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Sgt. Gregory Owens Jr., 24, Garland, Texas, died Monday in Wardak Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle, followed by enemy fire.
Bio:
å¦   Gregory Owens Jr. had an attitude of thinking of others first. When his sister had her appendix removed one summer, he kept her company for an entire week.
å¦   And instead of taking his scheduled leave from duty in Afghanistan in July, he swapped shifts with another soldier so that he'd be home in mid-October as a surprise for his father's 50th birthday.
å¦   Owens, 24, of Garland, Texas, died July 20 in Wardak province when his vehicle was hit with a roadside bomb and enemy fire. He was based in Fort Drum, N.Y.
å¦   "He always put others before himself," said his mother, LaDonna Owens. "He made time to spend with other people and to listen to them."
å¦   He was born in Germany during his father's military service and had followed in those footsteps by joining the Army in 2007. He had graduated with honors in 2002 from Hillcrest High School, where he kept a full schedule but still managed to find time to roughhouse with his younger brothers and play sports with them.
å¦   "He did everything to keep my mom busy 24/7: band, Boy Scouts, church," said his sister, Shelena.
å¦   Owens is survived by his parents, sister and younger brothers, Lamar and Jonathan.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment
IncidentDetails: died July 18 at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington of wounds suffered July 10 in Helmand province, Afghanistan, when insurgents attacked his unit using small arms fire
Bio:
å¦   Benjamin S. Kopp's journey into the military was strongly influenced by an interest in his great-grandfather's medals and tales from service during World War II.
å¦   "He took a liking to history, of our country, and had a lot of interest in the stories that he had to tell about where he went and what he did," said his mother, Jill Stephenson.
å¦   Kopp, 21, of Rosemount, Minn., died July 18 of wounds suffered eight days earlier in Helmand province when insurgents attacked his unit. He was assigned to Fort Benning and had served two tours in Iraq.
å¦   He enlisted in 2006, the same year he graduated from Rosemount High School.
å¦   Assistant principal Tom Conboy remembered Kopp as a football player who took on most activities with intensity and a strong work ethic. He wasn't surprised Kopp became an Army Ranger.
å¦   Kopp is survived by his father and mother, who said she's proud of Kopp's service and his decision to be an organ donor.
å¦   Transplant patient Judy Meikle, who received Kopp's heart, says she now has the heart of a bona fide hero.
å¦   Stephenson said Kopp asked to be buried at Arlington National Cemetery.

ServiceUnit: 11 Explosive Ordnance Disposal Regiment, The Royal Logistic Corps
IncidentDetails:
killed as a result of an explosion that happened whilst on patrol in din Nad-e-Ali District in Helmand Province

At the time of his death, Captain Shepherd was commanding IEDD team within the Joint Force EOD who were dealing with a confirmed IED.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Mentoring and Reconstruction Task Force (MRTF-2)
IncidentDetails: The 22-year old died early in the morning while on operations north of Tarin Kowt. He was killed by an improvised explosive device (IED) several hours after 4 Section, 2 Platoon occupied a security position during a cordon and search in the Baluchi Valley

ServiceUnit: 148th Brigade Support Battalion
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Raymundo P. Morales, 34, Dalton, Ga., died Tuesday in Methar Lam, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained during a vehicle roll-over.
Bio:
å¦   Everyone knew Raymundo P. Morales' smile.
å¦   "As soon as you seen him, whether he was down or not, he always had that smile no matter what," said his aunt, Maria Vicencio, adding that the man known as "Ray" had an infectious laugh and sense of humor.
å¦   Morales, 34, of Dalton, Ga., was killed July 21 when the Humvee he was riding in rolled over in Methar Lam. He was assigned to Cedartown, Ga.
å¦   The sergeant graduated from Murray County High School in 1992. He had only been in Afghanistan for about a month, but his family says he was doing what he enjoyed most.
å¦   "He was always trying to help people. He says he loved the Army, that's why he joined," said his uncle, Jorge Vicencio.
å¦   The Georgia National Guardsman planned to be in the military for the rest of his career, said his brother, Tommy Morales.
å¦   "He said, 'Daddy, if I don't who will? You know, who will protect us and our country?' So that's what he did," Morales said.
å¦   Morales is survived by four children, his parents and a brother and sister.

IncidentDetails: killed during de-mining operations
A blast killed a French soldier walking with other troops from their Afghan base to a firing range
injured in an attack in Afghanistan

ServiceUnit: 4th Engineer Battalion
IncidentDetails: The Department of Defense announced today the death of two soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom.  They died July 22 in Zabul Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Joshua J. Rimer read to his new wife every night and took care of her when she was sick. When it snowed, he always drove his mother-in-law to and from work.
å¦   "He is amazing. I mean he was amazing," said his widow, Annalisa. "People just love Joshua."
å¦   Rimer, 24, of Rochester, Pa., was killed July 22 by an improvised explosive in Zabul province. He was a 2003 high school graduate and was assigned to Fort Carson.
å¦   Rimer, who played the trumpet and was in band and chorus, joined the military right after graduation and spent three years in Iraq on his first tour. He received a Purple Heart after receiving shrapnel wounds to the neck.
å¦   "Everyone was saying, 'You got the Purple Heart, you can come home now,'" said Amy Nichols, his cousin. "But he said, 'This is what I do. This is me.'"
å¦   His family said Rimer was a good leader who constantly drilled his men and was respected for his knowledge and loved for his outgoing personality.
å¦   "I remember my brother as being a fun-loving person who had the best personality you'd ever meet," said Shannon Rimer. "He was always the center of attention. That's who Joshua was."

ServiceUnit: 4th Engineer Battalion
IncidentDetails: The Department of Defense announced today the death of two soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom.  They died July 22 in Zabul Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Randy Neff had an ability to put the people around him at ease and make his comrades laugh until their sides ached.
å¦   "He would flash his trademark grin, and everyone around him would feel better," Capt. David Cuthbertson said.
å¦   Neff, 22, of Blackfoot, Idaho, died July 22 when a bomb exploded near his convoy. He was based in Fort Carson, Colo.
å¦   The bomb also killed Sgt. Joshua Rimer. Both Neff and Rimer were combat engineers who helped clear roadside bombs.
å¦   "They chose the only job in the Army that starts with the word 'combat,'" said Lt. Col. Craig Simonsgaard.
å¦   Neff graduated from Blackfoot High School in 2006. Shop teacher Peter Golinveaux said Neff was laid back in high school, but appeared to change after enlisting and the military helped him overcome hardships he faced growing up.
å¦   "He talked to my son a couple of days before he left and said he was excited about going to Afghanistan and serving his time," Golinveaux said.
å¦   Neff is survived by his wife, Madelyn. The couple lived in Colorado Springs, Colo., before Neff was deployed to Afghanistan.
å¦   "He was a strong-hearted kid; he'd be the first one up ready to go," said Neff's friend Spec. Steven Speilbauer.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion Coldstream Guards
IncidentLocation: Nad e Ali District in Helmand province, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: He was serving as a rifleman with Number 2 Company, 1st Battalion Welsh Guards. was working as part of a team responsible for the protection of vehicle patrols. He was on foot clearing a vulnerable point when an Improvised Explosive Device detonated.

ServiceUnit: The Light Dragoons
IncidentDetails: died in an explosion while traveling in a SCIMITAR, or CVR(T), vehicle, part of a patrol in Lashkar Gah district, Helmand province, while helping ensure the security of an area earlier cleared as part of Operation PANCHAI PALANG.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Light Armored Reconnaissance Battalion, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: died July 23 of wounds suffered while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Those who knew Ryan H. Lane said serving his country as a Marine was a dream that went back to his days at high school.
å¦   "His father was in the military, and he followed in his footsteps," said Castle Shannon Mayor Donald Baumgarten. "He loved helping people. He was a great kid."
å¦   Lane's father, Harold, is a recently retired police chief for the borough, and Lane's brother is a local police officer.
å¦   "He was a sweetheart," said Sarah Coffey, a friend.
å¦   Lane, 25, of Castle Shannon, Pa., died July 23 of wounds suffered while supporting combat operations in Helmand province. He was a 2002 high school graduate, an avid Penguin's fan, and was assigned to Camp Lejeune. He was on his second tour.
å¦   "He was a Marine. He had to go back as he couldn't leave his guys. He was a wonderful guy," said family friend and borough police secretary Shirley McMonagle, who knew him since he was a baby.
å¦   "All I can see when I think of him in combat is him being the first one going ahead," she said. "He won all these medals with the Marines, but he never wanted to talk about that or what he was doing over there."
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Valerie.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails:
died July 23 of wounds suffered while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan

Two U.S. troops died in combat in an explosion in southern Afghanistan, according to a U.S. military spokesman Lt. Robert Carr.
Bio:
å¦   Jeremy S. Lasher's father-in-law, Ben Wolcik, said he always felt at peace knowing that a man like Jeremy was taking care of his daughter Andrea and his 1-year-old grandson Caden.
å¦   "He wasn't outspoken," Wolcik said. "He spoke with his actions."
å¦   Lasher, 27, of Oneida, N.Y., was killed July 23 in Helmand province. He was a 2000 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   "He was the kind of guy who would give you the shirt off his back," said Terri Clark, a friend of Lasher's mother.
å¦   "He would do things like walk your dogs in a snowstorm for you. If you needed something done, you could count on Jeremy."
å¦   He was a member of the Verona Fire Department and enjoyed music, golfing, snowmobiling, sketching, skateboarding, rollerblading and gardening.
å¦   "Those of us that had the privilege of knowing Jeremy could tell you how warm his smile was and how much he cared and loved his family and friends," said Fire Department Second Assistant Chief Steve Wright.
å¦   Said Lasher's brother Ryan, also a Marine: "Next time we meet at the gates of heaven, I will salute you and tell you, you are relieved of your post."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails:
died July 23 of wounds suffered while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan

Two U.S. troops died in combat in an explosion in southern Afghanistan, according to a U.S. military spokesman Lt. Robert Carr.
Bio:
å¦   At 6 feet, Nicholas G. Xiarhos was muscular and strong, but gentle at heart. After returning from service in Iraq, he changed battalions so he could be deployed to Afghanistan.
å¦   "He didn't feel comfortable living an easy life," said his mother, Lisa. "He just wanted to fight."
å¦   Xiarhos, 21, of Yarmouth Port, Mass., was killed July 23 in a roadside bombing in Helmand province. He was a 2006 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   Cpl. Matthew Madeux said Xiarhos was "one of the most phenomenal Marines" he ever met. At Camp Lejeune, he was always the first to make sure young Marines minded their manners around women, insisting they use the formal "ma'am."
å¦   Paul Funk, Xiarhos's high school football and baseball coach, remembered him as a motivated, selfless player. "I know he was doing something that he really believed in," he said.
å¦   Rebecca M. Barbo, a close friends, remembered their drives around the Cape blasting classic rock. She said his peers voted to present him the "Does Most For Others" title their senior year.
å¦   "It was a no-brainer," she said.
å¦   He also is survived by his father, Steven.

ServiceUnit: 40th Regiment Royal Artillery (The Lowland Gunners)
IncidentDetails: Hopson was killed when the Jackal vehicle in which he was travelling struck an improvised explosive device while taking part in Operation PANCHAI PALANG. He was part of a patrol in the Babaji area of Helmand province.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: died July 24 in Nuristan Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his unit using small arms and rocket-propelled grenade fires.
Bio:
å¦   Justin D. Coleman's interests were anything but narrow _ the Army specialist took courses in criminal justice, nursing and robotics in high school. And he loved playing video games like Halo 2.
å¦   His mother-in-law, Rosellen Jenkins, remembered him as a "smart kid" who took online courses in the military and was even certified as an ordained minister. More than anything, though, Jenkins remembers the love he had for his wife, Nicole.
å¦   "He was really respectful and has always been great," Jenkins said. Nicole agreed he was devoted.
å¦   "I'd say if we had kids, he would've made a great father," Nicole Coleman said.
å¦   Coleman, 21, of Weeki Wachee, Fla., was killed July 24 when his unit was attacked in Nuristan province. He was assigned to Fort Drum, N.Y. He enlisted right after he graduated from Nature Coast Technical High School in 2007.
å¦   Nicole Coleman said her husband often had shy, tender moments around her _ particularly before they started dating, when he penned a romantic blog on his MySpace page. He was too shy to read it to her, though, and she didn't find out about it until a year after they married.
å¦   "See that?" she told him. "You really do like me."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: died July 25 of wounds sustained while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan
Bio:
å¦   Donald W. Vincent _ better known by his middle name, Wayne _ had to work a few odd jobs before everything really fell into place.
å¦   "Wayne found he needed to get his life in focus," said his father, Lee Vincent, a retired U.S. Navy Captain. "The Marines was a means to an end ... he discovered abilities he didn't know he had."
å¦   Vincent, 26, of Gainesville, Fla., died July 25 after being wounded in combat in Helmand province. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   Family and friends recalled that Vincent's experiences in the Marines gave him a different perspective on life, and that his skills in math and other areas developed with his training. He had worked as an electrician and at a couple of restaurants before deciding to join the military.
å¦   "The Marines helped him discover his confidence," said friend Ian Walters.
å¦   Vincent, who loved to hunt, fish and scallop, was the oldest Marine in his unit, earning him the nickname "the old man," said his mother, Betty Sue Vincent.
å¦   "He touched a lot of hearts," Lee Vincent said. "People really loved him and they're broken-hearted with us."

ServiceUnit: 5th Regiment Royal Artillery
IncidentDetails: was killed as a result of an explosion whilst conducting a foot patrol in Sangin district, Helmand province. He was serving as second-in-command of Sangin's Police Mentoring Team.

ServiceUnit: Navy Expeditionary Guard Battalion
IncidentDetails: died July 23 at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami, Fla., from a non-combat related illness incurred while assigned to the Navy Expeditionary Guard Battalion, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
Bio:
å¦   Navy Petty Officer 1st Class Dennis True was a roommate of Andrew Scott Charpentier's and saw a different side of the guy known as "Charpy."
å¦   "He was very deep, and very quiet. I remember one Saturday morning, sitting out on the back patio having a conversation about religion and politics _ two subjects I don't do well with. I was shocked to hear how deep and insightful this young man was, something I never expected from a 21-year-old man," True said.
å¦   Charpentier, 21, of Great Falls, Mont., died July 23, 2009, at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami from a non-combat related illness. He was a 2007 high school graduate and was assigned to Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
å¦   His duty in Cuba was to guard prison detainees. "He was the go-to guy, not just by reputation, but by word of mouth," said Navy Cmdr. Michael Fulgham.
å¦   A self-taught guitarist, he was a member of his high-school debate team, played basketball, football, wrestling and track, and was a staff photographer and writer for his high school newspaper.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Kathleen.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine Lance Cpl. Gregory A. Posey, 22, Knoxville, Tenn., died Thursday of wounds suffered while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Sylvia James, remembered a bright-eyed, curly-haired boy who would come to her house whenever she baked.
å¦   "He was always looking for cookies; he was never bashful," she said of Gregory A. Posey with a soft smile.
å¦   Posey, 22, of Knoxville, Tenn., was killed July 30, 2009, while supporting combat operations in Helmand province. He was a 2005 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   Casey Bolin, Posey's high school girlfriend, remembered him as "a bright spirit who lit up the room."
å¦   She said Posey wanted to become a Marine for a long time. He left the University of Tennessee at Knoxville to enlist in 2007.
å¦   The two had e-mailed each other in June, and she said he was excited to be serving overseas. "He wouldn't want to be anywhere else," Bolin said.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Steven and Delma.
å¦   Red Roberts, retired principal of Franklin County High School, smiled as he remembered the time Greg dressed up as the school's mascot, a "Rebel," and showed up at a school board meeting where some wanted to change the mascot.
å¦   The mascot is still the Rebel.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 130th Infantry, Illinois Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: Army Pvt. Gerrick D. Smith, 19, Sullivan, Ill., died Wednesday in Herat, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered in a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
å¦   Gerrick D. Smith knew even before he graduated from high school in 2008 that he wanted to be in the military. He joined the Illinois Army National Guard in his junior year.
å¦   "If you needed someone to have your back, Gerrick was that guy," longtime friend and fellow soldier Tyler Craven said. "He would stand up with you to the bitter end."
å¦   Smith, 19, of Sullivan, Ill., died July 29 of a noncombat-related injury in Herat. His death is under investigation.
å¦   He was based in Marion, Ill. It was the first deployment for the former football and soccer player and choir singer from Sullivan High School.
å¦   Friends described him as an energetic performer who tried to make people laugh by occasionally goofing off _ even once putting on a girl's dress _ and occasionally drew tattoos on friends during study hall.
å¦   Sullivan police chief John Love said he saw a change when Smith returned to town with a deep pride about serving his country.
å¦   "He left here as a kid and came back as a soldier," Love said.
å¦   Smith is survived by his parents, Marilyn Smith and David Jones, a sister and a half-brother.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 10th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Army Chief Warrant Officer Douglas M. Vose III, 38, Concrete, Wash., died Wednesday in Kabul Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his unit using small arms fire.
Bio:
å¦   Doug Vose was described as a courageous Green Beret who was both confident on the battlefield and relaxed while enjoying a glass of fine red wine.
å¦   "That's what made Doug so unique," said Dave Takaki, a retired master sergeant who served with Vose.
å¦   Vose, 38, of Concrete, Wash., was based in Stuttgart, Germany. He spoke fluent German.
å¦   He was killed July 29 after insurgents attacked his unit in Kabul.
å¦   Vose is survived by his wife, Nicole, two sons, two daughters and mother, Paulette.
å¦   His late father was a Marine who instilled a strong work ethic in him, said Vicki Frank, the mother of a one of Vose's best friends.
å¦   "He was the best citizen and had the sweetest temperament," she said.
å¦   As a youth, Vose would split wood each day with his brother. Then, he would work a shift at Red Apple, a local market, Frank said.
å¦   After graduating from high school in 1988, Vose joined the Army. A decade later, he joined the Special Forces, and began rising through the ranks.
å¦   "The whole family is military, and that's all Doug wanted to do," Frank said. "He was a soldier first."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Combat Engineer Battalion, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine Lance Cpl. Jonathan F. Stroud, 20, Cashion, Okla., died Thursday of wounds suffered while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Jonathan F. Stroud was remembered as funny and upbeat. He made a special request that a particular song to be played at his memorial service.
å¦   "It's probably not what you would expect," said his friend Corey Travis at his funeral.
å¦   Mourners then chuckled as Queen's "Another One Bites the Dust" played.
å¦   Stroud, 20, of Cashion, Okla., was killed during a gun battle July 30, 2009, in Helmand province. He was a 2007 high school graduate and was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   "Jonathan had way above-average intelligence, in fact school kind of moved too slow for him," said Scott Anderson, his former teacher. "Jonathan was a perpetually happy kid."
å¦   In Stroud's 2007 yearbook, he was named "Most likely to smell of green beans."
å¦   "He probably came up with that all by himself. That's how he was, a very unique kid, but still very funny," Marva Oard, his high school superintendent.
å¦   Stroud and his wife, Lacie, whom he married last year, were expecting their first child, a daughter.
å¦   Sam Boyd, the best man in his wedding, said Stroud would have made a great dad. "Because of the way he treated his wife," he said. "Everything he did he did for her. He was ready to be a father."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 12th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 1 in Mushan Village, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained when insurgents attacked their patrol with improvised explosive devices and rocket-propelled grenades.
Bio:
å¦   As a kid, Jonathan Walls spent a lot of time playing "shoot-em-up" video games.
å¦   As it turned out, it was good training for his military career, said his father, Steven.
å¦   Walls, 27, of West Lawn, Pa., was once assigned to maneuver the high-tech armored combat vehicle called the Stryker, which has sophisticated sensors and communications systems.
å¦   "He loved it," Steven Walls told the Reading Eagle. "He said, 'Dad, it's just like the video games.'"
å¦   Walls was one of three Army soldiers killed Aug. 1 when their patrol was attacked with explosives in Mushan Village, Afghanistan. All were assigned to Fort Carson, Colo.
å¦   Walls, a 2001 graduate of Wilson High School, wanted to do work that helped people. Beyond his military work, becoming a family man allowed him to do that, his father said. he left behind a wife, Meghan; son, Hayden; and daughters, Lily and Allahna.
å¦   "He was a good dad, a good son, a good soldier and a good man," his father said.
å¦   "His kids were his life. He lived for them."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 12th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 1 in Mushan Village, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained when insurgents attacked their patrol with improvised explosive devices and rocket-propelled grenades.
Bio:
å¦   Richie Jones loved exploring outside and playing Army as a child. Or as his grandmother put it, "just being a typical roughneck little boy."
å¦   Even as an adult, though, Jones obeyed grandma.
å¦   Jones' grandmother, Peggy Bowling, told the aspiring soldier to go to school a bit longer before he joined the military. Jones said he'd keep learning about diesel engines at a school for auto mechanics, but there was a catch. If Jones decided that wasn't for him, grandma had to give her blessing so he could join the military.
å¦   Eventually, that love for exploring got the best of him. Bowling gave her blessing, and said she doesn't regret it at all.
å¦   "No sir, because that was his dream," Bowling said. "That's what he wanted to do."
å¦   Jones, 21, of Person, N.C., was killed Aug. 1 in Mushan Village when insurgents attacked his patrol.
å¦   He was an energetic man who would sneak in a call to his mom from boot camp and Afghanistan, even when he wasn't allowed.
å¦   He is survived by his mother, Franceen Jones; father, Richard Jones; his grandparents; and two sisters, Tanna Jones Lee and Kaitlyn Jones.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 12th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 1 in Mushan Village, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained when insurgents attacked their patrol with improvised explosive devices and rocket-propelled grenades.
Bio:
å¦   Patrick S. Fitzgibbon was a blossoming filmmaker who loved making short, goofy videos and posting them on the Internet.
å¦   "We shot this stupid music video to the song '99 Red Balloons,'" said his cousin Steven Fitzgibbon. "We blew up 99 red balloons and stuck them in the shower and started dancing with masks on. Patrick popped out of the shower. He would do anything to make you laugh, no matter how crazy."
å¦   Irreverence and humor was how he dealt with most things, including his parents' divorce, his family said.
å¦   "If you were laughing, it was because of Patrick," said his brother, John Fitzgibbon.
å¦   Patrick Fitzgibbon, 19, of Knoxville, Tenn., was killed Aug. 1 when insurgents attacked his patrol in Mushan Village.
å¦   Fitzgibbon dropped out of South Doyle High School, deciding he'd pursue a GED instead.
å¦   "Patrick was a very energetic young man, and kind of ... sometimes we'd say a little rebel," said 1st Sgt. Calvin Hartwell, a JROTC instructor at the school.
å¦   However, Hartwell said all that changed when Fitzgibbon joined the military in December. Just before the teen deployed in March, Hartwell said he saw the young man he'll remember: a clean-cut, focused soldier.
å¦   Fitzgibbon is survived by his fiancee, parents, four brothers and a sister.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 20th Special Forces Group (Airborne), Jackson, Miss.
IncidentDetails: The death of three soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom. They died from wounds suffered when insurgents attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device Aug. 2 in Qole Gerdsar, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   One of Ronald G. "Ron" Luce Jr.'s fellow soldiers remembers clearly how the Army captain fought on a pogo stick during infantry officer training: like "an animal in the ring."
å¦   "You were no doubt the toughest guy there," Aaron Flint, of Missoula, Mont., wrote in an online bulletin board.
å¦   "But outside the ring, you continued to serve with humility. You're the type of guy the rest of us Infantry officers look up to."
å¦   Luce, 27, of Fayetteville, N.C., was killed Aug. 2 by a roadside bomb in Qole Gerdsar.
å¦   Luce was born in Julian, Calif., and became a commissioned officer in 2002 after enrolling in the Reserve Officers' Training Corps at Valley Forge Military Academy. He also received a bachelor's degree in biology from Belmont University in Nashville, Tenn.
å¦   He graduated from the Special Forces Qualification Course in 2008 and was assigned to Jackson, Miss.
å¦   Luce is survived by his wife, Kendahl; his daughter, Carie; and his parents, Ronald and Katherine Luce.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 20th Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: The death of three soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom. They died from wounds suffered when insurgents attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device Aug. 2 in Qole Gerdsar, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Alejandro "Alex" Granado was a serious soldier, but once the uniform came off, his family said he was all smiles.
å¦   "He was ... always looking out for everybody, a real kind man," said his brother, Rolando Granado. "He was easy to get along with and real energetic. He took his job serious, but when he came home, he joked and laughed with people he knew and was always playing around."
å¦   Alex Granado, 42, of Tatum, Texas, was killed Aug. 2 by a roadside bomb in Qole Gerdsar. He was assigned to Jackson, Miss.
å¦   Granado was married with a child on the way at age 18, and joined the military after graduating from Tatum High School in 1986 to provide for his new family.
å¦   He was a track star in high school, and one friend said his dedication was an inspiration.
å¦   "I used to watch him run around that track at school for hours," Jimmy Jackson, of Joaquin, Texas, wrote in an online bulletin board. He was in Granado's graduating class.
å¦   "It always made me practice harder and do more."
å¦   Granado was in the military for 23 years, serving in Operation Desert Storm.
å¦   Granado is survived by his parents, two sons, a daughter, two grandchildren, two brothers and three sisters.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 20th Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: The death of three soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom. They died from wounds suffered when insurgents attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device Aug. 2 in Qole Gerdsar, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Severin W. Summers loved entertaining people, especially children _ a trait that served "Sev" well during his second tour of duty in Afghanistan.
å¦   "He was everybody's favorite uncle," said his father, Severin Summers II.
å¦   The younger Summers was an outdoorsman who loved to hunt, fish and explore in the woods.
å¦   "I will never forget our canoe trip in the tornado," Rob Savage of Phoenix wrote in an online bulletin board. "He was a darn keen woodsman."
å¦   Summers, 43, of Bentonia, Miss., was killed Aug. 2 by a roadside bomb in Qole Gerdsar. The Mississippi National Guardsman graduated from Christian Life Academy in 1984 and attended Louisiana State University. He was in the military for 20 years.
å¦   Many remembered his sense of humor and ability to make people laugh.
å¦   "His corny Arnold Schwarzenegger impressions always made me crack up," Michael Stampley wrote on an online bulletin board.
å¦   Another friend remembered Summers' days cutting up in high school classes.
å¦   "We were on the teacher's bad boys list pretty much every day," Scott Bice wrote online.
å¦   Summers is survived by his wife, Tammy; parents, Severin and Charlene Summers; and three daughters, Jessica, Shelby and Sara.

IncidentDetails: A French soldier was killed and two others were wounded during a clash with insurgents north of Kabul, the French military said in a statement.

ServiceUnit: 5e RÌ©giment du gÌ©nie de combat serving as a member of the 2nd Battalion, Royal 22e RÌ©giment Battle Group
IncidentLocation: Zhari District, west of Kandahar City, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: Two Canadian soldiers were killed and one injured when an improvised explosive device detonated near a patrol in the Zhari District. The incident occurred approximately 15 kilometres west of Kandahar City on August 1.

ServiceUnit: 5e RÌ©giment du gÌ©nie de combat serving as a member of the 2nd Battalion, Royal 22e RÌ©giment Battle Group
IncidentLocation: Zhari District, west of Kandahar City, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: Two Canadian soldiers were killed and one injured when an improvised explosive device detonated near a patrol in the Zhari District. The incident occurred approximately 15 kilometres west of Kandahar City on August 1.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: died July 31 in Nuristan Province, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his unit with rocket-propelled grenades and small-arms fire.
Bio:
å¦   Alexander J. Miller's loved ones remembered him as a man with an "angel-boy face" who showed people what it meant to have a good time.
å¦   "You never had to worry about being down around that boy," said Earl Shaver, 45, a youth roller hockey coach who eulogized Miller. "He'd always lift you up."
å¦   Miller, 21, of Clermont, Fla., died July 31 in Nuristan province after his unit was attacked by insurgents. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   "I can never remember him not smiling," said Kathleen Pickard, who knew Miller through her daughters. "He had a beautiful, angel-boy face."
å¦   His mother and stepfather said he loved playing sports, and was on the football and baseball teams at South Lake High School. He had hoped to attend the University of Central Florida after finishing his Army service.
å¦   "Any challenge you put in front of him, he would give it his all," said his stepfather, Rob Nadon.
å¦   He accomplished his biggest dream, though _ being in the military.
å¦   "This is what he wanted to do his whole life," said his mother, Sue Miller. "He wanted to serve his country."
å¦   He is also survived by a brother, Richard Miller of Clermont; and two half-brothers, John Miller of California and Jason Grove of Tennessee.

ServiceUnit: Emsdorf Troop, a CVR (Tracked) group from The Light Dragoons serving with A Company, 2nd Battalion The Mercian Regiment
IncidentLocation: Babaji, in the Lashkar Gah district of Helmand province
IncidentDetails: was killed in Babaji, in the Lashkar Gah district of Helmand province. He was driving a CVR(T) Spartan as part of an escort for a Viking supply convoy, moving between the company's two locations when the vehicle was hit by an explosion

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 3rd Marine Regiment, 3rd Marine Division, III Marine Expeditionary Force
ServiceUnitLocation: Marine Corps Base Hawaii, Kaneohe Bay
IncidentDetails: Marine Sgt. Jay M. Hoskins, 24, Paris, Texas, died Thursday while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Jay M. Hoskins was a believer _ in hard work, in God, and in the mission he was serving overseas.
å¦   "Jay Hoskins believed in what he was doing," the Rev. Chris Kelley said at Hoskins' memorial. "He believed in freedom. Not just for those within the boundaries of the United States but for everyone one in the world. And that freedom comes at a cost."
å¦   Hoskins, 24, of Paris, Texas, died Aug. 6 of wounds from a roadside bomb in Farah province. He was based out of Marine Corps Base Hawaii in Kaneohe Bay.
å¦   He graduated in May 2003 from North Lamar High School and joined the Marine Corps that August. He had deployed to Iraq in 2004 and to Afghanistan in 2005 and reported to Hawaii in January.
å¦   He was athletic, and as a high school football player, he was named All Red River Valley. He also was a Marine mixed martial arts black belt instructor.
å¦   His family says he learned his Christian faith from his grandmother and grandfather, the former pastor of the church where his funeral was held.
å¦   Hoskins is survived by his wife, Chandler, who is expecting their second child in January; his son, Tristen; his parents; and five siblings and step-siblings.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Combat Assault Battalion, 3rd Marine Division, III Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine Lance Cpl. Travis T. Babine, 20, San Antonio, Texas, died Thursday while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Christian A. Guzman Rivera, who piled on 35 pounds of muscle onto his once-wiry frame after joining the military, knew what brotherhood meant and had it tattooed on his chest: "Death Before Dishonor."
å¦   Guzman loved the system: work hard, earn more respect as you move up the ranks, said his 18-year-old brother, Jonathan Guzman. The only thing he loved more than the military?
å¦   Shoes. Lots and lots of top-of-the-line sneakers _ he had to have the latest Jordans, Dunks and others.
å¦   "It was his obsession," said his mother Velma Torres.
å¦   Guzman, 21, of Homestead, Fla., was killed Aug. 6 when his Humvee hit a roadside bomb in Farah province. He had been stationed in Okinawa, Japan.
å¦   There was a two-year wait for his dream _ becoming a firefighter _ so he decided joining the Marines would be a good way to get an adrenaline rush. He had hoped to specialize as a firefighter and earn a position with Miami-Dade Fire Rescue when he left the service.
å¦   He worked hard, working his way up to corporal in just 17 months. Guzman always expressed himself when he wasn't wearing those drab uniforms, donning bright red and blue in his free time.
å¦   Guzman is survived by his mother, his father, Felix, and his brother.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 3rd Marine Regiment, 3rd Marine Division, III Marine Expeditionary Force
ServiceUnitLocation: Marine Corps Base Hawaii, Kaneohe Bay
IncidentDetails: Marine Lance Cpl. Travis T. Babine, 20, San Antonio, Texas, died Thursday while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Travis T. Babine had tight ties to battles and heroism long before he joined the Marine Corps. He was named after Alamo commander William Barret Travis and, as a youngster, often pretended to be action heroes.
å¦   His mother, Alice Babine, told mourners at his funeral that her favorite was his portrayal of Batman. Playing those roles helped him find his place in the world, she said.
å¦   Travis Babine, 20, of San Antonio, died Aug. 6 of wounds from a roadside bomb in Farah province. Three weeks earlier, his family had been celebrating because he and several others survived a similar explosion in the same area.
å¦   He joined the Marine Corps immediately after graduating from Castle Hills First Baptist School in 2007 and chose to pursue infantry service. He was based in Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii.
å¦   His family describes him as a gentle and generous man and a devout Christian who tried to get consecrated bread sent overseas so he could have Communion with his friends.
å¦   "They respected him for his goodness and dedication to duty," said his father, Bill Badger.
å¦   Babine is survived by his parents, his stepmother and his sisters.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 3rd Marine Regiment, 3rd Marine Division, III Marine Expeditionary Force
ServiceUnitLocation: Marine Corps Base Hawaii, Kaneohe Bay
IncidentDetails: Marine Lance Cpl. James D. Argentine, 22, Farmingdale, N.Y., died Thursday while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   James Argentine gave serious thought to joining the military on his first day of high school.
å¦   It was Sept. 11, 2001. The parents of nine of his classmates died in the attack on the World Trade Center towers.
å¦   Some of his friends tried to change his mind about joining, but he did anyway, out of a sense of duty, said a friend, Andrew Carr.
å¦   "We were upset," Carr said. "We talked to him about it. He was pretty set in his ways." Argentine, 22, of Farmingdale, N.Y., graduated from St. Anthony's High School, on Long Island, in 2005. He joined the Marines after attending the State University of New York at Oneonta for a year.
å¦   Argentine was killed Aug. 6 during combat operations in Farah province in Afghanistan. He was assigned to the Marine Corps Base Hawaii, Kaneohe Bay.
å¦   Argentine was engaged to Crystal Saarie. He also is survived by his parents, Jan and Robert. In high school, Argentine helped assemble lights and sets for school performances as a member of the state crew.
å¦   "It's a thankless job," Principal Brother Gary Cregan said. "You're always behind the scenes, ensuring that other people's lighting and staging are perfect. It was a testament to his willingness to be of service in a quiet, gentle way."

IncidentDetails: Navy Petty Officer 3rd Class Anthony C. Garcia, 21, Tyndall, Fla., died Wednesday while supporting combat operations in Farah Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Anthony C. Garcia's hope of becoming a Navy SEAL was dashed, but it turns out being a medic tending to injured Marines in the field was an even better fit.
å¦   "We're combat medics. We take care of Marines," said Garcia's friend, Nicholas Cooper. They protect us, and when they need us, we go in."
å¦   Cooper said that there are two things a Marine will ask for in the field _ "God and the doc" _ and that Garcia loved being "the doc."
å¦   "He was a hero among heroes," Cooper said.
å¦   Garcia, 21, of Tyndall, Fla., died supporting combat operations Aug. 5 in Farah Province. He was assigned to Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii.
å¦   Cooper enlisted with Garcia, a self-described "Air Force brat" who moved around a lot and took Cooper under his wing in school.
å¦   "Things would have been rough for me in school," Cooper said. "He was the first person that befriended me. He took the time to show me around and helped me out."
å¦   Garcia last logged on to his MySpace account Aug. 4, his headline reading "turn that frown upside down."
å¦   "He had a great sense of humor. He liked to joke around," said Patrick Horgan, a fellow corpsman who worked with Garcia.
å¦   Garcia is survived by his wife, Jewell, his parents, and five siblings.

ServiceUnit: Marine Aircraft Group 36, 1st Marine Aircraft Wing, III Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine Capt. Matthew C. Freeman, 29, Richmond Hill, Ga., died Friday while supporting combat operations in Kapisa province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   The last time Matthew C. Freeman spoke to his mother, he asked her to send lots and lots of pens and pencils.
å¦   Freeman's childhood friend, Air Force officer Bryan Lewis, recalled the exchange as told to him by Freeman's mother, Lisa: "They didn't care about food and water, they just wanted to learn to read and write. 'Send as much as you can,' Freeman said. 'I want to give them this.'"
å¦   Freeman, 29, of Richmond Hill, Ga., was killed Aug. 7 in Kapisa province. The Naval Academy graduate was stationed in Okinawa, Japan.
å¦   The Marine had deployed to Afghanistan just two weeks before, and married his high school sweetheart, Theresa Hess, just 13 days before leaving.
å¦   His friends recalled that he had vivid enthusiasm for everything he did, whether being an Eagle Scout, honor roll student, student council president or tennis player.
å¦   Freeman also knew how to cut up _ ex-Richmond Hill High School tennis coach Pat Puruso remembered when he was competing in the regional final doubles match, and Freeman's partner couldn't keep his serves in bounds.
å¦   When a few chats didn't work, Freeman decided to take a lighter approach: He sent both his serves sailing over the fence and into the woods.
å¦   "They laughed so hard that they lost the game but rallied to win the set and the match," Puruso said.

ServiceUnit: Parachute Regiment
IncidentDetails: killed while undertaking a routine security patrol alongside Afghan National Security Forces to the north of Lashkar Gah when the Jackal vehicle they were travelling in was hit by an explosion, followed by a small arms fire attack.

ServiceUnit: Parachute Regiment
IncidentDetails: killed while undertaking a routine security patrol alongside Afghan National Security Forces to the north of Lashkar Gah when the Jackal vehicle they were travelling in was hit by an explosion, followed by a small arms fire attack.

ServiceUnit: The Parachute Regiment
IncidentDetails: killed while undertaking a routine security patrol alongside Afghan National Security Forces to the north of Lashkar Gah when the Jackal vehicle they were travelling in was hit by an explosion, followed by a small arms fire attack

ServiceUnit: 50th Signal Battalion, 35th Signal Brigade, XVIII Airborne Corps
IncidentDetails: Army Staff Sgt. Tara J. Smith, 33, Nashville, N.C., died Saturday in Bagram, Afghanistan, from a non-combat related incident that occurred Tuesday at Camp Phoenix, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   From the time Tara J. Smith was a child, she was energetic as a wasp: "She'd sting, hit you and keep going," recalled her brother, Earl Coley.
å¦   Friends and family remembered that energy as key to her ability to juggled so many roles _ sergeant, wife, mother. And she always made sure her sons, 6-year-old Jordan and 8-year-old David, were taken care of.
å¦   "Her kids were her No. 1 priority," said Sgt. 1st Class Yolonda Chaney, who served with Smith.
å¦   Smith died Aug. 8 at Bagram Air Base of a noncombat-related medical condition. She had complained of fatigue a few days earlier, and was taken to a clinic at the airfield after being told to rest.
å¦   Chaney also said Smith's appearance and work were impeccable.
å¦   "She was always squared away," Chaney said. "It was always everyone else before her."
å¦   Smith enlisted in 1997 and was assigned to Fort Bragg. She deployed to Camp Phoenix outside Kabul in January, and had previously served overseas in Kuwait and South Korea.
å¦   She was not only an outstanding leader, but also "a bright and charming young woman who will be missed by all," said her battalion commander, Lt. Col. Brian Foley.
å¦   She is survived by her husband, Army Sgt. Deron Smith; her sons; her mother; and a sister and brother.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Brigade Special Troops Battalion, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Matthew K.S. Swanson, 20, Lake Forest, Calif., died Saturday at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., of injuries sustained during a vehicle roll-over July 19 in Logar Province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Matthew Swanson was a beloved brother who once brought home a flower he picked on an Afghanistan mountain for his older sister.
å¦   "Over the past 20 years I don't think he has ever given me such a beautiful gift," said his sister, Traci. "It gave me validation that he was thinking of me while he was out there."
å¦   Swanson, 20, of Lake Forest, Calif., died Aug. 8 at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md. He had suffered injuries in a vehicle roll-over July 19 in Logar province. He was based at Fort Drum, N.Y.
å¦   Swanson joined the Army in October 2007.
å¦   "Matthew was a solider, a hero, a friend, a brother," his sister said. "His charisma, bravery, passion will always be remembered."
å¦   His closest friends said at his service that they also fondly would remember his pranks and the music he played on his guitar.
å¦   He is survived by his parents and sister.
å¦   "He always wanted a job where he was making a difference," Swanson's father, Jeff Swanson, said. "He's a hero in more ways than one."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Army Sgt. Jerry R. Evans Jr., 23, Eufaula, Ala., died Friday in Wardak Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Jerry R. Evans Jr. _ better known as "Lil Jerry" _ was an "all-American boy" who loved to hunt and fish.
å¦   "Jerry was an all-American boy as well as a true patriot," Braxton McLain of Eufaula, Ala., wrote in an online message board.
å¦   Eufaula Mayor Jay Jaxon called Evans "an outstanding young man."
å¦   Evans, 23, of Eufaula was killed by a roadside bomb Aug. 7 in Wardak province. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Rep. Billy Beasley also read a resolution commending Sgt. Evans at the soldier's funeral, calling him a "brave Alabamian and a brave soldier who gave his life so that we may have freedom in this great country."
å¦   Evans was born in Florida but spent most of his life in Alabama, moving to Eufaula in 1989. He also was a member of the White Oak Shores Volunteer Fire Department.
å¦   He is survived by a son, Landon; his parents, Jerry and Martha; a brother, John Rogers; and two sisters, Crystal and Brittany.
å¦   "Lil Jerry don't want us to stop living our lives he wants us to move on ... but have a beer for him and keep him in our hearts," his sister Brittany wrote on her MySpace page.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine Lance Cpl. Dennis J. Burrow, 23, Naples, Fla., died Friday while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Dennis J. Burrow's family remembered many of the funny situations he ended up in _ whether as a rambunctious 15-month-old who managed to wedge himself in a laundry chute or as a man who was wound up in plastic wrap after a night at a bar.
å¦   He always kept busy as a boy, whether it was swimming or participating in Boy Scouts or just picking on his little sister, Megan. But more than that, he was a dedicated Marine who always found time for his family.
å¦   Burrow, 23, of Naples, Fla., drove home from Camp Lejeune many weekends to visit his mother, and made time to call from Afghanistan and make sure she and his brother, Army Spc. Chris Burrow, were safe. He was killed by a roadside bomb in Helmand province the next day, Aug. 7.
å¦   "He was a very warm, loving kid, bright but impulsive," said his mother, Daryl. "I just feel his spirit with me all the time."
å¦   Burrow graduated in 2004 from Magruder High School in Rockville, Md., then fled the frosty winters to be a bartender in Florida. Then in 2006, Dennis fulfilled his childhood dream and joined the Marines.
å¦   He is survived by his father, R. Morgan Burrow, and his mother, brother and sister.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Marine Lance Cpl. Javier Olvera, 20, Palmdale, Calif. died Saturday while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   When he joined the marines, Javier Olvera said he wanted to make his mother proud and give back to his parents' adopted country.
å¦   "He found himself in the Marines," said his mother, Martha Olvera, a native of Mexico. "After the Marines, all the time he was happy, enjoying life."
å¦   Olvera, 20, of Palmdale, Calif., died Aug 8. He was killed in combat in Helmand province. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   A message posted on his MySpace page simply stated, "I went to Afghanistan ... I'll see you guys later."
å¦   "You know, I really feel like it's not possible," Martha Olvera said of her son's death. "I was thinking at that same moment, my son gave his life for this country."
å¦   The middle son in a family with three boys, Olvera planned to go to the police academy when his tour in Afghanistan ended in December. While he set his sights on a new career, he also encouraged his 14-year-old brother to do well in school and go to college.
å¦   Two days before he died, Olvera called to tell his mother he loved her.
å¦   "He was a good son," she said.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Lance Cpl. Patrick W. Schimmel, 21, Winfield, Mo., died Sunday while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Patrick W. Schimmel was a collector of knives and swords, a Boy Scout who had a thing for weapons, so it's perhaps no surprise he joined the Marine Corps in 2006 and became a rifleman.
å¦   "The first time he shot a .50-caliber machine gun, he was ecstatic," said his father, Wayne Schimmel.
å¦   Patrick Schimmel, 21, of Winfield, Mo., died Aug. 9 from injuries suffered in combat operations in Helmand province.
å¦   His family said the 2006 Winfield High School graduate and cross country runner was a shy guy with a frame so lean and wiry that military recruiters had him bulk up by eating fast food so he'd meet weight standards. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune and also had been deployed to Iraq from October 2007 to May 2008.
å¦   His older brother, Matthew, said Schimmel drove combat vehicles and translated Arabic.
å¦   The person he became as a Marine was a contrast to his high school persona as a spike-haired kid who typically wore baggy, black jeans and T-shirts, his family said.
å¦   "Everyone says he was a man, a warrior, but I still picture him as my little boy," said his mother, Mary Jean Schimmel.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Mercian Regiment
IncidentLocation: east of Gereshk in Helmand province, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: was killed following an explosion while on patrol just east of Gereshk in Helmand province on Saturday afternoon.

ServiceUnit: Operational Mentor and Liaison Team (OMLT),  1st Air Cavalry Battalion in Leznica Wielka
IncidentDetails: Captain Ambroziãski died of a gunshot wound on 10th August during the operation code-named ‰ÛÏOver the Top‰Û in Ajiristan district of Ghazni province. Polish and Afghani foot patrol was attacked by a group of Taliban. Was found next day after search.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: died Monday while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan
Bio:
å¦   More than anything, Bruce "Bubba" Ferrell's mom will miss her son's smile and hearing him say "I love you."
å¦   "He was goofy," Pam Ferrell said of her son. "He was a free spirit and was true to the Marines."
å¦   Ferrell, 21, of Perdido, Ala., was killed Aug. 9 when he stepped on a roadside bomb during a foot patrol in Kandahar. The 2006 graduate of Baldwin County High School in Bay Minette was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   "I told Bubba that he'd probably done more in his short lifetime than I'd ever do in my whole lifetime," said his father, Bruce Ferrell Sr. "That's some kind of comfort."
å¦   Pam Ferrell said her son was kind-hearted and "would do anything for anyone, and I'm not saying that because he's my son. Just ask anyone."
å¦   Bubba Ferrell's family hadn't spoken to him since he left in May for a seven-month deployment. Then, the day before he died, he finally called.
å¦   "We got to talk to him for 10 or 15 minutes, and we feel very lucky about that," the Marine's father said.
å¦   Ferrell is survived by his parents and two teenage siblings. A sister, Danielle Whatley, died in a car crash in 2006.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 12 in Kunar Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   John Tinsley and his buddy used to hang out on the back deck of their fraternity house, the two martial arts lovers teaching each other different moves.
å¦   "Some people thought he was a little rough around the edges," said Jason White, who was in the Chi Phi fraternity with Tinsley at Florida State University. "But once you got to know him, he was one of the best guys you could ever be around. He cared for all of the brothers."
å¦   Tinsley 28, of Tallahassee, Fla., was killed by a roadside bomb Aug. 12 in Oruzgan province. He was a Green Beret assigned to Fort Bragg. He was in FSU's ROTC program before becoming a full-time soldier.
å¦   A former teacher said he was also a serious student who never backed down from doing what was morally correct.
å¦   "He always went against the flow," said said Margie Duplantis, who taught Tinsley religion at Vandebilt High School in Houma, La., and worked with him in the campus ministry.
å¦   "If someone was doing something wrong and they wanted him to be a part of it, he wouldn't be a part of it. Even if it meant him standing up alone."
å¦   Tinsley is survived by his wife, Emily; daughter, Isabella; and parents, Debra and John Tinsley.

ServiceUnit: 4th Civil Affairs Group, Marine Forces Reserve
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 13 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   William "Bill" Cahir was covering Washington politicians for a newspaper in his native Pennsylvania, but decided after the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks he needed to do something else.
å¦   "He was in his mid-30s, only days away from being ineligible _ too old _ to sign up for the Marine Corps, and he essentially talked his way in because it was something he had to do," said Joe Owens, editor of the Express-Times of Easton, Pa.
å¦   Cahir worked in the newspaper's Washington, D.C. bureau and enlisted in the Marine Corps Reserve in 2003. The 40-year-old sergeant was killed Aug. 13 in Helmand province.
å¦   The reporter served two tours in Iraq before returning to Pennsylvania, and then decided to run for Congress, entering a three-way Democratic primary last year to replace retiring GOP Rep. John Peterson.
å¦   The Express-Times reported that after losing the primary, Cahir said, "My journalism career is over. I'll talk to the Marine Corps and see what they want me to do and talk to my wife and see what she wants me to do."
å¦   Owens called the former newspaperman "a great American."
å¦   "He was committed to serving this country," Owens said. "He was on a career path before this that could have led anywhere for him, and he chose this because it was what he needed to do."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Rifles (2 Rifles)
IncidentLocation: near Sangin in Helmand province, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: Ministry of Defence confirmed that three British soldiers, two from The 2nd Battalion The Rifles and a third from 40 Regiment Royal Artillery have died following an explosion while on patrol near Sangin in Helmand Province, Thursday Aug 13

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion the Royal Welsh
IncidentLocation: near Musa Qaleh in Helmand province, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: died at the Royal Centre for Defence Medicine in Selly Oak on Saturday Aug. 15 from wounds sustained in Helmand province two days previously. He was wounded as a result of an explosion while on a vehicle patrol near Musa Qaleh in Helmand province Aug. 13

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 3rd Marine Regiment, 3rd Marine Division, III Marine Expeditionary Force
ServiceUnitLocation: Marine Corps Base Hawaii, Kaneohe Bay
IncidentDetails: Marine Lance Cpl. Joshua M. Bernard, 21, New Portland, Maine, died Friday while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Joshua Bernard was a strong believer in his faith who would sometimes put the needs of others before his own.
å¦   "He was inclined to help people if they needed it," said his friend, Michael Grooms. "That's a lot of the reason why he went into the Marines, is to serve."
å¦   Bernard, 21, of New Portland, Maine, served in both the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. He died Aug. 14 during combat in Helmand province in Afghanistan. He was assigned to Marine Corps Base Hawaii.
å¦   He leaves behind his parents, John and Sharon Bernard, and a sister.
å¦   Bernard, who was home-schooled, was active in the youth group at Crossroads Bible Church in Madison, Grooms said. He also was a member of the church and freely spoke of his faith, including to his fellow Marines.
å¦   "He was a great example for Christ and a great witness," Grooms said.

ServiceUnit: 1st Psychological Operations Battalion, 4th Psychological Operations Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Army Cpl. Nicholas R. Roush, 22, Middleville, Mich., died Sunday in Herat, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Nicholas R. Roush came into the world frail, with a breathing problem that his grandfather thought might kill him. But his family said Roush left it as a man of strength and fierce loyalty.
å¦   "Thank you for being the man I hope to be someday," Roush's older brother, Bobby, said at his memorial.
å¦   Roush, 22, of Middleville, Mich., died Aug. 16 in Herat of wounds from an explosion near his vehicle. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   He graduated in 2005 from Thornapple Kellogg High School. He had considered becoming a teacher or opening a custom car shop before he decided to join the Army, Bobby Roush said.
å¦   Their father, Bob, said his son joined the military because he wanted to "do something significant" _ something his family believes he accomplished.
å¦   "He has completed the mission ... and I await a great family reunion," said his grandfather, Robert Roush Sr.
å¦   Friends and family remembered the fallen soldier as a disciplined, driven man who loved a good prank. They say he was an active member of Middleville's First Baptist Church, where hundreds crowded in for his memorial.
å¦   He is also survived by his mother, Donna, and brother Kyle.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Royal Regiment of Fusiliers
IncidentDetails: died as a result of injuries sustained in an explosion that happened while on a foot patrol near Sangin, northen Helmand province on Saturday Aug. 15.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 17 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan
Bio:
å¦   Leopold F. Damas _ known to many as "their boy Leo" _ loved North Carolina, where he was stationed, and was scrounging so he could buy his mother a house there.
å¦   In fact, he volunteered to deploy to Afghanistan so he could use the extra money for a house for his mom, Carol, who suffers from chronic health problems. His family said that was typical of the dedicated family man who loved to play basketball and play video games.
å¦   "He was always trying to get everybody together," said his aunt, Marie Damas.
å¦   Damas, 26, of Floral Park, N.Y., died Aug. 17 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   The man who recruited Damas, Master Sgt. Darin Bell, said Damas was determined to become a Marine despite being turned away at first because of asthma problems. Bell kept in touch with Damas while the Marine served two tours in Iraq and recalled seeing pictures of him online.
å¦   "He hit me up on Facebook and I saw the photos of him in uniform and I was like, 'Man, he finally made it,'" Bell said.
å¦   In addition to his mother, Damas is survived by two brothers and two sisters.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Royal Regiment of Fusiliers (2 RRF)
IncidentLocation: near Sangin in Helmand province, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: died following an explosion while on patrol near Sangin in Helmand province on Sunday, Aug. 16.

IncidentLocation: near Sangin in Helmand province, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: died following an explosion while on patrol near Sangin in Helmand province on Sunday, Aug. 16

IncidentLocation: near Sangin in Helmand province, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: died following an explosion while on patrol near Sangin in Helmand province on Sunday, Aug. 16.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 501st Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Airborne Brigade Combat Team, 25th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers died Aug. 18 in Paktika province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Clayton P. Bowen had a reputation for rising to a challenge.
å¦   "It seemed like the tougher (the job) was, the harder he went after it and the better he got," said his stepfather, Buddy Doebbler.
å¦   In the Army, it was as a drill sergeant and shooting instructor. In three years singing a capella with the 82nd Airborne All-American Chorus, it was holding the low note.
å¦   "He had to be in every song, because he was the only bass," said his mother, Reesa Doebbler.
å¦   In Afghanistan, it was making life better for his buddies _ something he did by requesting donations of construction tools to improve their outpost.
å¦   Bowen, 29, of San Antonio, was killed Aug. 18 by a roadside bomb in Paktika province. The Churchill High School graduate joined the Army a decade ago and was assigned to Fort Richardson.
å¦   From Afghanistan, he sent home a DVD in which he jokingly posted "what we think about every day": a photo of beer. It was followed by photos of Bowen relaxing with loved ones.
å¦   "He was a great kid," Buddy Doebbler said. "He really grew up into a hell of a man, and we were really proud of him."
å¦   Bowen is also survived by his stepbrother, Troy.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 501st Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Airborne Brigade Combat Team, 25th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: To soldiers died Aug. 18 in Paktika povince, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their vehicle
Bio:
å¦   Morris L. Walker was like "a ray of sunshine," an incurable optimist as easygoing around adults as he was teenage pals.
å¦   "What I think of first when I think of Morris is his smile because he was always smiling," said Wanda Bordone, who taught him seventh- and eighth-grade English at Fayetteville Academy in North Carolina. "He had a great sense of humor, lots of friends."
å¦   Walker, 23, of Fayetteville, N.C., was killed Aug. 18 by a roadside bomb in Paktika province. He graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 2008 and was assigned to Fort Rich.
å¦   He was on the varsity basketball team, served as student government treasurer and worked with a community service club at the academy.
å¦   "He didn't have to be a star of anything," said Barbara Lambert, his guidance counselor. "He just wanted to be a participant."
å¦   Another guidance counselor, Pam Little, said Walker approached life with an unusual serenity.
å¦   "He had a peace about him that I find to be extremely rare in someone in high school," she said. "He was always an optimist."
å¦   And Walker always was comfortable around adults.
å¦   "He looked you in the eye and could talk to you," said Connie Koonce, a math teacher.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 20th Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 16 at Landstuhl Regional Medical Center in Landstuhl, Germany, of wounds suffered when he was shot Aug. 14 while on patrol in Ghanzi, Afghanistan
Bio:
å¦   William B. Woods _ better known by his middle name, Brian _ took his girlfriend to Colorado in January 2007, and she figured the romantic man would propose.
å¦   He upped the ante by taking her to pick out a wedding gown for what he planned as a destination wedding, said Patti Russell, the bride's mother. He was also known as a dedicated family man.
å¦   "He would always be beaming when he was around his kids," said Bob Woods, 58, an uncle who lives near Cincinnati. "And he and his wife ... they really just made a nice couple. They really worked well together. They were happy and in love."
å¦   Woods, 31, of Chesapeake, Va., was shot and killed while on patrol Aug. 16 in Ghazni province. He was a special forces medical sergeant assigned to Glen Arm, Md., who essentially served as a doctor in the field.
å¦   Bob Woods said his nephew was an adventurous outdoorsman who enjoyed sports and skydiving.
å¦   Woods came from a long line of military men _ his father, William B. Woods Sr., served in the U.S. Marine Corps during the Vietnam War. His grandfather, John Woods, was in the Navy in World War II; and his uncles, Johnnie and Bob Woods, served in the Army in Vietnam.
å¦   He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth, and two daughters, 5-year-old Lily and 1-year-old Ella.

ServiceUnit: 8th Engineer Support Battalion, Combat Logistics Regiment 2, 2nd Marine Logistics Group, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 18 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan
Bio:
å¦   Adam Benjamin knew a long time ago he wanted to be a Marine.
å¦   "Even when we were kids in grade school, he had the passion," said his longtime friend, Mark Russo. "He wanted to be a Marine. Everyone went off to college, and he went to boot camp."
å¦   That passion is reflected throughout his MySpace page: His favorite movies include "Full Metal Jacket" and "Saving Private Ryan." The Military Channel is among his favorite TV networks.
å¦   And one of the most recent books he read was "An Nasiriyah, The Fight for the Bridges," about a bloody battle early in the Iraq war that left more than a dozen Marines dead.
å¦   Benjamin, 34, of Garfield, Ohio, died Aug. 18 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province.
å¦   Survivors include his mother and stepfather, Judy and Robert Watters, and father, Frank Benjamin.
å¦   The 1993 Garfield Heights High School graduate was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   "I love my job," he wrote on MySpace. "How many of you can say that you are right where you want to be at this point in your life? I know I can."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 17th Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade Combat Team, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers died Aug. 18 in Arghandab, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their unit.
Bio:
å¦   Before he was 18, Troy Tom begged his family to let him join the Army, saying he wanted the challenges and experiences time in the service would bring and he wanted to attend college on the GI Bill.
å¦   The high school honor roll student didn't want to burden his family with tuition for school and other expenses, said his aunt Lena Dorme.
å¦   "He was a smart boy," his father, David Tom, added. "He begged us to let him go into the Army early, before he even turned 18."
