å¦   Troy Tom, 21, of Shiprock, N.M., was one of two soldiers killed Aug. 18 when a roadside bomb exploded near them in Kandahar province, on the Pakistani border. He was based at Fort Lewis, and was posthumously promoted to sergeant.
å¦   Tom joined the Army in June 2006 after graduating from Aztec High School in Aztec, N.M. He was a member of the Navajo Nation. His family said they will remember him as someone who could make people around him smile.
å¦   "He was the nicest, the kindest, son. He made everybody smile. He always had a smile on his face _ never, ever did he get mad. We're going to miss him very much," his mother Carolyn Tom said before breaking down in tears.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 17th Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade Combat Team, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers died Aug. 18 in Arghandab, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near their unit.
Bio:
å¦   Jonathan C. Yanney once described himself on a social networking Web site as a "pretty active" person who didn't like "just sitting around doing nothing."
å¦   He was a driven kid with a dry sense of humor, said Principal Marcella Swatosh of Norwood High School in Norwood, Mo., where Yanney attended for three years.
å¦   "He was always very focused on wanting to help people, and it sounds like that's what he was doing," she said.
å¦   Yanney, 20, of Litchfield, Minn., died Aug. 18 in Arghandab, Afghanistan, when an improvised explosive detonated near his unit. He was based in Fort Lewis, Wash.
å¦   His former baseball coach, Kevin Drake, said Yanney joined the team even though he hadn't previously played. He said even as a slugger on the junior varsity team, Yanney had at least one trait that's characteristic of the military.
å¦   "Very respectful, always, 'Yes sir, Mr. Drake,'" Drake said.
å¦   He was also outgoing and friendly, said Samantha Lynn Fedele, who worked with Yanney at a fast food restaurant.
å¦   "His smile would be the very first thing you noticed," she said.
å¦   Yanney is survived by his mother, Jane Kuhn Yanney; his father, Russ Yanney; and his brother, Josh.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 22 in Logar province, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained during a vehicle rollover.
Bio:
å¦   Darby Morin had big dreams. Not just for himself, but also for the generation behind him growing up as he did on the Big River First Nation reservation in Saskatchewan, Canada.
å¦   So just after graduating from Big River First Nation High School in 2003, he joined the U.S. Army, drawn partly by opportunities to work with advanced technology. He specialized in chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear defense systems and was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   He hoped his accomplishments would inspire the youth back home on the reservation.
å¦   "He wanted to be a role model; he wanted to show kids they could be much more than being in a gang or whatever," his uncle, Federation of Saskatchewan Indian Nations Fourth Vice Chief Lyle Whitefish, told the Canadian Press.
å¦   Morin, 25, died Aug. 22 in Logar province of injuries sustained during a vehicle rollover.
å¦   He and his wife, Veronica, had two sons, Christian, 3, and Blue Sky, 19 months.
å¦   Morin became the unofficial barber for his Army buddies. Even some of the men back home would ask him for haircuts during his visits.
å¦   They would line up to get their hair cut just like his, Whitefish said.

ServiceUnit: 149th Transportation Company, 10th Transportation Battalion
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 19 at Kandahar Airfield, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained from a non-combat related incident.
Bio:
å¦   Paul Dumont knew exactly how to cheer someone up: He'd slick his dark hair into Ace Ventura's signature pompadour, mimicking the catch-phrases and face contortions of Jim Carrey's famous pet detective character.
å¦   "He could lift you out of a bad mood very fast," said his sister, Stefanie Dumont. He was a class clown who was always kidding around _ "his favorite class was lunch," said another sister, Michelle Wolfe.
å¦   Still, Dumont knew his way around an engine. He was very mechanically inclined and was often tinkering with his Suzuki motorcycle or dreaming about buying a new Jeep Wrangler for off-roading.
å¦   "I lived with him for a while, and I'd come home and (his motorcycle would) be all torn apart in the middle of the room," Stefanie Dumont said.
å¦   Dumont, 23, of Williamsburg, Va., died Aug. 19 at Kandahar Airfield of injuries sustained in a noncombat related incident. The military was investigating his death. He was assigned to Fort Eustis.
å¦   The soldier also leaves behind a wife, Candice. The couple married a year ago after a high school friendship that eventually blossomed into romance. Dumont is also survived by his parents and six siblings.

ServiceUnit: International Security Assistance Force Kabul
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 18 in Kabul, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   Dozens of pushpins dot a world map in Jose Crisostomo's Spanaway, Wash., home, representing each international trip the 59-year-old soldier made during a 24-year military career.
å¦   He fought in the Vietnam war, and he went to Kuwait before retiring from the military in 1993. A native of Guam, Crisostomo re-enlisted last year.
å¦   "He insisted on going back and serving his country," said Crisostomo's wife, Patricia. "That was his passion, his life."
å¦   Crisostomo was killed Aug. 18 when a roadside bomb detonated near his vehicle in Kabul. He died two weeks before his 60th birthday and is believed to be the oldest U.S. soldier killed while fighting in Afghanistan.
å¦   "My father loved the military," said his daughter Tricia Crisostomo-Meyers.
å¦   Jay Crisostomo described his father as a handyman who could repair electric and plumbing problems. A tool belt was presented at the traditional offering of gifts during Crisostomo's service.
å¦   "He was willing to help anyone out," said Norman Ruediger, his next-door neighbor. "He never asked for compensation. ... He would just say, 'OK, let's sit down and have a beer.'"
å¦   Crisostomo is survived by his wife, four children and 10 grandchildren.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 20 in Kunar province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his unit with indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   Two years after graduating from high school in Oak Park, Calif., Brian Wolverton returned to help coach the hurdlers on the track team.
å¦   The athletes he worked with affectionately called him "Wolvie" or "Coach Wolvie."
å¦   "He was a vocal, enthusiastic coach who motivated his runners to find personal success," said Kevin Smith, the Oak Park track coach. "He developed a devoted following among his charges.
å¦   Wolverton, 21, was killed Aug. 20 when insurgents attacked his unit in Kunar province. He was based at Fort Drum, N.Y.
å¦   Wolverton ran on the Oak Park High School track team before graduating in 2006. Lyle Greenberg, an assistant track coach, said a quote Wolverton picked to appear next to his senior yearbook photo reads: "Courage is facing your fear; with no fear there is no courage."
å¦   "Once Brian decided that he wanted to do something, he usually worked very hard to achieve his goals or at least gave it his best efforts," said his mother, Miriam Wolverton.
å¦   Brian Wolverton earned an associates degree from Moonpark College, according to the Armed Forces News Service.
å¦   When Wolverton enlisted in January, his family said, he became a fifth-generation soldier. His great-great-grandfather served in the Union Army during the Civil War.
å¦   "I was very proud of him," his father Christopher Wolverton said.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion the Rifles
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers were killed following two explosions that happened while they were on a foot patrol taking place in Sangin District, Helmand province on Thursday morning Aug. 20

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion The Yorkshire Regiment (Duke of Wellington's)
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers were killed following two explosions that happened while they were on a foot patrol taking place in Sangin District, Helmand Province on Thursday morning Aug. 20

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 12th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 21 in Kunar Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle, and his unit came under small arms fire from enemy forces.
Bio:
å¦   It didn't matter that Matthew L. Ingram's brother was five years older _ the younger Ingram was the one giving orders, even as a child.
å¦   Ingram's mother, Patricia Ingram, said it's a trait he carried with him into adulthood and served him well in the military.
å¦   "He's always been a leader, not a follower," she said.
å¦   Ingram, 25, of Pearl, Miss., died Aug. 21 in Kunar Province after a bomb went off near his vehicle and his unit came under small-arms fire. He was assigned to Fort Carson.
å¦   His wife, Holly Ingram, remembered her husband as a proud father who did everything he could for their baby girl, Chloe.
å¦   "He went walking into the waiting room and was puffed up and was proud to be a daddy," Holly Ingram said of the day Chloe was born. And he didn't want to go to Afghanistan this time "because of his little baby," his mother said.
å¦   Ingram, who loved playing paintball and riding his Harley-Davidson motorcycle, was awarded the Purple Heart on his first overseas tour in Iraq, when an explosive injured his ankle and foot.
å¦   Besides his wife, daughter and mother, Ingram is survived by his father, James, and a brother, Jamie.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 20 in Wardak Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.
Bio:
å¦   He liked American muscle cars with powerful engines. He liked being the life of the party.
å¦   But Justin R. Pellerin loved his wife, Chelsey.
å¦   The high school sweethearts married in July 2008, but celebrated their first wedding anniversary apart _ she in Concord, N.H., he somewhere in Afghanistan.
å¦   He was to see her in mid-December, when he was to return from war. He said in a Facebook posting that he had "nothing to look forward to except for seeing my wife again."
å¦   "I've never seen anyone in love so much as those two," longtime family friend Geordan Rule told the Union Leader newspaper. "They were inseparable _ a match made in heaven."
å¦   Pellerin, 21, of Boscawen, N.H., died Aug. 20 in Wardak Province after a bomb exploded near the vehicle he was driving. He was based in Fort Drum.
å¦   Pellerin had told friends how little he cared for Afghanistan. He felt the opposite about his wife, proclaiming on MySpace: "one thing in my life that everyone should know about is that I have found the one, and i love her to death, we're married now and i love every minute of it. and honestly, she completes me, i love you Chelsey J Pellerin."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 22 in Yakhchal, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his unit
Bio:
å¦   Richie Jones loved exploring outside and playing Army as a child. Or as his grandmother put it, "just being a typical roughneck little boy."
å¦   Even as an adult, though, Jones obeyed grandma.
å¦   Jones' grandmother, Peggy Bowling, told the aspiring soldier to go to school a bit longer before he joined the military. Jones said he'd keep learning about diesel engines at a school for auto mechanics, but there was a catch. If Jones decided that wasn't for him, grandma had to give her blessing so he could join the military.
å¦   Eventually, that love for exploring got the best of him. Bowling gave her blessing, and said she doesn't regret it at all.
å¦   "No sir, because that was his dream," Bowling said. "That's what he wanted to do."
å¦   Jones, 21, of Person, N.C., was killed Aug. 1 in Mushan Village when insurgents attacked his patrol.
å¦   He was an energetic man who would sneak in a call to his mom from boot camp and Afghanistan, even when he wasn't allowed.
å¦   He is survived by his mother, Franceen Jones; father, Richard Jones; his grandparents; and two sisters, Tanna Jones Lee and Kaitlyn Jones.
‰ÛÊArmy Staff Sgt. Andrew T. Lobosco
å¦   Andrew T. Lobosco was never one to stand by and watch.
å¦   At home, he was the one organizing a drive to collect canes, crutches and wheelchairs to be sent to Afghanistan. In battle, he was leading his fellow soldiers.
å¦   And in Afghan villages, the Green Beret medic was a "warrior healer" who treated local men, women and children, said Capt. Marcus Hunter, who served with Lobosco in 2006 and 2007.
å¦   "Everywhere you looked, he was there," said Chief Warrant Officer Dennis Guy. "He was just one of those guys who knew what to do next without being told."
å¦   Lobosco, 29, of Somerville, N.J., died Aug. 22 of wounds suffered when his unit was attacked. He was assigned to Fort Bragg and was on his second deployment to Afghanistan. He is survived by his parents and twin sister.
å¦   Lobosco was light-hearted and knew how to have a good time, said his friend, Jeff Mosier. But he was also disciplined and worked hard to be his best. He played in bands in high school but also was an expert in martial arts.
å¦   One of his teachers at Immaculata High School in Somerville, Sister Karen, said Lobosco and his sister both showed that discipline when they performed at a talent show his freshman year.
å¦   "They were doing karate with fire," she said. "It was amazing."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 17th Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Aug. 25 in southern Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   John Hallett grew up in the San Francisco Bay area playing basketball and water polo, and delivering the newspaper for the Contra Costa Times.
å¦   After he graduated from the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., he married his wife, Lisa, in 2004. They have two sons _ Jackson, 4, and Bryce, 2. A daughter, Heidi, was born in August. Hallett never met her.
å¦   "Captain John Louis Hallett III was an amazing father, devoted and joyful husband, thoughtful son, loving brother, and inspiring friend," his wife said in a statement released by the Army. "He was a patient teacher to our children."
å¦   Hallett, 30, of Concord, Calif., died Aug. 25 when his vehicle hit a roadside bob. The explosion also killed three others. They were assigned to Fort Lewis and were serving with the 5th Stryker brigade, which assumed responsibilities in August in Kandahar and Zabul provinces.
å¦   Hallett's wife lives in Dupont, Wash., near Fort Lewis. His parents still live in Concord, where Hallett's two younger brothers also were raised.
å¦   "He had the warmest and most genuine smile. John would always make people laugh by his clever ways and kind humor," his wife said. "Words fail to begin to describe John's true spirit."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 17th Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Aug. 25 in southern Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   A month before Cory Jenkins' deployment, his daughter, Reagan, was born, giving him a chance to spend time with her before he left for Afghanistan.
å¦   Photos show Jenkins, a new father, holding the newborn and flashing a wide grin. Before he boarded his bus for deployment on July 19, his wife, Brooke, said Jenkins held and hugged his daughter briefly for the last time.
å¦   "Fortunately, he was here when she was born," said Jenkins' father, Stanley.
å¦   Jenkins, 30, of Mesa, Ariz., was among four soldiers killed Aug. 25 when a roadside bomb exploded near their vehicle in southern Afghanistan. He was based at Fort Lewis.
å¦   Stanley Jenkins said his son, a physician's assistant, joined the Army because he wanted to gain intense experience treating trauma injuries.
å¦   "His biggest delight in life was serving other people, and he figured being a physician's assistant would be the best way," the elder Jenkins said. "We knew he was in danger but never expected this."
å¦   Cory Jenkins graduated from BYU in 2003 with a bachelor's degree in conservation biology. He also graduated from A.T. Still University's physician-assistant program.
å¦   Jenkins was an active member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and served a mission to Russia, his father said.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 17th Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Aug. 25 in southern Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   In his younger years, Ronald W. Sawyer was the Dan Aykroyd of his family, or maybe the John Belushi.
å¦   "Ron was a prankster and a joker," said his mother, Judy Thompson. "He and his brother used to impersonate the Blues Brothers in talent shows."
å¦   Sawyer, 38, of Trenton, Mo., was killed Aug. 25 in southern Afghanistan when his vehicle hit a roadside bomb. He was assigned to Fort Lewis.
å¦   "Whenever he came home from overseas he'd bring home presents," his mother said. "One time he brought back a framed piece of barbed wire that had separated North and South Korea for his uncle who had served in the Korean War."
å¦   On one break, Sawyer _ in his fatigues _ went to his niece's elementary school to share lunch with her class.
å¦   The graduate of Grundy R-5 High School in Galt served as a military recruiter and a medic. He also loved baseball and had pitched for American Legion teams.
å¦   "Just before he left for Afghanistan he called me," Thompson said. "His last words to me were, 'I love you Mom. Be safe.'"
å¦   Sawyer is also survived by his wife, Sarah; their 2-year-old son, Daniel; his father; his stepfather; two brothers; and a sister.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 17th Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers died Aug. 25 in southern Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Dennis Williams, pictured in his military uniform with a serious, stoic look, was really "mischief" and a clown around his family, said his grandmother Kathy Anderson.
å¦   He was helpful, too, she said.
å¦   "Denny always put up my Christmas lights," she said, choking back tears after her grandson's death. "I'm so confused, I don't hardly know my own name."
å¦   Williams, 24, of Federal Way, Wash., and three others were killed Aug. 25 when a roadside bomb exploded near their vehicle. He was based at Fort Lewis.
å¦   When he left for deployment a month ago, he told his grandmother he might never see her again.
å¦   Anderson remembers responding, "Denny don't be silly."
å¦   Williams graduated from Federal Way High School in 2003. Before enlisting in October 2007, he was a security guard at a building in Seattle.
å¦   "He was very proud of that job," his older brother David Williams said. "He looked sharp in his uniform. That's when it started to grind on him."
å¦   It was then that Dennis Williams decided to serve in the military, his brother said. Williams' father had been in the Army and his grandfather was a Marine.
å¦   "We had him about talked out of it 10 times," David Williams said. "But he went. He wanted to provide for his wife and kids."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 5th Marine Regiment, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 26 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Donald Hogan ran cross country in high school and while he wasn't the best, he was still an athlete who could push and motivate others.
å¦   "We'd do a lot of hill runs and he would always be the last one, right behind me and always pushing me," former teammate Rachel Nama, 19, said with a laugh. "I really appreciate him for that. He was always one to push you and not one to leave you behind."
å¦   "He wasn't very good at it," his father, Jim Hogan, said, "but he always showed up and competed."
å¦   Hogan, 20, of San Clemente, Calif., died Aug. 26 in Helmand province. A blast that injured several others killed Hogan while he was on foot patrol, a spokesman for the 1st Marine Division at Camp Pendleton, Calif., said.
å¦   Hogan was based at Camp Pendleton. He enlisted soon after graduating from Tesoro High School in 2007.
å¦   "He had planned on making a career out of the Marines. He had told me that his goal was to attain or surpass my father's rank of Gunnery Sergeant," his father said.
å¦   Donald's grandfather, James Hogan Sr., was a career Marine who fought in World War II, and the Korean and Vietnam wars. He retired as a gunnery sergeant, Jim Hogan said.
å¦   Hogan is survived by his father, mother, Carla, and sister Adrianna.
å¦   Hogan called his son "a beautiful kid."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 501st Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team (Airborne), 25th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Died Aug. 26 in Paktika Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when he was shot while his unit was supporting Afghan security forces during an enemy attack
Bio:
å¦   An occasional food fighter with a good sense of humor is how a number of Kurt Curtiss' four siblings and more than 60 foster brothers and sisters remember him.
å¦   "We're family," said Curtiss' sister Lynn Burr. "And we're all here to help each other out."
å¦   Curtiss' mother, Ruth Serrano, had a foster home that provided him with dozens of playmates as a kid.
å¦   "He was quite the joker," his mother said. "He could cheer up anybody."
å¦   Curtiss, 27, of Murray, Utah, was killed Aug. 26 in Paktika Province. His family learned from the Army that he was shot while helping evacuate a hospital that was under attack. He was assigned to Fort Richardson.
å¦   "He was always honorable," his mother said. "He always treated his family _ and everyone else _ with respect."
å¦   He enlisted the day after 9/11. He had been deployed twice to Iraq, his mother said, and he left for Afghanistan less than a year before he died.
å¦   "He just wanted to make a difference," his sister said. "He wanted to help keep everybody safe, especially his family."
å¦   Curtiss leaves behind his wife, Elizabeth; a son, Joshua; and a daughter, Cecilia.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Royal Regiment of Fusiliers
IncidentDetails:
The soldier died at the Royal Centre for Defence Medicine, Selly Oak, Tuesday Aug. 25.
He died from wounds he sustained in an explosion while on a foot patrol near Sangin in Helmand province on the evening of Saturday Aug 15.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 12th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Died Aug. 27 in Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his vehicle with an improvised explosive device
Bio:
å¦   Matthew E. Wildes was known for his sense of humor and carefree attitude.
å¦   "Wildes always tried to make everyone laugh with his corny raps and his famous 'Blue Steel' look he had mastered," said Staff Sgt. Michael Nares, referring to the pose struck by Ben Stiller as a model caricature in "Zoolander."
å¦   "You were a great soldier, but an even better friend."
å¦   Wildes, 18, of Hammond, La., was killed Aug. 27 by a roadside bomb in southern Afghanistan.
å¦   The teen's parents tried to talk him out of joining, but he was determined. Wildes earned his GED to join up as soon as possible, in April 2008, said his mother, Mary.
å¦   Halway through basic training, he was sent home with stress fractures _ and couldn't wait to get back with his fellow soldiers.
å¦   "He was a sweet kid," she said. "He didn't like me saying that, but he was a kid. I treated him like a baby. But he was my baby."
å¦   Mary Wildes talked to him on MySpace the day before he died and told him she loved him _ but let him go so he didn't spend all his allotted 30 minutes on the computer talking to her.
å¦   He is survived by his mother; his father, Clint; a brother, also named Clint; and a sister, Jamie Ackan.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Squadron, 71st Cavalry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Abraham S. Wheeler III, 22, Columbia, S.C., died Friday in Logar province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Abraham S. Wheeler III, whom friends called "Rod," couldn't wait to get home and finish restoring his 1985 Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme.
å¦   His father, Abraham Wheeler Jr., was hoping to have it repainted by the time his son came home. But he won't have that chance.
å¦   "I've never had a feeling like that ever," the elder Wheeler said of the moment he learned of his son's death. "My heart, it felt like it had fallen down to my foot."
å¦   Wheeler joined the Army in 2007, two years after graduating from Ridge View High School, where he was a 6-foot-2, 260-pound defensive end on the football team. He was assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   The 22-year-old from Columbia, S.C., was killed by a roadside bomb Aug. 28 in Logar province.
å¦   His father said when he last spoke to his son on the phone, the soldier said "things were getting a little hectic, but he told me not to worry because he would be all right."
å¦   However, the younger Wheeler knew the risks, according to posts on his online Facebook page.
å¦   "Man, so many soldiers fallin all over this ... country," he wrote. "My heart goes out to them."
å¦   Wheeler is also survived by a brother.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: died Aug. 31 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   David Hall had a pretty good job at a Ford assembly plant when he joined the Marines three years ago.
å¦   Hall, of Elyria, Ohio, said he wanted to do more for society. His sister, Lora Hall, was concerned, and she told him so.
å¦   "David, you could be dead in a year," she said to him.
å¦   "You have to understand, this is something I have to do," he responded.
å¦   More than a year after wrapping up seven months in Iraq, Hall, 31, went to Afghanistan this year. He died in an Aug. 31 blast in Helmand province. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   His father, Delmar Hall, said that his son wanted his life to have a purpose, and that he never regretted joining the Marines.
å¦   "He wanted something to be proud of," his father said.
å¦   Hall enjoyed traveling and meeting people from different cultures. While growing up, exchange students from Italy, Brazil, Yugoslavia and Germany spent time in his home. He traveled to Brazil after high school, staying with the family of an exchange student his family had hosted.
å¦   Hall, a 1997 graduate of Southview High School, is also survived by his mother, Lulu Hall, and three sisters.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 17th Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Jonathan D. Welch, 19, Yorba Linda, Calif., died Monday in Shuyene Sufia, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his unit with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Jonathan Welch _ funny and a fan of punk music _ knew how to make the most out of life, friends said.
å¦   "He was one in a million," Alex Morgenstern wrote on a Los Angeles Times Web page dedicated to Welch. "We will always remember listening to music all trying our best to dance ... His laugh was very memorable as well as him in general."
å¦   Welch's father Ben Storll remembered the 19-year-old saying less than two months before his death that he had no regrets.
å¦   "Jon knew there was a chance of this happening," Storll said of his son's death.
å¦   Welch, of Yorba Linda, Calif., was killed Aug. 31 in Shuyene Sufia when enemy forces attacked his unit with an improvised explosive. He was based at Fort Lewis.
å¦   Welch attended Esperanza High School in Anaheim before earning his GED. In 2007, when he was 17, he enlisted. He was went to Afghanistan in July. It was his first deployment.
å¦   Dave Hill wrote online that he grew up attending the same church as Welch. Hill said he and Welch, a fellow home-school student, got together as kids and created a comic strip about a child spy armed with gadgets and fighting evil overseas.
å¦   "Being a couple years older I thought he was a little squirt," Hill said. "But I liked him a lot. I will miss him."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment
IncidentDetails: Army Staff Sgt. Jason S. Dahlke, 29, Orlando, Fla.; died Saturday in Paktika province, Afghanistan, after he was shot by enemy forces Friday during combat operations.
Bio:
å¦   Jason S. Dahlke was an easy guy to talk to and get along with, but he never said much about his work as an Army Ranger in Afghanistan. He never even told his parents about the Purple Heart he was awarded.
å¦   "We didn't know anything until we searched on the Internet. There was his picture, getting a Purple Heart," said his father, Roger Dahlke.
å¦   Dahlke, 29, of Orlando, Fla. was killed Aug. 29 during a firefight in Paktika province. It was his third deployment to Afghanistan. He was assigned to Hunter Army Airfield and lived with his wife in Savannah, Ga., his father said.
å¦   He graduated from the University of Central Florida with a degree in criminal justice and had considered a career in law enforcement. But he decided to join the military soon after graduation.
å¦   Dahlke first met his wife, Niki, in grade school. In high school, Niki was drawn to Dahlke because he was fun and adventurous and could make her laugh, said Niki Dahlke's sister, Amy Jensen. They went to prom together.
å¦   "It was one of those high school romances," said Stephanie Norvell, Niki Dahlke's mother.
å¦   He followed her to Orlando when she moved there for college, and the couple married in 2005.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment
IncidentDetails: Army Pfc. Eric W. Hario, 19, Monroe, Mich.; died Saturday in Paktika province, Afghanistan, after he was shot by enemy forces Friday during combat operations.
Bio:
å¦   When it came to the military, Eric W. Hario had one goal: to be an Army Ranger.
å¦   "He always strived to be the best," said his mother, Rebecca. "He wanted to be a Ranger because they're the best. Rangers all the way. He was on top of the world. He was always so sure of himself."
å¦   Hario, 19, of Monroe, Mich., died Aug. 29 in Paktika province after he was shot by enemy forces during combat operations. He was assigned to Hunter Army Airfield.
å¦   His parents said it was obvious early on that Hario would be a military man like his father, James, and older brother, Robert. The teen enjoyed playing video games with military themes and had put up an American flag in his room. He enlisted after graduating last year from Monroe High School, where he played football and was on the wrestling team.
å¦   His friend Carter Lanning described Hario as a bubbly guy who enjoyed spending time at home and hanging out.
å¦   Mark Hario said his younger brother, who had been in Afghanistan for only three weeks, eventually hoped to become a police officer or an FBI agent.
å¦   "I told my sons to follow their dreams," their father said. "He was very committed."

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 12th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 5 in Abad, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his vehicle using small arms and recoilless rifle fires
Bio:
å¦   In one photograph, Army Sgt. Youvert Loney, a father of two, stands straight and tall in his uniform, holding his young son. The baby boy wears a soldier's camouflage hat.
å¦   Another photo shows Loney sporting a hooded sweatshirt and baseball cap. A rocky, scenic slope serves as a backdrop.
å¦   On a MySpace page filled with photos of Loney and his family, "I love you" is written to him 95 times in one post.
å¦   Loney, 28, of Pohnpei, Micronesia, was killed Sept. 5 in Abad when his vehicle was attacked. He was based at Fort Carson.
å¦   A Department of the Interior's Office of Insular Affairs release says Loney is survived by his wife, two children and father.
å¦   The department also says Loney's death was the fourth Guam casualty in 2009. He was the 34th Micronesian to be killed in a U.S. war since 2003.
å¦   A man identified only as Pfc. Cabrera wrote in an online message board that Loney remained deeply missed by his platoon.
å¦   "It definitely hasn't been the same here," Cabrera wrote. "We miss you SGT and you will not be forgotten."
å¦   Loney enlisted in 2005. He was deployed to Iraq from October 2006 to December 2007. He was sent to Afghanistan in June.

ServiceUnit: The Black Watch, 3rd Battalion The Royal Regiment of Scotland
IncidentDetails: The soldiers were killed as a result of an explosion believed to have been caused by a rocket-propelled grenade when they were attacked by insurgents whilst patrolling on foot in Babaji District, Helmand Province on the morning of Monday, Aug. 31.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion The Royal Regiment of Scotland
IncidentDetails: The soldiers were killed as a result of an explosion believed to have been caused by a rocket-propelled grenade when they were attacked by insurgents whilst patrolling on foot in Babaji District, Helmand Province on the morning of Monday, Aug. 31.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 17th Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Army Pfc. Jordan M. Brochu, 20, Cumberland, Maine, died Monday in Shuyene Sufia, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his unit with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Jordan Brochu got a rough start in life. He was abused and neglected until age 3, said his adoptive mother, Suzanne Brochu.
å¦   Overcoming his early childhood horrors was hard, with many setbacks, she said.
å¦   As he got older, he poured himself into a variety of activities _ fishing, video games, sports, cooking, reading J.R.R. Tolkien books, even poetry writing.
å¦   "It was very real," his former high school guidance counselor Nancy McClean said of his writings. "He was very, very good and expressing life, expressing hope."
å¦   Brochu, 20, of Cumberland, Maine, died Aug. 31 in Shuyene Sufia of wounds suffered after his Army unit was attacked with an explosive device. He was assigned to Fort Lewis.
å¦   Brochu wrote on his MySpace page that "my life has been hell and no one thought or cared if i would make it." But he added, "for once my head is held high."
å¦   Brochu, a 2008 graduate of Lake Region Vocational Center, was popular student and athlete. He joined the Army as a way to do some good, McClean said.
å¦   His mother and father, Daniel Brochu, believe he succeeded.
å¦   "Jordan lived a lifetime in 20 years," Suzanne Brochu said. "He started with us broken but he has finished complete. A hero."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 17th Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Tyler R. Walshe, 21, Shasta, Calif., died Monday in southern Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his unit with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Tyler Walshe-Vietti's wife, Kirsten, said he was "the most amazing person."
å¦   Friend Ruben Contreras wrote online that he'll miss playing basketball with the 21-year-old soldier and he has "nothing but good things to say" about Walshe.
å¦   "I watched Tyler hold and comfort his daughter like a proud father," another acquaintance, Guy Lane, wrote online, sympathizing with Walshe's family. "Memories and stories from others will be all she ever has of her father now."
å¦   Walshe-Vietti, the father of 11-month-old Karsyn, died Aug. 31 when his unit was attacked in Shuyene Sufia in Kandahar province. He was based at Fort Lewis.
å¦   Walshe joined the Army in October 2006. He was deployed to Afghanistan in July 2009.
å¦   "I just can't believe he's gone," his wife said. "I'm trying really, really hard to keep it together and to stay strong for my daughter. She doesn't understand that daddy's gone."
å¦   Walshe's wife said their daughter's first birthday is Nov. 11, which is Veterans Day.
å¦   Walshe's honors include the National Defense Service Medal, and Army Service Ribbon and Combat Infantryman Badge.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Light Armored Reconnaissance Battalion, 2nd Marine Expeditionary Battalion
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 3 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Benjamin P. Castiglione was unfazed even by a scorpion. He helped civilians and comrades in the Afghan and Iraqi war zones as a medic in the Navy, once treating an unconscious Marine having breathing and heart problems after being stung by the desert-dwelling creature.
å¦   "Those Marines meant the world to him," said his mother, Carrie Castiglione. "I talked to him before he went to Iraq about preparing himself for losing one if he had to. He said, 'Mom, I'm bringing all those guys home.'"
å¦   Instead, they lost him.
å¦   Castiglione, 21, of Howell, Mich., was killed Sept. 3 by an improvised explosive in Helmand province. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   He graduated from Howell High School in 2006 and joined the Navy that November. He served in Iraq for eight months last year and deployed to Afghanistan in June.
å¦   He wanted to continue medical work and planned to become a physician's assistant. He also was looking forward to going to Germany or Hawaii when his deployment ended in November, his parents said.
å¦   He died one day after talking about those plans with his family.
å¦   Castiglione is also survived by three stepbrothers.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Light Armored Reconnaissance Battalion, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force, Camp
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 3 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan
Bio:
å¦   Christopher S. Baltazar Jr. could irritate his brother in a way only brothers could.
å¦   "If he poked me with a stick, I'd curse at him and laugh at him at the same time," said his younger brother, Brendon. "There's never been anyone else on this planet who I could not be angry at."
å¦   Raised by a mother who was deployed several times, they were in the habit of saying "I love you" each time they spoke, including the last.
å¦   "In a military family, you just don't want to send anyone away without hearing that," Brendon Baltazar said.
å¦   Christopher Baltazar, 19, of San Antonio, was killed Sept. 3 by an explosive in Helmand province. He was based at Camp Lejeune.
å¦   He seemed more comfortable in his ROTC camouflage getting dirty than in a military dress uniform, so friends weren't surprised he joined the Marines after graduating from Judson High School in San Antonio in 2008.
å¦   "He was always a real funny, joyful, happy person," said Will Weber, who described Baltazar as a close friend growing up. "He was so excited about being a Marine. He believed in honor and serving his country."
å¦   Baltazar also is survived by his sister and two stepbrothers, his brother said.

ServiceUnit: Corps of Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers
IncidentLocation: south of Gereshkt, Helmand province, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: was killed south of Gereshk in Helmand province. He was the driver of a recovery vehicle carrying out an essential resupply task when it hit an improvised explosive device on Sept. 2.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Mercian Regiment
IncidentDetails: he died as a result of a gunshot wound sustained whilst on a foot patrol in Babaji district, central Helmand province on Thursday, Sept. 3. He was the point man on a clearance operation.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 501st Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team (Airborne), 25th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Army 2nd Lt. Darryn D. Andrews, 34, Dallas, Texas, died Friday in Paktika Province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his vehicle with an improvised explosive device and a rocket-propelled grenade.
Bio:
å¦   Darryn D. Andrews wasn't one for shaking hands.
å¦   "If he knew you, it was always a bear hug. It didn't make any difference," said his mother, Sondra.
å¦   She said he loved life, especially with his wife, Julie, and their 2-year-old son. The couple was expecting their second child when Andrews died Sept. 4 of wounds from a rocket-propelled grenade in Paktika province.
å¦   The 34-year-old from Dallas was assigned to Fort Richardson.
å¦   His mother said he was lighthearted, energetic and "could put a fun spin on any situation." He enjoyed scuba and sky diving, fishing and hunting, and he immersed himself in athletics, theater productions and church youth group while growing up in the Texas Panhandle.
å¦   He and his twin brother, Jarrett, attended Texas Tech University, and he earned a master's degree from Texas State University in 2008. But his sense of duty led him to the military six years ago, following in the footsteps of his father and grandfather.
å¦   "We grew up with an enormous amount of pride for our nation," she said. "We passed it on to our children, never thinking we would pay the ultimate sacrifice."
å¦   Andrews also is survived by his father.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Special Troops Battalion, 2nd Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Army Sgt. Randy M. Haney, 27, Orlando, Fla., died Sunday in Nangarhar, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his unit using small arms fires.
Bio:
å¦   When Randy M. Haney got a care package filled with candy while serving in Afghanistan, he wasn't the one who ate it. He gave it to Afghan children, his mother said.
å¦   "He was very proud of the fact that he helped people and that he was serving his country," added his mother-in-law, Cindy Alexopoulos. "He cared a lot about the kids and trying to help people who were there."
å¦   Haney, 27, of Orlando, Fla., was killed Sept. 6 when enemy forces attacked his unit. He joined the military in search of a stable job after he earned his GED and had trouble finding jobs. He was a military police officer assigned to Fort Carson.
å¦   Haney had served a tour in Afghanistan from 2005-2006, and in Iraq from 2007-2008. But he was ready to come back to civilian life with his wife and two young children. And he was especially excited to work on his speedy Honda Civic, which he was always taking apart and putting back together.
å¦   His family said he was also a jokester who decided he would be in charge of boosting morale in his military unit.
å¦   Haney is survived by his wife, Katie, and two children, 5-year-old Aubry and 18-month-old Austin.

IncidentDetails: platoon leader Marcin Poreba was killed when a home-made IED exploded under the armored vehicle in which he and five other soldiers were traveling in was about two kilometres from the Polish base of Giro on September 4.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 501st Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team (Airborne), 25th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 6 in Paktika province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his unit with an improvised explosive device
Bio:
å¦   Those who knew him say Michael C. Murphrey had all the qualities of a good soldier, including loyalty, respect and a selfless sense of service.
å¦   He always prioritized his comrades' needs and did more than his share of the work, Brig. Gen. Keith Walker said at Murphrey's memorial service, where hundreds of people packed the church and locals lined the streets, waving American flags.
å¦   The 25-year-old from Snyder, Texas, died Sept. 6 in Afghanistan's Paktika province after enemy forces attacked his unit with an improvised explosive.
å¦   He graduated from Snyder High School in 2003 and joined the Army a few months later. He was assigned to Fort Richardson after spending time at Fort Bragg in North Carolina.
å¦   Mourners at the First Baptist Church of Clyde wiped away tears as a slideshow flashed images of Murphrey growing up, from his own infancy to the birth of his son, Jaden, and daughter, Cameron.
å¦   Murphrey is also survived by his wife, Ashley; his parents, Elvie and Evelyn Murphrey of Clyde; and his sisters Jeanie Rutherford of Clyde, Wendy Stehouwer of Waxahachie, Pearl McKay of Sweetwater and Krisa Johnson of Colorado Springs, Colo.

ServiceUnit: 1st Marine Special Operations Battalion, Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 5 while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Joshua S. Meadows was about to become a father. He was only two weeks away from coming home _ where his wife was waiting to reveal whether they'd have a boy or girl _ when he died Sept. 5 while supporting combat operations in Farah province.
å¦   The 30-year-old from Bastrop, Texas, was assigned to Camp Pendleton.
å¦   Friends said Meadows was a devout Christian and Eagle Scout who always had a sincere smile. He joined the Marines before graduating from Elgin High School in 1997 and earned a business degree from Texas Tech University before he was commissioned as an officer.
å¦   "He was just a very polite young man, very 'Yes, sir, No, sir,' " said family friend Jeff Carter. "Some people join the military, and it's just a job. But he approached it like it was his destiny."
å¦   Local library director Sandy Ott said she remembered watching Meadows as a boy, riding in a green pickup and wrestling with his late father, Robert Meadows, also a Marine.
å¦   "Joshua and Robert are probably up in heaven now knocking each other in the head and playing," she said.
å¦   Meadows is survived by his wife in Carlsbad, Calif.; his mother, Jan; and his sister, Erin.

ServiceUnit: embedded training team with Combined Security Transition Command
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 8 in Kunar province, Afghanistan, while supporting combat operations.
Bio:
å¦   James Layton's plan was to get an education in health care, see the world during eight years of military service, then become a radiology technician.
å¦   Before going to Afghanistan, he was stationed in Okinawa, Japan, and told his family he loved the people and food while he was there.
å¦   "He was a very caring person, so it didn't surprise me that he was looking at the healing profession," his grandmother Kathy Anderson said.
å¦   Layton, a 22-year-old Navy medical corpsman from Riverbank, Calif., was killed Sept. 8 in Kunar province while aiding a wounded U.S. Marine.
å¦   Layton enlisted in the Navy two years ago. One of his teachers at Vista High School in Escalon, Calif., recalled Layton saying several years ago that he was inspired by his grandfather's Naval service during the Korean War.
å¦   "I wouldn't say he was a giant go-getter, but he recognized the need to do something with his life," teacher Shane Bua said.
å¦   Layton earn his high school diploma in 2005.
å¦   He is survived by his grandmother, his mother, Nikki Freitas, his father, Brent Layton; two younger brothers, Jonathan and Jesse; a stepsister, Andrea; and stepbrother, Jason.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Combat Assault Battalion, 3rd Marine Division, III Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Three Marines died Sept. 8 while supporting combat operations in Kunar province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Edwin W. Johnson Jr. wasn't known to many people as Edwin. To loved ones and friends, he was Wayne. To fellow Marines, he was "Gunny J."
å¦   To his younger sister, LaToya Lowe, he was Superman.
å¦   "He always tried to help people do better for themselves," Lowe said. "He was like the role model of the century. Everybody I know who knew my brother, they looked up to him."
å¦   Johnson, 31, of Columbus, Ga., died Sept. 8 in Kunar province when insurgents attacked. He was stationed in Okinawa, Japan. He enlisted in the Marine Corps after graduating from Columbus High School in 1996, and served in Korea and Japan.
å¦   His wife, Tasha, is a fellow Marine.
å¦   Johnson loved his life of discipline, though he was quite mischievious as a child. His cousin, Theopolis Ramsey, recalled a time the two were trying to get rid of ants they found in the house with broom straw they would set on fire. They ended up setting a bed on fire.
å¦   "That was one of the worst whippings we got," Ramsey said, laughing. "We would still laugh about it."
å¦   Johnson is also survived by three children, Jaron, Jalissa and Toren.

ServiceUnit: 7th Communications Battalion, 3rd Marine Headquarters Group, III Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Three Marines died Sept. 8 while supporting combat operations in Kunar province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Michael E. Johnson and his wife once made a deal: He would teach her to surf if she taught him how to snowboard.
å¦   That love for nature is what brought Johnson to Oregon for college _ and kept him there.
å¦   "He was all about doing stuff outdoors, traveling around, hiking," said his uncle Greg Chase. He grew up in Virginia Beach, Va., working at surf shops and swimming pools. But Johnson eventually was lured to Oregon State University while visiting friends and family in the state.
å¦   His wife, Durinda, also loved to be active, and the two married in an outdoor ceremony in 2007. They moved to Okinawa when he was stationed there, setting up a home and adopting a couple of pets. Then he was sent to Afghanistan.
å¦   Johnson, 25, was killed Sept. 8 in Kunar province during an insurgent attack.
å¦   He had graduated from OSU in 2006, where he was in the Marine ROTC. He was commissioned as a 2nd lieutenant the same day he graduated.
å¦   "He was just a hard-working, dedicated kid," Chase said.
å¦   Johnson is survived by his wife, parents, a twin brother, Dan, and brother Steve.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Combat Assault Battalion, 3rd Marine Division, III Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Three Marines died Sept. 8 while supporting combat operations in Kunar province, Afghanistan
Bio:
å¦   A few years ago on Thanksgiving, Aaron M. Kenefick asked his mom what time dinner would be served. He wanted to make sure he'd have time to visit patients at the Veterans Administration hospital.
å¦   "That's where the true heroes are," Kenefick told his mother, Susan Price.
å¦   "I just smiled and said, 'That's why I love you so much,'" Price recalled telling her son.
å¦   Kenefick himself was the recipient of a Purple Heart after he was wounded by shrapnel in Afghanistan. A fellow Marine died next to him; a sandbag saved Kenefick's life, said his sister, Jade Myszka.
å¦   Two days later on Sept. 8, the 30-year-old from Roswell, Ga., was killed in an ambush in Kunar province. He had been stationed in Okinawa. He enlisted in the Marines immediately after high school.
å¦   He was twice named Marine of the Year during his 12-year military career.
å¦   "... He was a big part of our young athletic program, and our coaches viewed him as a leader, so I'm not surprised he took that role of leadership as a Marine," said Kevin Lester, the athletic director at Williamsville South High School in New York. Kenefick went to school there for two years.
å¦   Kenefick is survived by his mother and father; two sisters; his girlfriend; and his young daughter, Landon.

ServiceUnit: The Parachute Regiment
IncidentDetails: Was killed in Afghanistan in the early hours of Wednesday, Sept. 9. Was part of an operation to free hostages from Taliban captivity. Stephen Farrell, a journalist of dual British/Irish nationality, was freed in the operation.

The Polish army says Pfc. Artur Pyc was injured May 22 in Afghanistan's eastern Ghazni province when a roadside bomb exploded under the mine-resistant armored vehicle he was driving. He died at a military hospital in Lublin, Poland on Tuesday, Sept. 8.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, Royal 22e RÌ©giment Battle Group
IncidentDetails: Two Canadian soldiers were killed and five injured when an improvised explosive device detonated near their armoured vehicle in the vicinity of Dand District, southwest of Kandahar City at around 12:00 p.m. on Sept. 6.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, Royal 22e RÌ©giment Battle Group
IncidentDetails: Two Canadian soldiers were killed and five injured when an improvised explosive device detonated near their armoured vehicle in the vicinity of Dand District, southwest of Kandahar City at around 12:00 p.m. on Sept. 6
A French soldier was killed and nine others injured when their vehicles were hit by a improvised explosive device near Bagram Air Base, in Kapisa, northeast of Kabul.

A French soldier succumbed to his wounds on Sept. 6 after being evacuated on the American military hospital in Landstuhl,  Germany. He was injured Sept. 4 when vehicles were hit by a improvised explosive device near Bagram Air Base, in Kapisa NE of Kabul.

IncidentLocation: Deh Rahwod district, Oruzgan province, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: In the morning of Sept. 6, Dutch corporal Kevin van de Rijdt, part of the Special Task Force Unit 55, was shot and killed during a fire fight with insurgents in the Deh Rawad district of Orugan province, Afghanistan.

He was killed in an attack with an improvised explosive device near the TabarÌ© outpost, northwest of Camp Holland. He was part of an Operational Mentor and Liaison Team (OMLT), which deals with support of the Afghan army in operations and training.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Squadron, 61st Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 10 in Konar province, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained when insurgents attacked his unit using rocket-propelled grenades and small arms fire.
Bio:
å¦   Tyler E. Parten entertained the "kiddos" in Afghanistan with his harmonica, built a chicken coop and wrote warmly of the look on a man's face "when you show his child a little compassion."
å¦   Those are some of the war zone experiences he documented through photos and messages on the social networking site Facebook.
å¦   "Tough days make the good days that much better," Parten said in a mid-August posting.
å¦   The 2007 graduate of the U.S. Military Academy at West Point was assigned to Fort Carson and studied Arabic because he wanted to help target terrorist groups overseas.
å¦   "That was his reason for wanting to serve, to face the challenge and to serve others, serve his country," said his father, Dave Parten. "He wanted to lead other men."
å¦   The 24-year-old from Marianna, Ark., was doing just that when he died during an ambush Sept. 10 in Konar province.
å¦   His father said Parten's talents went beyond those of a good soldier.
å¦   "He wrote music," Dave Parten said. "He could pick up and play anything he wanted. He was just incredibly gifted."
å¦   The Marianna Lee High School graduate is also survived by his mother, Lona, and brother, Daniel.

IncidentDetails: Poland's Defense Ministry says a soldier was killed and four others injured Thursday in an exchange of fire in the eastern Ghazni province after a group of 30 Polish troops was sent to support a U.S.-Afghan force that encountered Taliban fire.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Light Armored Reconnaissance Battalion, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 10 from wounds sustained Sept. 3 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Christopher Fowlkes had just returned from a tour of duty in Iraq, but it wasn't too much to drive six hours so he could send off his buddy to Marine boot camp.
å¦   "His heart was just huge," said friend Cameron Snuggs. "He was my brother."
å¦   Snuggs said Fowlkes always wore his uniform with pride _ whether it was a Little League jersey, his Gaffney Indians high school uniform, Marine dress blues or camouflage.
å¦   "No one wore that Gaffney High School uniform like Chris did," Snuggs said.
å¦   Fowlkes, 20, of Gaffney, S.C., died Sept. 10 at a U.S. military hospital in Germany. He had been seriously wounded a week earlier in Helmand province when an improvised explosive detonated. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune.
å¦   The Rev. David Kite eulogized Fowlkes at his funeral.
å¦   "He gave laughter in situations that were really difficult to find humor," Kite said.
å¦   "He gave friendship to those who needed a friend."
å¦   Jessica LeMaster, who attended high school with Fowlkes, said it was clear in high school that he wanted to be a Marine. The two shared a love for University of Tennessee sports _ and LeMaster said she had borrowed a pair of basketball shorts from him some time ago.
å¦   Now, she'll keep them as a memento.

ServiceUnit: 4th Squadron, 73rd Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division,
IncidentDetails: Sgt. Tyler A. Juden, 23, of Winfield, Kan., died Sept. 12 in Turan, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his unit using rocket-propelled grenade and small arms fires.
Bio:
å¦   Tyler A. Juden was never one to take the middle ground.
å¦   "He was passionate with his friends, his family and the things he loved," said his father, Bob Juden. "He loved the things he loved and hated the things he hated."
å¦   Juden, 23, of Winfield, Kan., died Sept. 12 during an attack involving rocket-propelled grenades and small-arms fire in Turan.
å¦   Juden was known inside and outside the military for his shooting expertise, his family said.
å¦   It started with a BB gun he got for Christmas as a boy. By summer, he was shooting bees on the family farm.
å¦   He attended a shooting camp in New Mexico when he was 13 and returned the following year as an instructor, his father said. He went on to become a sniper and a squad leader in Afghanistan.
å¦   He was also a track athlete and started on the football team as a kicker in his freshman year at Arkansas City High School, where he graduated in 2004. He joined the Army the following year and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   He was expecting to leave the Army when his enlistment ended in 2010 and planned to be a teacher like his parents.
å¦   Juden is also survived by his mother, Reatha, and sister, Jacey.

ServiceUnit: 28th Civil Engineer Squadron
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 12 near Bala Baluk, Afghanistan, of wounds sustained from enemy fire while supporting combat operations.
Bio:
å¦   Bryan D. Berky had the focus to disarm bombs in faraway places like Afghanistan, but friends say he was also a dedicated punk rocker.
å¦   Berky and his high school classmates would often jam at Berky's house, said former Bradford High School classmate John Moore. Berky would play guitar _ the precursor to his band, My Friend the Artery," Moore said.
å¦   At school, he did what he had to for his video class: Berky would often burst into a classroom during lessons, and simply tell the teacher he had to do it for another class.
å¦   "He was really a charismatic person who got away with quite a bit," Moore said.
å¦   Berky, 25, of Melrose, Fla., died Sept. 12 when he and other soldiers were ambushed near Bala Baluk. He was assigned to Ellsworth Air Force Base. Berky enlisted in 2003, a year after graduating from high school.
å¦   A former teacher, Christie Torode, said Berky always kept busy and focused _ so it didn't surprise her that he became a detonation specialist.
å¦   "He was good at paying attention to detail, but he didn't like to sit still for too long," she said.
å¦   Berky is survived by his wife, Erin, and his infant son, Harrison.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, Royal 22e RÌ©giment
IncidentDetails: One Canadian soldier was killed and four injured when an improvised explosive device detonated near their armoured vehicle on a road in Panwjai district, southwest of Kandahar City on Sept. 13.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Army Spc. Daniel L. Cox, 23, Parsons, Kan., died Saturday in Wardak province, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained when enemy forces attacked his vehicle with an improvised-explosive device and small arms fire.
Bio:
å¦   Daniel L. Cox didn't mind working hard to help others be better, whether he was with comrades at Fort Drum or playing the sport that stole his heart: football.
å¦   He started in the Pee Wee league and worked his way up to the scout teams in practice at Parsons High School in Parsons, Kan.
å¦   "They would get knocked around a lot out there by the varsity pretty good," assistant coach Mark Pound said. "Not a lot of freshmen wanted to get out there, but Daniel was always first to volunteer."
å¦   The 23-year-old died Sept. 12 of injuries from an attack in Wardak province during his second tour. He had joined the Army even before graduating in 2005 and had special workouts to get in shape for boot camp.
å¦   Pound said Cox's on-field attitude translated to his military work.
å¦   "He never worried about his own stats or glory for himself; it was always about the team," Pound said, adding that Cox "wanted to be a part of something bigger than himself."
å¦   In his downtime, Cox enjoyed four-wheeling, fishing, old trucks and cars and tinkering with things.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Kim and Sharon, and two sisters, Jennifer and Shannon.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Army Staff Sgt. Nekl B. Allen, 29, Rochester, N.Y., died Saturday in Wardak province, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained when enemy forces attacked his vehicle with an improvised-explosive device and small arms fire.
Bio:
å¦   When Nekl Allen was home from the Army, he always found time to interact with his daughter and two sons.
å¦   Riding dirt bikes with 10-year-old Christopher. Roughhousing in the living room with 7-year-old Michael. Helping 5-year-old Grace learn to count.
å¦   "He was the most lovable person I know," said his sister, Rana Allen.
å¦   Allen, 29, of Rochester, N.Y., died Sept. 12 in Wardak province, Afghanistan, when he and a fellow soldier were attacked with an explosive and small weapons. Both were assigned to Fort Drum.
å¦   Allen, known also as Nick or Nicky, loved the outdoors. He enjoyed fishing, bow-hunting and playing paintball. He was a 1999 graduate of Churchville-Chili High School, where he was a wrestler and played fullback and linebacker for the football team.
å¦   "He showed the signs of courage by taking on big tasks, even when he was young," said his high school coach, Paul Dick.
å¦   Allen joined the Army in May 2002, prompted by the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks. He was deployed twice to Iraq before being sent to Afghanistan.
å¦   "He stepped up to serve his country because he knew it was the right thing to do," said his father-in-law, Mike Meehan.
å¦   Allen also is survived by his wife, Amy Meehan-Allen.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Three soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Sept. 16 in Helmand province, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle Sept. 15 with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   As a child, Bradley S. Bohle could often be found woodworking with his grandfather. When the pair finished their work, "Pops" would shave the ice for a couple of refreshing milkshakes.
å¦   Those grandfather-grandson days are one of Ethel Bohle's fondest memories of Bohle and her husband, Edward, who died three years ago.
å¦   Not too long ago, Brad Bohle's father came to tell Ethel Bohle that her grandson had died.
å¦   "He said, 'I guess Brad and Pop are having a milkshake,'" Ethel Bohle said.
å¦   Bohle, 29, of Glen Burnie, Md., died Sept. 16 when the Humvee he was riding in hit a roadside bomb in Helmand province. He was assigned to Fort Bragg and had been in the military since graduating from North County High School in 1998.
å¦   His aunt Shirley Bohle recalled the last time she spoke to him, remembering Bradley Bohle as an "all-American kid" who loved playing with his children.
å¦   "We were eating crabs and talking about whether we liked them spicy or not and what beer goes well with them," she said.
å¦   His sister, April Clark, said her brother was her hero.
å¦   "When I was upset he'd always hug me, and even if I wasn't he would," she said.
å¦   Bohle is also survived by his wife, three daughters and parents.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Three soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Sept. 16 in Helmand province, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle Sept. 15 with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   When Shawn McCloskey was working in the construction industry several years ago, he'd hunt for excuses to go back to the same home improvement store he was always going to.
å¦   He wasn't necessarily interested in what was on the shelves. He wanted to build a romance with a woman named Jessica _ who would eventually become his wife.
å¦   "He didn't boast about anything," Jessica McCloskey said of her husband. "He was always helpful. He was always willing to give 110 percent to his friends. He was a guy's guy."
å¦   McCloskey 33, of Peachtree City, Ga., was killed by a roadside bomb Sept. 16 in Helmand province. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   The Green Beret, who was an avid Notre Dame football fan, enlisted in the military after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. In his obituary, McCloskey's family wrote "he knew who he was and who he was fighting for."
å¦   It was his third overseas deployment.
å¦   Besides his wife, other survivors include his daughter, Katie; son, Collin; his parents; a sister; and two nieces.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Three soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Sept. 16 in Helmand province, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle Sept. 15 with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   When Joshua M. Mills was young, he aspired to two careers, and only one was in the military.
å¦   "He wanted to be a paleontologist," said his older brother, Quent. "He loved dinosaurs."
å¦   But he also loved being a Green Beret. Mills graduated from the Silva Magnet High School in his hometown of El Paso, Texas, where he was reportedly a member of the Junior ROTC and was on the rifle team. He joined the Army in 2005 and was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Family was important to Mills, and despite training and deployment, he almost always made it home for Christmas, his brother said.
å¦   "He would always try to surprise you," Quent Mills said. "He'd come into town, but he wouldn't tell you. He would just show up on your doorstep."
å¦   The 24-year-old died of wounds from a roadside bomb in Helmand province on Sept. 16, about two months after deploying to Afghanistan.
å¦   Quent Mills said his brother followed in the footsteps of their father, Tommy, who was an air defense soldier at Fort Bliss.
å¦   Joshua Mills is also survived by his wife, Magen; a son, Malaki; his mother, Celeste; and his brothers.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Duke of Lancaster's Regiment
IncidentDetails: died after his platoon became locked in an exchange of fire with the enemy during a foot patrol in the Babaji district of Helmand province on Sept. 13. He received a gunshot wound to the neck and despite efforts to save him, died of his wounds.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 501st Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team (Airborne), 25th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Army Pfc. Matthew M. Martinek, 20, died Friday at Landstuhl Regional Medical Center in Landstuhl, Germany, of wounds suffered in Paktika province, Afghanistan, Sept. 4 when enemy attacked his vehicle with an improvised-explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Friends and family say Matthew M. Martinek had a sparkle in his eyes, maybe the seed of the smile he drew out of others.
å¦   "If you were in a bad mood, he always did something to cheer you up y'know, one of those clowns," said Ryne Jones, who worked with him at a car care center in Martinek's hometown of DeKalb, Ill.
å¦   Martinek, 20, died Sept. 11 at Landstuhl Regional Medical Center in Germany, of wounds suffered earlier in a roadside ambush in Paktika province.
å¦   "He tried not to talk too much about what he was doing, but he said he liked helping people," said his brother, Travis Wright.
å¦   The Bartlett High School football player graduated in 2007 and joined the Army the next year, following a family tradition that included his grandfather, uncle and two older brothers.
å¦   His stepmother, Char DeGand, said he loved the outdoors _ snowboarding, camping, all-terrain vehicles _ and had an impressive tan for someone stationed at Fort Richardson, Alaska.
å¦   She said he was an organ donor, helping to save other soldiers even after his death.
å¦   Martinek also is survived by his father, Michael; mother, Cheryl Brandes Ferguson; and brothers Frank and Michael Jr.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 1st Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade Combat Team, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device Sept. 14 in southern Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   David Wright II didn't let his football and track talent go to waste after graduating from Moore High School in his hometown of Moore, Okla. He went to the University of Oklahoma on a track scholarship and earned a bachelor's degree in criminal justice in 2006.
å¦   He didn't let that training go unused, either. Wright enlisted in the Army and was chosen almost immediately to serve as a platoon leader at Fort Benning.
å¦   "It was 9/11 that did it for David," the Rev. Randy Nail said at his memorial. "He wanted to do something about it, and he did."
å¦   The 26-year-old was killed Sept. 14 by a roadside bomb in southern Afghanistan. He was assigned to Fort Lewis.
å¦   After being deployed to Afghanistan in July, Wright wrote home about the honor he felt for his country and his fellow soldiers as they protected a village. He said he had no hard feelings toward the villagers, though some were angry with the soldiers.
å¦   "These people deserve a better existence," he wrote, "and hopefully my efforts will help, in a small way, provide that to them."
å¦   That letter was waiting for his parents, Tim and Michele, when they returned to Oklahoma after receiving his body.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 1st Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade Combat Team, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device Sept. 14 in southern Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Andrew McConnell's fellow soldiers remembered him as a walking encyclopedia, able to recite random trivia at any moment _ and a man with an intense personality.
å¦   "He was 100 mph, 100 percent of the time," Staff Sgt. Philip McIlroy said during McConnell's eulogy.
å¦   McConnell, 24, of Carlisle, Pa., died Sept. 14 in southern Afghanistan when his vehicle hit a roadside bomb. He was assigned to Fort Lewis, and although he listed Carlisle as his hometown, he considered the northwest home.
å¦   He was the son of a military man and moved around a lot _ he was born in California, went to high school in Italy and attended Georgia Military College. His sister Ashlee said Washington was his true home, however. It was where he met his wife, Sarah, who is expecting the couple's first child.
å¦   Ashlee McConnell said her brother was married for only seven months before his death, but said "they were seven months that made Andrew the happiest man in the world, and they were seven months that I know Andrew is thanking God for right now in Heaven."
å¦   McConnell enlisted in 2005 and was on his first deployment. His father, Col. Gregory "Scott" McConnell previously was deployed to Iraq.
å¦   In addition to his wife, father and sister, McConnell is survived by his mother and three other sisters.

ServiceUnit: 57th Expeditionary Signal Battalion, 11th Signal Brigade, III Corps
IncidentDetails: He died Sept. 15 at Kandahar Airfield, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained when a military vehicle struck him while conducting physical training.
Bio:
å¦   Demetrius Void was always focused on academics in high school: Teachers said he never shied away from asking for help and had a competitive nature.
å¦   "He kept at it until he figured out that calculus," said math teacher Sharlene Foster.
å¦   But Void also always wanted to be different. He decided not to apply for college and instead chose to follow his family's tradition of military service.
å¦   "He said he was tired of school," said his uncle Keith Void. "He said he was tired of being smart."
å¦   Void, 20, of Orangeburg, S.C., died Sept. 15 at Kandahar Airfield of injuries sustained when a military vehicle struck him while he was jogging. He was assigned to Fort Hood. The military has said it is investigating the hit-and-run accident.
å¦   Demetrius Void was disciplined before he joined the Army, being active in the JROTC at Orangeburg-Wilkinson High School.
å¦   "He greeted students at the front desk and said, 'You can't go in there until you get your pants up. ... This is an order,'" recalled Angelia Fersner, the school's guidance counselor, who called Void her "acting secretary."
å¦   Void is survived by his mother and two brothers.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Royal Tank Regiment
IncidentDetails: Hall died on Sept. 16 at the Royal Centre for Defence Medicine, Selly Oak, following injuries sustained when an explosion hit his Combat Logistic Patrol in rural north west Helmand province.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Rifles
IncidentDetails: McGrath was killed as a result of an explosion in Gereshk district, Helmand province, on the afternoon of Sept. 16, dying from his wounds before he could be extracted to hospital.

ServiceUnit: 186st Parachute Regiment "Lightning"
IncidentDetails: A suicide car bomber killed six Italian soldiers Thursday in the heavily guarded capital of Kabul. The bomber rammed his explosives-filled car into two Italian military vehicles in a convoy about midday, said Italian Defense Minister Ignazio La Russa.
Bio: Born in 1974.

ServiceUnit: 187th Parachute Regiment "Lightning"
IncidentDetails: A suicide car bomber killed six Italian soldiers Thursday in the heavily guarded capital of Kabul. The bomber rammed his explosives-filled car into two Italian military vehicles in a convoy about midday, said Italian Defense Minister Ignazio La Russa.
Bio: Born in 1972.

ServiceUnit: 186st Parachute Regiment "Lightning"
IncidentDetails: A suicide car bomber killed six Italian soldiers Thursday in the heavily guarded capital of Kabul. The bomber rammed his explosives-filled car into two Italian military vehicles in a convoy about midday, said Italian Defense Minister Ignazio La Russa.
Bio: Born in 1983.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 1st Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade Combat Team, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 16 at Landstuhl Regional Medical Center in Landstuhl, Germany, from a non-combat related illness, after becoming ill Sept. 11 in southern Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Robert Gordon couldn't enlist until he was 18, so he until then, he played out his dream of being a soldier with his G.I. Joes.
å¦   "If I had all the money we spent on G.I. Joes, I'd be set," said his mother, Diane Gordon. "But it carried through until the age he could sign up on his own."
å¦   Gordon, 22, of River Falls, Ala., died Sept. 16 at a U.S. military hospital in Landstuhl, Germany, after contracting an illness Sept. 11 while serving in southern Afghanistan. He was assigned to Fort Lewis, and had enlisted after graduating from Red Level High School.
å¦   His father died at a young age, and Gordon was raised by his mother.
å¦   "We always knew he was going into the military. He put on a tough front for his friends, but deep down, he was such a sweet, sweet boy," Diane Gordon said. "His daddy was an infantryman, so that made up his mind."
å¦   Diane Gordon said she was proud of her son for doing what he always dreamed of.
å¦   "That's the kind of person he was," she said.
å¦   "He had a mischievious streak, and when he made up his mind, that was it."
å¦   Gordon is also survived by a brother and sister.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, Royal 22e RÌ©giment
IncidentDetails: One Canadian soldier was killed when an improvised explosive device detonated in the vicinity of his vehicle while on patrol in Panjwai district, southwest of Kandahar City on Sept. 17.

ServiceUnit: 7th Engineer Battalion, 10th Sustainment Brigade, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 17 in Kandahar, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Jeremiah Monroe liked to build and fix things, and his brother said he was a master tradesman.
å¦   "You name a blue-collar trade, he could do it," Robert Monroe said of his older brother. Robert Monroe said he had a strong relationship with Jeremiah, forged through the family's hard times.
å¦   "We haven't had the easiest life. There wasn't any little brother, big brother," said Robert Monroe, who also is in the military. "We were together as one."
å¦   Jeremiah Monroe, 31, of Niskayuna, N.Y., was killed in Kandahar when the vehicle in which he was riding hit a roadside bomb. He was a combat engineer assigned to Fort Drum. He joined the Army in March 2008 and was on his first deployment to Afghanistan, Army officials said.
å¦   Monroe enjoyed drawing motorcycles and cars, and served as a mentor in the Big Brothers Big Sisters program, his family said in his obituary.
å¦   Monroe's great-aunt, Netty Manning, said her great-nephew was well-liked and was happy to use his skills in the military.
å¦   "It made him grow up a little bit more," she said. "He was happy to be there and protecting us and doing what he could protecting his country."
å¦   Monroe is also survived by his daughter, mother and grandmother.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Sharing, 3rd Mechanized Infantry Company, Royal Life Guards
IncidentDetails: A Danish soldier was killed early Saturday morning when his division came under fire during a patrol. He died in the green zone where the division was about to solve a common problem with our partners from the Afghan and the British army.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 508th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Sept. 20 in Zabul province, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained during a vehicle rollover.
Bio:
