å¦   Ashley West was determined to marry the man she called her "everything."
å¦   Her boyfriend, Corey Kowall, was over in Afghanistan with the Army. They'd have to get through that first and make sure he safely returned home.
å¦   "He was the most amazing person I ever met," West said. "He had a great sense of humor and always treated people the way they wanted to be treated. He was the best boyfriend, and I wanted to spend the rest of my life with him."
å¦   She wouldn't get that chance. Kowall, 20, of Murfreesboro, Tenn., was killed Sept. 20 in a vehicle rollover in Zabul province. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   West was gearing up to move in with him on the base, and she hoped to attend North Carolina State University about an hour away. She was just waiting for him to come home in March.
å¦   Kowall's father, C.J., said his son was his personal hero.
å¦   "When I didn't think I could make it, he was my inspiration and made me laugh," C.J. Kowall said.
å¦   Many friends and family said they were happy Kowall lived his dream of serving his country.
å¦   "At a young age, he understood what it was to be an American, said his mother, Kelly Rae Speight.
å¦   In addition to his parents and girlfriend, Kowall is survived by two sisters.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 508th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Sept. 20 in Zabul province, Afghanistan of injuries sustained during a vehicle rollover.
Bio:
å¦   Damon Winkleman loved science and the outdoors _ whether at the lake near his house or Carolina Beach.
å¦   "There wasn't a tree, animal or piece of anatomy he couldn't identify," his family wrote in his obituary. Winkleman also loved playing in his "garage band" in high school, fishing and woodworking.
å¦   Winkleman, 23, of Lakeville, Ohio, died Sept. 20 in Zabul province when his vehicle overturned. The crash also killed a soldier riding with him. They were on their way to help another unit facing enemy fire.
å¦   Winkleman was a combat medic assigned to Fort Bragg. He graduated from Loudonville High School in 2004.
å¦   Winkleman played football and baseball in high school and continued to follow sports, though an Army chaplain who met him at Fort Bragg said he had unusual favorites.
å¦   "He loved the Ohio State Buckeyes and the Pittsburgh Steelers, a combination most of us in North Carolina never heard of and still don't understand," said Capt. Larry McCarthy.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Richard and Patricia; two brothers, one of whom is currently deployed to Iraq; two nephews; and several aunts and uncles.

ServiceUnit: 32nd Transportation Company, 68th Combat Sustainment Support Battalion, 43rd Sustainment Brigade, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 19 at Bagram Airfield, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked Bagram Airfield using indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   David A. Davis always had a way of making others smile. Before joining the Army, he worked at a United supermarket near his hometown of Dalhart, Texas, and was happy to help customers with their groceries.
å¦   "When you'd go to United, he knew who you were by name, and you didn't even have to take your keys," local resident Angela Reynolds said. "He took your keys and took it out to the car for you."
å¦   His love of Texas showed even in Afghanistan. While other soldiers slept in normal pajamas, Davis always wore "Texas PJs," Army Maj. Gen. Thomas Robinson said. He said Davis had a great sense of humor but was selfless and serious when he needed to be.
å¦   Davis, 28, died Sept. 19 at Bagram Air Field, Afghanistan, when the facility was attacked with indirect fire.
å¦   "He always had a smile on his face, and I'm sure when he was over there, I'm sure he was still smiling," said Reynolds, who first met Davis at church.
å¦   The 2000 graduate of Dalhart High School also had served two tours in Iraq. He was assigned to Fort Carson.
å¦   Davis is survived by his wife, Devon; six children and stepchildren; his parents, Bernard Davis and Vicky Williamson; and a brother, Roy.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Mercian Regiment (Worcesters and Foresters)
IncidentDetails: Lockett MC died on Sept. 21 while on a dismounted patrol near Patrol Base SANDFORD in the Gereshk district of Helmand province when an explosion detonated, killing him before he could be extracted.
Bio: At Garmsir in 2007, as Platoon Sergeant in A (Grenadier) Company he displayed selfless commitment and unshakable bravery fighting and leading his Platoon to rescue wounded comrades trapped in a Taleban ambush. For his actions that night he received one of the nation's highest awards for gallantry, The Military Cross.

ServiceUnit: 569th Engineer Company, 4th Engineer Battalion
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 21 in Kandahar, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Master Sgt. Lloyd Lee Meredith was a bit surprised when his son, William "Lee" Meredith, called to say he had joined the military.
å¦   "Lee is the kindest, gentlest soul I have ever met in my life," the elder Meredith said. "He never had a hard word for anybody. Would never fight anybody. He was not a fighter. He was very passive."
å¦   It was even more surprising that Lee had chosen a combat specialty. Sandy Mahoney, the mother of Lee Meredith's best friend Chris, said the timid boy had blossomed after the Army.
å¦   "I never saw him stand so tall and proud as in his uniform," Mahoney said.
å¦   Meredith, 26, of Virginia Beach, Va., was killed Sept. 21 in Kandahar after enemy forces attacked the vehicle in which he was riding. He was assigned to Fort Carson.
å¦   Mahoney fondly remembered all the times her son spent with Meredith, including the time Meredith lived with her and her son. Chris Mahoney had a bunk bed, and the two would argue over who would get the top bunk.
å¦   Now, Meredith was a guy who loved music and playing video games, and had hoped to propose soon to his longtime girlfriend.
å¦   "He took life day by day _ just trying to get by," Chris Mahoney said of his friend.

ServiceUnit: 9th Aircraft Maintenance Squadron
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 12 as a result of a non-hostile incident in the Mediterranean.
Bio:
å¦   James Hornbarger was described as a dedicated and selfless airman who died supporting operations in Afghanistan.
å¦   "James' incredible selflessness and devotion to the ideas our nation was built upon are an inspiration," California Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said in a statement after Hornbarger's death.
å¦   Hornbarger, 33, died Sept. 12 as a result of a non-hostile incident in the Mediterranean.
å¦   He was assigned to the 9th Aircraft Maintenance Squadron, U.S. Air Force, Beale Air Force Base near Marysville, Calif., and he had ties to Washington state, where his mother and stepfather, Linda and Richard Raab, of Yakima, live.
å¦   Hornbarger, who enlisted in the military in 1996, was stationed in Cyprus when he died.
å¦   He is survived by his mother and stepfather, his wife, Tara, and daughter, Asia, in Marysville, Calif.

ServiceUnit: 4th Battalion, 23rd Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade Combat Team, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Three soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Sept. 24 in Omar Zai, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive dev
Bio:
å¦   Titus Reynolds was both the neighborhood helper and organizer _ and a pretty good-looking one at that.
å¦   His father, Rod Reynolds, reaclled many waitresses giving his son their phone numbers when the family would go out to eat.
å¦   "It happened many times," the elder Reynolds said.
å¦   Reynolds, 23, of Columbus, Ohio, died Sept. 24 in Omar Zai when his vehicle hit a roadside bomb. He was assigned to Fort Lewis. He graduated from Reynoldsburg High School in 2005.
å¦   Childhood friend Emil Davitian, 25, recalled that Reynolds' home was the hotspot for get-togethers among friends, typically planned by Reynolds.
å¦   "We would get together and have video game tournaments," he said. " The Sony PlayStation was at my house, and the Nintendo 64 was at his."
å¦   Reynolds could also often be seen helping neighbors haul groceries inside, or playing electric guitar and bass for his church band.
å¦   "Titus would do anything for you," said neighbor Sheryl Sycks. "He was nice and mannerly, such a sweet kid."
å¦   In addition to his father, the soldier is survived by his wife, Nikki; his mother; and two brothers and a sister.

ServiceUnit: 4th Battalion, 23rd Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade Combat Team, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Three soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Sept. 24 in Omar Zai, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Edward Bernard Smith loved talking about the military with his grandfather.
å¦   "He would always tell me about the new technology, the new weapons they had," said Smith's grandfather, Edward Parrish.
å¦   But Smith was scared, too _ he knew the risks and was afraid he may not make it home. His sister, June Render of Atlanta, recalled her brother thanking her for her prayers.
å¦   "'Thanks sis, I needed to hear that,'" she recalled him saying.
å¦   Smith, 30, of Homestead, Fla., was killed Sept. 24 in Omar Zai when the vehicle in which he was riding was hit by a roadside bomb. He was assigned to Fort Lewis. He graduated from South Dade Senior High. He enlisted in 2002, inspired to join by the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.
å¦   The soldier was close to his grandparents _ his mother, Sophia Smith Carter died in 1997 at age 32. He was one of eight children and was close to his family.
å¦   "He loved his family, and really appreciated what family meant," said his aunt Yalunda Evans. "He was the one who always pulled the family together."
å¦   Smith is also survived by his wife, Jamie, and two stepchildren. He is preceded in death by a brother, Samuel Smith, who was killed in a car crash earlier this year.

ServiceUnit: 4th Battalion, 23rd Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade Combat Team, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Three soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Sept. 24 in Omar Zai, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   If any guys messed with Joseph White's sisters, they knew they would have to answer to him.
å¦   "He was very protective of his teenage sisters," White's mother, Robyn White, wrote in an e-mail to The Seattle Times. "Joseph White is our hero and will be greatly missed by many, many people."
å¦   White, 21, of Bellevue, Wash., was killed Sept. 24 in Omar Zai when when his vehicle was attacked with an improvised explosive. Two other soldiers also died in the attack.
å¦   White was committed to his two brothers and seven sisters, his mother said. He also loved the outdoors, and his favorite pastimes included playing Frisbee, golf and paintball.
å¦   While on leave during the Christmas holiday, White proposed to his wife. The two married in May, a month and a half before his deployment, his family said.
å¦   "Joe was not happy to be leaving his bride to go to Afghanistan, but he did not complain. Rather, he went with a strong sense of duty and desire to maintain freedom and safety for others," his mother wrote.
å¦   She said her son was home-schooled and took some classes at Bellevue Community College before joining the Army in 2006.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Foreign Infantry Regiment (2nd REI)
IncidentDetails: On Sept. 27, a French soldier was killed in a road accident involving a vehicle ahead shielded (VAB), east of Kabul. He was helping to rally the base TORA in Surobi, with their section, when their vehicle left the road and fell into a ravine below.
Bio: He joined the French ranks February 15, 2006 from his native Russia. The State Secretary of Veterans Affairs conferred military medal and the Cross of Military Valor to order the Army Corps posthumously to Corporal Chechulin.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 3rd Marine Regiment, 3rd Marine Division
ServiceUnitLocation: Marine Corps Base Hawaii, Kaneohe Bay
IncidentDetails: Lance Cpl. John J. Malone, 24, of Yonkers, N.Y., died Sept. 24 while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   John Malone liked to see his friends smiling.
å¦   So if they weren't, he'd try to change that.
å¦   "You would never have a bad day because he would always make you smile," a friend, Zahara Majeed, told the Journal News in Yonkers, N.Y.
å¦   He was friendly and polite and could light up a room.
å¦   "He was an all-around good Marine," said Marco Kilcawley, who served with Malone in Iraq and Afghanistan. "He made everyone happy, even when we were around the field cold and miserable."
å¦   Malone, 24, of Yonkers was killed Sept. 24 during fighting in Farah province. He was assigned to Marine Corps Base Hawaii, Kaneohe Bay.
å¦   Malone, a graduate of Charles E. Gorton High School, had looked forward to serving in the military, friends and family members said.
å¦   "It was a dream that he always wanted to do," said his mother, Maria Pacheco. "It was something he had always talked about."
å¦   Malone joined the Marines in February 2007 and was deployed to Iraq a year later. His Afghanistan deployment was in May.
å¦   Malone also had a passion for music and had written and produced some songs.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 17th Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade Combat Team, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: Spc. Kevin J. Graham, 27, of Benton, Ky., died Sept. 26 in Kandahar, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Kevin Graham loved muscle cars. It started when he built a 1939 with his dad and brother, and culminated in his prized vehicle: A 1965 Pontiac LeMans.
å¦   "He loved to drive that thing," said Graham's brother, Sean Graham. "That was his pride and joy. He was always working on that thing, always driving and washing it."
å¦   Graham, 27, of Benton, Ky., was killed Sept. 26 when the vehicle in which he was riding hit a roadside bomb. He was assigned to Fort Lewis.
å¦   Sean Graham said his brother always wanted to be a soldier, dressing up in Army gear, playing Army games and eagerly listening to stories of World War II and Vietnam. He enlisted in 2007.
å¦   "He had always been that way and I fully supported his decision to go into the Army," Sean Graham said. "It took a while for him to make that decision. When he did, I was so proud of him."
å¦   Jonathan Goodman, the pastor at Calvary Baptist Church in Benton, said Graham was proud to serve his country, noting that the congregation often prayed for him when his parents brought reports to the church.
å¦   Graham is survived by his parents and three older brothers, including Sean.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 26 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan
Bio:
å¦   Jordan Chrobot's wedding in his grandparents' back yard was a long time coming.
å¦   "I immediately fell in love with him. I was about 11 years old," said his wife, Amber. "One day he told me he loved me, and that was it."
å¦   She spoke with him for about a half-hour before he went out on a mission, and the whole time he was "being silly and joking" as he thanked her for packages from home, said Chrobot's mother, Kandy Poole Johns. It was the last mission he'd head out for.
å¦   Chrobot, 24, of Frederick, Md., died Sept. 26 in combat in Helmand province. He was assigned to Camp Lejeune. He graduated from New Life Christian School in 2003.
å¦   Friends and family said he was proud to be a Marine and help other Marines. An unnamed neighbor said Chrobot came home from a deployment before he did and spent extra time helping the neighbor's wife do chores around the house.
å¦   Justin Coffey, a friend from New Life, recalled the last time he saw Chrobot before he deployed to Afghanistan.
å¦   "He opened the trunk and pulled out his helmet and just said, 'Look at my helmet.' He was just so proud to be a Marine," Coffey said.
å¦   He is also survived by a his stepfather; his father and stepmother; three siblings; and numerous other relatives.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion The Royal Welsh
IncidentLocation: Musa Qaleh district, Helmand province, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: He died as a result of an explosion that happened during a vehicle patrol in Musa Qaleh district, northern Helmand province.

ServiceUnit: 13thRDP  Parachute Dragoon Regiment, Dragons
IncidentDetails: On the night of Sept. 26, three French soldiers died accidentally in Kapisa, province. Due to violent storms, one, belonging to the 13th (RDP Parachute Regiment, Dragons), was swept away by flash flooding of a river during the disengagement phase.

ServiceUnit: 13th RDP  Parachute Dragoon Regiment, Dragons
IncidentDetails: On the night of Sept. 26, three French soldiers died accidentally in Kapisa, province. Due to violent storms, one is swept away by flash flooding of a river. A noncommissioned officer in his unit, went looking, disappears. The two were found dead at dawn.

ServiceUnit: 3rd RIMA (Regiment Marine Corps), Vannes
IncidentDetails: On the night of Sept. 26, three French soldiers  accidentally in Kapisa province. Due to violent storms, one is stricken by lightning during the phase of infiltration. Despite attempts, he can not be revived.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 121st Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails: died Sept. 30 in Kwhost, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his unit using an improvised-explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Alex French had a thing for the spinach-gobbling "Popeye" the sailor man as a child and followed his own dream of being a sailor.
å¦   French was honorably discharged in 2000 and continued his career in public service, becoming a sheriff's deputy. But he wanted to keep serving his country and later joined the National Guard.
å¦   "It was in him to do that," said his sister Latoya French. " When you'd see him, you'd think he belonged in uniform."
å¦   French, 31, of Milledgeville, Ga., died Sept. 30 in Kwhost when enemy forces bombed his unit. He was assigned to Lawrenceville, Ga.
å¦   Another sister, Laquitta French Basley, said she often talked to her brother online while he was deployed. He always asked to make sure things were OK back in Georgia, rarely talking about himself.
å¦   French was always close to his family, Basley said, and always protective of his sisters.
å¦   "He was a rock," she said.
å¦   Bibb County Sheriff Jerry Modena said French was an intelligent sergeant in the booking division who worked hard to rise through the ranks.
å¦   "He had a good career ahead of him," Modena said. "To have it terminated so early, it's a waste."

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 1st Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Sept. 29 in Jolo Island, the Philippines, from the detonation of an improvised-explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Christopher D. Shaw was fast, a former standout runner at Natchez High School in Natchez, Mississippi.
å¦   "I think he held the state record at one time," former classmate Kareem West said. "He was maybe one of the best track stars ever at the school."
å¦   That talent earned him a track and field scholarship at Texas Southern University, where he studied history. He enlisted in the Army Reserve in 1994 and put his studies on hold to join active duty the following year.
å¦   "He was the best God could have put out here," Camille Felton said of her oldest son.
å¦   Shaw, 37, of Markham, Ill., was killed Sept. 29 on Jolo Island in the Philippines by a bomb buried under the road. Officials said he was part of a task force helping to quell militants there. He was assigned to Fort Lewis, and it was his second deployment.
å¦   "He was a nice, good kid," said his stepfather, Willie Felton. "He didn't do anybody any harm."
å¦   Shaw enjoyed motorcycles and talking about sports, but his family was his priority, Felton said.
å¦   The Mississippi native is survived by his wife, Attina; five children; his father, mother and stepfather; two brothers; and two sisters.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 1st Special Forces Group
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Sept. 29 in Jolo Island, the Philippines from the detonation of an improvised-explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Jack M. Martin III dreamed of working as an educator or finding another way to help people when his time in the military ended, his family said.
å¦   The 26-year-old from Bethany, Okla., was helping to resupply a school construction project in the Philippines when he was killed Sept. 29 by a bomb buried beneath a road on Jolo Island. Military officials said he was part of a task force deployed to help quell militants there.
å¦   Martin, the youngest of five children, was born in Iowa and grew up there and in Oklahoma. He played football and was an honors student at Bethany High School, graduating in 2001.
å¦   He started out in the Army Reserve before studying at the University of Central Oklahoma, said his father, Jack Martin Jr., adding that his son was in basic training during the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
å¦   The younger Martin had volunteered to go to Iraq, and when that deployment was canceled, he met with a recruiter looking for special forces volunteers and became a Green Beret. He was assigned to Fort Lewis.
å¦   "He was a very kind and loving person that was very intelligent with numbers," his father said.
å¦   Martin's survivors include his wife, Ashley.

ServiceUnit: 34 Squadron Royal Air Force Regiment
IncidentDetails: A RAF Gunner was killed Thursday, Oct. 1 as a result of an explosion that happened while commanding his vehicle on a force protection patrol in the desert to the south of Camp Bastion Joint Operating Base in central Helmand province.

ServiceUnit: 4th Battalion, 101st Aviation Regiment, 159th Combat Aviation Brigade, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 1 in Wardak province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his unit using small arms fire.
Bio:
å¦   Russell Hercules couldn't be home when his son was born. But he heard the baby's first whimpers from a telephone connection _ he in Afghanistan, his family at the hospital.
å¦   When the soldier came home on leave, though, he didn't talk about Afghanistan, said his mother, Cheryl Tipton. He spent time with his family, and held that baby as much as he could.
å¦   "I would give anything in the world to have him back," Tipton said. "My son was loved by a lot of people. He will be remembered for the soldier he was."
å¦   Hercules, 22, of Murfreesboro, Tenn., died Oct. 1 during combat in Wardak province. He was a graduate of Blackman High School and was assigned to Fort Campbell.
å¦   He first became interested in enlisting in the military when he did a report on the Iraq war in high school. Both his parents served in the military. While he was in Afghanistan, he kept in frequent contact with his wife, Victoria. Just two days before he was killed, Hercules called to wish his wife a happy birthday.
å¦   He ended that conversation as he did every other: "He never said good-bye," Victoria said. "He always said, 'See you later.'"
å¦   In addition to his wife, son and mother, Hercules is survived by his father and stepdaughter.

ServiceUnit: 91st Engineer Company (Sapper),  Wisconsin Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 2 in Logar province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his vehicle using rocket-propelled grenade fire.
Bio:
å¦   Ryan C. Adams celebrated life, whether he was enjoying the outdoors by hunting and fishing or volunteering with Angels on My Shoulder, a nonprofit cancer support group dear to his heart. He had an infectious sense of compassion, his family said.
å¦   Adams joined the Wisconsin Army National Guard shortly after graduating in 2001 from Rhinelander High School, in Rhinelander, Wis., where he was a quarterback on the football team and played baseball and golf. Staff at the school remembered him as a respectful, hard-working student who made time for others, and those qualities stuck in his military life.
å¦   "He was where he wanted to be, doing what he wanted to do," his parents, Peter and Jalane, said in a statement. "He did it with pride and honor."
å¦   Adams, 26, died Oct. 2 in Logar province of wounds from an attack involving rocket-propelled grenades. He had previously served in Iraq.
å¦   "He was very proud to serve his country," said his uncle, Patrick Adams. "He was incredibly proud to be a soldier, and he loved doing what he did."
å¦   Survivors include his sister, Amanda, and dozens of aunts, uncles and cousins.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 1 in Kandahar province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his unit with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Anyone who wanted to know what career Roberto Sanchez would choose only had to look at what he was wearing on Halloween as a child.
å¦   "Halloween came around; he was GI Joe, machine gun, the whole nine yards. That's who he was," said his uncle Ken Wilson. "He fulfilled that. It makes us proud of him."
å¦   Sanchez, 24, of Satellite Beach, Fla., died Oct. 1 in Kandahar province of wounds suffered from a roadside bomb. The Army Ranger graduated from Satellite Senior High School and enlisted in the military in July 2004. He was assigned to Hunter Army Airfield.
å¦   He had previously deployed three times to Iraq and served another tour in Afghanistan before his death.
å¦   Family and friends remembered a dedicated soldier with a good sense of humor and a zest for life. Amanda Weston, wrote in an online message board that Sanchez had a commanding presence and was always there to give her a hug.
å¦   "He even earned the nickname 'handsome' Rob among my friends and I, and he had such an amazing voice," Weston wrote. "I will miss our talks, I will miss his smile."
å¦   Sanchez is survived by his parents, Will and Wendy Holland, and two brothers.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 2 in Wardak province, Afghanistan, of injuries sustained when enemy forces attacked their unit using small arms fire.
Bio:
å¦   Aaron M. Smith was raised in many places, changing towns as his Army father transferred posts, but it was after he joined the Army five years ago that he really grew up.
å¦   "When he became sergeant, he would call me and say, 'Mom, I'm raising these guys kind of like you did me,'" Ann Jones said of the son she had expected to see at home on leave in mid-October.
å¦   The 25-year-old from Manhattan, Kan., died Oct. 2 in Wardak province of injuries from an attack involving small arms fire. He was assigned to Fort Drum. It was his second tour of duty in Afghanistan.
å¦   Eventually, when his time in the military ended, Smith thought he might building homes as a carpenter.
å¦   "Always said that he wore his heart on his sleeve," Jones said. "Very gentle soul. Very caring. Kinda dorky sometimes. I always said he'd grow out of it."
å¦   Smith's family said his survivors include his mothers, Ann Jones and Rose Jones; his father, Christopher; his sister, Shannon; and brother, Logan.

ServiceUnit: 118th Military Police Company, 503rd Military Police Battalion, 16th Military Police Brigade, XVIII Airborne Corps
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 2 in Wardak province, Afghanistan of injuries sustained when enemy forces attacked their unit using small arms fire.
Bio:
å¦   Brandon Owens was a precocious boy who could hold a conversation with adults when he was as young as 4. And he was always proper, his family said.
å¦   "One time, he got in an argument with a young man across the street because he was cursing in front of me," said Owens' grandmother, Marion Jackson. "He didn't want anyone cursing in front of me."
å¦   Owens, 21, of Memphis, Tenn., died Oct. 2 in Wardak province when insurgents attacked his unit. He was assigned to Fort Bragg.
å¦   Despite his confident, outgoing nature, Owens was frightened over in Afghanistan. His mother, Lynda Owens, said he would call and sometimes cry because he couldn't sleep at night. But he joined the military with the hope it would lead to a better life.
å¦   "He wanted things in this world that you couldn't get working at McDonald's," said his brother, Eric.
å¦   Owens hoped to marry his fiancee, April Walton, when he got home in April. The pair met three years ago when Walton noticed him while he played basketball. But she was too timid to talk to him _ she sent her little sister over to get his phone number. It worked.
å¦   "I can't lie. I thought he was the handsomest guy in the gym," Walton said. "That's what caught my eye."

ServiceUnit: 1st Brigade, 1st Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 7 at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, D.C., of wounds suffered Sept. 8 when insurgents attacked his unit in the Ganjigal Valley, Afghanistan, using small arms and indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   Like his older brother, 41-year-old Kenneth Westbrook was an athlete and soldier who was proud of his Navajo heritage.
å¦   Then on Oct. 7 _ four years and six days after his older brother was killed during combat in Iraq _ Kenneth Westbrook, of Shiprock, N.M., died. He was being treated at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, D.C., for wounds suffered during a Sept. 8 attack in Ganjgal Valley.
å¦   An instructor who trained Afghanistan border police, Westbrook was about two months from retiring.
å¦   "The family's sad, of course," said David Westbrook, the late soldiers' brother. "We're leaning on our faith quite a bit. We're just putting our faith in God, and that's helping us through this."
å¦   Army Sgt. Marshall Alan Westbrook was 43 when he died in October 2005 and the first New Mexico National Guard soldier killed during combat in Iraq.
å¦   The brothers' father, Marshall Westbrook Sr., served in the Army, and he was based in locations that included Korea and Alaska. Kenneth Westbrook followed in his father's footsteps, enlisting in the Army when was 18.
å¦   "He just had to go, just had to do something," his father said.
å¦   Kenneth Westbrook was the youngest of five born to Marshall and Ruth Westbrook, of Farmington, N.M., the family said.
å¦   He is survived by his parents; wife Charlene; and sons Zachary, 20, Joshua, 18, and Joseph, 14.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Squadron, 61st Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: The death of eight soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 3 in Kamdesh, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their contingency outpost with small arms, rocket-propelled grenade and indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   Vernon W. Martin dreamed of opening a youth development center that would help mentor youngsters, and even drew up a business plan before he deployed.
å¦   "He really felt there were just too many kids who didn't have anyone," said his mother, Connie Brown.
å¦   His wife, Britanny Martin, said the soldier loved his children and wanted to make that dream come true. "He loved children, music and basketball, in that order," she said.
å¦   Martin, 25, of Savannah, Ga., died Oct. 3 in Kamdesh when insurgents attacked his unit. He was assigned to Fort Carson.
å¦   The Martins married right after high school and had three children together _ Nasine, 6; Zakiyah, 4; and Chastity, 2. Vernon Martin, who also is survived by a brother and sister, spent most of his life in Savannah and attended Johnson High School. During those years, he could often be found playing basketball at St. Pious Community Center.
å¦   "He was the best in so many ways, and loved our kids," Britanny Martin said.
å¦   The girls, Chastity and Zakiyah, are too young to understand what's happened. But Nasine knows.
å¦   "My grandson told me he doesn't want to bury his daddy," Brown said. "And I said I don't want to bury my son."

ServiceUnit: 3rd Squadron, 61st Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: The death of eight soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 3 in Kamdesh, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their contingency outpost with small arms, rocket-propelled grenade and indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   Before he died, Justin Gallegos spent most of the time that he wasn't deployed with his 5-year-old son.
å¦   When a service was held for Gallegos, 27, the boy, McAidan, sat at the graveside and was given a folded U.S. flag.
å¦   "This flag is presented on behalf of a grateful nation," Brig. Gen. Sean Macfarland told the boy.
å¦   Those close to Gallegos say the soldier had been especially close to his son.
å¦   "He was a hero because he loved his family," said the soldier's sister, Amber Gallegos.
å¦   Gallegos died of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked a contingency outpost in Kamdesh. He and eight other soldiers killed in Oct. 3 attacks were assigned to Fort Carson.
å¦   Gallegos received a Bronze Star Medal, Purple Heart, National Defense Service Medal, two NATO Medals and a number of other honors.
å¦   He grew up in Tucson, Ariz. Before enlisting in 2005, Gallegos played football at Tucson High Magnet School from 1996 until 2000, then transferred to Aztec Middle College and graduated there.
å¦   Pfc. Rene McCormick, an Army National Guard member who played football with Gallegos, also said his teammate was a hero.
å¦   "One of the best men that we knew," McCormick said.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Squadron, 61st Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: The death of eight soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 3 in Kamdesh, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their contingency outpost with small arms, rocket-propelled grenade and indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   Joshua Hardt called the small town of Applegate, Calif., home. And when he got to visit, he liked nothing more than being with his wife, playing with his niece and fishing in the Sierra Nevada mountains.
å¦   Hardt's mother, Shelley Bell, said her son pursued a military career because he wanted to provide for his wife and serve his country.
å¦   "He was a very giving son," Bell said. "He went into the Army wanting to make a difference."
å¦   Hardt, 24, joined the Army in 2006. He died in Kamdesh of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked a contingency outpost. He was assigned to Fort Carson.
å¦   He received military honors that include a Bronze Star Medal, Purple Heart, National Defense Service Medal and NATO Medal.
å¦   Some 350 people attended his service in Auburn, Calif., where he was remembered through words and photographs as an outdoorsman, a smiling and rambunctious 6-year-old, a high school linebacker and a loving husband to his wife, Olivia.
å¦   "I'm sure Josh is looking down and seeing this crowd, saying 'people liked me,'" said Hardt's brother Sgt. John Hardt. "He was more than a brother _ he was my best friend and there for me when I needed it most."

ServiceUnit: 3rd Squadron, 61st Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: The death of eight soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 3 in Kamdesh, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their contingency outpost with small arms, rocket-propelled grenade and indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   Army Sgt. Joshua Kirk was anything but passive.
å¦   "He was a real aggressive guy," said David Eng, an instructor at Southern Maine Community College, where Kirk took construction technology classes. "He would jump right into projects as a lead person."
å¦   Kirk, of South Portland, Maine, used the same kind of assertiveness after being convinced a young woman he met at the college, Megan, was the one for him.
å¦   "It took three times of Joshua persisting to Megan that she marry him, and the third time, she said yes," said the Rev. Marc Montminy of St. Michael Parish in Exeter, N.H.
å¦   Montminy made the comment at a Mass for Kirk, 30, who died Oct. 3 in Kamdesh when insurgents attacked his contingency outpost. He was assigned to Fort Carson.
å¦   He and Megan Gavin-Kirk had been married four years and have a daughter, Kensington. Friends say Kirk was a devoted husband and father.
å¦   "Meg, you brought the sun into his life and forever changed him. Kens, you made it even brighter and completed him," Mike and Becky Fessler posted on an online memorial to Kirk.
å¦   Besides his wife and daughter, Kirk is survived by his mother and five sisters.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Squadron, 61st Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: The death of eight soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 3 in Kamdesh, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their contingency outpost with small arms, rocket-propelled grenade and indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   It was no surprise that Michael Scusa joined the Army after finishing high school in 2005.
å¦   A favorite childhood pastime was playing military video games. As a teen, he loaded up a backpack with bricks and marched around the neighborhood wearing it, an attempt to simulate one of the rigors of Army life.
å¦   Scusa, of Villas, N.J., was even more certain of a military career when the country was attacked Sept. 11, 2001, during his freshman year at Lower Cape May Regional High School.
å¦   "There were some people who didn't want him to join the military, and that sometimes bothered him," his brother, James Woodard, wrote in a tribute online. "I would (assure) him to do what he wanted to do, and what he felt was right, and that is exactly what he did."
å¦   Scusa, 22, died in an Oct. 2 attack in Kamdesh. He was assigned to Fort Carson in Colorado, where his wife, Alyssa, and 1-year-old son, Connor, live.
å¦   "He became the type of soldier every leader wants," a sergeant wrote in a note read at Scusa's funeral.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Squadron, 61st Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: The death of eight soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 3 in Kamdesh, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their contingency outpost with small arms, rocket-propelled grenade and indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   As a youngster, Christopher T. Griffin was a cheesehead, and a proud one. He grew up in Michigan, in a town called Kincheloe, but his heart was across Lake Michigan with the Green Bay Packers.
å¦   "We would pop in to see him around game time, there he was with his cheese hat on," said Marcia Griffin, who is married to Griffin's grandfather. But Griffin wasn't a couch potato.
å¦   "He was friendly, and he was a hard worker," she said. "If any of the neighbors needed their lawns mowed or anything, he would do it."
å¦   Griffin's aunt, Nikcole Johnson, said the 2004 graduate of Rudyard High School wasn't interested in college or the mostly prison jobs in his hometown but was very proud of his Army life.
å¦   The 24-year-old known sometimes as "Griff" was one of eight soldiers who died Oct. 3 in Kamdesh when their outpost came under fire. He was based at Fort Carson and previously served in Iraq, his aunt said.
å¦   Griffin was soft-spoken and unassuming but had a competitive streak and had played football and wrestled, principal Mark Pavloski told CNN. He said Griffin "wasn't one of those kids who needed to be the center of attention, but he wanted to be successful."

ServiceUnit: 3rd Squadron, 61st Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: The death of eight soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 3 in Kamdesh, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their contingency outpost with small arms, rocket-propelled grenade and indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   Stephan Mace was an avid hunter, fisherman and paintballer who loved to go on Safaris with his friend Adrian Bouwer in South Africa.
å¦   He's also the only guy Bouwer ever knew who ate raw rabbit.
å¦   "His spirit will live on in every camp fire under these skies," Bouwer said.
å¦   Mace, 21, of Lovettsville, Va., was killed Oct. 3 in Kamdesh when insurgents attacked his unit. He was assigned to Fort Carson and attended Loudoun Valley High School.
å¦   Friends and family remembered Mace at his funeral as a young man who loved sports and never gave up. His former football coach, Jeff Brown, remembered Mace's enthusiasm as a teenager when his team was in the championship game.
å¦   Mace had to hobble along on crutches because of an injury, but he never left his team's side.
å¦   "Although not the fastest or strongest, he was always the toughest," Brown said.
å¦   At a memorial service, many also recalled Mace's misgivings about going back to Afghanistan. But they said he was determined to serve with his fellow soldiers and protect the Afghan people.
å¦   "I need to get back to protect my friends and soldiers," neighbor Steve Miller recalled. "They will do anything for me and I will do anything for them."
å¦   Survivors include Mace's mother, father and three brothers.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Squadron, 61st Cavalry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: The death of eight soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 3 in Kamdesh, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their contingency outpost with small arms, rocket-propelled grenade and indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   Once, Kevin Thomson tried to convince a friend that "Ghostbusters" was the best movie in the world.
å¦   Another time, he scared his friends "half to death" with a werewolf mask. He was quick to make friends and an occasional prankster.
å¦   "All I have are good memories and every single one of them makes me smile," said friend Chris Rabe. "I've never been more proud of anybody in my life. I'm gonna miss him a lot."
å¦   Thomson, 22, was one of eight soldiers killed by insurgents Oct. 3 in Kamdesh. His unit had been deployed in Afghanistan for about six months. He was based at Fort Carson.
å¦   Thomson was born in California and grew up in Reno, Nev. He attended Wooster High School and the Academy for Career Education. He earned his GED before enlisting in the Army in April 2008.
å¦   He is survived by his mother, Deborah Rouston, and father, Douglas Thomson.

ServiceUnit: 363rd Explosive Ordnance Detachment
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 3 in Wardak province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated during an attempt to disarm it.
Bio:
å¦   Thomas Rabjohn liked trucks, sports and country music. He liked his work as a Phoenix police officer, and the challenge of explosives work _ his job with the Arizona Army National Guard.
å¦   But "more than anything," he loved his three daughters, said Army Staff Sgt. Jason Hipp, his friend.
å¦   Tall with broad shoulders, Rabjohn was looking forward to standing in the doorway of his Litchfield Park, Ariz., home when a high school boy might pick up one of his daughters _ ages 12, 13 and 14 for a date.
å¦   "When he was back home in July for a leave he talked about how much the girls had grown since he'd been deployed in February," said Rabjohn's wife, Nikki. "He missed that the most: not being around to see the changes that the kids go through everyday."
å¦   Rabjohn, 39, was killed Oct. 3 in Wardak province while he was trying to disarm a roadside bomb. He was based in Coolidge, Ariz.
å¦   Rabjohn knew his wife since grade school. They dated in high school, then reconnected a number of years later at a George Strait concert, then married in 1994.
å¦   "He always promised me that there was nothing that could keep him from coming back," Nikki told The Arizona Republic. "He used to say that he had too much to lose. But there are things that are out of our control."

ServiceUnit: 576th Mobility Augmentation Company
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 4 at Contingency Outpost Dehanna, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his unit using small arms and indirect fire.
Bio:
å¦   Kevin Hill got serious about his goals after graduating in 2004 from John Dewey High School in Brooklyn.
å¦   He enrolled at Monroe College in the Bronx and got a job as a security agent at John F. Kennedy International Airport. Despite transportation issues and other challenges, Hill got to his classes and earned a bachelor's degree in criminal justice four years later.
å¦   "He was really determined and goal-focused," said his sister, Chinyere Hill.
å¦   Next came figuring out a career. He had many ideas: detective, lawyer, Secret Service agent. He decided that military service would give him good work experience.
å¦   He joined the Army in September 2008 against the wishes of family members, especially his father, Olsen Hill, who had served in the Gulf War. With a college degree, his son had more options, he said.
å¦   Hill was assigned to Fort Carson. He was deployed to Iraq in February and relocated to Afghanistan in April. He was killed Oct. 4 when his contingency outpost was attacked.
å¦   Hill, 23, was quiet and playful and enjoyed video games and museums. He is survived by his mother, Mahalia Hill, and sister, Shantel Hill.

ServiceUnit: 422nd Civil Affairs Battalion
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 2 in Murcheh, Afghanistan, from wounds suffered when they were attacked by a suicide bomber
Bio:
å¦   When working on a mission in Africa in 2006, Army Reserve Capt. Ben Sklaver was struck by the number of Ugandan children dying because they didn't have access to clean drinking water.
å¦   After returning home, he founded the ClearWater Initiative, a nonprofit that puts simple, sustainable water projects in remote east African villages. The group says it's on track to impact 10,000 people by 2012.
å¦   Sklaver, of Hamden, Conn., was assigned to a civil affairs battalion in Greensboro, N.C. He was killed Oct. 2 in Murcheh when his unit was ambushed by a suicide bomber.
å¦   Sklaver, 32, held two degrees from Tufts University, including a master's from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy. He had recently begun a job in New York with the Federal Emergency Management Agency. He previously worked for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta.
å¦   "He could have very easily just coasted along on his talent, looking out for himself," said friend Jake Herrle. "But because of the way he saw the world and saw his place in it, he always tried to improve it."
å¦   Survivors include his parents, Gary and Laura Sklaver, his fiancee, Beth Segaloff, and her son, Danny.

ServiceUnit: 422nd Civil Affairs Battalion
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 2 in Murcheh, Afghanistan from wounds suffered when they were attacked by a suicide bomber.
Bio:
å¦   Alan Newton, a bespectacled man known as "Hubble" because of his thick eyeglasses, never complained about taking cortisone shots and having fluid drained from his knee in the field after a serious injury, his fellow soldiers said.
å¦   In fact, Newton fought to remain on the roster for deployment after the injury, said 1st Sgt. Kent Chicosky.
å¦   Newton, 26, of Asheboro, N.C., died Oct. 2 in a suicide bombing attack in Murcheh. He was based in Greensboro, N.C.
å¦   The Southwestern Randolph High School graduate played football there and was involved in JROTC. When he wasn't spending time with his daughter, Riley, he liked to riding motorcycles and four-wheelers, according to an obituary posted online.
å¦   He also enjoyed "mud bogging" _ a type of off-road racing. His family said he was a dog-lover who also liked to play video games.
å¦   Mike Walsh said Newton was engaged to his daughter, Shannon, who had several photos of her and Newton posted on her MySpace page. Mike Walsh said Newton was planning to surprise family and friends with a trip home for Thanksgiving. They weren't expecting him until Christmas.
å¦   Newton is also survived by his father, mother and stepfather.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion Grenadier Guards
IncidentLocation: Nad Ali district, Helmand province, Afghanistan
IncidentDetails: The soldier was killed as a result of an explosion that happened while on a foot patrol near to Nad e-Ali district center in central Helmand province on the morning of Oct. 5. He was mortally wounded by an improsived explosive device.

ServiceUnit: Ligera Soria 9th Infantry Regiment
IncidentDetails:
A Spanish soldier died  after his army vehicle drove over a mine near Syah Washan, on the outskirts of Herat on Wednesday morning. 
The soldiers were carrying out a security reconnaissance mission to dismantle illegal check points.
Bio: He had been awarded the UN Medal for his role in Lebanon.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Regiment Marines (3rd RIMA) Vannes
IncidentDetails: He died of his injuries Oct. 8 at Percy Military Hospital in Paris. He was wounded when an improvised explosive device hit his armored vehicle on Sept. 4 while escorting a convoy  between Bagram and Nijrab in Surobi, north of Kabul.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion Coldstream Guards
IncidentDetails: Lance Corporal Hill was killed as a result of an explosion that happened near Camp Bastion in Helmand province, Afganistan on Oct. 8.

ServiceUnit: 114th Truck Company of the Minnesota Army National Guard
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 10 in Bagram, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked his vehicle with an improvised explosive device on Oct. 7 in Helmand province.
Bio:
å¦   George W. Cauley was a perfectionist who always wanted to do things right, whether he was playing around with the mechanics to increase the speed of a small sports car or cranking out tunes on the guitar, piano and drums.
å¦   He also enjoyed playing basketball with friends, spending time on the computer and listening to music.
å¦   The 24-year-old from Walker, Minn., died Oct. 10 in Bagram of wounds from an improvised explosive attack on his vehicle three days earlier in Helmand province. He was assigned to the Minnesota Army National Guard in Duluth, Minn.
å¦   It was his first tour in Afghanistan, his family said.
å¦   The 2003 graduate of Remer High School in Remer, Minn., had enlisted in the National Guard at age 17. His family said he was known as a patient, respectful guy who stood up for others and took pride in wearing his uniform.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Richard and Gloria, about a dozen aunts and uncles and several cousins.

ServiceUnit: Polish Task Forces, 5th Regiment of Engineering
IncidentDetails: Two Polish soldier were killed on Oct. 9. They were traveling on a logistics mission when their vehicle, part of a convoy which was coming from Bagram Ghazni, hit an improvised explosive device in Wardak province, towards Highway 1.

ServiceUnit: Polish Task Forces, 5th Regiment of Engineering
IncidentDetails: Two Polish soldier were killed on Oct. 9. They were traveling on a logistics mission when their vehicle, part of a convoy which was coming from Bagram Ghazni, hit an improvised explosive device in Wardak province, towards Highway 1.

ServiceUnit: Marine Wing Support Squadron 372, Marine Wing Support Group 37, 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 9 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Aaron J. Taylor was the type to dive into an interest headfirst, and that's what he did with the Marines.
å¦   "He had spontaneous wit and was a very caring individual," said his father, Clifford. "Very intelligent. His goal was to be promoted to gunnery sergeant before his third enlistment. I think he would have made it. It's tough to do."
å¦   Taylor, 27, of Bovey, Minn., was killed Oct. 9 by an explosive while on patrol in Helmand province. He was assigned to Camp Pendleton and had previously served in Iraq.
å¦   He graduated in 2000 from Greenway High School in Coleraine, Minn., where he played trumpet in a band, wrestled and was a manager for the hockey team. He studied law enforcement at Hibbing Community College before joining the Marines in 2002.
å¦   His military work sent him globe-trotting from Spain to Japan and even Vietnam, where he assisted anthropologists recovering soldiers' remains.
å¦   "He was just a likable, personable guy. Everyone who knew him just loved him," his father said. "If the Taliban had met him, I'm sure they would have liked him."
å¦   Taylor's survivors include his mother; stepfather; brother; half-sister; and his dog, Walnut.

ServiceUnit: 2nd Battalion, 3rd Marine Regiment, 3rd Marine Division, III Marine Expeditionary Force, Marine Corps Base Hawaii
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 10 while supporting combat operations in Farah province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   When he played soccer, Alfonso Ochoa could motivate his team _ "no matter what," said fellow player Steven Levario.
å¦   Soon after Ochoa graduated high school, principal Bobby Peters began telling students about the Marine, who had goals, worked hard and made no excuses.
å¦   "His is one of those stories that I tell other kids when they may be facing some adversity in their life," Peters said.
å¦   Ochoa, 20, of Armona, Calif., enlisted shortly after his 18th birthday. So that he could graduate early, Ochoa transferred from Hanford West High to Hanford Adult School. He entered the Marine Corps in January 2008.
å¦   He was killed Oct. 10 in Farah province while supporting combat operations. He was based at Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii.
å¦   "I played soccer with Alfonso in high school great goalie, even better person always had our team pumped an going no matter what he was great," Levario wrote in a comment on the Los Angeles Times Web site.
å¦   During his junior year of high school, Ochoa told Peters he wanted to join the military to serve his country and continue his education, the principal said.
å¦   "He knew what he wanted to do," Peters said. "He sticks out in my mind."

ServiceUnit: Parachute Battalion 263
IncidentDetails: The 24-year-old paratrooper died Oct. 4 of his wounds 14 months after a suicide bomb attack near Kunduz, Afghanistan on Aug. 6, 2008. He fought against the attack's severe consequences in German hospitals in Koblenz and Mainz.

An Italian soldier died Thursday from wounds sustained when his vehicle tipped over while traveling on an unstable road, the Italian military said. Two other soldiers on board were bruised in the accident near Herat in the west.

ServiceUnit: 569th Mobility Augmentation Company, 4th Engineer Battalion
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 15 in Kandahar province, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   With 13 years of service, Army Staff Sgt. Glen Stivison Jr. believed in mentoring and protecting younger soldiers.
å¦   Keeping them safe was his top priority when they went on missions to clear roadside bombs. Back in Fort Collins, Colo., he was known to whip up a batch of his famous chili for them.
å¦   "He was a man of character, one of the finest heroes I've ever had the honor of serving with," said Capt. Heath Papkov.
å¦   Stivison, 34, died Oct. 15 when his vehicle was bombed in Kandahar province. Stivison grew up in Blairsville, Pa., and was a 1994 graduate of Blairsville High School, where he played on the football and wrestling teams. He was a Pittsburgh Steelers fan and enjoyed the outdoors.
å¦   But most of all, he loved his family _ his wife, Eryn, and their children, William Blaze, 8, and Andrew Wyatt, 6. He showered his kids with attention whenever he was home on leave, said his mother, Jan Stivison.
å¦   "He went to school and ate lunch with them, and he went to their after-school activities," she said. "He took them to track practice and ran along with them."

ServiceUnit: 569th Mobility Augmentation Company, 4th Engineer Battalion
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 15 in Kandahar province, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Jesus O. Flores Jr. was "Flo," "Jun-jun" and "Lil Boi" to his many friends.
å¦   As a youth, "Jun-jun" was kind and liked to play video games, said Phil Rivera, who wrote on a Los Angeles Times Web page dedicated to the 28-year-old Flores.
å¦   On Oct. 15, Flores was one of four soldiers killed in Kandahar when their vehicle was attacked with an improvised explosive device. All were based at Fort Carson.
å¦   Flores, who joined the Army in December 2003, was a decorated soldier. He received the National Defense Service Medal, the Afghanistan Campaign Medal with Campaign Star, the Iraq Campaign Medal with Campaign Star, the Global War on Terrorism Service Medal and the Army Service Ribbon.
å¦   "Specialist Jesus Flores will be forever remembered for his courage and strength while protecting our country's freedom," Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said in a statement.
å¦   He also will be remembered as a high schooler who could break dance, wrote friend Melgaspher Rozul.
å¦   "I'll miss you homie," Rozul said. "... Watch over us."

ServiceUnit: 569th Mobility Augmentation Company, 4th Engineer Battalion
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 15 in Kandahar province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Daniel Lawson fit right in helping kids.
å¦   Before joining the military, Lawson worked as a teacher's assistant in the Broward County, Fla., school system. Among his assignments was helping children with autism.
å¦   "We know that Daniel endured many challenging days with our son but he never complained and always remained positive with his big, bright, beautiful smile!" Desiree Perron of Pompano Beach, Fla., wrote of Lawson in an online message board.
å¦   "He was compassionate and loved our son unconditionally."
å¦   Lawson, 33, of Deerfield Beach, Fla., died Oct. 15 when his vehicle hit a roadside bomb in Kandahar province. He earned an associate's degree in computer programming from ITT Technical Career Institute, but joined the military for a more stable financial future, his family said. He was assigned to Fort Carson.
å¦   Lawson's mother, Carolyn Lawson, said her son wanted to make sure he could provide for his wife, Latoria, and three children: Kiara, 10; Kourtney, 8; and Kevon, 5.
å¦   "He was so full of life," Carolyn Lawson said. "Outgoing. Helpful. Kind. Considerate. A fun-loving, big kid."

ServiceUnit: 569th Mobility Augmentation Company, 4th Engineer Battalion
IncidentDetails: Four soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 15 in Kandahar province, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   There were many things dear to Brandon Styer: his nieces, nephew and other family members, his restored Mazda RX-8 and the Philadelphia Phillies.
å¦   But also high on his list was the U.S. Army.
å¦   Styler, also known as B-Sty, enlisted before graduating last year from Conestoga Valley High School in Lancaster, Pa. Less than a year later he was in Iraq, then Afghanistan, where his job was to find and remove roadside bombs.
å¦   "He was not scared. He never talked negative about the experience. He loved it," said his sister, Tracy Bowling.
å¦   Styer, 19, died Oct. 15 in Kandahar province when his vehicle was struck by a roadside bomb. He was assigned to Fort Carson.
å¦   Styer knew his family and friends worried about him. Just before his deployment he set up a Facebook page, "Brandon Styer is going to Iraq," for them to keep in touch with him. He said in an early post, "ill be home in 1 piece."
å¦   His survivors include his mother, Jill M. Myers, and father, Terry Styer.

ServiceUnit: 143rd Infantry Detachment
IncidentDetails: died Friday in Wardak province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Anthony "Gabe" Green died wearing his wedding band, the symbol of his devotion to his wife, Lindsay.
å¦   Soldiers aren't allowed to wear jewelry in combat. But Green had it tattooed on his finger the day before he left for Afghanistan.
å¦   "Hey man, this will be permanent, and you can't get rid of it later," Green's father, Cornell, recalled his son telling the tattoo artist.
å¦   "The wedding ring is also forever," Gabe Green replied.
å¦   Green, 28, of Yorktown, Texas, was killed by a roadside bomb Oct. 16 in Wardak province. He was assigned to Austin, Texas. He graduated from high school in Yorktown, where he played football and was in drama club.
å¦   His family wrote in his obituary that Green loved working with the people of Afghanistan. One of his proudest accomplishments was teaching villagers how to irrigate from a windmill they erected, tripling their yield.
å¦   On Saturdays back home, Green enjoyed simpler pursuits: He always made time to watch "SpongeBob SquarePants" with his daughters, Kaydence and Madie.
å¦   Other survivors include his mother, Patricia, four brothers and three sisters.

ServiceUnit: 143rd Infantry Detachment
IncidentDetails: died Friday in Wardak province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Chris N. Staats was "a man's man," according to fellow soldiers.
å¦   "It's true," said his wife, Monteigne. "They were saying he really was the glue that held them together, and was pushing for a lot of things to help the people in Afghanistan."
å¦   Staats, who earned a degree in renewable natural resources from Texas A&M in 2002, was sent to Afghanistan with a small team to help people there be more self-sufficient, his wife said.
å¦   "I'm so proud of Chris for his hard work, his dedication, his service and belief in helping others," she said.
å¦   The 32-year-old native of Fredericksburg, Texas, was killed in a roadside bomb attack in Wardak province on Oct. 16, about a month before he was scheduled to return home. The Texas National Guardsman was assigned to Camp Mabry and had previously deployed on a peacekeeping mission to Kosovo.
å¦   After graduating from Fredericksburg High School in 1996, he joined the Guard, following after his father, Bobby, and brother, Garrett. He worked for Halff Associates, a San Antonio engineering and professional services firm.
å¦   Staats is also survived by his mother and stepfather, Lorna and Gary Eckhardt, and a sister, Jennifer.

ServiceUnit: 293rd Military Police Company, 385th Military Police Battalion, 16th Military Police Brigade (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: died Friday near Kandahar, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Christopher M. Rudzinski was upbeat, a characteristic that stood out to onlookers as he coped with losing his mother to cancer and then comforted mourners when his sister died a few years ago.
å¦   "I hadn't talked to him in years, and then I saw him at the funeral and the first thing he did was hug me and say 'Hey, it's going to be all right,'" high school friend Angela Erickson said.
å¦   His father, Michael, said Rudzinski had a good sense of humor and jokingly sewed derogatory patches on other soldiers' uniforms in the spot where Ranger patches went.
å¦   The 28-year-old from Rantoul, Ill., died Oct. 16 near Kandahar when his vehicle hit a roadside bomb. He had served in Kosovo and Iraq and was assigned to Fort Stewart.
å¦   Rudzinski graduated in 1999 from Rantoul Township High School, where he was in school musicals and the band.
å¦   "I think being in the military is probably where he really wanted to be," said Violet LaPine, who worked with him at the public library. "He just seemed like the kind of guy who was ready for bigger action than the library."
å¦   Rudzinski's survivors include his wife, Caroline, and son, Ryan; his stepmother; and four siblings and step-siblings.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 17th Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade, 2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 17 in Arghandab, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Michael Dahl Jr. may have been calm and soft-spoken, but he didn't care much for sitting around.
å¦   When other soldiers at his Army base played video games or watched movies, Dahl pushed for a trip to Las Vegas.
å¦   At age 23, Dahl's friends said, he was fun-loving yet serious; humble, yet proud of his work.
å¦   He "wouldn't trade his job for the world," wrote Spc. Peyton Cloninger, Dahl's friend.
å¦   Cloninger's statement was read last month at a memorial service for Dahl, who was killed Oct. 17 in Arghandab when his vehicle was hit by a roadside bomb.
å¦   "Not only was he a great friend, he was a good soldier," Cloninger's tribute said.
å¦   Dahl was from Moreno Valley, Calif., and assigned to Fort Lewis.
å¦   Before deploying to Afghanistan, Dahl served for a year in Iraq, said his mother, Patricia Dahl.
å¦   "I think my son's a hero," Michael Dahl Sr. said. "He died for what he believed in."

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 5th Marine Regiment, 1st Marine Division, I Marine Expeditionary Force
IncidentDetails: Died Oct. 20 while supporting combat operations in Helmand province, Afghanistan.
Bio:
å¦   Growing up just off Lake Erie in northeast Ohio, David Baker was quiet and more comfortable in the background.
å¦   That changed after he joined the Marines. While serving in Afghanistan, he took on the job of leading patrols, searching out hidden explosives and other dangers to protect his fellow Marines behind him.
å¦   "You could just see the transformation of his personality from being a shy boy into a young man because of his tour of duty in the Marines," said his uncle Jim Baker.
å¦   Baker, 22, of Painesville, Ohio, died Oct. 20 while on patrol in Helmand province. He was based at Camp Pendleton.
å¦   Baker joined the Marines shortly after graduating in 2006 from Riverside High School in Painesville, Ohio.
å¦   "From the beginning, Dave's goal was to be a Marine," Riverside computer and math teacher Sally Vaidean wrote on the school's Web site. "His work always reflected this _ from his use of the Marine Emblem to the words of the Marine hymn."
å¦   Friends and relatives say Baker was smart, witty and enjoyed country music.
å¦   Survivors include his parents, Laurie Lewkowski and Mark Baker.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 17th Infantry Regiment, 5th Stryker Brigade Combat Team,  2nd Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 21 in Kandahar province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Kyle Coumas would have gotten away with throwing a party in his parents' house when he was in high school. But he gave himself away.
å¦   With his parents gone, Coumas cleared the front room of their Lockeford, Calif., removing pieces of furniture and pictures so they wouldn't get damaged. But after the party ended, said Stockton resident Mycal Wayte, Coumas forgot to put a picture back in place, and his mother noticed. The ordeal had been fairly out of character for Coumas, Wayte said.
å¦   "He was probably one of the best kids I ever met in my life," Wayte said. "Basically good natured; you didn't have to worry about him."
å¦   Coumas, 22, died Oct. 21 in Kandahar province when his vehicle was hit by a roadside bomb. He enlisted in February 2007 _ two years after he graduated high school. He was based at Fort Lewis.
å¦   He is survived by his parents, Lori and Greg Coumas.
å¦   "Our goal was for you to be your own person," said a letter Coumas once received from his parents.
å¦   The letter was read at a service for Coumas attended by some 500 people. Letters Coumas wrote while in Afghanistan were read aloud, too.
å¦   "It's hot as hell," he wrote to his parents.
å¦   "I just want to let you know I'm OK."

ServiceUnit: Royal Military Police
IncidentDetails: He died after being mortally wounded by an improvised explosive device Thursday, Oct. 22 during an early morning foot patrol in the Gereshk region of Helmand province Thursday.

ServiceUnit: 569th Mobility Augmentation Company, 4th Engineer Battalion
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 23 in Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Eric Lembke wasn't always Eric Lembke.
å¦   It wasn't until Dorothy Lembke began fostering a boy named Michael Beckum. When she adopted the boy, he changed his name to Eric Lembke. Regardless of his name, he was devoted to those he loved.
å¦   "His family was the most important thing to him," said his sister-in-law, Mary Lembke. "As young as he was, he took very good care of his family" _ his wife, Mashelle, and two kids: 6-year-old Alexis, "his princess," and 3-year-old Nathaniel, "his Nater the Gator."
å¦   Lembke, 25, of Tampa, Fla., was killed by a roadside bomb Oct. 23 in Afghanistan. He was assigned to Fort Carson. He graduated from Simmons Career Center of Plant City High School in 2002.
å¦   An associate pastor of Planty City's First Baptist Church, where Lembke was a lifetime member, said he appreciated Lembke's work ethic and approach to life.
å¦   "Eric was strong on ambition," said the Rev. Tommy Warnock, who presided over Lembke's wedding ceremony. "He looked for ways to better his career and the lives of his family."
å¦   His family also remembered him in an online obituary as a dedicated family man with a good sense of humor.
å¦   "He was a happy and free spirit who could always make you laugh when life was hard," his family said.

ServiceUnit: 569th Mobility Augmentation Company, 4th Engineer Battalion
IncidentDetails: Two soldiers who were supporting Operation Enduring Freedom died Oct. 23 in Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked their vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Kimble Han enlisted in the Army in 2008, fulfilling his hope of leading a life he could be proud of.
å¦   "It gave him purpose and meaning in life," said his older brother Jerod Han. "He was scared, but he was proud. He was a soldier."
å¦   Han, 30, of Lehi, Utah, and another soldier were killed Oct. 23 when their vehicle was hit by a roadside bomb in Afghanistan. Both were based at Fort Carson.
å¦   Jerod Han said he and his younger brother graduated from Cheyenne High School in Las Vegas, and the two moved to Utah in 2002 to seek work.
å¦   Han's mother, Lisa Barnes, said her son, a combat engineer, was transferred to Afghanistan after starting a tour of duty in Iraq. Barnes said her son was big and strong. He was a patriot, she said.
å¦   The last time she talked to him, though, she said she sensed fear in his voice. Han told her the Taliban's improvised explosive devices had become more difficult to detect.
å¦   "I'd never heard that from my son before, but yes, I could tell. He was so scared," she said.
å¦   Han is survived by his wife, Melissa, and three stepchildren.

ServiceUnit: 1st Battalion, 12th Infantry Regiment, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 24 in Zhari province, Afghanistan, of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his unit with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Devin J. Michel had choices after graduation, his mother told him, but the list didn't include "sit on the couch and eat Cheetos all the time." So he picked the Army.
å¦   He enlisted last year after graduating from Stockton High School in Stockton, Ill. He was assigned to Fort Carson.
å¦   Terry Michel said his son could be difficult but always loved to have fun.
å¦   "He was free-spirited, and if he wanted a goal he aimed for it," he said. "He wanted it all his way, and he seemed to think things were easy to come by. He was a typical kid."
å¦   The 19-year-old from Stockton died Oct. 24 in Zhari province when enemy forces attacked his unit with an explosive device.
å¦   Weeks earlier, he had managed a surprise for his wife, Anika, on their first wedding anniversary.
å¦   "I don't know how he did it because they were in the process of moving between bases, but I did get a half-dozen roses," she said.
å¦   It wasn't the first time he pulled off something unexpected while he was overseas.
å¦   "He worked hard and called me in situations when I could not understand how he managed to get a call through," she said.
å¦   Devin Michel is also survived by his mother, Rebecca.

ServiceUnit: 178th Military Police Detachment, 89th Military Police Brigade, III Corps
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 25 in Laghman province, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when enemy forces attacked his vehicle with an improvised explosive device.
Bio:
å¦   Brandon K. Steffey was known as "The Big Teddy Bear" because of his smile and the comforting hugs he doled out _ all 6-foot-3, 200-plus pounds of him.
å¦   "Brandon was a very kind and considerate person," said John Sherry, a principal at Sault Area High School in Steffey's hometown of Sault Sainte Marie, Mich. "A gentle giant with a very good sense of humor."
å¦   Sherry said Steffey played football at his school and then transferred to play baseball at Brimley High School, where he graduated in 2005.
å¦   A friend, Timothy Shaw, remembered Steffey as polite and honest, with the exception of one time when he pulled off a win in a cribbage game by pegging extra points during temporary power outages on a stormy night in Michigan's Upper Peninsula.
å¦   Steffey's uncle, Jim Worsham, said Steffey's decision to join the Army followed a family tradition of military service.
å¦   The 23-year-old was killed Oct. 25 in Laghman province by a roadside bomb. He was assigned to a military police detachment out of Fort Hood.
å¦   "He was so proud of what he was doing during his deployment," his wife, Andrea, said, adding that he also was a doting father to his young daughter.

ServiceUnit: 704th Brigade Support Battalion, 4th Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division
IncidentDetails: died Oct. 25 in Kunar province, Afghanistan of wounds suffered when insurgents attacked her vehicle with a rocket propelled grenade.
Bio:
å¦   Friends called Eduviges G. Wolf "Duvi" and many _ if not all _ knew she wanted had wanted to join the military since she was a girl.
å¦   Wolf, whose maiden name was Preciado, was the youngest of four sisters. All four immigrated with their parents from Mexico.
å¦   "She wanted to do what was right to protect the country and to help people," said Susie Martin, who supervised Wolf when she was a high school student and participated in the Hawthorne, Calif., police department's Explorer program. "She was one of those amazing human beings."
å¦   As a Leuzinger High School student, Wolf told Martin that enlisting in the military would provide a way for her to serve the country and provide a path to citizenship.
å¦   Wolf, a 24-year-old mother of two, was killed Oct. 25 in Kunar province when insurgents attacked her vehicle with a rocket-propelled grenade. She enlisted in the Army in 2003. She was based at Fort Carson.
å¦   She is survived by her husband, Josh Wolf, who also was serving in Afghanistan at the time of her death, and two daughters _ Valerie, 1, and Isabel 3.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 160th Special Operations Regiment (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Seven soldiers died Oct. 26 of wounds suffered when the MH-47 helicopter they were aboard crashed in Darreh-ye Bum, Afghanistan. They crashed while returning from the scene of a firefight. The crash was believed not to be the result of hostile fire.
Bio:
å¦   Michael Montgomery served with the storied Night Stalkers, a special operations aviation unit known for flying speedy, dangerous missions in the dark of night.
å¦   "He was an amazing troop and an even better pilot," Andy Knudson, who said he's known Montgomery since he finished flight school in 1992, wrote in an online message board.
å¦   "The honor of flying in the Night Stalkers is reserved for the Army's best pilots. There can be no question that this nation has lost one of its finest."
å¦   Montgomery, 36, of Savannah, Ga., was killed Oct. 26 when the MH-47 helicopter he was aboard crashed in Darreh-ye-Bum. He was assigned to Hunter Army Airfield.
å¦   Montgomery began his career in the Army National Guard in 1991 and graduated from flight school in 1996. He joined the Night Stalkers in 2006.
å¦   The soldier was on his seventh deployment, having been to Iraq twice and Afghanistan four other times.
å¦   First and foremost, Montgomery was "a devoted and loving father to his son, Riley, and a beloved best friend and husband to his wife, Anita," his family wrote in his obituary.
å¦   Other survivors include his mother, father and brother.

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 160th Special Operations Regiment (Airborne)
IncidentDetails: Seven soldiers died Oct. 26 of wounds suffered when the MH-47 helicopter they were aboard crashed in Darreh-ye Bum, Afghanistan. They crashed while returning from the scene of a firefight. The crash was believed not to be the result of hostile fire.
Bio:
å¦   Niall Lyons' young son remembers fondly the time he spent and places he went with his father.
å¦   "Almost every holiday my dad spent with me. It was just an adventure going places with him," 8-year-old John Patrick Lyons said. "One big adventure."
å¦   Now, the boy is coping with the loss of his father, who was killed Oct. 26 in Darreh-ye Bum. Lyons, 40, died of wounds suffered when the MH-47 helicopter he was aboard crashed.
å¦   April Lyons said she believes her husband died helping others because "that's the kind of person he was."
å¦   Niall Lyons, a native of Spokane, Wash., joined the Army in 1994 and moved to Dothan, Ala., in 1998.
å¦   His wife told the Dothan Eagle that a meeting with President Barack Obama has helped her and her son as they mourn Lyons' death. Obama, who honored the return of 18 other fallen Americans late last month at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware, spoke with the Lyons and other families who were present at the solemn return of their loved ones' remains to U.S. soil.
å¦   "It was a good gesture. It meant a lot for the president to be there," Lyons said.
å¦   "I think it was good for John Patrick to be there to start healing," she said. "It's hard for him to understand his daddy is not coming home."

ServiceUnit: 3rd Battalion, 160th Special Operations Regiment (Airborne)
